A House vote is expected this week. The Senate Ethics Committee proposes ``denouncement'' of Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., for breaking rules on outside income, evading disclosure requirements, and improperly accepting free limousine rides. Senate action is expected within a couple of weeks. Despite the different words ``reprimand'' and ``denouncement,'' there's no significant difference between the two chambers' punishments. Like almost everything else in Congress, a large and murky vocabulary has evolved to hide the unpleasant choices at hand. When a member of Congress misbehaves, House or Senate, there are only three real options: Do nothing, scold the offender, or throw him or her out. Doing nothing is a popular option. For example, Republican Rep. Donald E. Lukens has been convicted in his home state of Ohio for having sex with an underage girl. The House has not disciplined him. ``Reprimand'' and ``denouncement'' fall in the middle category. In each case, the chamber approves a document that then gets attached to the offender like a scarlet bulls-eye _ to be used in the next election by his or her opponent. Given the impact on their public images, lawmakers are very sensitive to the wording of such statements. Durenberger's aides argue to reporters that a ``denouncement'' is something less than a ``censure,'' which is the term most commonly used in past Senate cases. It isn't. In the House, though, ``censure'' is a small half-step up from ``reprimand,'' the difference being that the offender must actually attend and stand in the well of the House and hear the Speaker recite the punishment. Tears ran down the face of Rep. Dan Crane, R-Ill., when he was brought before his colleagues after being censured in the sex scandal involving a teenage congressional page. He lost his bid for re-election. Both chambers are extremely reluctant to expel a member, usually reserving that punishment for the voters to dish out. That's already happened with Lukens, as he's been defeated in the Ohio primary. And it happened in the general election two years ago with Rep. Fernand St Germain, D-R.I., the former Banking Committee chairman who was investigated but never charged by the ethics committee. But if the voters want a tainted lawmaker, they can have him, and in some cases they have. Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., and Rep. Edward Roybal, D-Calif., are examples of House members who have retained their House seats and considerable power despite being punished. Studds was censured for sex with a male page and Roybal was reprimanded for his part in an influence-peddling scandal. It's been more than a decade since the House expelled a member, and the Senate is even more reluctant to expel than the House _ it hasn't done so in this century. It also seems less necessary in the Senate. No senator has been re-elected after being censured. And though the formal punishment may seem light to an outsider, the effect within the clubby institution is severe. Much more so than the House, the Senate functions via personal relationships and mutual trust earned over the years. A censured senator becomes a pariah. One senior Senate aide recalled when former Sen. Thomas Dodd, father of the current Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., was censured for financial misconduct more than two decades ago. Asked how a member of ``the club'' could be so punished by his colleagues, he responded: ``Yes, we have a club in the Senate. And when a senator misbehaves, we eat him.'' In Dodd's day, it was a private dinner. Now, with the advent of C-Span, millions of people will watch in their homes as Congress tries to judge its own.
Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Banned Assault Weapons Being Admitted After Modifications
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, saying it has no choice under the law, has approved importation of some previously banned firearms that were modified to get around the ban, according to a published report. Relying on documents obtained under the Freedom of Information Act by the Firearms Policy Project, The Washington Post said permission has been granted to import new versions of the Uzi, AK-47, Galil, HK-91 and other assault weapons. The importation of those weapons was prohibited last year. The paper, in Monday's editions, quoted officials as saying the new versions have been altered to remove flash suppressors, grenade launchers, bayonet attachments and other military-style features that made them unsuitable for ``sporting purposes.'' Once the military-style features were removed ``they no longer fit the category of semiautomatic, assault-type rifle'' and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms had no grounds for keeping them out, the paper quoted BATF spokeswoman Dot Koester as saying. However, the guns still can accept magazines of up to 30 rounds of ammunition and have pistol-grip type stocks that enable them to be reloaded quickly. Josh Sugarman, director of the group that made the documents available to the Post, was quoted as saying those features make them every bit as deadly as the banned weapons and ``makes a mockery of last year's action.'' Attempts to obtain a home telephone listing Sunday night for Ms. Koester were unsuccessful and Sugarman's telephone was answered by an answering machine.
DOC.HEAD: Pepper Commission: Government Should Make Medicare Changes
DOC.TEXT: A bipartisan commission says the government should help the elderly poor pay Medicare charges, add coverage of preventive services to Medicare and order improvements in supplementary insurance coverage. The $2.8 billion package recommended by the Pepper Commission would add to a $66 billion plan the panel suggested in March that would provide health care coverage to nearly all Americans. The panel voted 11-4 for the latest three recommendations. ``People may think that because the elderly have Medicare they are adequately protected. That's wrong,'' Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., commission chairman, said in the panel's Sunday announcement of the action. The improvements are ``desperately needed to assure older Americans the same minimum standard of protection we've already recommended providing Americans under 65,'' he said. The panel, created by Congress in 1988 as the U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, includes 12 members of Congress and three White House appointees. It was later renamed to honor the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. The commission's larger package of proposals in March was criticized by some of its own members for failing to recommend funding. In its earlier action, the panel split 8-7 on the plan to achieve universal access by requiring businesses to provide private health insurance to their workers or to contribute to a public plan for employees and non-working dependents. At that time, panel members also voted 11-4 for a plan offering all Americans coverage for long-term care in their homes and for the first three months in a nursing home.

DOC.HEAD: Sailor Accused of Raping Enlisted Woman
DOC.TEXT: A Navy sailor has been accused of raping an enlisted woman aboard the submarine tender USS Holland, published reports said today. The allegations are the second rape accusations against naval personnel in three months, The Washington Post reported in its Monday editions. The assault allegedly occurred July 14 in the enlisted women's quarters aboard the ship while it was docked at its home port in Charleston, S.C., the paper said, quoting Navy officials. The woman has taken a temporary leave from the ship. The suspect, a petty officer third class is being detained in the naval brig at Charleston. A magistrate's hearing Friday found enough evidence to continue the investigation. The sailor was not identified, pending the filing of formal charges against him. The allegations came one day before the court-martial in another case involving the rape of a female officer, allegedly by another officer, aboard an ammunition supply ship in the Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,894.79, down 526.73 points or 1.62 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: East German Parliament Gives Governments Decision on Formal Merge
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Lothar de Maziere has averted the collapse of his broad coalition government with an agreement by the governing parties to put off a decision on the precise date of German unification. The Social Democrats, East Germany's second-largest party, and the smaller Liberal centrist alliance had threatened to pull out of the government over the issue, but reached a compromise on Sunday. The parties have demanded that unity occur a day before elections, set for Dec. 2. In that way, all of Germany, not two separate nations, would vote at once. But de Maiziere's Christian Democrats have said unity before the vote would place East Germans under a government they did not elect _ the West German government _ if only for a day. The coalition partners agreed to have the two German governments consult on the issue and try to come up with a solution. Lawmakers did resolve a major difference in the election laws of the two Germanys by establishing the same 5 percent minimum for party representation as exists in West Germany. The law means parties must get at least 5 percent of the vote in state and local elections to win seats in councils or legislatures. The Communists' successor party, the Party of Democratic Socialism, had pressed for a 3 percent threshold. De Maiziere and his Christian Democrat allies in West Germany, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, have favored allowing East Germans to hold elections for a united Parliament on the same day as in the West, but counting the vote separately in areas that are now part of East Germany. This would lower the amount of votes East German parties would need for representation in the federal Parliament, allowing smaller parties a chance to get past the 5 percent threshold and win seats. It would also help the Christian Democrats, who rely more on coalitions with smaller parties than the Social Democrats, form a legislative majority. Also Sunday, Parliament voted to reconstitute the country's five states that had been dissolved under Communist rule 38 years ago. The move was intended to facilitate East Germany's merger with the West under terms of Bonn's constitution. Lawmakers overwhelmingly voted to make Oct. 14 the date for elections in the states of Mecklenburg, Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt, Thueringia and Brandenburg, as well as in East Berlin. The move restores the five states to roughly their 1946 borders and abolishes the 14 districts created by the Communists in a 1952 administrative reform program. The Parliament also passed its last independent budget. The $38.8 billion budget will have a deficit of about $20.6 billion, which will be covered in part by the Bonn government and through new credit. East Germany merged its economy with West Germany on July 1. Experts have predicted that up to half its 8 million workers could lose their jobs as formerly state-supported industries lose to free market competition.

DOC.HEAD: Flood Victims Recoup After Some of Worst Flooding This Century
DOC.TEXT: J.C. Franklin gambled and lost when he moved three years ago into this flood-prone community on the banks of the unpredictable Brazos River. As he and other people in southern Parker County, just west of Fort Worth, recover from some of the worst spring flooding in north Texas this century, the dice keep coming up snake eyes. ``It's wiped us out financially. I thought about suicide,'' Franklin said as he stood in the doorway of his $42,000 home that was flooded for nine days in late April. ``I have a pretty good job, my wife's got a pretty good job ... but we're financially ruined. We don't have enough money to buy our supper.'' Franklin, a 51-year-old truck driver, spends his weekends cleaning up and repairing what he can. He hopes to sell the house and move to nearby Weatherford. He takes a well-trodden path through the home, stopping to sigh at a rusted $2,200 antique stove before surveying the dirt-covered walls of a family room added to the home recently. ``We never got a chance to sit in (the family room),'' he said. ``Never had a chance, not once, to sit in there.'' Like the Franklins, thousands of families in the hardest-hit north and north central Texas counties of Liberty, Bowie, Brown and Dallas watched the rain-swollen Brazos, Trinity and Red rivers wash away their homes, mementoes and chunks of their lives. The Federal Emergency Management Agency has received more than 6,000 disaster assistance applications from 68 Texas counties in the wake of storms between April 15 and June 4 that claimed 15 lives and caused millions of dollars in damage. About 200 Parker County families also took advantage of FEMA's temporary housing program, which provides money for disaster victims to rent housing for up to 18 months, said Graham Nance of FEMA's disaster aid office. Parker County officials are now working with FEMA on how to meet federal regulations that would make county residents eligible for the federal flood insurance program. Counties must belong to the program before its residents can qualify for rebuilding loans from FEMA, Nance said. Several families in Horseshoe Bend and the Dallas neighborhood of Rochester Park had no flood insurance. Families in Rochester Park, which has flooded for two years straight, got a boost last week when the city announced it would be able to build an $8.9 million flood levee by November 1991, two years ahead of original estimates. The good news hasn't come often, though. Billie Farrington, a Horseshoe Bend bartender, says she has ``no big bank account,'' and now lives from paycheck to paycheck with friends, with no immediate plans for the future. Insects fly freely through the broken windows of her home and many of the abandoned trailer homes along Horseshoe Bend's Comanche Trail. A discolored, dirty line along the wall is a reminder of the 5 feet of water that stood in the trailer for more than a week. Piles of wood, mud-caked furniture and clothing still litter some lawns, even though the community has held two weekend cleanups. But at least 20 residents, including the Franklins, in this community of 400 say it's time to clean up and clear out. ``I'd just as soon do anything than to have to leave this place,'' Franklin said. ``But we can't afford it. Every time I turn around that damn water's coming up, and you have to take off from work to watch the water so you can evacuate. I just can't do it.'' Though she lost everything, Ms. Farrington says she's staying put. ``It's home. You've got roots,'' she said. ``This is where I want to live till I die.''

DOC.HEAD: Mississippi Has New Education Reform Package _ But No Funding
DOC.TEXT: Mississippi, long the last on most education yardsticks, has a school reform package that lawmakers hope will change all that. But finding money for it hasn't been as easy as A-B-C. The package is designed to reduce adult illiteracy and teen-age pregnancy and lower the number of dropouts. But its price tag is $182 million over three years. And the prospect of coming up with the money, even the $45 million needed in the first year, is bleak. Especially with statewide elections coming up next year. Gov. Ray Mabus won't go along with a tax increase and legislators have balked at a package of fee increases and a proposal to let voters decide whether the state should start a lottery. ``Mississippi is clearly leading the pack in terms of ideas,'' Mabus said. ``We have passed the best education reform act in the country. We just need to go ahead and finish the job.'' Mabus won election in 1987 on a pledge that Mississippi would ``never be last again.'' He has a big job ahead of him. More than 400,000 of the state's 2.5 million residents are illiterate. The dropout rate is 37 percent, giving Mississippi one of the five highest rates in the nation. Mississippi students have the lowest average scores in the nation on the ACT, the college entrance exam. Mississippi ranks last in spending per student. In April, Mabus signed into law his BEST package, short for Better Education for Success Tomorrow. The legislation continued reforms begun in 1982 that have helped raise test scores and increase accountability by requiring district ``report cards.'' Last month, the govenor called the Legislature into special session to find money for the new reforms, which include curriculum improvements and bonds to replace aging buildings and buses. Proposals to let voters decide if Mississippi should have a lottery passed the House but failed by five votes in the Senate during the 13-day special session, which cost nearly $357,000. Now, the Democratic governor must decide whether to call another special session of the Democratic-controlled Legislature or wait until January's regular session to try to find funding for BEST. ``We're disappointed,'' said Andy Mullins, spokesman for the state Department of Education. ``This was the best shot that we've had at getting these programs that are controversial passed in a long time.'' Privately, some legislators say Mabus put them on the spot just before an election year. ``You'd have to ask them if it's me,'' Mabus said. ``Tell me how sad is it and how terrible is it if you want to punish children because you happen to dislike a particular individual. We ought to be better than that.'' Jim Simpson, chairman of the House Education Committee, is looking to Mabus for a little flexibility. ``If the Legislature funds it, I think it will be with a broad-based tax increase mutually acceptable to the House and Senate,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Flock To Eastern Orthodox Service Led by Patriarch
LaserPhoto CX1 of July 22
DOC.TEXT: At least 10,000 Eastern Orthodox Christians gathered in a lakefront park for a Divine Liturgy celebrated by their highest spiritual leader, the Archbishop of Constantinople. Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I looked tired but smiled and waved as he alighted from a limousine Sunday morning to begin a two-hour outdoor liturgy at the Petrillo Band Shell in Grant Park. The service was the first event in a three-day Chicago stay by the world leader of 180 million to 250 million followers of Eastern Orthodoxy. His 27-day tour of the United States, which concludes Sunday in Boston, is the first visit to this continent by anyone in his office. ``He's like our pope. ... He's the head person in our religion and it's a big religious event for us,'' said Frances Halikias, 54, a Greek Orthodox Christian from suburban Palos Hills. A steady early morning rain failed to dampen the spirits of those who traveled from all over the Midwest to see the man they consider ``first among equals'' in their faith. Christian Orthodoxy is largely divided along national lines, including Greeks, Russians, Albanians, Serbians, Ukrainians and others. ``For him to come to us is just magnificent,'' said the Rev. James S. Gordon, a spokesman for the Greek Orthodox Diocese of Chicago. ``It's a thrill for everybody here.'' The amphitheater where the service was held is located in a park between skyscrapers and Lake Michigan. Worshipers made the sign of the cross as the 75-year-old archbishop strode from his car to the red and gold-carpeted stage. There, amid six painted icons, an altar covered with consecrated relics and an ornate pulpit and bishop's throne brought from Greece, Dimitrios led the liturgy, including reading a brief homily in Greek, which was translated into English as he went. The homily marked a commemoration of Mary Madgalene and the women mourners at Christ's tomb that is part of the Eastern Orthodox liturgical calendar for this Sunday, Gordon said. After the homily, communion was offered by 30 priests to all Orthodox Christians who wanted it. The patriarch did not make any remarks about his visit during the service. But Gordon said he was sure the patriarch had to be impressed by the number of worshipers who had come o see him. ``There are only 2,000 Orthodox communicants in Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul, Turkey) now. So when he sees easily 7,000 or 8,000 people _ it could be 10,000 by now _ this has got to blow him away,'' Gordon said. The service was the largest ever held for Orthodox Christians in the United States, according to Jim Peponis, organizer of the liturgy for the Chicago Greek Orthodox Diocese. He estimated the crowd at 10,000 to 12,000. Eastern Orthodoxy and Roman Catholicism split almost 1,000 years ago over differences in belief about the origin of the Holy Spirit and over the Roman pope's claim of authority over the eastern church. The two churches still hold similar beliefs on most points, however. Six million followers of Eastern Orthodoxy live in the United States, including about 250,000 in Chicago and its suburbs.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Defeats Rabin in Labor Party Battle
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres has won a major political victory over rival Yitzhak Rabin, who attempted to force immediate elections for party chief. ``I fell in love with my party again,'' Peres said Sunday after he won a battle in the party's policy-making body to postpone until next year a vote on the party chairman post. ``The party and the country shall benefit from this victory,'' he said. Labor's 1,400-member central committee was called into session to consider demands by Rabin, Labor's No. 2 man, for a vote soon on the chairman post. According to official results, about 54 percent of the 1,212 Labor members present supported Peres and decided to postpone the election. Peres, a former prime minister, had argued that the center-left party should prepare for a battle with the rival Likud bloc and deal with internal struggles later. Just before official results of the vote were announced at the end of the seven-hour meeting, dancing and singing supporters surrounded Peres, and many kissed and hugged him. Rabin has been maneuvering to oust Peres since May, when Peres failed to form a Labor-led government after bringing down a shaky coalition with Likud. The failure enabled Likud leader Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to form his right-wing Cabinet in early June. ``I accept the majority decision,'' Rabin said after the vote. ``I thank the great number of central committee members who saw the need for a change, but the majority decides. I believe that from now on, the party should be united ... and organize itself as an opposition confronting Likud.'' Peres and Rabin then briefly shook hands. Peres, who has been party chief since 1977, said later that he would not seek revenge. ``There is room for everyone, for Yitzhak Rabin and others,'' he said on an interview on Israel radio. Although Rabin and Peres both appealed for party unity, observers predicted that Labor will remain split and unable to present a strong opposition. ``We will see two organized and hostile camps, with leaders who hardly speak with each other ... a kind of prolonged war of attrition,'' said Israel radio's political observer, Hanan Cristal. ``Likud may forget about opposition; it will have an easy life in the government.'' Mordechai Gur, a senior Labor member and a Rabin supporter, said Peres' victory had ``weakened the party.'' ``We thought we should change the leadership to lead a strong, active opposition. With Peres it would be very difficult. We shall do our best, but I'm afraid it would not be as strong as it could have been,'' Gur said. Recent polls have consistantly indicated that Rabin, 68, is Israel's most popular leader. Also a former prime minister, he gained popularity for his tough stance as defense minister in the last government in dealing with the 31-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. He also is remembered as chief of staff in the 1967 Middle East war when Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt. By contrast, the popularity of the Polish-born Peres, who turns 67 in 10 days, has been on the decline.

DOC.HEAD: Says Instruments Used to Create Hubble Mirrors Possibly Were Faulty
DOC.TEXT: Some scientists suspect the measuring instruments made and used by a Connecticut company to create the Hubble Space Telescope's two mirrors were faulty or improperly used, a newspaper reported. The Hartford Courant said several scientists familiar with the Hubble project are focusing on the optical devices used to guide the grinding and polishing of the mirrors as the root of the focusing problems. Because of the mirror problem, the $1.5 billion orbiting observatory cannot properly focus the light from distant stars as it orbits 380 miles above the Earth. About half of its astronomical research must be delayed until a solution is found. The mirrors, a 94.5-inch primary mirror and a 12.5-inch secondary mirror, were made by Perkin-Elmer Corp. at its Danbury division, which it sold last year to Hughes Aircraft Co. Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc. officials agree there is a problem with one mirror, but are not convinced the company is responsible, said Hughes spokesman Thomas J. Arconti. ``From day one, people have been attempting to lay blame,'' Arconti said. ``That is just much too early.'' The instruments, which are called null correctors, also were used to test the finished mirrors on the Hubble. Daniel Schulte of Lockheed's Palo Alto (Calif.) Research Labs, a member of a NASA committee assigned to find ways to correct the Hubble's focusing problem, told the newspaper he is certain there was something wrong with a null corrector. Schulte said other committee members support his theory. The Courant said other scientists, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also agreed the problem was in the null correctors. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and other scientists believe the Hubble's flaw is most likely in the larger mirror. Schulte said he has ruled out the possibility of a problem with the design of the null corrector for the primary mirror, and concluded the problem had to be in the manufacture or assembly of the null corrector. ``If the null corrector is correct, the mirror would be correct,'' said Daniel Schroeder, a NASA telescope scientist who helped oversee the Hubble project and is chairman of the physics and astronomy department at Beloit College in Wisconsin. Abe Offner, a retired scientist who designed the null system in the 1970s for Perkin-Elmer, said it was almost certain the null corrector was flawed. Offner is among several scientists due to meet Wednesday and Thursday in Danbury with a six-member NASA team investigating the Hubble's flaw. There are other possibilities to explain problems with the telescope, but ``they are kind of far-fetched,'' he said. Investigators have not yet tested the null correctors, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: A Boycott Grows in Brooklyn
DOC.TEXT: Bong Jae Jang rises before dawn and goes to the Brooklyn Terminal Market, where he stocks up on green plantain, Haitian mangos and other produce popular with the Caribbean immigrants who used to shop at his store. These days, Jang's trip is an academic exercise; he knows most of the fruits and vegetables will sit unsold on the shelf, rot in the July heat and wind up in the trash bin outside. ``Who's going to buy this?'' he asks, holding up a cellophane-wrapped hunk of a vegetable called pium kim that is besieged by a swarm of tiny flies. After six months, a black-led boycott of Jang's greengrocery continues, even though the television cameras are gone and the pickets who gather outside the front door each afternoon have dwindled to a handful. The boycotters' avowed aim is to force the store to close. Jang's business is sustained largely by $5,000 to $7,000 a month in donations from the city's other Korean grocers. ``They will support him until the boycott is over,'' says Michael Kang of the Korean Produce Association. ``He is their Maginot Line. They think they're going to be next.'' Jang's troubles began Jan. 18, when Giselaine Felissaint, a Haitian immigrant, got into an argument with several of his employees over some merchandise. One of them touched her. She says the man knocked her down; another employee says the man put his hands on her and she laid down. It would be five months before the manager of the store, Pong Ok Jang, was charged with assault, but the incident immediately became a symbol of the tensions between the city's black and Korean communities. Within a few months, hundreds of demonstrators were gathering outside the store each day, along with almost as many police and journalists. Pickets yelled racial slurs at the Koreans and urged them to ``go back to where you came from.'' The problem went far beyond a simple assault charge. Many blacks resent the way they are treated in some of the Korean grocery stores that have opened in their communities, and some are jealous of the immigrants' business success. The self-employed account for 6.7 percent of all city workers, but only 3.4 percent of black ones. Skeptics derided the boycott as a news media creation that would end as soon as the last camera crew departed; they were wrong. By 5 p.m. there are usually about a dozen demonstrators behind the blue police barricades that line the sidewalk outside the store in the Flatbush neighborhood. Few local residents defy their cries of ``Boycott!'' ``The stores have become a symbol of what has happened across this city in terms of the lack of recognizing the humanity of black people,'' says George Dames, a spokesman for the Flatbush Coalition for Economic Empowerment, a boycott group. ``It was not an isolated incident.'' Since May, however, ``tensions there have been lessening, if not dramatically, then incrementally,'' says Lonnie Soury, spokesman for the city's Human Rights Commission. Mayor David Dinkins has appointed a fact-finding panel and called for an end to the boycott, but none seems likely soon. There still have been no direct negotiations between the Korean and Haitian communities, let alone Jang and Mrs. Felissaint. She has refused to denounce the boycott and has filed a $6 million suit against the store. According to a poll taken last month, only 13 percent of New Yorkers support the boycott, while 58 percent support the Koreans. Among blacks, only 27 percent sympathize with the boycotters, while 37 percent side with the Koreans. Boycott leaders say this simply reflects biased news coverage. Jang, 35, says he came here in 1983 and worked for five years at another store before opening his own. He says that before the boycott he routinely worked 17 hours a day, and was robbed three times. He shows off the scar where a robber's bullet entered his abdomen last year. Jang says neither Dinkins nor Police Commissioner Lee Brown wants to stand up to the boycotters, and pass responsibility for dealing with them back and forth. He does not speak English very clearly, but he gets his point across: ``They play a ping-pong game. They killing my dream.'' To Soury, the boycott is a tragedy. ``Two immigrant groups are pitted against each other, when they should be fighting together to demand more government aid for small businesses _ for blacks and Koreans and everyone else.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Spin Off from Sluggish Cold Front
DOC.TEXT: A sluggish cold front out of Texas created ideal thunderstorm conditions today. An upper level weather disturbance also produced showers and a few thunderstorms, mainly over the upper Mississippi Valley and western sections of the Great Lakes region. Rain was widely scattered across the Rocky Mountain region. The cold front was slowly pushing across southwest and north central Texas. Showers and thunderstorms extended from southwest Texas to Arkansas. Thunderstorms ranged along the middle Atlantic Coast and through western New England. Rain was developing in eastern sections of the Ohio Valley. Heavy storms in Ohio on Sunday spawned at least three tornadoes and thundershowers that soaked already saturated ground, leaving much of eastern Ohio under a flood watch, authorities said. Tornadoes were reported in Niles and near East Palestine in northeast Ohio, and near Marietta in southeast Ohio, but there were no reports of injuries and damage appeared to be minor, sheriffs' officials said. Temperatures in the West on Sunday soared above 100 degrees as far north as Washington state. Pasco, Wash., recorded 111 degrees. Borrego Springs, Calif., was 115 degrees and Death Valley, Calif., had an afternoon high of 119 degrees. DOC.HEAD: Mongolians Await Results of First Multi-Party Election Ever
DOC.TEXT: Officials in Mongola began tabulating results today of the first multiparty elections ever held in the world's second-oldest Communist state after the Soviet Union. Voters turned out across the Asian nation's 600,000 square miles of grasslands and steppe on Sunday for a primary involving 2,400 candidates for the national legislature, or Great People's Hural. The balloting was to reduce the field to 860 candidates, two for every seat in the Hural. The runoff is scheduled for next Sunday. A source in the capital, Ulan Bator, visited 10 polling stations in the city and described the voting as ``very well organized.'' ``The voters appeared to have a lot of confidence in the voting. They seemed enthusiastic about having a choice this time,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said results would be announced at a news conference tonight. Sunday's elections made Mongolia the latest Soviet-bloc nation to move toward multiparty democracy following a huge outpouring of pro-democracy sentiment during street demonstrations last winter. Mongolians were given the choice of voting for candidates from the ruling Communist party, known as the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, or from one of five new opposition parties. The opposition parties were formed following weeks of rallies for reform that forced former president and Communist party chief Jambyn Batmonh from power last spring. The Communists, known as the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, and the opposition parties all say their next step will be market-style economic reforms. Only 300 of the candidates in the primary are members of the non-communist parties. Together they have 15,000 members, compared with the Communist party's 90,000. The ruling party is almost certain to win a majority in the 430-seat Great People's Hural because one seat is being allocated for every 2,000 rural residents, compared with one seat per 10,000 urban residents. Most of the support for the non-communist parties is among educated urban residents, but the Communists remain strong in rural areas. The opposition parties, however, hope to win a strong majority in the 53-seat Small Hural, which was newly created to replace the current standing committee of the Great People's Hural. The Small Hural will meet year-round and hold most governmental power. However, the Great Hural still will elect a new president. The incumbent, Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat, was elected by the outgoing Great Hural in April. The Small Hural originally was to have been elected by the Great Hural. But, under pressure from the opposition, the government agreed to allocate Small Hural seats according to the percentage of votes each party receives. The Communists made more concessions last month after the opposition parties threatened to pull out of the election. The ruling party agreed to allow opposition participation in local election commissions, which count ballots, and to allow international observers to monitor the election. The Communists also gave each party state funds for campaigning and suspended party cells in the army and state security forces during the campaign and balloting. Foreign observers in Ulan Bator include a team of British parliamentarians. Mongolia has been ruled by the Communists since 1921, when a small band of revolutionaries aided by Soviet troops drove out the Chinese who had controlled Mongolia since 1691. China retained southern Mongolia, called Inner Mongolia, where Mongolian tribal princes had formed alliances with the Chinese.

DOC.HEAD: Government Confirms Fierce Fighting In Central Province
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government today reported fierce fighting in a mountainous central province that it said Khmer Rouge guerrillas were trying to seize. ``The enemy is attempting by all means to seize control'' of Kompong Thom, the official SPK news agency quoted the chief provincial administrator, Khieu Horl, as saying. Khieu Horl showed heaps of firearms, ammunition and other materiel recently captured from the guerrillas, said the report, who was monitored in Bangkok. He said about 800 Khmer Rouge guerrillas struck from all directions on June 17, but were repulsed in fighting that killed 112 guerrillas. Government Col. Hang Thol was quoted as saying the guerrillas have intensified attacks since a last month's agreement in Tokyo to arrange a truce, ``and have played havoc with any place they infiltrated into.'' The Khmer Rouge did not sign the Tokyo agreement. The SPK report said the Khmer Rouge infiltrated through the many rivers crossing the province. Claims of military successes by the government and the Khmer Rouge, both communist, are treated with skepticism. But other sources have confirmed heavy fighting in Kompong Thom, which previously was largely spared in the 11-year-old war as fighting focused on western areas bordering Thailand. The Khmer Rouge and non-communist guerrillas loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk have seized wide areas of the province in recent months. Sihanouk's fighters also briefly penetrated the provincial capital, also called Kompong Thom, said an Associated Press correspondent who visited the area. The Khmer Rouge radio said Saturday it was preparing a new attack on the provincial capital, about 75 miles north of Phnom Penh. It said that on July 12 and 13, 537 of its civilian supporters _ including youths _ voluntarily portered weapons, ammunition and food to guerrillas readying for the attack. The Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of people when in power in the 1970s, is allied in a guerrilla coalition with the forces of Sihanouk and of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. Vietnam installed the current government in Phnom Penh after invading in late 1978. A U.S. policy shift announced Wednesday has increased fears that the Khmer Rouge will escalate the fighting because of its international isolation. The United States, citing its opposition to the Khmer Rouge, said it was withdrawing recognition of the coalition's seat at the United Nations in order to open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian war. The SPK agency on Saturday urged the Khmer Rouge and its main source of arms, China, to return to talks on arranging the cease-fire. Sihanouk and Phnom Penh's Prime Minister Hun Sen signed on June 5 in Tokyo the agreement calling for a truce, but the Khmer Rouge boycotted the talks after complaining it was not being treated as an equal. China later said it did not support the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Dismemberment of Activist Sparks Concern over Canvassing Safety
DOC.TEXT: The dismemberment of an environmentalist soliciting donations in a rural neighborhood has raised concerns about the safety of canvassers nationwide. James Michael Madden, 24, of Whitefish Bay was last seen June 27 going door to door in rural Racine County to enlist support and solicit funds for Citizens for a Better Environment. On June 29, his remains, minus the head and arms, were found in plastic bags by a farmhand near a road. The missing body parts were found last week about five miles from where the torso was discovered. No arrests have been made and the investigation is continuing. Detectives say they believe Madden met a psychotic killer and his death was not related to the political slant of his work. But groups that hire canvassers say the slaying has raised interest in improving safety precautions, including self-defense training, for their thousands of employees. ``It happened once and it could happen again,'' said Gordon White, canvass director for the environmental group Greenpeace's New York chapter. ``We want to play it safe and be prepared given the possibility something like this might reoccur.'' White's office is one of 29 Greenpeace offices nationwide that employ up to 1,000 canvassers during the summer. Many are college students looking for summer jobs. White, who coordinates 50 canvassers in the New York City area, said his office is scheduling a series of safety courses involving self-defense and non-violent training. ``Because of the heightened awareness, we wanted to take care of the concerns about safety,'' he said. Some canvassers say such efforts should become routine. ``You go canvassing, you go into a different neighborhood, meet 50 to 150 people you have never met in your life and will probably never see again, then you're going to have a greater likelihood of running into these nuts,'' said former canvasser Tom Oates, 32, of Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Wilts, Gold Shades Upward
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against European currencies this morning but gained against the Japanese yen. Gold prices were up marginally. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 148.50 yen, up 0.15 yen from Friday's finish. Later in London, the dollar firmed to 148.84 yen. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: _1.6369 West German marks, down from 1.6410 _1.3985 Swiss francs, down from 1.4070 _5.4900 French francs, down from 5.5045 _1,198.50 Italian lire, down from 1,201.75 _1.1552 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1565 In London, the British pound rose to $1.8188 from $1.8140 late Friday. The rate for the Dutch guilder was not available. The dollar was lower in the morning in Tokyo but advanced in the afternoon session. Investors flocked to the dollar after the Nikkei index shed nearly 600 points at one point, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. ``Due to a lack of fresh market news, however, there's no sign for any big movements,'' Ms. Takeuchi said. Currency dealers were expecting a further drop in the dollar's value because preliminary figures for second-quarter U.S. economic growth, to be released Friday, were expected to show a decline, said Chiyuki Watanabe of Sanwa Bank. Gold was quoted in London at $361.80 per troy ounce at this morning's fixing, up from $361.25 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $361.90, from $361.50 bid late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 11 cents an ounce today, to close at $362.28. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid price of $4.86 a troy ounce, down from $4.87 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Miss Black America Selected
LaserPhoto NA1 of July 22
DOC.TEXT: Rosie Jones, a 26-year-old computer programmer, was named the new Miss Black America early today. Jones was selected from among 39 contestants in the 22nd annual pageant. A native of St. Louis, she lives and works in Bridgeport, Conn. Jacklynne Ann Fletcher of Dayton, Ohio, was second; Elaine Joyner of Columbia, S.C., was third; and Cynthia Richardson of Cincinnati was fourth. The pageant included swimsuit, public speaking and talent competitions. The outgoing Miss Black America, Paula Gwynn, 23, of Washington, D.C., said Jones must become a voice for blacks. ``She has to reach from black America to others to say `this is what black America is about,''' Gwynn said. Jones will receive a $2,000 minimum cash prize, a trip to Hawaii, new clothes and a crown. She will make appearances across the United States during her reign. Unlike the Miss America pageant, the contestants were from major metropolitan areas across the United States rather than from each state, said Aleta Anderson, a producer and the daughter of the pageant's founder, J. Morris Anderson.

DOC.HEAD: Couture for Winter with Exoticism, Artistry
DOC.TEXT: Shorter skirts than ever and plenty of lush fabrics appear to be the main themes for next winter's lines of haute couture. Christian Lacroix opened a week of fashion shows Sunday with a stunning display of exotica and opulent fabrics, refining his line with some superb jackets and trapeze coats, fur-trimmed velvet and gilded brocade. A gold-shot raspberry tweed suit with bold rhinestone buttons seemed to please Ivana Trump, who is staying at the famed Ritz hotel. She beamed througout Lacroix's show. Like the other main houses, Lacroix is ready to lengthen the short styles on the runway for a rich client who decides $10,000 is too much for a bathing-suit length cocktail dress. The cheery designer from southern France looked somewhat pale as he took a bow to enthusiastic applause. But after two back operations several months ago, and a lawsuit brought by his former employer Patou, he says he's still in fine shape. The Lacroix exuberance occasionally flounces out in too many details, such as layer on layer of lace, or yet another bustle, but most of his fitted clothes were splendid. So were the adornments _ sparkly buttons, sable cuffs, detailed embroidery and heavy-metal jeweling straight from Byzantium. Even boots were jeweled, giving the slightly 1960s silhouettes new lavishness. ``I get my inspiration from all over,'' said Lacroix. Another dream world for rich fashion devotees was turned out by Hanae Mori. The Japanese couturiere, who won the Legion of Honor last year, also is the only Japanese officially accepted as a member of the French haute couture group, the Chambre Syndicale. Mori was awarded a delicate white rose in her name at the Parc de Bagatelle a few weeks ago. The French have honored many famous women, including Barbara Bush, by naming a rose after them. At her show, Mori concentrated on exquisite drapes and flowers as a theme for her dressier clothes. Her rose-fastened satin gowns with draping and sparkling embroidery were luscious for debutantes or women a bit older. Mori did some wonderful short suits in smooth wools, easily-fitted with flaring long peplum jackets, and luxuriant short cashmere or smooth-wool capes in colors raspberry or mustard. But her show-stoppers were the slithery sequined gowns embroidered to look like Van Gogh paintings, with all the swirls and cypresses right out of the Arles masterpieces. Meanwhile, Italian Gianni Versace threw a splashy party in the Ritz gardens Saturday night following his show. The guest of honor was Sylvester Stallone. The big idea was an array of print mixes and sparkly embroidery _ in the shortest outfits possible. His dots, checks and 1960s-style graphics for the sheer fun of it drew kudos. And he showed some new pleated and draped looks he says were inspired by Leonardo da Vinci's paintings. Among the sprouting new talent, Dutch-born Paul B. Elsen, 27, gave a promising offering of truly couture-finished styles. He reportedly sewed all 32 garments himself. His long fitted redingote-style jackets with their jaunty riders' top hats were well made, as were some of the terrific pants suits, often with an interesting bolero flared with sharp pleats at the back. To amuse the jaded fashion crowd and launch a new watch collection called ``Mademoiselle,'' the Chanel company is opening up the Chanel suite at the Ritz for the week. The rooms are reconstituted exactly as when Coco Chanel lived there before World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Hijacking Attempt Fails, Two Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A student and a bricklayer who claimed to have explosives tried to hijack a domestic flight to Sweden today but the jet's crew apparently didn't believe them and they were arrested, authorities said. ``There were no bombs, no weapons, nothing,'' Mikhail Timofeyev, the deputy minister of civil aviation, said by telephone. The two tried to hijack an Aeroflot Tupolev-134 with 74 passengers that was en route to the arctic port of Murmansk from the Latvian capital of Riga, Timofeyev said. ``Following consultations with ground security services, the crew decided, however, to land at Petrozavodsk,'' 150 miles north of Leningrad, Tass said. Security officials arrested the two passengers, who were identified by the official Soviet news agency only as Kovalenko, 22, a vocational training student, and Kuznetsov, a 27-year-old bricklayer. Five young Soviet men hijacked five airliners to Sweden and Finland in June and July. They surrendered to police and said they wanted to stay in the Nordic countries. Sweden extradited one hijacker to the Soviet Union last week and Swedish officials said it was a warning to potential hijackers that they could not expect to stay in Sweden. Soviet extradition requests for the other four hijackers are being considered.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Villagers Flee as Shiite Groups Send Reinforcements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with casualties. Pickup 6th pvs, `Palestinian guerrillas...'
DOC.TEXT: Shiite Moslem factions rushed reinforcements to an embattled mountaintop town in southern Lebanon today, and thousands of villagers trekked out of the region fearing escalated warfare. Police observed a marked decrease of fighting after eight days of ferocious battles between the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal militia around the hilltop town of Jarjou. They said one combatant was killed and two other Amal militiamen wounded in sporadic exchanges of artillery and sniper fire near Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' inside Lebanon. Police said the dead fighter was a Syrian belonging to the Damascus-based Baath Party fighting with Amal. The Monday casualties raised the toll to 126 people killed and 369 wounded since the latest round in the intermittant, three-year Amal-Hezbollah confrontation broke out July 16. By police count, at least 1,167 people have been killed and 4,011 wounded in the power struggle for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Palestinian guerrillas, stationed between Amal and Hezbollah in the disputed region, took up four new hilltop positions west of Jarjou on Sunday. ``The Palestinian force is now capable of preventing any advance from either side,'' said Lt. Col. Anwar Madi, commander of the PLO intervention force, as he checked on his guerrillas at Jarjou today. Police said dozens of truckloads of ammunition and jeeps carrying Amal militiamen were sent to the militia's positions around Jarjou during the night. Amal has fielded about 6,500 frontline fighters. They said Hezbollah set up several additional artillery and mortar batteries in Jarjou. The fundamentalist group has an estimated 2,000-strong force in the Iqlim al-Tuffah, or Apple Province. The arrival of reinforcements panicked the region's remaining inhabitants. Long lines of fleeing villagers trudged through the rugged hills of the province, carrying household necessities under their arms and on their heads. Most of them sought refuge in southern Lebanon's major cities of Sidon, Tyre and Nabatiyeh. Others fled to open fields, sleeping at night in cars. ``Jarjou is almost completely deserted with a few people and many Hezbollah fighters there,'' said one refugee, who spoke on condition his name not be published. ``The town has been turned into a pile of debris,'' he said. Police estimated that no more than 50 elderly people of Jarjou's original 5,000 inhabitants remained in the town. About 50,000 people fled the Apple Province since the clashes broke out last week. Hezbollah appealed to the International Committee of the Red Cross to remove corpses decomposing under a blazing sun in Jarjou and pledged to facilitate the humanitarian mission. The fighting erupted last Monday when Hezbollah attacked and seized Jarjou, an Amal stronghold, seeking to expand its area of control as far as the Mediterranean coast to open a badly needed supply line. A 600-member Palestinian force, drawn mainly from PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah group, was deployed Tuesday along a 7-mile-long line, ostensibly to stop the fighting. Amal militiamen, supported by the Palestinians, retook Jarjou in ferocious battles on Saturday. But the fundamentalists drove the more secular Amal out of town to the western entrance of Jarjou in close-quarter combat Sunday. The PLO fears if Hezbollah expands from Jarjou to the Mediterranean they might link up with anti-Arafat Palestinian radicals and threaten the PLO bases in refugee camps near the port of Sidon, 10 miles northwest of Jarjou.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Hit As Death Toll Surpasses 1,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, `Figures compiled...' to UPDATE with death count rising to 1,055. Pickup 8th pvs, `More than...'
DOC.TEXT: Strong aftershocks rocked this mountain city today, sending residents fleeing into the streets and hampering the search for victims of last week's earthquake. The death toll surpassed 1,000. In Manila, President Corazon Aquino urged Congress to approve a $500 million relief package to rebuild infrastructure destroyed by last Monday's quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale. Mrs. Aquino made the call in a 55-minute state of the nation speech that television commentators said was surprisingly lackluster. Also today, Rep. Rolando Andaya, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said he would pursue proposals to suspend debt payments for two years to free funds to rebuild. Mrs. Aquino has warned that any unilateral reduction in debt payments could worsen the country's economic plight by prompting international lenders to reduce the flow of new money. In Baguio, the search for survivors shifted to the task of recovering the dead. British and other foreign experts declared there were no signs of life in any of the nearly 30 buildings devastated by the temblor. Official figures put the death toll at 1,055, but it was expected to rise. More than 200 bodies are believed still buried in rubble. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos, chairman of the National Disaster Coordinating Council, said more than 3,000 people were severely injured in the quake and more than 700 were missing. Ramos said nearly 90,000 people were homeless. British volunteers abandoned the search for survivors after failing to find signs of life in the Hyatt Hotel, the last area of Baguio where experts believed there might still be survivors of the quake. Hopes that some people were still alive at the Hyatt faded after rescuers no longer heard tapping sounds on walls near the hotel basement. Rescuers said the last of the survivors probably died after aftershocks shifted the rubble, either crushing them or depriving them of air. More aftershocks jolted Baguio today, including one about 9:45 a.m. that sent hundreds of people fleeing into the streets. Many Baguio residents have been sleeping outdoors since the quake because of continuing aftershocks. On Sunday, one of Mrs. Aquino's Cabinet members acknowledged that his construction firm built the Baguio Hyatt 15 years ago, but he refused to comment on allegations by a prominent civil engineer that the building was structurally unsound. ``There are many factors to consider before you can pinpoint where the fault lies,'' said Fiorello Estuar, secretary of the Department of Public Works and Highways. Last week, Octavio Kalalo, former president of the Association of Structural Engineers of the Philippines, said he inspected the Hyatt in 1985 and warned that the building could suffer serious damage in an earthquake because it was structurally unsound. But he said the warning went unheeded. In Manila, Justice Secretary Franklin Drilon said he would launch an investigation into possible criminal liability of builders and owners of buildings that collapsed here and in Cabanatuan during the quake. Jose de Jesus, presidential relief coordinator, said 373 people were killed in Baguio alone and another 175 in the surrounding province of Benguet. He said 135 people were believed trapped inside eight factories in Baguio but all were believed dead. De Jesus said information on deaths and damage was still trickling in from remote areas, including Nueva Vizcaya province, where many villages and roads were buried by landslides. Philippine pilots who surveyed the areas saw masses of survivors walking over the mountains to safety. The pilots described them as looking like ``columns of ants'' silhouetted against the barren mountain slopes.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Signs Sister State Agreement with Russian Federation
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's biggest republic and the state of Illinois today signed a ``sister-state'' agreement, the first formal agreement of cooperation between an American state and a Soviet republic. The agreement with the Russian Federation was proposed by Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson in April 1989 when he was in Moscow to open a trade show. ``This agreement establishes a formal governmental relationship and a framework for a wide range of cultural, educational, technological and economic cooperation programs,'' Thompson said at signing ceremony. Ivan Silayev, chairman of the Russian Council of Ministers, signed for the republic. ``Our efforts to improve trade relations between Illinois and the Soviet Union have already given birth to several positive results,'' Thompson said. ``We have welcomed numerous Soviet delegations to our state. There have been several days of discussions in Chicago between the Ilinois Department of Commerce and Community Affairs and the U.S.S.R. Association for Small and Medium Businesses.'' The agreement calls for business, farming and cultural exchanges, including film festivals in Chicago and Moscow. Forty-nine Fortune 500 companies are headquartered in Illinois, according to officials traveling with the Republican governor. Many of them are already doing business in the Soviet Union, including McDonald's, Abbott Laboratories, Caterpilar and Dresser Industries. ``It is the heartfelt desire of the people, businesses, organized labor and the government of Illinois to establish permanent and cooperative relationships throughout Russia, for the mutual benefit of both our people and for an expanding peace and prosperity for the world,'' Thompson said.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Metro Rail's Blue Line Train Jumps Track; 30 Passengers Unharmed
DOC.TEXT: A train on the new Southern California light-rail trolley line derailed when a metal wire prevented it from switching smoothly. The 30 passengers aboard the Japanese-built, overhead-powered train were unhurt when the cars left the tracks early Sunday, said Jim Smart, a Southern California Rapid Transit District spokesman. The train, which has a top speed of 55 mph, was traveling only about 10 mph at the time, he said. ``The good news is no one was hurt. No harm, no foul,'' Smart said. The accident forced a three-hour closure of downtown's Pico Station. The station is at the end of the 22-mile Long Beach-to-Los Angeles line that began running July 14. Paul O'Brien, rail operations superintendent for the Southern California Rapid Transit District, said the derailment apparently was caused by a 4-inch-long metal wire that became wedged between switching tracks. The $877 million Blue Line is the first stage of an ambitious 150-mile, $10 billion rail system that transportation officials hope will make commuters forsake their smog-spewing cars.

DOC.HEAD: Engineers Working on Controversial Canal Project Killed
DOC.TEXT: Sikh gunmen burst into a meeting of senior government officials today and killed two engineers working on a controversial irrigation project, police said. The victims, M.L. Sekhri and A.S. Aulakh, were in charge of constructing a canal that will divert river waters from Punjab state to other parts of India. Police inspector Jaspal Singh said three Sikhs entered a meeting on the Sutlej-Yamuna Link Canal Project. The Sikhs then fired automatic weapons. Sekhri, 52, and Aulakh, 50, were killed and two officers were injured, Singh said. The assailants fled from the offices of the construction project on motor scooters, he said. The offices are located in a busy market complex in Chandigarh, the joint capital of Punjab and Haryana states. The canal is supposed to divert water from the Sutlej river to the Yamuna river. Work began in 1982 and is nearly completed, government officials say. Sikh politicians, whose support largely comes from Sikh farmers in Punjab, fear the project will deprive the state of irrigation facilities. Sikh militant groups, agitating for an independent nation in Punjab, have also opposed the canal. In May 1988, 32 laborers working on the project were killed by Sikh radicals. Sikhs form only 2 percent of India's 880 million people but are in a slight majority in Punjab. The militants began fighting for independence in 1982, accusing the Hindu community of cultural and political discrimination. Nationwide, Hindus make up 82 percent of the population. The militants have killed at least 1,456 people in Punjab this year in their quest for a separate nation.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Trapped in Helotes Creek Freed After 8{ Hours
LaserPhoto SA1
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers used a jackhammer to free a 13-year-old boy who was trapped for 8{ hours after his leg got stuck in a hole in a creekbed. ``I'm OK, I'm fine,'' the boy, William Burnett, told rescuers as they worked to free his right leg Sunday evening. Bexar County Sheriff's Sgt. Ed Olivares said the boy was walking in Helotes Creek with some friends around 3 p.m. when he fell into a hole. His leg got pinned when rocks fell into the hole. After they were unable to free the boy with pickaxes, rescuers used a compression jackhammer to chip away at the rock surrounding the hole, said police Officer Perry Rose. He was finally freed about 11:30 p.m. To keep water away from the boy during the rescue effort, workers used earth-moving equipment to build a 4-foot-tall dam, and then pumped water out of the area around the boy. Rose said Burnett's right leg was swollen but not broken. The boy was taken to San Antonio's Methodist Hospital for observation. Helotes Fire Capt. Kurt Johnson said he thought the hole was originally part of a concrete well casing. But others said the hole had been drilled into the creek bed several years ago to gather core samples. Originally, authorities had feared that severe storms forecast for the area would put the boy in danger, but the rain remained at bay. The creekbed is dry much of the year. Helotes is a town of about 1,800 just northwest of San Antonio.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Lawmakers Resign, South Agrees To Discuss Terms Of Border Opening
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th pvs, `Today, North...' to UPDATE with North Korean proposal for talks Friday. Pickup 7th pvs, `Longtime observers...'
DOC.TEXT: Opposition lawmakers resigned en masse today, demanding new elections and accusing President Roh Tae-woo of using sensitive inter-Korea issues to divert attention from pressing domestic problems. The resignations of all 79 opposition members in the 299-member National Assembly could throw the country into political crisis as it prepares for the first meeting ever between the prime ministers of North and South Korea. The Roh government announced today that it was willing to negotiate with the Communist north on conditions the north is setting for opening the border between the Koreas to travelers. In a dramatic speech on Friday, Roh proposed that the common border be opened for five days in August on a trial basis, allowing people on both sides free travel. He said open borders could lead talks on unification. But North Korea demanded that South Korea scrap its anti-Communist national security laws, release prisoners jailed for promoting unification and allow South Korean dissidents to attend an Aug. 15 border rally sponsored by North Korea. North Korea today proposed expanded high-level talks among government and political leaders of the two sides Friday. North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, reported the proposal. Longtime observers view the border talks as part of a continuing sporadic dialogue between rivals. Mutual distrust has blocked any real progress in prior talks. Three South Korean Cabinet ministers said Seoul is willing to negotiate conditions set by the north and also suggested the two sides meet on Friday. ``In order to open the border and realize grand national exchanges, we are ready to discuss any problems related to it,'' Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul said on national radio and television. Hong and other Cabinet ministers said North Korea has a number of barriers to free travel and a poor human rights record. Justice Minister Lee Jong-nam cited reports by international human rights groups that North Korea is holding 152,000 political prisoners at 12 concentration camps. He also noted that the north's constitution makes communization of the south the country's top goal. The heavily fortified border is tightly sealed, and more than 1.5 million troops are stationed on either side behind bunkers and barbed wire. There is no mail, travel or other communication between the nations. Kim Dae-jung, head of the leading opposition Party for Peace and Democracy, said his party welcomed efforts for border openings with North Korea. But he said Roh should not use the issue to bolster what he called sagging support for the governing Democratic Liberal Party. The mass resignations from Parliament included 71 members of Kim's party and eight members from the splinter Democratic Party. The legislators cleaned out their offices and said they and their staffs would refuse further government paychecks as of today. They said they would not return unless the governing party agrees to discuss their demands, including new elections. They also want 26 controversial bills that were pushed through the legislature at a special session earlier this month returned to committee. Roh's party was a minority party in Parliament until it merged in January with two smaller groups, giving it a two-thirds majority. The opposition says the legislature's makeup no longer reflects the wishes of voters and new elections must be held. The governing party said the resignations would not be immediately accepted. Under Korean law, the speaker can refuse to accept the resignations until the next parliamentary session _ in September _ when they would be voted upon. Opposition lawmakers said they considered themselves finished with Parliament, regardless of how the resignations are dealt with. On Saturday, anti-government protesters clashed with police after a huge opposition rally that attracted an estimated 300,000 people. Fighting broke out when riot police firing tear gas blocked a column of about 20,000 radical students chanting anti-government slogans. Police said 195 protesters were arrested. There were no reports of injuries. The rally had been called to celebrate talks to unify the two opposition parties with a nationwide dissident group by September. The Korean peninsula was divided into the pro-Western south and Communist north at the end of World War II. The nations fought the Korean War from 1950 to 1953, and are technically still at war because no peace treaty was signed.

DOC.HEAD: Rains Blamed for Boulder That Destroyed Cabin, Killing 2
DOC.TEXT: A retired couple apparently were asleep when a large boulder tumbled down a mountain and crashed through their cabin, killing them both, officials said. The boulder, estimated to be 25 feet by 20 feet, broke loose from a mountain near the mouth of the Big Thompson Canyon at about 6:30 a.m. Sunday, said Larimer County Undersheriff Marv Schlageter. The undersheriff said the boulder tore through the cabin, knocking it off its foundation, and came to rest nearby. The victims were identified as Charles and Dorothy Brown, who had retired and moved into the cabin less than a year ago. The site is about eight miles east of this Rocky Mountain resort town. Recent heavy rains apparently caused the boulder to break free, Schlageter said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Team to Make First MIA Mission to Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. military team goes to Cambodia on Tuesday to examine what may be the remains of Americans missing from the war in Indochina, a spokesman said. It will be the first such mission since the 1975 communist takeover in Cambodia. The United States does not recognize the Vietnamese-installed Phnom Penh government and has supported guerrillas fighting for its overthrow. But Wednesday, the United States announced it was withdrawing recognition of the guerrilla coalition and would open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian war. The six-man team leaves from Bangkok aboard a U.S. Air Force plane and will stay overnight in Phnom Penh, said team spokesman Lt. Col. Thomas Boyd. He said if the remains are identified as those of Americans, a 17-member team will fly to Cambodia on Thursday to take the remains to Hawaii. Boyd would not say how many sets of remains will be examined. At least 82 U.S. servicemen are listed as missing in action in Cambodia, he said. U.S. officials have also said there are at least eight civilians reported missing in Cambodia, including four journalists, two contractors, a merchant seaman and a missionary. Most American servicemen missing in Cambodia are airmen. U.S. airplanes heavily bombed the country from 1969 until 1973. Earlier this month, John Gunther Dean, the last U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia, made a six-day visit to Phnom Penh _ his first since carrying out the U.S. flag out in 1975. The U.S. severed relations with Cambodia in 1975 after Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas seized power. During their four year rule, the Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people as they tried to implement radical agrarian reforms. Phnom Penh said in 1984 it was willing to cooperate on the issue of missing Americans and declared in 1988 that it was willing to hand over remains. But the repatriations have been delayed by the diplomatic stalemate. Cambodia's premier, Hun Sen, was quoted as saying in February 1989 that his government had eight sets of American remains and was searching for more. Last month, the Cambodian government said it had set up a five-man commission led by a deputy minister to help search for the remains of U.S. servicemen. There are 2,353 Americans missing from the war in Indochina. The largest number, 1,719, are missing in Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Chess Expert Says He Has Cracked Puzzle in Missing Woman Mystery
DOC.TEXT: A chess expert, drawing inspiration from Sherlock Holmes and Lewis Carroll, said today he believes he has cracked a puzzle that could lead to the whereabouts of a woman missing since January. Police believe the woman is buried somewhere in Ireland, and the chess expert's work ``would appear to reinforce these views,'' Detective Superintendent Roy Fletcher of Lancashire Police said. The puzzle, drawn by a man arrested in connection with the case, is a crude map and a series of moves for a black king, a black queen, a black pawn and ``white king _ all pawns.'' Raymond Keene, chess correspondent of The Times of London and an international grand master, said the puzzle's author shows ``tremendous intellectual arrogance, allied with a perverted ingenuity and rooted in the belief that he can dangle all sorts of intellectual clues in front of the police's nose without their being able to solve them.'' Fletcher said Therese Terry, 43, has been missing since January. Colin English was arrested in June and charged with fraud in relation to funds taken from Mrs. Terry's bank account. ``While in custody he drew a map which he says gives the answer to where she is buried,'' Fletcher said. ``He claims she died at her own hand.'' Keene, who was given the puzzle Friday, said he was unable to pin down the burial site, but ``it is my firm belief that the body is located ... some miles northwest of Limerick.'' Keene wrote in today's Times that the diagram was a crude mirror image of southern Ireland, rotated 90 degrees to put east at the bottom, and that Roman numerals stood for various places in England and Ireland. He believes the black king is the suspect, the black queen is the victim, the black pawn is the suspect's brother, and the white pawns are the police _ ``a scarcely veiled insult to the suspect's assessment of the competence of the police force.'' Keene wrote that the moves appear to show events between Jan. 18, when Mrs. Terry left Lancashire for London, and Jan. 23, when English returned from Ireland. Keene said that while trying to solve the puzzle, he recalled a Sherlock Holmes story called ``The Dancing Men,'' in which Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's fictional detective breaks a code that used figures of dancing stick men. He also was inspired by Lewis Carroll's story in which Alice enters a world of reflections peopled mainly by chess pieces.

DOC.HEAD: Sacha Pitoeff, Actor and Director, Dies In Paris
DOC.TEXT: Sacha Pitoeff, an actor and director best known for his stage productions of Chekhov and Pirandello, has died of a heart ailment, associates said today. He was 70. Pitoeff, who died in a Paris hospital Saturday, was the last survivor of a theatrical dynasty founded by his Russian-born parents, Georges and Ludmilla Pitoeff. Born in Geneva on March 11, 1920, Pitoeff joined his father's company in 1938. His father died in 1939, and his mother took over the company and kept it functioning in Switzerland during World War II. Pitoeff formed his own company in France in 1949, and become renowned for productions of Chekhov classics such as ``The Sea Gull,'' ``The Cherry Orchard'' and ``Uncle Vanya.'' He also produced on several occasions, most recently in 1977, one the plays favored by his parents, Luigi Pirandello's ``Six Characters in Search of an Author.'' He acted in several films, including ``Last Year At Marienbad.'' Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Politicians Resign To Protest Military Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: Members of a political party considered close to Tamil Tiger rebels today resigned from Parliament to protest what they called atrocities by the military in its war against the guerrillas. The government declared a curfew in the northern district of Kilinochchi and began search operations for rebels involved in a fierce gun battle with troops Sunday. At least nine soldiers and 18 rebels were killed in the battle, military officials said. The deaths were among 122 reported Sunday. At least 76 rebels were killed in what the officials described as mopping up operations in the east. Eight soldiers and three civilians died in other fighting in the north, they said. The bodies of eight Moslems, believed killed by the rebels, were found in the east, they said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The deaths raise to at least 2,856 the number of combatants killed since fighting resumed June 11 between the rebels and security forces. Many civilians also have died. All 11 members of the Eelavur Democratic Front resigned from Parliament today. ``We do not want to be dormant spectators who witness the tormentation of our people,'' they said in a statement. The Front won 13 of the 225 seats in Parliament in the 1989 general elections. Two of its members resigned earlier this year for personal reasons. Last month, the group called for a cease-fire between the Tamil rebels and the government. President Ranasinghe Premadasa rejected the offer, asking the rebels to lay down their arms first. ``It appears that the hope we had that the solution be made through political measures is not sensible,'' the statement said. ``The chance to find a solution to the problems of the Tamil-speaking people is out of reach.'' Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's population and say they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. Tamil rebels began fighting for an independent homeland in 1983. The Tigers are the largest rebel group.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of 24 Ceausescu Aides Adjourned
DOC.TEXT: The trial of 24 top associates of ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was adjourned for two weeks today to permit medical examinations of the defendants. The 24, all former members of the Communist Party Politburo, are accused of backing Ceausescu's orders to shoot at peaceful demonstrators in December. Those protests marked the start of the revolution that led to Ceausescu's overthrow. The defendants face maximum sentences of life in prison on charges of complicity in mass killings. The defendants pleaded innocent to the charges. The trial, which opened Saturday, was first adjourned after the defense requested that the president of the five-man military tribunal be replaced. The defense argued that Ion Nistor was potentially biased because he was one of the five judges who conducted the secret trial against Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, after they were deposed. The Ceausescus were found guilty and were executed Dec. 25. The death penalty was outlawed after their execution. Nistor and the rest of the tribunal were replaced and the trial was resumed. But it was again adjourned today after the new president of the tribunal, Capt. Bogdan Graur, agreed to the defense request for medical examinations for most of the defendants. The defendants have complained that harsh prison conditions have led to the deterioration of their health. The trial was adjourned until Aug. 8. Former Vice-Premier Ion Radu, one of the defendants, described jail conditions as ``deplorable.'' Dumitru Popescu, former rector of the Academy of Social and Political Studies that trained Communist officials, said ``the rats, mosquitoes and the smell jeopardize our life and capacity of telling the truth.'' Other defendants complained of loss of weight and memory while in detention. Three of the defendants were not present in court because of illness, including former Premier Constantin Dascalescu. Media reports say he has tried to commit suicide at least twice while in detention. The charges against the 24 are based on their participation in a telephone conference of the ruling Politburo in December at which Ceausescu gave the orders to open fire on demonstrators. According to the official transcript from the meeting published in Bucharest dailies, the defendants agreed with the decision. The latest official figures show that at least 1,038 people were killed in the uprising against Ceausescu's rule.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0469 to CORRECT category code
DOC.HEAD: Greg LeMond Wins Tour de France
DOC.TEXT: American Greg LeMond won his third Tour de France title in five years, and two more victories in bicycling's most prestigious race would put him in the category of all-time greats in a sport long ruled by Europeans. For the next two years, the 29-year-old native of Wayzata, Minn., said he intends to pedal his bicycle more and peddle himself less. LeMond got himself in trouble by accepting too many outside activities that cut into his training time over the winter. It was a frantic rush to get back into shape and he doesn't want to go through it again. ``My next two years, I am dedicating myself to cycling,'' LeMond said. ``I will be try to be back and strong next year.'' Eddy Merckx, Jacques Anquetil and Bernard Hinault share the record of five victories in the Tour de France. Cheered by thousands who gathered along Paris' famed Champs Elysees, LeMond stayed with the rest of the pack Sunday. It was enough for him to preserve his two-minute, 16-second lead over Italian Claudio Chiappucci, and take his second title in a row. In 1986, LeMond was the first American to win the race. LeMond fell behind early in the three-week, 2,112-mile race and trailed by nearly 10 minutes at the midway stage. He narrowed Chiappucci's lead to five seconds after the 16th stage, but remained in second place until surging ahead in Saturday's time trial.
