DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0467 to CORRECT category code
DOC.HEAD: Nick Faldo Wins British Open by 5 Shots
DOC.TEXT: Nick Faldo snatched his second British Open golf crown in four years with the exactitude that has become his trademark and has made him the world's dominant player. The 33-year-old Englishman beat American Payne Stewart and Mark McNulty of Zimbabwe by five strokes and finished two shots off the tournament record with an 18-under par total of 270. He shot a one-under par, final-round 71 on Sunday at St. Andrews, the world's oldest course. Faldo has topped four of the last 13 major championships, including the Masters in April. He missed making a playoff in the U.S. Open in June when a putt on the final hole refused to fall. Faldo is the first player to win two majors in a season since Tom Watson in 1982. The performance was vintage Faldo, only slightly less consistent than his 18 pars in the final round of the British Open at Muirfield in 1987 _ his first major title. Faldo claimed $154,000 for his victory in a tournament that lost its defending champion, Mark Calcavecchia, after two rounds. The cut was at a record-low 143, 1-under par, and among the other casualties were Seve Ballesteros, Curtis Strange and Tom Kite. Also missing the cut by one stroke was Arnold Palmer, playing in his final British Open 30 years after his first at St. Andrews.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Considering Gas Masks for Polluted Region
DOC.TEXT: The government is considering issuing up to 100,000 gas masks in southern Poland to protect people from air pollution, an official said today. A proposal is being drafted to distribute them in heavily industrialized Katowice province, said Col. Czeslaw Bujala of the provincial Civil Defense Office. Air and water pollution has reached desperate levels across Poland because of outdated factories, a heavy dependence on coal, and decades of neglect of the environment. The problem is particularly severe for the 4 million residents of Katowice, in the Silesia region. Katowice accounts for 20 percent of Poland's industrial output and 30 percent of its air pollution. The province makes up 2 percent of the national territory but has a population density five times the national average. A 1988 report said it is home to a quarter of Poland's 900 worst-polluting plants. Elevated infant mortality rates, substantially increased cases of tuberculosis, cancers and other diseases as well as shortened life expectancy are documented in the region. The province has 1,053 factories making hazardous materials or using them for production, the Zycie Warszawy newspaper reported. It said initial plans call for distributing gas masks to up to 100,000 people, particularly those living near seven plants considered the most dangerous in case of accidental emissions, the newspaper said. Bujala confirmed the report and said by telephone, ``We have the gas masks and we are considering giving them to people, mainly to those who live near factories producing toxic elements.'' The plan still must be approved by Civil Defense headquarters, he said. The new Solidarity-led government has vowed to address the pollution problem but is hampered by lack of funds. Environmental Minister Bronislaw Kaminski recently published a list of the 80 worst polluting factories and ordered them to meet emissions standards or face possible closure.

DOC.HEAD: British, Czechoslovak Foreign Ministers Sign Anti-Terrorist Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Douglas Hurd of Britain and his Czechoslovak counterpart, Jiri Dienstbier, signed an anti-terrorism pact today to strengthen cooperation between their countries, the state CTK news agency reported. Hurd, who arrived Sunday for a three-day visit, also met today with President Vaclav Havel to discuss British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's visit to Czechoslovakia in the fall. No date was announced. The anti-terrorism accord provides for cooperation in fighting drug trafficking and organized crime. It calls for granting mutual assistance in investigating individual cases, as well as a general exchange of information. The agreement takes effect immediately, the agency said. Czechoslovakia has been a major exporter of Semtex, a virtually undetectable explosive believed to be used by terrorists worldwide. During an official visit to London in March, Havel disclosed that Prague sold Libya 1,000 tons of Semtex over the past 10 years but said the sales stopped some time ago. Security experts say the explosive has been used in a number of terrorist attacks, including the bombing of a Pan Am Boeing 747 over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988, which killed 270 people. During their talks today, Hurd and Dienstbier also discussed questions of European security, including the future of NATO and Warsaw Pact military alliances, CTK said. It did not elaborate. Earlier this month, the two countries signed an agreement on private investments in Czechoslovakia that offers government guarantees to future British investors and safeguards their property in the country. ``Both ministers agreed that Czechoslovak-British relations are currently at their highest level in the entire postwar history,`` CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin Calls for Halt to B-2 Bomber Program
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 2nd graf to restore Aspin's first name.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee announced today he will oppose future production of the B-2 bomber, a major boost to House efforts to kill the aircraft President Bush has sought. ``Production of the B-2 should be stopped and the production facility should be mothballed. Research and development should be continued and completed,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said in a speech to be delivered on the House floor. Aspin cited the increasing fiscal constraints on the defense budget as the basis for his decision. The chairman noted that five strategic programs _ the B-2 bomber, the C-17 transport plane, the Advanced Tactical Fighter, the A-12 attack plane and the light helicopter _ will cost more than $300 billion. Specifically, the cost of a single B-2 bomber is estimated at nearly $860 million, a price tag that has caused sticker shock among members of Congress. ``The answer to the question of whether the B-2 will be as stealthy and otherwise work as advertised is: The early results are good, but we just don't know yet,'' Aspin said. In the final analysis, the Armed Services chairman said the program turned up no ``unique and compelling mission for the B-2.'' In proposing a $307 billion defense budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, Bush called for $5.5 billion for five of the radar-evading aircraft and related items. Faced with a diminishing Soviet threat and a burgeoning federal deficit, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney in April revised the administration's request to two planes in fiscal 1991. Cheney also cut the total number of planes to built from 132 to 75 at a total cost of $63 billion. Aspin's announcement is certain to help legislation sponsored by Reps. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., John Rowland, R-Conn., and John Kasich, R-Ohio, to stop production of the planes at the 15 currently in development. In his speech, Aspin said he would incorporate the Dellums-Kasich-Rowland amendment in his proposal to the committee. Last year, the legislation failed in the House by a vote of 279-144, largely because Aspin opposed the bill and joined forces with Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., on a compromise bill that scaled back the program. The Aspin-Synar amendment was approved 257-160. Although proponents of the House measure are optimistic they can kill the program, support for the bat-winged aircraft in the Senate remains strong. The Senate Armed Services Committee, in approving a $289 billion defense bill earlier this month, approved the administration's request for two planes in fiscal 1991 and the panel's chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., remains a strong supporter of the aircraft. Aspin's decision comes as his panel is scheduled to begin crafting their version of the defense bill for fiscal 1991. The committee will draw up a budget to a total of $283 billion, $24 billion less than Bush proposed.

DOC.HEAD: Report: PLO Leader Says Abu Nidal Holds Swiss Red Cross Workers
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss newspaper today quoted a top PLO official as saying terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal planned the October kidnapping of two Swiss Red Cross workers and is holding them in Lebanon. The Neue Zuercher Zeitung newspaper reported that Salah Khalaf, the No. 2 figure in the PLO, said records confirming Abu Nidal's involvement in the abduction were found last month after the PLO seized a base used by Abu Nidal supporters in the Rashidiyeh refugee camp in Lebanon. The Palestine Liberation Organization and Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council have been involved in a bitter feud since Abu Nidal split with the PLO in 1973. No group has formally claimed responsibility for the kidnapping of Emanuel Christen, 32, and Elio Erriquez, 23, two specialists at the artifical limb center operated by the International Committee of the Red Cross near Sidon. Three days after their disappearance, Lebanese police said they were held by the Fatah-Revolutionary Council. But on Oct. 16, Abu Nidal issued a statement denying any role in the abduction. Khalaf, also known as Abu Iyad, said Abu Nidal is waiting for the Swiss to open negotiations with his group. The newspaper quoted Khalaf as urging the Swiss not to let themselves be blackmailed. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, is believed to be in Libya. A U.S. State Department report last year described Abu Nidal as the world's most dangerous terrorist. It blamed his hirelings for 34 terrorist attacks in 20 countries since 1973. At least 900 people were killed or wounded in these attacks, the report said. The atrocities included the December 1985 attacks on Rome and Vienna airports that killed more than 20 people. Abu Nidal's group was torn by a bloody internal feud in late 1989 in which some 200 dissidents were slain. The group's strength is now estimated to be less than 100. Christen and Erriquez are among 16 Westerners, including six Americans, believed held hostage in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Two Suspected Arab Collaborators Killed
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinians in the occupied territories hacked to death one alleged collaborator and strangled a second Arab suspected of cooperating with Israeli authorities, Palestinian reports said. Fourteen Palestinians accused of cooperating with Israeli officials have been killed since July 1 despite repeated orders by the underground Palestinian leadership not to execute suspected collaborators without PLO approval. The body of one victim was discovered in the West Bank town of Qalqilya and the second was killed in the Gaza Strip's Rafah refugee camp, the army said. It said police were investigating the deaths. In Qalqilya, Arab reports said, five Palestinians abducted 26-year-old Ahmad Atturi from his home Sunday night and then stabbed and hacked him to death. Atturi, suspected by Arabs of cooperating with the Shin Bet security service, was beaten by masked men six months ago and then released. The victim in Rafah was 22-year-old Issam Nawajaha, who was found strangled to death on the street after being seized by masked Palestinians, Arab reporters said. Nawajaha, who worked in Israel as a day laborer, was accused of aiding Israeli authorities, camp residents said. The two deaths raised to 242 the number of Palestinains slain by fellow Arabs during the uprising on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities. During the 31-month-old revolt, 723 Palestinians have been slain by Israeli soldiers and civilians, and 45 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Activist Indicted For Meeting With Arafat
DOC.TEXT: Peace activist Abie Nathan has been charged with violating Israeli law by meeting with PLO leader Yassir Arafat, a Justice Ministry spokeswoman said today. Spokeswoman Etti Eshed said no trial date has yet been set on the charge, the second time Nathan has been so charged. Nathan was sentenced in October to six months in prison after being convicted of meeting with Arafat and other leading figures in the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1988. Released after four months for good behavior, he then traveled to PLO headquarters in Tunis and again met with Arafat. Israel considers the PLO a terrorist organization, and an amendment to Israel's anti-terror law passed in 1986 prohibits Israeli citizens from meeting with members of such groups. Nathan, 63, said he met with Arafat in March to protest the anti-terror amendment, ``which is an obstacle to peace.'' Most Palestinian leaders maintain Israel should negotiate with the PLO as their representative. Palestinians have been waging a 31-month-old revolt against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which were captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. Nathan said he was convinced a majority of Israelis were ready to talk to the PLO, and warned that if again convicted he would ``use all non-violent measures'' to fight the amendment. ``I will even risk my life,'' he vowed. Nathan is best known for making a dramatic trip in a private plane to Cairo in 1964 to try to convince Egypt to make peace with Israel. In 1978, he went on a 45-day hunger strike to protest the building of Jewish settlements in the occupied lands. He also runs a popular ship-based radio station _ The Voice of Peace _ off Israel's Mediterranean coast.

DOC.HEAD: ANC, Communists Deny Allegations of Insurrection Plot
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with Communist Party denying plot, 21 reported killed in township violence. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress today acknowledged that ANC guerrillas have been infiltrating South Africa and many have been arrested, but it denied reports of a revolution plot. South Africa's Communist Party also denied the allegations, which said Communist Party members within the ANC were planning an insurrection without the approval of the African National Congress. Also today, police reported 21 people killed Sunday night and today following battles in two Johannesburg-area townships between ANC supporters and members of the Zulu-based Inkatha party. The Communist Party said in a statement that the government allegations, reported in newspapers Sunday, were a ``Red-scare tactic'' designed to coincide with a Communist rally planned this weekend in the black township of Soweto. An ANC leader, Walter Sisulu, also denied the newspaper reports, which quoted government sources as saying a secret unit of ANC guerrillas directed by the Communist Party planned an armed insurrection because they oppose the ANC's policy of negotiating with the government. The reports said the ANC military wing's command did not know of the plot. Sisulu said it was impossible for the Communist Party to have a different agenda from the ANC because the two organizations share many leaders. He was quoted in The Daily Mail newspaper as saying the ANC believed as many as 150 of its members had been arrested in recent weeks. He said he assumed the guerrillas had been engaged in the ``normal activities'' of the organization and noted the ANC's armed struggle had not been suspended. The Citizen, a pro-government newspaper with strong ties to the security police, said today that President F.W. de Klerk planned to make an announcement about a ``national insurrection'' plot this week. ``The disclosures are expected to be so serious that they will shake the world and could have a profound effect on internal policies,'' The Citizen said. The president's office denied de Klerk intended to make such a statement. The State Security Council met today to discuss the insurrection allegations, according to newspaper reports. The ANC executive committee also met today in preparation for its next round of talks with the government on Aug. 6 to discuss a cease-fire and other issues. The government wants the ANC to formally end its ineffective 29-year-old armed struggle and has asked Nelson Mandela and other ANC leaders to stop ``war talk.'' But the ANC has said it will not suspend the military wing's activities until the government has made irreversible changes to end apartheid and share power. Sisulu said he expected detentions of ANC members to continue as long as the organization had not arranged a cease-fire with the government, but ``one thing we are not going to do is to stop the process of negotiations.'' A man claiming to be a sub-lieutenant in the ANC's military wing reportedly entered the U.S. Consulate in Durban seeking asylum. An ANC official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Dhekumusa Jabulani Ximbe, 38, had been in hiding since police raided his home a week ago and confiscated a cache of hand grenades and limpet mines. The official said the raid was part of the nationwide police sweep on ANC militants and Communist Party members who recently returned from exile or infiltrated secretly. Police reported 21 people were found dead after running battles in the townships of Sebokeng and Evaton after Inkatha held a rally at a stadium. Police said they fired tear gas and tried to separate the factions and that one policeman was killed by a thrown spear.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Sides With Critics in Protesting Film Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with film board chairman saying ban came on legal advice. Pickup 4th pvs, `Now they...'
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie has joined his Moslem critics in opposing a ban on a Pakistani film that depicts him as a murderer, and a Moslem leader said today that his group will demand the ban be lifted. The British Board of Film Classification has refused to permit distribution of ``International Guerrillas,'' which depicts Rushdie, author of ``The Satanic Verses,'' as the agent of an international conspiracy. The board's chairman, James Ferman, said today that it had to ban the film on legal advice that the movie appeared to violate the law of criminal libel. ``It was the most difficult decision that the board has ever taken,'' Ferman said Monday. ``Those of us who believe in freedom of expression ... believed very strongly there was an argument for not increasing the grievance of the Moslem community and taking the film with a pinch of salt.'' Sher Azam, president of the Council of Mosques in Bradford, said: ``The ban clearly shows there is discrimination, double standards and hypocrisy in high places against Moslems. ``Now they have made this decision, surely we will be doing something about writing to them and saying that the public at large should have an opportunity to see this film,'' Azam said. Rushdie was born into a Moslem family in India and now is a British subject. He has been in hiding under guard since February 1989, when the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran said ``The Satanic Verses'' blasphemed Islam and that Rushdie deserved to die. The 3{-hour film portrays Rushdie as the agent of a conspiracy against Islam and depicts him killing and torturing Moslems until he himself is killed by a bolt of lightning. Rushdie believes the film should not be censored, one of his supporters said. ``He feels it should not be decided in advance what the public should or should not see without there being proof that it would cause public disorder,'' said Frances D'Souza, chairwoman of the Rushdie Defense Committee. ``The reaction of the Moslem community is in itself understandable; they feel they have been blasphemed by the book and feel there are two different standards being applied,'' Ms. D'Souza said Sunday. Mohammed Fayyaz of London, who owns the worldwide distribution rights to the film, said he would try to persuade the film board to overturn the ban, then go through the appeals procedure. ``If still they refuse us then we will go to court,'' he said. The film board issued a statement saying: ``We are informed that this video presents a prima facie case of criminal libel on a British citizen, Salman Rushdie, and that the libel is a serious one.'' The board said the distributor of the film had been told that it could be resubmitted if the Rushdie character had a new name, and if calls for Rushdie's death were excised. An editorial in The Times of London noted that Rushdie's own defense of his book is that it is fiction. ``The distributors will argue in turn that a film which shows Mr. Rushdie slitting the throats of good Muslims or, more horrid torture still, forcing them to listen to tapes of `The Satanic Verses,' should also be construed as fiction,'' The Times said. It added that ``in any case a ban will mean that millions, not a few thousands, will want to see what is now a notorious film. Censorship always backfires.'' Rushdie's publisher announced earlier this month that two new books by him would soon be brought out. They will be his first since ``The Satanic Verses'' brought the death threats from Khomeini. The death threats have hampered restoration of diplomatic ties between Tehran and London, which were effectively severed in June 1987 after a series of expulsions of diplomats.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With Attorney General, Others on Brennan Successor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; restores original byline; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's opposition to abortion remains unchanged but ``there will be no litmus test on specific issues'' in his search for a Supreme Court nominee, Bush's spokesman said today. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that Bush would meet with key advisers each day through the week as he ponders a successor to retired Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan. ``He wants the best candidate, the most qualified candidate, a person of experience and temperament and wants to pursue that search for a person with the least constraints possible,'' Fitzwater said. Asked whether Bush would insist on knowing the abortion views of his court nominee, Fitzwater said: ``We can't define what the specific philosophy would be of the candidate.'' ``You can expect that he would look for someone who favors a faithful interpretation of the Constitution as opposed to seeing the court as a legislative tool. (But) there will be no litmus test on specific issues,'' Fitzwater said. ``The president views on the issue have not changed. But there will be no litmus test,'' Fitzwater said. Bush opposes abortion except to protect the life of the mother or in cases of rape and incest. Fitzwater said that Bush still intends to name his choice as quickly as possible and already had ``a fairly well defined list of people who are qualified'' from which to work. Bush met with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today and other top advisers after holding similar meetings over the weekend. Fitzwater said that the president planned to meet frequently with Thornburgh, Chief of Staff John Sununu and White House counsel Boyden Gray as he narrows his list. In addition, the president called four congressional leaders over the weekend to get their views on a nominee, Fitzwater said. They were Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine; Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan.; House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash.; and House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. ``I think it's fair to say that most of the candidates we are looking at have judicial experience,'' and already have undergone review by the American Bar Association, Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, key senators say President Bush should shun ideologues and look for solid judicial experience in his choice. But even so, congressional leaders are suggesting that abortion is likely to be a focal point in Senate debate no matter who the president selects. ``If the president sends up somebody committed to overturning Roe vs. Wade, there will be a battle,'' Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said today. If the nominee is not committed to an anti-abortion position, he added, ``I think such a person will be confirmed if he has a decent balanced background.'' Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, appearing with Metzenbaum on NBC's ``Today'' show, said no one issue ``should be a determinant on a person's future on the Supreme Court,'' and predicted the Judiciary Committee, on which he and Metzenbaum both sit, would not ask direct questions on a nominee's position on abortion. Dole said abortion ``shouldn't be the single litmus test in picking a Supreme Court justice.'' The GOP leader acknowledged, however, that he has warned Bush that ``I assume the big `A' word would be the tough hurdle to climb.'' ``If you have to have someone who wants to overturn Roe vs. Wade, it's going to be a bloodbath getting the nomination confirmed, and the same is true on the other side,'' he said. Bush has said he hopes to have a new justice seated by October. Brennan, who was a leading voice of liberalism on the Supreme Court, resigned Friday. Conservatives have held a slim 5-4 majority on the court and liberals fear Brennan's successor could push the court further to the right. Possible candidates who have been mentioned include: Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr; federal appellate judges Edith H. Jones and Patrick E. Higginbotham of the 5th Circuit; William W. Wilkins Jr. of the 4th Circuit; and David Souter of the 1st Circuit. Other federal appellate judges mentioned are: Roger J. Miner and Ralph K. Winter Jr., both of the 2nd Circuit; J. Harvie Wilkinson III of the 4th Circuit; and Pamela A. Rymer, a former federal district judge whom Bush recently put on the 9th Circuit. There also has been speculation Bush might want to appoint the court's first Hispanic justice. Possible candidates would be Ferdinand Fernandez, a federal judge from California, and Ricardo Hinojosa, a federal judge from Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Small Planes Collide; All Three Aboard Killed
DOC.TEXT: Two small planes collided over western Wayne County today and crashed in a field, killing three people, authorities said. The planes collided about 9:40 a.m. over Plymouth Township in Detroit's western suburbs, Wayne County Sheriff Robert Ficano said. Chip Snider, township deputy police chief, said it wasn't known why the twin-engine Cherokee 140 and a single-engine plane collided. Police identified two victims as Charles Nix of Detroit and Robert Gunn of Livonia, both aboard the Cherokee. Nix was a licensed pilot undergoing further training from Gunn. Their plane had taken off from a private airstrip about five miles southeast of the crash site, authorities said. The third victim, piloting a single-engine plane that had taken off from Detroit City Airport, wasn't immediately identified. Witnesses said the planes caught fire and showered the ground with debris after colliding. No one was injured on the ground, Snider said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Honecker Barred From Chile After West German Objection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Chile denying report. Corrects West to Welt in 2nd graf. Pickup 4th pvs, `Honecker, 77...' Subs 8th pvs, `There have...' to CORRECT spelling of daughter's last name to Yanez sted Yaniz.
DOC.TEXT: Chile considered giving asylum to East Germany's ousted Communist leader, Erich Honecker, but decided against it after West Germany objected, a newspaper said. Chile denied the report. The West German government said allowing the ailing Honecker and his wife, Margot, to go to Chile would be an ``especially unfriendly occurrence,'' West Germany's respected Welt am Sonntag newspaper said Sunday. It did not give sources for its report. Chile's foreign minister, Enrique Silva, told the Santiago newspaper El Mercurio his government had not received a request for asylum from Honecker. ``I know absolutely nothing about that,'' he was quoted today as telling the Santiago newspaper El Mercurio. Honecker, 77, is in a Soviet military hospital in the Berlin suburb of Beelitz and is reportedly suffering from kidney cancer. East Germany, which he ruled with an iron fist for 18 years, has charged him with abuse of confidence and unfaithfulness to the state during his time in power. Authorities are also investigating Honecker's role in promulgating shoot-to-kill orders at the border between the two Germanys, and are looking into allegations he harbored terrorists. A medical committee will rule whether Honecker is fit to stand trial. Chile and West Germany have good political relations, but there is no extradition treaty between them. If West German decided to prosecute Honecker and he were in Chile, it could present a problem. There have been reports in the German media recently that Honecker was interested in moving to Chile, where his daughter, Sonya Yaniz, lives with her Chilean husband. According to Welt am Sonntag, Chile was ``at first prepared to grant Honecker and his wife asylum'' and that the ousted leader's daughter had submitted a request for him. But the newspaper said the West German Foreign Ministry informed the Chilean government that ``Bonn would have to see acceptance of Honecker as an especially unfriendly occurrence.'' The ministry said Honecker ``carries the political responsibility for years of criminal activities'' of the East German Communist government, the newspaper reported. Welt am Sonntag said Honecker's travel papers have been taken away from him. Honecker was driven from power in October during East Germany's peaceful pro-democracy revolution.

DOC.HEAD: EDITORS:
WIRE EDITORS:
ART EDITORS:
DOC.TEXT: In 1917, in the aftermath of the Russian Revolution, Lenin reassured the Moslems of Central Asia that the new regime in Moscow would allow them to ``organize your national life freely and without impediment.'' In 1990, in the age of Gorbachev, many in Central Asia are ready to call on Lenin's heir to finally honor that long-dishonored commitment. AP Special Correspondent Mort Rosenblum recently journeyed to the republics of Soviet Central Asia, and found a new mood of dissent and assertiveness, fed by a religious revival, economic resentment and ecological disasters blamed on the central government. Upcoming shortly are the first two parts of a four-part series by Rosenblum, ``Soviet New South,'' for use Sunday through Wednesday, July 22-25. The first installment, b0532-533, presents an overview of recent developments in Soviet Central Asia. It is accompanied by sidebar b0534, a thumbnail look at the five republics. Part II, b0463, examines the Islamic revival. Part III focuses on what local people call ``the catastrophe,'' the shrinking of the Aral Sea. Part IV looks at the ethnic tensions underlying much of the recent violence in the area. The second two parts will move Tuesday. The articles, which can be used separately or as a series, will be illustrated with pictures by AP photographer Greg English, who accompanied Rosenblum, and with Graphics by AP's Pat Lyons.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Forest Fires Blanket Alaska With Smoke
DOC.TEXT: Continued warm, dry weather and dense smoke today hampered crews battling some of the 121 fires reported across central Alaska. Ninety fire crews, or more than 2,600 people, were fighting the fires, which had charred more than 1 million acres of timber and tundra by today, officials said. Crews were focusing on just a few of the fires, said Trish Hogervorst-Rukke, a spokeswoman with the Alaska Fire Information Center in Fairbanks. ``They're concentrating on the fires threatening structures,'' she said today. Many fire-fighting crews had been released recently as scattered showers and cooler temperatures dampened many of the state's fires. But they are returning because of the dry weather and highs in the 80s, said John Quinley, a National Park Service spokesman. No one has been injured and few dwellings have been lost, officials said. Most of the fires have been caused by lightning. The 54,000-acre Tok River fire, started by lightning three weeks ago, remains the state's most labor-intensive fire, occupying nearly 800 firefighters. More crews are being assigned there than at other fires because the fire is relatively close to two towns, Tok and Tetlin Junction. The Beaver fire north of the Yukon River was Alaska's largest. The fire on Sunday had burned a section of spruce forest 10 miles wide by 48 miles long, Hogervorst-Rukke said. The fire had burned to within four miles of the Chandalar River, and authorities expect it to diminish once it hits the river, she said. The Kanuti Flats fire, about 140 miles north of Fairbanks, was burning 100,000 acres on Sunday and was within two miles of the trans-Alaska oil pipeline. Authorities were monitoring the fire but it was not being fought. The pipeline is buried beneath the tundra near where the fire is burning, officials said. Smoke was a widespread problem. Fires along the Alaska Highway had reduced visibility to less than 2 miles in a wide region from Tok to Fairbanks. ``The smoke is so dense that it's reducing temperatures and raising the relative humidity in some areas,'' Hogervorst-Rukke said. ``The sun simply can't penetrate it. ``The flip side is that we can't see the fires. We're using a specially-modified plane with an infrared camera to look through the smoke and locate the hotspots.'' Visibility at the Riley Creek Visitors Center at Denali National Park dropped to a quarter-mile at times.

DOC.HEAD: Education Department Working on Crisis at Student Loan Guarantor
DOC.TEXT: The Education Department said today it is holding daily meetings in an effort to resolve a financial crisis at one of the nation's largest guarantors of student loans. ``It's a matter of urgency,'' department spokeswoman Etta Fielek said today after a morning session on problems at the Higher Education Assistance Foundation. The non-profit corporation, based in Overland Park, Kan., guarantees nearly $10 billion in student loans. The foundation has notified the department ``that it is facing serious financial problems,'' Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said in a statement late last week. He said the department was considering various options that would ``ensure the availability of new loans and the continuation of guarantees and claim payments on outstanding loans.'' Fielek said HEAF has asked Congress and the department to approve a federally assisted takeover by another guarantor, the Nebraska Student Loan Program Inc. But she said the department was apprehensive about that proposal. ``There's a problem of scale,'' Fielek said. ``There's concern on the part of the department that Nebraska would be too small an operation to consume something the magnitude of HEAF.'' There are 55 guarantors responsible for repaying banks in the event of defaults on student loans. HEAF is a national guarantor operating in many states, while Nebraska operates in only one state. The student loan program will make a projected $13 billion in loans this year and has $51 billion in loans outstanding. According to a report today in The Wall Street Journal, HEAF expects a cash shortfall of $50 million to $100 million in the next 12 months. Part of HEAF's problem is that it has guaranteed billions in high-risk trade school loans with high default rates. Scott Hoober, a spokesman for the corporation, said such loans accounted for 59 percent of HEAF's portfolio in 1988 but only 35 percent in 1989, after HEAF had begun to restructure its portfolio.

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Aboard Atlas Intended for Look at Earth's Fields
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with forecast sill looking gloomy. Launch scheduled for 3:26 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: A government satellite due for a ride into space on an unmanned Atlas rocket is to spray the cosmos with chemicals for a look at the Earth's usually invisible magnetic and electric fields. A third attempt at launch was scheduled for 3:26 p.m. today, despite predictions for bad weather. At midday, officials said the chances that conditions would be good enough to launch were still less than 50-50. Launch Sunday was called off less than two hours before liftoff because of the threat of severe thunderstorms. The first attempt, on Friday, was postponed because of a helium leak. A liquid helium vent duct used for engine cooling apparently slipped off an engine outlet in the rocket's upper-stage thrust section. As a precaution, all four vent ducts were replaced with a new set Saturday, said Jack Isabel, spokesman for rocket builder General Dynamics. ``Any time you don't launch, you are disappointed,'' Isabel said Sunday. ``But when the weather is in sync, and we're in sync, I'm sure we'll get off and be successful.'' The Atlas 1 rocket, making its commercial debut, was to boost the Combined Release and Radiation Effects Satellite, or CRRES, into an elliptical orbit 217 miles by 22,236 miles high. The $189 million satellite is a joint program of NASA and the Defense Department. Twenty-four canisters filled with barium, lithium and other chemicals will be ejected from the satellite over the next year. The released chemicals will be ionized by the sun's ultraviolet rays, creating glowing clouds about 60 miles in diameter. The clouds will spread along Earth's magnetic field lines, allowing scientists to see the normally invisible charged particles of the ionosphere and magnetosphere. The 2-ton satellite was to have been deployed in 1987 from space shuttle Challenger, but the mission and all others were put on hold after the Challenger disaster in 1986. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Air Force opted for a quicker launch aboard General Dynamics' commercial Atlas. The satellite was redesigned to fit into the rocket's payload fairing. The launch will be the first of a commercial version of the Atlas and the eighth commercial rocket launch by an American company. General Dynamics provided the $65 million rocket and launch services under a barter agreement with NASA. In return, NASA gets the satellite launched. Earlier versions of the Atlas were used by NASA to boost planetary probes and other midsized payloads. It hasn't been a good year for NASA. Leaks have grounded the shuttles and John Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, said it will take more than a successful shuttle launch to get NASA back on track. ``The agency is supposed to be doing more than just getting shuttles launched,'' he said. ``That's important, but in a sense it's the minimum requirement.'' Logsdon expects it will take years for NASA to clear its name over the debacle created by the Hubble Space Telescope, a $1.5 billion project unable to fulfill its potential because of a flawed mirror that cannot be repaired until 1993 at the earliest. NASA's proposed space station Freedom has come under attack by Congress, too. A study released Friday shows up to 10 spacewalks a week will be needed to maintain outside components of the station unless major design changes are made. The Bush administration last week ordered an outside panel of experts to consider the long-term direction of America's space program.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Author Of `Kiss Of The Spider Woman' Dies In Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th pvs, `The novel...' to CORRECT that ``Kiss of the Spider Women'' set in unnamed South American country, not Argentina. Pickup 9th pvs, `Puig was...'
DOC.TEXT: Argentine novelist Manuel Puig, who abandoned filmmaking for a literature with cinematic style and gained fame for ``Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' has died of a heart attack at age 57. Puig, suffering complications from gall bladder surgery, died Sunday at a hospital. He had earned a reputation as a leading member of the younger generation of Latin American writers. Puig's works often explored the relationships between his characters' impoverished lives and their rich, if unfulfilled, fantasies. He turned away from a potential career as a filmmaker to devote himself to literature. But his style reflected the influence of screenplays _ with little descriptive prose. ``I mostly hear the action,'' Puig said in a 1985 New York Times interview. ``When I started writing, I found I trusted more the language of the characters than the first person.'' Puig wrote several novels, and some were later made into movies, including ``Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' ``Betrayed by Rita Hayworth,'' ``Eternal Curse on the Reader of These Pages'' and ``Heartbreak Tango.'' Brazilian filmmaker Hector Babenco's 1985 film version of ``Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' starring William Hurt and Raul Julia, brought the novelist a larger international audience. Hurt won an Academy Award for that performance. The novel ``Kiss of the Spider Woman'' was set in a bleak South American prison cell shared by a Marxist guerrilla and a homosexual. Their dialogue is interspersed with the homosexual Molina's recounting of plots of romantic movies. Puig was born on December 28, 1932, in the small town of General Villegas, on the arid pampas of Argentina. As a youth, he spent much of his free time in the local movie theater watching popular American and Argentine films. He studied philosophy at the University of Buenos Aires during the early 1950s and won a scholarship to study film in Italy in 1956. He went on to work on several films, but his futile attempts at writing screenplays led him into literature. One failed attempt at a screenplay in 1961 developed into the autobiographical novel, ``Betrayed by Rita Hayworth,'' about the influence American movies have on the people of a small Argentine town. It was completed in 1965 but published three years later, partly because of problems with censorship. Panned by Argentine critics, the book received more favorable reviews in France and the United States, and Puig began writing more novels. With the return of Juan Peron to power in Argentina in 1973, Puig felt increasingly alienated from his country. He went into self-imposed exile, eventually settling in Mexico. He moved to New York City in 1976, partly because of a heart condition, then settled later in Rio de Janiero, Brazil. He is survived by his mother, Maria Elena de Puig, a brother Carlos Puig and sons Javier Labrada and Agustin Garcia Gil, all of whom live in Cuernavaca. Puig had lived in Cuernavaca, 50 miles south of Mexico City, since October. His funeral was held there Sunday night. He will be buried in a family plot in La Plata, Argentina, Labrada said.

DOC.HEAD: President Asks for Inquiry into Report that CIA Aided Terrorism
DOC.TEXT: President Francesco Cossiga wants an investigation into a report on government television that the CIA supported terrorism activity in Italy and played a part in the slaying of Swedish Prime Minister Olaf Palme. The CIA today denied the report and called it ``nonsense.'' The allegations were made during a series of television interviews with two men who claimed to have worked for the CIA. One was identified as Dick Brenneke. The other wore a hood during the interviews on state-run RAI television, saying he wanted to protect his identity. The television report alleged the CIA paid Licio Gelli, grandmaster of the secret Propaganda Due (P-2) Masonic lodge, to foment terrorist activities in Italy. The P-2 has been accused of seeking to install a right-wing dictatorship in Italy during the 1970s with the help of secret service officials. At that time right-wing and left-wing terrorist groups were active in Italy. Gelli denied the TV report and said he would sue RAI for libel. Charges were also made in the RAI report that the CIA and P-2 were involved in the Palme murder in 1986. The killing remains unsolved. In a statement issued today in Washington, the CIA said: ``The agency flatly denies that Mr. Brenneke was ever an agent of the CIA or associated in any way with the CIA. We repeat this public denial because of the outrageous nature of his claims. Allegations attributed to him regarding agency involvement in terrorist activities in Italy or the Palme assassination are absolute nonsense.'' In a letter to Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, Cossiga said ``the information broadcast in these transmissions requires, in my opinion, a serious evaluation on the part of the Italian government.'' Cossiga's letter was dated July 3, shortly after the interviews were broadcast. The president's office released the letter Sunday after the newsweekly Panorama reported its existence. Cossiga said if the government felt the charges were well-founded, the case should be turned over to the courts and a parliamentary commission on terrorism. If the information was false or reckless, he said, RAI should be taken to court.

DOC.HEAD: Fake Doctor's Popularity Lands Him in Jail
DOC.TEXT: A doctor who prescribed tea, honey and long sick leaves ended up in jail after a patient researching a biography of the popular physician discovered he was a fake. According to a report Monday in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, Fyodor Kuznetsov, a 30-year-old cloakroom attendant, tired of his job and decided to become a doctor. Kuznetsov, who previously lost jobs as a piano tuner and salesman because of a drinking problem, obtained false documents and was able to pass himself off as a general practitioner and got a job at a Leningrad polyclinic, the newspaper said. ``He did not prescribe any pills,'' Pravda said of his four-month stint at the unidentified hospital. ``Instead, he recommended tea and honey, and was very generous with sick leaves.'' Kuznetsov's patients liked him so much, they requested his picture be hung at the Health Ministry and wrote to Pravda praising his work, the newspaper said. ``Someone even decided to write his biography and that's how he was found out _ and put into jail,'' Pravda said. The newspaper did not say if any of his patients was harmed by his tea-and-honey treatment.

DOC.HEAD: High-Speed Train Derailed by Vandals
DOC.TEXT: A rail placed across train tracks by vandals derailed a high-speed locomotive with 368 passengers aboard, but no one was injured, railway officials said Monday. The bullet-nosed TGV _ ``train a grand vitesse'' or high-speed train _ was traveling at a relatively slow 78 mph when it struck the 551-pound rail Sunday evening. The impact caused the train's front wheels to jump off the tracks, but the rest of the engine and the dozen cars it was pulling remained on the rails. Officials from the national railway, Societe National des Chemins de Fer, said the rail used to block the track came from a nearby repair site. Police said the incident was unconnected to a series of protests by regional residents opposed to a plans to expand the high-speed rail network into the Provence wine country. ``This was the work of idle juveniles, not train sabotage,'' a railway spokesman said. The accident near the village of Cuers blocked traffic on the Toulon-Nice line from Sunday evening until dawn Monday. A crane lifted the locomotive onto the track and another engine towed it to a rail yard for inspection. The TGV trains normally travel at 187 mph on special track between Paris and Lyon or Le Mans, but elsewhere they ride on regular tracks at slower speed.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Quayle Recovering From Cervical Cancer Surgery
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with 9 grafs to name hospital, provide update; picks up 8th graf pvs, `The Quayles.
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle underwent surgery over the weekend for cervical cancer detected in a Pap smear, according to sources close to the family. The vice president's office said today she is doing well. The operation was performed at Bethesda Naval Hospital, Vice President Dan Quayle's office revealed today. Quayle has visited his wife there every day since the operation on Saturday, said spokesman David Beckwith. ``She's doing well. We expect her home sometime this week,'' said Beckwith. Mrs. Quayle, 40, has been active in a breast cancer awareness campaign. She testified before a congressional health subcommittee in May and both she and the vice president ran in a celebrity 5-kilometer ``Race for the Cure'' to encourage women to undergo early screening and mammograms. Despite her high-profile involvement in that campaign, the Quayles appeared reluctant to disclose full details of her condition. The announcement did not reveal what the actual diagnosis was or where the operation took place. Beckwith said today he ``had no further word'' on the disease or the operation. But the sources said Sunday the operation was for cervical cancer that had been detected earlier this year. It was not an emergency procedure, according to the sources, who spoke only on condition they not be named. President Bush called Mrs. Quayle over the weekend ``to wish her a speedy recovery,'' spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. The original announcement said Mrs. Quayle, who turns 41 on Sunday, was ``recovering well'' from the operation and will ``resume her full schedule in four to six weeks. Full and total recovery is expected.'' The Quayles also urged all women to have yearly Pap tests. A Pap test can help detect two dozen or more medical problems, but its primary purpose is to uncover malignancies in the reproductive tract, said Dr. Allan B. Weingold, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the George Washington University Medical Center. Weingold is not involved in treating Mrs. Quayle. Other doctors speculated that she had undergone a simple hysterectomy, or removal of the uterus, given the White House announcement on the length of her convalescence and the expectation of ``full and total recovery.'' The Pap test is named for Dr. George Papanicolau, who introduced the procedure nearly half a century ago. It is credited with reducing deaths from cervical and uterine cancer in the United States by 70 percent. Mrs. Quayle, a lawyer and mother of three, became active in breast cancer education last year. Her mother, Mary Tucker, an Indiana pediatrician, died of breast cancer in 1975 at age 56. Mrs. Quayle has said her mother might have been spared had the disease been detected earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Ghost Hunters Say Spirits Thrive at North Texas Restaurant
DOC.TEXT: Maybe the dessert special at the Catfish Plantation should be Poltergeist Pie. Restaurant owners Tom and Melissa Baker say the 95-year-old house where the restaurant is located is home to three ghosts. Employees and customers alike have reported ``otherworldly happenings'' in the six years since the restaurant opened. So Saturday night, the Bakers and Dallas ghost hunter T. Everett Bookings III gave a dinner-divination. Participants say the spooks didn't disappoint. ``The lady I was sitting next to, she said she felt sort of a mist on her left shoulder,'' said Becky Morgan, who attended the dinner with husband James, publisher of the Waxahachie Daily Light. Mrs. Morgan said she and her husband smelled roses, which Bookings says is a sign that ghosts are present. And from their seats near the kitchen, they heard the kitchen clock fall off the wall at about midnight. ``It startled us,'' she said. ``All the kitchen workers had already left. And the clock was sitting on a nail.'' Bookings, who uses an alias in his ghostly profession, said he wanted to encourage the spirits to communicate with participants, so he had the guests sign some of his business cards and put them in a box. He said one was returned with the message: ``Now do you believe? Elizabeth.'' That's the name given to one of the three suspected apparitions, a young woman dressed in a white lace wedding dress who appears in a restaurant window at night. She's believed to have died in the 1920s. Then there's farmer Will, who was in his 60s when he died during the Depression. And Caroline, an older woman who passed away in the 1960s. Will is known to move around creating cold spots; Caroline throws things and slams doors. The Bakers say Saturday night's tricks fell in line with the phantasms' usual pursuits. Other reported happenings have included tips levitating off tables and menus flying across the room. ``Some things happened. To me, you can explain them away,'' Baker said. ``And the group consensus of the people that were here, probably a third of them would say `Hokey,' and probably two-thirds of them would say, ``Hey, there's something here.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Storm Apartment, Recover Weapons from Finn
DOC.TEXT: Anti-terrorist police shot tear gas and then stormed an apartment to arrest a Finn who stole machine guns and other weapons from a private collection, news reports said Monday. Newspapers said police surrounded the building where the 38-year-old Finn lived, but the suspect, who has not been named, refused to surrender. After 90 minutes, police fired tear gas through his apartment windows, broke down his door and arrested him without firing any shots. The man was released Sunday after he reportedly confessing to the theft. Police said after the raid they recovered 57 of the 117 weapons stolen from a private Norwegian collection on June 26. Police said some of the weapons were found in the man's apartment while additional weapons were hidden at a barn where the suspect took police. The cache included seven machine guns, pistols, ammunition and other weapons. They were apparently stolen for profit.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 836 People in Weekend Drug Bust
DOC.TEXT: Police said Monday they arrested 836 people and seized LSD, marijuana and amphetamines at a raid on a party. Three police were slightly injured and needed hospital treatment after the Sunday raid. The 836 were released Monday, but charges may be filed in some cases, West Yorkshire police said. Assistant Chief Constable Denis O'Toole said after police stormed the unused warehouse in northern England where the party was held, partygoers and drug dealers began pelting the officers with rocks, bricks, broken glass and smashed furniture. Youths who had tickets to the party _ which cost about $10 _ told reporters the police using dogs and charged into the building without warning, swinging truncheons. The party was held in Gildersome near Leeds, 185 miles north of London. Police said they found drugs with a street value of more than $3,600 at the scene. The 836 people were arrested early Sunday for drug possession, breach of the peace and criminal damage. The raid came just over one week after the introduction of legislation mandating stricter sentences for the organizers of illegal events. Fines can now run up to $36,200 or six months' imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Sylvester Stallone says he will flex his brain more than his biceps in films. Stallone, 44, who rose to prominence with the original ``Rocky'' film about an underdog fighter, said in this week's People magazine that audiences cannot identify with the kind of superhero he portrayed in ``Rambo III.'' ``I recently saw `Rambo III' again and recoiled at a scene where, strong and invulnerable, I stood up there. I mean, I was so invincible, I had veins in my hair. There I was, superhuman, with my gun obliterating everyone crossing my path,'' Stallone said. He said filmmakers need to place more emphasis on developing characters. ``Right now, we don't care about dialogue. We know it's just a boring interlude before the action starts.''

Isaac Stern, who has played more than 100 concerts here since his debut more than half a century ago, finally put down his violin to relax while others made music. The occasion: his 70th birthday. The San Francisco Symphony celebrated the event with a concert Sunday before a crowd of 30,000, including cellist Mstislav Rostropovich who donned wig, tiara and tutu to perform ``The Swan'' from Saint-Saen's Carnival of the Animals. A delighted Stern, whose birthday was Saturday, said the celebration was ``the most gallant gesture that I will receive this year, to be able to sit and enjoy.'' Born in Russia, Stern was brought to San Francisco before he was a year old. He made his debut with the San Francisco orchestra at age 15. At Sunday's concert, Gregory Peck delivered a tribute to Stern. ``The name Isaac Stern means magic in the world of music, an irresistible one-man cultural force,'' Peck said.

Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, hopes to write an autobiography entitled ``In The Darkness'' to reflect what she thinks about as she falls asleep. The book will be ``about my life, my family, all the pet animals I've had,'' said the 13-year-old girl, a fan of scary films and gothic novels. Stormie received the double transplant in 1984. Hepatitis damaged that liver and in February, the girl from White Settlement, Texas, received her second liver. She and her mother, Lois Purcell, are staying at a hostel near Children's Hospital, where Stormie is being treated for hepatitis that has damaged her second transplanted liver. Stormie said she likes frightening books, movies and television programs. Her favorite show is the USA Network horror series ``Tales From The Crypt,'' and her favorite movie is ``Pet Sematary,'' which is based on a Stephen King book. ``She loves to be scared because she knows it's all make believe,'' Ms. Purcell said. ``Besides, it's what all the kids her age like. She'd be totally left out otherwise.''

Rosie Jones says she hopes to be a role model for youth as the new Miss Black America. Ms. Jones, 26, who is from St. Louis and works in Bridgeport, Conn., was selected early Monday from a field of 39 contestants representing major metropolitan areas across the nation. Ms. Jones, a computer programmer, said leadership is the most important quality a Miss Black America can have. ``I want to talk to a lot of young people,'' she said. Jacklynne Ann Fletcher of Dayton, Ohio, was second; Elaine Joyner of Columbia, S.C., was third; and Cynthia Richardson of Cincinnati was fourth. Ms. Jones will receive a $2,000 minimum cash prize, a trip to Hawaii, a wardrobe and a crown.

Guitarist Nancy Wilson of the band Heart said male groupies are more romantic that female groupies. ``In fact, the males are more like fans. I wouldn't even call them groupies because they deserve better,'' said Wilson, 36, in this week's People magazine. She said male fans will send poems and flowers. ``Guys get very shy. They're not as obvious about it,'' said Wilson, who leads Heart along with her sister, singer Ann Wilson. The band's latest album is ``Brigade.''

DOC.HEAD: Latvian Leader Wants Relations With Separate Soviet Republics
DOC.TEXT: Treaty negotiations between the Soviet Union's Baltic republics could provide them with the basis for an economic or political association outside the Soviet government, the prime minister of Latvia said Monday. Ivars Godmanis said however, that Latvia, one of the Baltic states considering independence from Moscow, should have separate relationships with Russia, the Ukraine and the other 15 Soviet republics before such a union is formed. ``We have concluded that direct bilateral treaties and decisions between different states _ I have said states, independent states _ will be the fundament,'' Godmanis said in a speech at the National Press Club. He called his goal ``Finlandization,'' which he defined as good neighborly relations with the Soviets such as nearby Finland has had. In the United States ``Finlandization'' has been used to mean subordination to the Soviet Union. Godmanis noted that the Baltic states, in which multi-party systems already exist, did not joined in the formation of the Soviet Union in a 1922 treaty, but were occupied by the Soviets in 1940 at the start of World War II. Latvian foreign minister Janis Jurkans, who is traveling with Godmanis, said that although the United States has continued to recognize Baltic diplomatic representation in Washington since the 1940 occupation, the U.S. does not recognize his government. Its recognition by the Soviet Union must come first, he said in an interview. Godmanis said his government expects to become a member of the United Nations, as it was a member of the League of Nations before 1940, and to have its own diplomats.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Drowned in Boat Capsize, l3 Others Killed in Floods
DOC.TEXT: An overcrowded boat sank in a flooded river in southeastern Bangladesh, killing 11 passengers, police said Monday. In the northwest, four children drowned Sunday in the Jamuna river, raising to 13 the death toll from monsoon flooding in that region, officials and news reports said. About 100,000 people have been left homeless and 400,000 stranded. On Sunday, a boat capsized with 70 people on board in Matamuhuri river at Bandarban, 155 miles southeast of Dhaka, police said, adding it had been carrying 17 more people than its sanctioned capacity. Fifty-nine people swam ashore and eight bodies have been found, said a police official who was contacted in Bandarban by telephone. Three other bodies were believed to have washed downstream. Ittefaq, a Bengali-language newspaper, said the rain-swollen Jamuna river in the northwest has inundated an 830 square-mile area in Sirajganj and surrounding districts. Many people were reluctant to leave their flooded homes, fearing theft of their household goods, said Ittefaq, Bangladesh's largest circulated daily. Marauders in motor boats were stealing cows and tin roofs from abandoned homes. Most houses in the areas, however, have mud-coated bamboo walls and thatch roofs that washed away with the first wave of flood waters.

DOC.HEAD: Civil War Veteran's Remains to Be Buried in Massachusetts
DOC.TEXT: More than a century after he fell in battle, and nearly 20 years after his bones were unearthed by a South Carolina road crew, an anonymous Civil War soldier is headed for a hero's burial in Massachusetts. ``We're going to feel very good when we finally put him to rest in his native soil. He's had a strange journey,'' said Robert Berkeley, a member of the volunteer 12th Massachusetts Regiment and the 2nd Rhode Island Infantry, which re-enact Civil War battles. Burial is scheduled for Aug. 4 at the Massachusetts National Cemetery at Bourne. The soldier's origins haven't become clear since his remains were found in the early 1970s. ``I'd love to know more details, but I'm afraid they've been lost in time,'' said Larry Fudger, administrative director of Family Court in Sumter County, S.C., and a Civil War buff. ``We're just at a point now where this individual, whoever he is, whatever he died of, is a federal soldier that fought for his country and he needs a decent burial,'' said Fudger, who takes part in re-enactments of Civil War battles in his spare time. The idea of bringing the body back to Massachusetts started in spring 1989 when Berkeley and Fudger met at a battle re-enactment. The modern history of the unknown soldier goes back about 20 years, when the remains were unearthed by a road crew working in Clarendon County, S.C., Fudger said. The county sheriff sent the remains to a laboratory and reports indicated the bones were those of a man between ages 19 and 21 who had died many years before, Fudger said. Fragments of cloth and buttons indicated the man was probably a Union soldier, Fudger said. It was theorized that he died during an assault on a Confederate supply troop in the area at the close of the war in 1865. ``The road they found him on is the road the Union soldiers came down,'' Fudger said. Once it was determined that the sheriff did not have a murder investigation on his hands, the remains ``just got lost in the shuffle,'' and have been stored at a South Carolina funeral parlor, Fudger said. Because many of the soldiers in the area were from Massachusetts, local historians think the soldier most likely came from that state, Fudger said. Further speculation is that he may have been black, because the 54th Massachusetts, the regiment commemorated in the movie ``Glory,'' was in the area along with other black regiments. The old forensic tests didn't determine whether the victim was black or white and no tests have been conducted since on the remains, Fudger said. Fudger said he and his fellow volunteers are glad to see the episode draw to a close. ``We're just trying to do the right thing by him,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Argues Barry Was at Meeting at Time of Alleged Drug Deal
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry was in a meeting and could not have received drugs at the time the government alleges he was getting crack cocaine, Barry's attorney argued today. Two defense witnesses also testified that Barry was with them at the meeting, but under cross examination acknowledged that the Sept. 7, 1988, meeting was delayed until after the mayor's tardy arrival. Barry's chief lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, attacked one of the misdemeanor cocaine possession charges Barry faces by arguing that a videotape proved Barry arrived for the meeting just moments after 10 a.m. that day. A government witness, Lydia Reid Pearson, has testified that she gave crack cocaine _ and a city job application _ to the mayor shortly after 10 a.m. that day. But Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin has argued that the mayor's tardiness allowed him to pick up the drugs from Pearson at the time Pearson said she delivered them to him. The two defense witnesses, former top city official Joseph Yeldell and District of Columbia Fire Chief Ray Alfred, agreed with Retchin's suggestion that the meeting began sometime after 10:30 a.m. ``I know we did have a slight delay before the meeting,'' Yeldell said. The prosecutor said the videotape made of the gathering confirms that it began late. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. Pearson's testimony is the most specific, with regard to date and time, of any of the possession charges lodged against the mayor. Retchin argued last week that Barry's car telephone records indicate that the mayor did not arrive for the meeting until approximately 10:45 a.m., or minutes after the last call was logged. His late arrival would have given Pearson time to slip him the drugs as he came to the meeting, Retchin said. ``All that proves, perhaps, is that someone else was using the car phone,'' Mundy shot back. Mundy, who expects to complete his case this week, says he may call key prosecution witness Charles Lewis to ask him about his ties to the family of a notorious District of Columbia drug dealer. Lewis, a twice-convicted cocaine dealer, has portrayed himself as a small-time drug peddler whose distribution network was designed primarily to keep himself and his friends supplied with narcotics. But Mundy, relying on notes from a police interrogation of Lewis, said Friday that Lewis once introduced a drug cohort to a man identified as Rayful Edmond. The notes do not make clear whether Lewis met with Rayful Edmond Jr. or Rayful Edmond III, but the distinction is important. Rayful Edmond III is serving two consecutive life terms in prison after being convicted last December of running an elaborate Washington cocaine supply network. Prosecutors estimated that the younger Edmond's drug ring was responsible for up to 30 percent of the cocaine supply in the nation's capital. Witnesses in that trial said the elder Edmond also was involved with drugs, but he has never been charged with a crime. Mundy said Lewis' ties to Edmond show that Lewis was untruthful about his own drug activity and can be used to cast doubt on other aspects of his testimony, particularly his assertions that he provided Barry with cocaine on numerous occasions. Retchin insisted in court Friday that Lewis did not know Rayful Edmond III. Likewise, Rayful Edmond III's attorney said his client does not know Lewis.

DOC.HEAD: Bush and Congressional Leaders to Meet Daily on Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 7, Bush and, to CORRECT eastern to western
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and the leaders of Congress will meet daily this week for ``hard bargaining'' to produce an agreement to cut the federal deficit, the White House said today. Bush will confer with the House and Senate leaders on Tesday before departing for political speeches in Philadelphia and New York, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``The tentative plan is for them to meet each day this week early in the morning,'' he said. ``This is a period of very intense negotiations. The president wants to give it a major push,'' he said. ``So they felt the leadership should get together and do some hard bargaining to see if we can't get it resolved.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told reporters, ``We are going to get reports back and forth, exchange ideas and approaches. We do not intend to make agreements outside the summit group.'' Foley said the meetings would be ``continuous'' but not necessarily daily. Bush and the leaders last met on Wednesday before the president embarked on a three-day Western trip, during which he blamed the Democrats for ``government by gridlock'' in Washington. Fitzwater said Bush is aiming for a budget agreement before Congress takes its summer break. ``We would hope to have an agreement between the president and the legislative branch by the time of the August recess,'' Fitzwater said. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said earlier today he hopes for an accord by Aug. 3 or Aug. 10. ``We would share his view of the timetable,'' said Fitzwater. The Office of Management and Budget, in its mid-session budget review last Monday, estimated that the fiscal 1991 deficit has ballooned to $169 billion, not counting $62 billion in costs of the savings and loan clean-up. ``There's still a great deal to be done on all the issues,'' Fitzwater said. ``They have reached the point where they're dealing with very specific options and they are trying to make judgments about them.'' He gave no specifics. Bush said in Boise, Idaho, last Thursday that ``I've done my part'' by agreeing to consider raising tax revenues, and ``now it's their turn'' _ meaning he wants the Democratic leaders to put a package of spending cuts on the table. Bush will meet Tuesday with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Dole.

DOC.HEAD: Navy to Scan Ocean For Jet's Cargo Door
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with search under way. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Flight 811...'. SUBS 11-13th grafs, `The cost...', with 3 grafs to delete now-redundant first reference to Anderson, update with ship at site. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `The towfish...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: The Navy began its needle-in-a-haystack search of the ocean floor today for a cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jumbo jet and caused nine people to be swept to their death over the Pacific 17 months ago. Investigators hope the door will help them establish beyond doubt the cause of the accident. During the weeklong search, a deep-sea probe equipped with sonar and a video camera will be dragged across a 24-square-mile area about 100 miles southwest of Honolulu. If the door is spotted, another device will be used at a later date to recover it. After their ship arrived at the scene overnight, workers this morning began setting up a transponder field, an electronic grid used to mark locations during the sophisticated undersea probe, said Lt. Cmdr. Bob Anderson, a spokesman for the Pacific Fleet. Flight 811 was bound for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989, with 355 people aboard when the door tore popped off at 22,000 feet, carrying away a section of fuselage and causing sudden decompression of the Boeing 747. Nine people were sucked out; five others were seriously hurt. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu. The National Transportation Safety Board concluded that a deficiency in the design of the door's locking mechanism probably indicated to the pilot that the door was locked when it was not. The agency blamed United, the Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failure to correct problems with the door. NTSB investigators said the door still could provide evidence for improving aircraft safety. The agency asked the Navy to find it. The door is believed to be 15,000 feet down. ``It's like a needle in a haystack, but a big factor is what the bottom looks like,'' said project manager Bob Whaley. Whaley said the ocean floor in the search area is generally flat, which is good for searching. The cost of the project will not be known until it is completed, Anderson said. A search for the door was to have begun last October but was delayed by technical problems during testing of the Orion deep submergence search system, he said. The 226-foot Navy ocean tug Narragansett left Pearl Harbor on Sunday and arrived on the scene about midnight. The underwater portion of the search system, known as a towfish, is attached to the tug by a 35,000-foot, triple-armored cable. The towfish is operated from on board the vessel. A computer enhances its sonar findings for later analysis, Anderson said. The Orion system has been used once before, to retrieve an airplane that crashed off the East Coast earlier this year, Anderson said. The search will be carried out by the Navy's prime contractor for underwater search operations, the Naval Sea Systems Command and Steadfast Search Division of Oceaneering International Inc., Anderson said. Oceaneering International helped find wreckage from an Air-India jumbo jet that was ripped apart by a bomb over the Atlantic in 1985, and parts of a South African jumbo jet that burst into flames and crashed off East Africa in 1987. It made an unsuccessful attempt to recover vital parts from the Korean Air Lines 747 shot down by the Soviet Union in 1983, and helped in the search for the space shuttle Challenger in 1986, Anderson said.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers to Study Why Type A Polio Survivors May Suffer More Problems
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have started a year-long study to find out why polio survivors with Type A personalities may suffer more severe post-polio problems than less-stressed victims of the disease. The study will try to determine if there is a physical reason why the high-achieving, hard-driving Type A's become more disabled, said Richard Bruno, a psychophysiologist at the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation in East Orange. Bruno theorizes that all polio victims suffered brain damage when the virus struck some 35 years ago. That damage is now beginning to show up. The condition is known as post-polio sequelae. ``It's like running electricity in the house with only one fuse,'' said Bruno, chairman of the national Post-Polio Task Force. ``It worked for awhile, but they finally blew a fuse.'' Compounding the problem, Bruno said, is that stress adds to the damage that has already been done. In an earlier study, by Bruno and Nancy Frick of Harvest Center in Hackensack, 676 polio survivors scored 18 points higher than the norm for Type A personality characteristics. Bruno wasn't surprised. ``They have to achieve more just to be the same. They have to be time conscious. It takes them twice as long to get dressed,'' he said. The pressure to strive and excel started in rehabilitation therapy virtually as soon as they began to recover, he said. The earlier study also found that 88 to 91 percent of all polio survivors said they suffered some symptoms of extreme fatigue, weakness and muscle pain, all occurring decades after the original polio virus attack. The survivors who scored highest on the Type A test suffered the most severe symptoms, Bruno said. ``These people are overwhelmed,'' he said. ``They can't focus, they can't remember. Sleeping doesn't help.'' Bruno said the medical community should have known that many of the 1.6 million polio survivors would be struck by these symptoms later in life. He cited the 1949 work of Dr. David Bodian of Johns Hopkins University who ``showed that the virus killed brain cells in the cortex that controlled motor functions. ... It wipes out nerves that go to blood vessels.'' Bruno wants to test his theory that nerve cells damaged by polio are further impaired when survivors under stress release a large amount of cortisol hormone which keeps nerve cells from using glucose. He believes this increased damage causes the extreme fatigue, and may account for some of the other symptoms. Dr. Anthony Windebank, neurologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., said the cortisol hormone theory ``was certainly a reasonable hypothesis. At the cellular level it makes sense.'' However, Windebank questioned whether personality type had anything to do with the severity of the post-polio symptoms. Mayo researchers studied a random group of 50 from the 250 people still alive who were stricken with polio between 1935 and 1955 in Olmsted County, Minn., where the clinic is located. About 20 percent of the 50 had ``quite significant problems _ the muscle pain, fatigue and increased weakness,'' he said. But there was no tie-in to personality traits, he said. ``When we looked at the psychological factors, there was no difference at all with people who were having problems and the people who weren't,'' Windebank said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Blast Way Into Downtown Monrovia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with reports that rebels advancing on downtown Monrovia, members of dissident group. Pickup 2nd pvs, `Sources in ...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is based in part on a pool dispatch filed by journalists in Monrovia. Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith was among them.

Rebels blasted their way into the capital's center today, and government troops fought back from atop high buildings. Rocket and heavy machine gun fire shook downtown. Diplomatic sources in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, said the rebels were loyal to a splinter group headed by Prince Johnson. Reports from the main rebel group said Charles Taylor's fighters remained blocked by government troops on the eastern outskirts of Monrovia. The sources said Taylor's forces remain blocked by government troops on the eastern outskirts of Monrovia. The rebels who have fought their way into the city are loyal to Johnson, the sources said today. Johnson split with Taylor several weeks ago and the rebel leader accused him of murdering several soldiers of Taylor's National Patriotic Front. The dissidents subsequently attacked Taylor's forces, forcing them to regroup and delay their assault on the capital. Today's attack came from the northwest from Bushrod Island, across two bridges and through a swamp. The diplomats, in contact with Monrovia, said the insurgents involved in the attack were Johnson's fighters. Defending government troops fired rockets from high buildings at the rebels. There was heavy machinegun fire and rifle fire aroiund the telecommunications headquarters in the heart of the Liberian capital's business district. President Samuel Doe has said he will remain in the capital until the civil war is decided, and sources say even if he tried to go sooner, loyal soldiers would not let him leave without guaranteeing their safety. The 500-member presidential guard, made up of soldiers from Doe's Krahn tribe, fears massacre at the hands of rebels who have fought their way to within a mile of Doe's oceanfront mansion. Sources in Liberia said some government soldiers were urging the president to flee to avoid a bloodbath and that there was bitter infighting in the executive mansion. Doe has been deserted by nearly all senior members of his government. Doe, in a telex to the British Broadcasting Corp., said Sunday that he would remain until ``a clear victor emerges.'' The presidential mansion was stockpiled with ammunition and explosives, said a diplomatic source, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
