The president remained ``convinced he is invincible,'' the source said, adding that he expected Doe to fight to the finish. The source said Doe was ``relying increasingly on his belief that black magic will save him.'' Rebel troops have overrun all of the Bushrod Island district containing the city's port, fuel and storage depots and repair shops. Doe's eight-story mansion was like a desolate military camp, with soldiers roaming the otherwise empty hallways. The president was closeted in his fifth-floor apartment, away from outsiders. Sources inside the mansion said Doe's Krahn bodyguards had gathered Saturday with the president and told him they would refuse to allow him to leave unless their collective safety was guaranteed. There were also reports of deep divisions within the Krahn tribe, the sources said. The Krahns fear the rebels will kill them in revenge for the killings of many civilians who support the rebels. Some retribution killings already have been reported by journalists with the rebels. In exchange for allowing Doe to leave, the Krahn soldiers seek safe passage to their home territory in Grand Gedeh County. Grand Gedeh is Doe's last remaining stronghold, apart from his few remaining square miles in downtown Monrovia. But the rebel National Patriotic Front would fiercely resist any effort by Doe to evacuate his forces to his home region. With the Gio and Mano tribes _ among the country's largest _ on Taylor's side, the civil war has turned into an outright tribal conflict. The rebels began their offensive in December and effectively control two-thirds of the country. They have accused Doe, who took power in a 1980 coup, of corruption, mismanagement and human rights abuses. Taylor has promised to maintain close ties with the United States if he comes to power, but he has ruled out immediate elections. The African nation, founded by freed American slaves 150 years ago, has traditionally had close ties with Washington. The U.S. Embassy has been trying to persuade Doe to flee the capital. Washington refused to send in a peacekeeping force, and on Saturday Doe ordered the American military attache expelled, accusing him of helping the rebels. The United States denied the accusations.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Rules Out U.S.-Soviet Pilot Exchanges
DOC.TEXT: The Cold War may be over but the Pentagon says goodwill can go too far. After learning that a Soviet pilot had been at the controls of a U.S. Navy F@A-18 fighter plane during an impromptu test ride at a July 8 air show at Kalamazoo, Mich., the Defense Department sent word to all the services: Don't let it happen again. Lt. Dave Wray, a Navy spokesman, said the department ruled that Soviet pilots would not be allowed to fly in any U.S. aircraft, and that no American pilots would fly Soviet planes. Wray said no reason for the prohibition was given. The Defense Department declined to comment, referring questions to the Navy. ``I don't think anyone had any concern that a ride in the back seat of an F@A-18 affords even a trained observer a technology leak,'' Wray said, noting that the Blue Angels plane is used only for show flying and for Navy training purposes. Wray said the Soviet pilot was invited to a half-hour ride in the rear seat of the plane, taking the flight controls for part of the trip. To reciprocate, the Soviets took Capt. Pat Moneymaker, the Blue Angels' commanding officer, for a test ride in a Soviet MiG-29.

DOC.HEAD: Summertime Beijing, Usually Sleepy, Buzzes With Political Rumors
DOC.TEXT: Signs of division in China's secretive top leadership have Beijing residents buzzing at a time when hot days and muggy nights usually breed apathy even among the capital's avid politics-watchers. Will Li Ruihuan, the up-and-coming propaganda czar from Tianjin, prevail with his recent appeals for a kinder, gentler Marxism? Has 83-year-old President Yang Shangkun's hospitalization for appendictis thrown him out of the running as a successor to senior leader Deng Xiaoping? What about the latest report, attributed to a Chinese mayoral delegation in the United States, that ousted Communist Party General Secretary Zhao Ziyang is about to make a comeback? And why can't ideological hard-liner He Jingzhi win confirmation as culture minister nearly one year after he was made acting minister? Among the laobaixing _ the ``old hundred names,'' China's nickname for ordinary folk _ self-appointed experts admit their bafflement. ``No one knows what's going on,'' said a college student who passionately follows politics. Western diplomats also appeared baffled. ``There are many reasons for floating a rumor,'' said one, before launching into a half-hour analysis that ended with a shrug. But all agree the summer political scene has suddenly become much more interesting than the long winter of monolithic hard-line editorializing that followed the crushing of last year's pro-democracy protests. The shift is not immediately obvious. Portly, often avuncular Jiang Zemin, who replaced Zhao as party chief, frequently appears on national television leading soldiers and workers in singing the revolutionary classic, ``Unity is Strength.'' The official media are filled with production reports and commentaries on strengthening Marxist education, opposing bourgeois ideas and building party discipline. Most ordinary people hold closely to this line, in public, at least. A Chinese journalist who has had to write articles supporting the line, even though he backed the democracy movement, said bitterly: ``It is like being raped.'' It was the government's agreement in June to let dissident Fang Lizhi go to England, after a year of hiding in the U.S. Embassy, that crystallized the sense of a softening in the leadership's hard front. ``You'll be busy in the coming weeks, because there will be a lot happening,'' advised a middle-aged intellectual with ties to the reformist camp. Western analysts linked Fang's departure to pragmatic Chinese needs, such as retaining most-favored nation trade status with the United States. But the intellectual said, ``A few months ago they wouldn't have done it. It does show new flexibility.'' The continued release of protesters jailed since last year added to the optimism. A total of 881 have been freed, and sources have said another group will be released soon. Shanghai Mayor Zhu Rongji said in Hong Kong recently that fewer than 10 participants in last year's democracy movement remain in jail without charges in his city. He said he expects they will be released soon. Authorities say 355 people are still in jail ``undergoing investigation'' in Beijing. There are no nationwide figures. Authorities also have announced recently they will go ahead with plans, stalled immediately after the hard-line crackdown, for developing a national securities market and transferring housing to private ownership. Great public interest has centered on a series of speeches by Li Ruihuan, the former mayor of the east coast city of Tianjin who joined the party's top leadership body, the six-member Politburo Standing Committee, after the ouster of Zhao. The 54-year-old Li, a former carpenter who speaks in a distinctive, somewhat shrill voice, was put in charge of supervising the media and cultural circles. He has used the role to make provocative comments on the nature of socialist society. ``Making human relations tense is not the original intention of Marxism,'' the semi-official Hong Kong China News Service quoted Li as saying in June. ``We should in various kinds of work enable people to have ease of mind and to be harmonious with each other.'' The speech was widely commented on, including in a Worker's Daily article that denounced ``erroneous leftist'' emphasis on class struggle. The notion of a continuing struggle within Chinese society between the proletariat and remnants of the bourgeois class was revived after the crushing of the democracy movement last year. A stir also was caused by reports from Washington in late July that indicated Zhao would be rehabilitated. The official Xinhua News Agency denied the reports, but only after a flustered Foreign Ministry spokesman said he couldn't confirm or deny it. A Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it was unclear whether the source of the reports was reliable, and that misinformation about Zhao's status could have been floated by both his supporters and his opponents. ``His enemies might want to remind people of all the reasons they don't want him to return to power _ before it happens,'' the diplomat said.

DOC.HEAD: Brando's Son Told Police He Didn't Mean To Shoot Sister's Boyfriend
DOC.TEXT: Christian Brando told a police officer: ``I didn't mean to shoot him,'' shortly after the killing of his half sister's boyfriend, the officer testified today. Marlon Brando sat in the front row of the jammed courtroom at the preliminary hearing for his 32-year-old son. The actor occasionally took notes as officials told under oath what happened the night 26-year-old Dag Drollet was found slain at the Brando mansion May 16. Officer Steve Cunningham was the first witness to take the stand, moments after Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop announced he was dismissing one count against Christian Brando _ possession of a silencer. Christian Brando remains charged with murder and a weapons violation. There was standing room only in the courtroom of Municipal Court Judge Larry Fidler, who presided over the hearing to decide whether there is sufficient evidence to hold Christian Brando over to trial. Cunningham told of receiving a call to go to the Brando residence on Mulholland Drive in West Los Angeles at 10:44 p.m. As he arrived at the gated estate, Cunningham said he saw paramedics and firefighters and ``I was told there was a guy in the house that had been shot in the head and he was dead and the suspect was still in the house.'' Through a window, he said, he saw Drollet lying dead on the floor, and when he went inside he saw Christian and his half sister, Cheyenne, who was then seven months pregnant with Drollet's child. ``I got approximately three to five feet from the defendant and he stated he didn't mean to shoot him ...,'' Cunningham said. ``At that time, I arrested him.'' The defense contends the .45-caliber handgun went off accidentally during a scuffle over the weapon with Drollet. But authorities say that Cheyenne, who left for Tahiti and recently gave birth to Drollet's child, said her brother threatened to kill Drollet and got a gun the night the boyfriend was shot.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Approves Designs of Six Revised Versions of Banned Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 9-10, The White House spokesman, with Fitzwater saying he made a mistake.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said today it has approved prototypes of six foreign-made semiautomatic rifles redesigned to eliminate military-style features that resulted in their ban as imports last year. However, it was unclear if any requests to import the weapons have been submitted or approved, said Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms spokesman Jack Killorin. Receiving approval were new designs of the Uzi, AK-47, Galil, HK-91, SAR-8, and SAR-4800, officials said. The Washington Post first reported the approvals in today's editions, citing documents obtained by the Firearms Policy Project under the Freedom of Information Act. Those rifles were among the 43 styles of semiautomatic assault-style rifles banned from import by the administration last July. The weapons had such characteristics as threaded barrels to accommodate a silencer; flash suppressors that could hide the shooter's position at night and prevent a loss of night vision; provisions for mounting a bayonet; folding or collapsible stocks; pistol grips; and large capacity magazines. An administration official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said weapons of the type recently approved could be adapted by the purchaser to add the prohibited features. He said such features would be prohibited by federal law under a crime bill now pending in Congress. Earlier, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``Apparently the way the existing rules are written, ATF (the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms) is not authorized to prevent these weapons from coming in.'' ``The new crime bill, I'm told, does rectify this problem,'' he said. ``We look forward to signing that crime bill.'' Fitzwater said the guns should not be allowed into the country ``if they are the same weapon that was originally banned and that was a circumvention of the rule.'' The White House spokesman made the statements in his daily question-and-answer session with reporters. Later he issued a statement admitting that he had made a mistake. ``The crime bill, which the administration proposed, limits the number of rounds in detachable magazines,'' Fitzwater said. ``However, it will not influence the redesign of weapons within the configuration of traditional sporting rifles. I was wrong to suggest that the new crime bill will influence redesigned weapons.'' Federal regulations require that imported rifles be suitable to sporting purposes, and the administration determined that the 43 styles _ many of which were favored by drug traffickers _ did not meet that requirement. Nine manufacturers of the banned weapons have provided the ATF with plans or prototypes of new rifles that eliminate the military-style accoutrements, and the ATF has told six that the new styles meet the sporting requirement, Killorin said. ``The bottom line is, if the firearms conform to the changes required, without bayonet slugs, without flash suppressors, night sites, pistol grips and large-capacity detachable magazines, then we're talking about a weapon consistent with semiautomatic sporting weapons,'' Killorin said. Since such weapons fit the sporting requirement, the ATF must approve them, he said. ``The prototypes that we're looking at are weapons that have none of the accoutrements, not even the pistol grip,'' he said. A pistol grip that hangs down behind the trigger is intended to enable the shooter to have control while firing from the hip or to fire one-handed from the hip in a combat situation, he noted. Although the new designs of the guns do not have such grips, ``Some are designed with a thumb hole in the stock, a configuration frequently seen on Olympic-style rifles,'' he said. Josh Sugarman of the Firearms Policy Project said the thumb hole serves as a pistol grip, enabling weapons to be reloaded quickly and easily and fired from the hip. ``In addition, they can be easily modified to full assault-weapon configuration,'' he said in a statement. Sugarman noted that the rifles still can accept large-capacity magazines even if they are fitted with limited capacity magazines, something that is true of every firearm that takes a detachable magazine, according to Killorin. ``Although these weapons may look less threatening, they are no less deadly,'' Sugarman said. ``The industry knows this, ATF knows this and criminals know this.'' Killorin said the ATF was still checking to see if there had been any requests to import the new weapons and whether such requests have been approved. ``Our correspondence has been relative to prototype configurations rather than a finished product,'' he said. ``The majority of our dialogue has been, `Look, if we made the following changes, would this be importable?' For the most part, we've said, `No, you'd have to change this and this.'''

DOC.HEAD: Ethanol Would Be Bonanza for Corn Growers
DOC.TEXT: Production of ethanol, a clean-burning fuel made from corn, could triple in the 1990s, but only if Congress offers tax breaks and other benefits, a report says. Escalation of ethanol production would be good news to corn growers, who would see bushel prices climb, and to the Agriculture Department, which could then spend less on farm subsidies. But congressional investigators also note some possible negatives: lower soybean prices, higher prices for cattle feed and increased costs to consumers who purchase corn in grocery stores. ``Expanded use of ethanol fuels would have mixed effects on various sectors of American agriculture,'' the General Accounting Office said in the report, which was released last week. GAO is the investigative arm of Congress. The fuel has great appeal among farm-state lawmakers, especially this year as Congress considers new limits on automobile pollution. Lawmakers tout ethanol as an environmentalist's dream and a farmer's bonanza. When gasoline is blended with ethanol, harmful auto emissions are reduced. If the ethanol market picks up, growers would have another use for their corn. In 1988, nearly 1 billion gallons of ethanol were produced. The ethanol industry told GAO it could triple output if Congress dangles some incentives. For example, there is a 9-cent tax on each gallon of motor fuel, but the levy for gasoline made with ethanol is only 3 cents. The industry would like to keep the 6-cent exemption and get passed a law that would order the use of alternative fuels. If production is tripled, the industry would enjoy an average annual tax break of $813 million through 1997, GAO said. While that might hurt the Treasury, GAO said the greater demand for corn would reduce the need to subsidize farmers, saving the government an average of $1.42 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Police Enlist Chess Expert in Woman's Disappearance
DOC.TEXT: Stumped by a bizarre list of chess moves and a suspect who won't talk, police in Lancashire have turned to a chess grandmaster to help find a missing woman. Raymond Keene, chess columnist for The Times of London, said Monday he believes he has cracked the code, but he hasn't located the woman. Her grave, Keene believes, is somewhere northwest of Limerick in western Ireland. The case is reminiscent of a Sherlock Holmes story in which baffled police turn to the brainy amateur, and of Lewis Carroll's looking-glass world of talking chess pieces in which ``the alternation of black and white is perhaps not so strictly observed.'' Police in Preston, in northwestern England, say a suspect has told them that 43-year-old Therese Terry is dead, and buried somewhere in Ireland. Detective Superindent Roy Fletcher, who enlisted Keene as a tracer of lost persons, said the woman had returned to her native Lancashire from Australia in November after discovering that nearly $49,000 was missing from her bank acount. She intended to return to Australia in January, but met a man named Colin English in London, Fletcher said. Mrs. Terry telephoned a friend to say she had changed her plans and was in Dublin with her boyfriend. She was never heard from again, Fletcher said. English was arrested in June, and charged with fraud in connection with Mrs. Terry's bank account, he said. ``While in custody he drew a map which he says gives the answer to where she is buried,'' Fletcher said. ``He claims she died at her own hand.'' English won't say where she is buried, but drew a blob marked with Roman numerals, accompanied by a series of moves for a black king, a black queen, a black pawn and ``a white king _ all pawns.'' Keene took the black king to be the suspect, the black queen to be the victim and the pawn to be the suspect's brother. The chart deviated wildly from conventional chess: the king writes a letter to a ``lady in waiting.'' Black makes all the moves. The ``white king ... all pawns,'' Keene believes, are the police, dismissed as ``no better than a collection of pawns, menial foot soldiers with no directing stratgegy.'' ``If true this gives an essential clue to the suspect's psychology, one of tremendous intellectual arrogance, allied witha perverted ingenuity and rooted in the belief that he can dangle all sorts of intellectual clues in front of the police's nose without their being able to solve them,'' Keene wrote in Monday's editions of The Times. Keene wrote that the moves appear to record events between Jan. 18, when Mrs. Terry left Lancashire for London, and Jan. 23, when the suspect returned from Ireland. He said the moves indicate financial transactions that tally with records from Mrs. Terry's Visa card. For the 21st, the puzzle reads: ``BK (plus) BQ GH _ BK BP do this.'' Keene believes it means, ``the suspect and his brother inflict grievous harm (GH) on the victim. The words `do this' seem particularly sinister in this context.'' The blob, Keene figured, is a mirror image of southern Ireland, rotated 90 degrees so that west is at the bottom. The numbered points, he believes, refer to places including London and the Irish cities of Dublin, Limerick and Cork. An arrow points from the numeral Keene believes is Limerick to the letters HG. ``It is my firm belief that the body is located at HG some miles probably to the northwest of Limerick,'' Keene said. He thought HG might mean ``her grave,'' or perhaps ``hallowed ground.'' Police say they will begin searching for the woman's body in the area identified by Keene.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans Seek Refuge in Swiss Embassy in Havana
LaserPhoto XHAV6
DOC.TEXT: Three Cubans have entered the lightly guarded Swiss Embassy in Havana, raising to 25 the number seeking asylum in European delegations. The three entered the embassy Sunday evening, said informed sources, Swiss officials and the Mexican government agency Notimex on Monday. A car pulled up in front of the Swiss Embassy on Sunday evening, and while the driver distracted the guards in front, an unidentified Cuban entered the building, informed sources said. A short while later, two other Cubans jumped the fence at the embassy compound. Security was light at the Swiss Embassy but heavy at others where Cubans have sought refuge or were thought likely to. More police were dispatched outside the Swiss Embassy on Monday. Notimex said at least 40 police surround the American interest section in Havana and that security also is heavy around the embassies of Spain, Italy, West Germany and Canada. Cuba and the United States do not have embassies in each others' countries but maintain interest sections under a 1977 agreement. Switzerland, which represents the United States in diplomatic matters in Cuba, is the fifth diplomatic mission or residence used by Cubans for asylum in the past two weeks. The U.S. interest section is in a different building from the Swiss Embassy. In the Swiss capital of Bern, the foreign ministry said it was studying the possibility of giving the three temporary refugee at the embassy, but Swiss officials said there is committment to allow the three to travel to Switzerland or a third country. The names of the three were not disclosed. Four Cubans remain in the residence of the Italian ambassador. Cubans who took refuge in the Czechoslovak Embassy and the home of its charge d'affairs abandoned attempts at asylum last week. Eighteen Cubans remain in the Spanish Embassy. Spain suspended $2.5 million in grants-in-aid and persuaded the European Community to put three ``symbolic'' projects on hold after Cuba issued a vitriolic attack on Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez. Fernandez Ordonez had said President Fidel Castro is afraid his hard-line Communist government will fall like those in Eastern Europe if he allows Cubans to leave. Fernandez Ordonez also urged a transition to democracy in Cuba. Cuba has contended the refugee-seekers are part of an American-inspired Western plot, a charge the United States and European countries have denied. The wave of embassy break-ins began two weeks ago, not long after similar incidents were occurring at foreign embassies in Albania. Albania, like Cuba, is a hard-line Communist state.

DOC.HEAD: CNBC President To Leave Company
DOC.TEXT: The first president of NBC's consumer and business cable channel, CNBC, is leaving it and NBC to form an independent company that manages broadcast properties, he and NBC said Monday. No successor was immediately named for 45-year-old Michael Eskridge, who said he has a non-exclusive agreement to provide management and consulting services to GE Capital Corp., whose parent company, General Electric, owns NBC. Eskridge was named president of NBC's Consumer News and Business Channel, based in Fort Lee, N.J., in July 1988. The service began in April 1989. He said he would stay at CNBC until his replacement is found. He said he ``never had any firm plan'' on how long he would stay at the money-losing company, but denied published speculation that he was forced out. Eskridge was praised Monday in a statement by NBC President Robert C. Wright, who said he ``did a phenomenal job in the start-up of CNBC ... in my opinion, Mike is the best executive in the industry in start-up situations.'' He and NBC officials have said that NBC expects to lose money on CNBC for three years but predict that it will have 30 million subscribers and will start making a profit in its fourth year. CNBC's main rival in the daytime is the New York-based Financial News Network, which began in 1981 and says it now is seen in 33.7 million homes and offices in the United States and Canada. CNBC, co-owned by Cablevision Systems Corp., began its 24-hour-a-day operation with reported start-up costs of $65 million and 9.5 million subscribers. It says it now serves 16.8 million homes and offices. Unlike FNN, however, CNBC is not yet available on cable in Manhattan and thus isn't seen there by members of the influential Wall Street and advertising communities.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Insurance Shortage Threatens Health System
DOC.TEXT: Physicians and hospital officials pleaded for national health insurance Monday, saying the burden of treating uninsured patients is endangering the health-care system. ``There is mounting evidence that the system is on the verge of fiscal collapse,'' said Norton J. Greenberger, chairman of the Department of Medicine at the University of Kansas Medical Center. As many as 37 million Americans have no health insurance, Greenberger told the Senate Subcommittee on Health for Families and the Uninsured. Nearly as many have inadequate or interrupted coverage, he said. The number of uninsured rose 43 percent between 1978 and 1986, Greenberger said. Meanwhile, the cost to hospitals of charity care and bad debts more than doubled in the last decade, accounting for 5 percent of their expenses. Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., the subcommittee chairman, said the situation ``underscores the need to develop a national strategy for providing health care for all Americans. It ought to be clear to us that the system is breaking down.'' However, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan told business leaders in Atlanta on Monday that the solution to America's health-care problems will be found in a free market where businesses aren't burdened with requirements. ``Those who call for a radical revamping of our health-care system _ suggesting nationalized medicine _ are mistaken,'' Sullivan said in his prepared remarks, which were made available here. ``As much as possible, we must permit the medical marketplace to work,'' he said. ``A dynamic economy will find some solutions on its own. We do not want to rush in with unproven government remedies which may create more problems than they solve.'' There are many reasons for the rise in the number of uninsured, including Medicaid's failure to keep pace with increasing poverty. High unemployment in the early 1980s, increasing numbers of part-time workers with few benefits and small businesses that offer no insurance are other causes, said E. Jackson Allison Jr. of Pitt County Memorial Hospital in Greenville, N.C. The Senate subcommittee and a bipartisan panel are developing a plan to provide universal health-care coverage and control costs, Riegle said, adding that reducing the number of hospitals poses a hazard to all Americans. ``The wealthiest man ... could be in an automobile accident ... and if there's no room in the hospital, all his health insurance and wealth don't mean a thing to him,'' he said. Michigan hospitals lost $350 million last year treating patients who could not or would not pay, said Edward Thomas, president of Detroit Receiving Hospital and chairman of the corporate board of the Michigan Hospital Association. Especially hard hit are ``safety-net hospitals'' in inner cities, said Barbara Lord Watkins, vice president of public affairs and human services at Dallas' Parkland Memorial Hospital. Safety-net hospitals _ about 300 of the nation's 6,000 hospitals _ treat disproportionately large numbers of AIDS patients, drug and alcohol addicts and victims of violent crime, Ms. Watkins said. Of the 90 safety-net hospitals in the National Association of Public Hospitals, 61 percent reported operating deficits in 1988, she said. About 12 million children aren't covered by health insurance and 100,000 are members of families with such tremendous medical needs that their insurance coverage is exhausted, said Lawrence A. McAndrews, president of Children's Mercy Hospital of Kansas City, Mo. Many such families don't have incomes low enough to qualify for Medicaid, he said. A 13-year-old boy badly injured in a car accident was ineligible for Medicaid even though his parents' combined income totaled only $850 a month, McAndrews said.

DOC.HEAD: Some States Still Allow Public Schools To Teach About Religion
DOC.TEXT: Public schools in 13 states are permitted to teach about religion, and the Bible may be taught as literature in 10 states, a new survey finds. It also shows that 23 states allow excused absences for religious holidays and 22 mention observance of a moment of silence in their laws or regulations. The survey was conducted by the National Council on Religion and Public Education, which says its purpose is to provide a forum for issues involving religions and public education. The survey, which drew responses from all states except Hawaii, was to determine how many laws, regulations or guidelines were on the books of states in matters of religion or moral education. A law or regulation was counted whether it permitted or forbade a practice. Teaching about religion in public schools is different from teaching religion, said Charles C. Haynes of Americans United Research Foundation. ``We advocate public discussion about religion in public schools,'' he said. The survey was by Charles R. Kniker, assistant dean of education at Iowa State University. Character and citizenship education was in the practices of 41 states, he said. The second most frequently cited curriculum category was textbook review procedures, in 32 states; then, numerically, in 27 states, are laws and regulations about state textbook selection policies. In matters of teaching about religion, said the survey, ``few states are as explicit as Alabama, which permits `religious facts only,' to be discussed; many others, like Alaska, have regulations that prohibit teaching of sectarian books or doctrines.'' On the Bible, the survey says few states are as specific as Iowa, which says ``religious books such as the Bible, the Torah, and the Koran shall not be excluded from any public school or institution in the state, nor shall any child be required to read such religious books contrary to the wishes of the child's parents or guardian.'' In virtually every state with a requirement for the pledge of allegiance, participation was voluntary, the survey said. ``Kentucky said that the local school boards may encourage students to participate in the pledge and also in building respect for the flag,'' it added. Wisconsin's law was cited as typical in language: ``No student shall be compelled, against his objections or those of his parents or guardian, to recite the pledge.''

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles County May Test Some Job Applicants for Drugs, Judge Rules
DOC.TEXT: The county may administer drug tests to applicants for such ``sensitive'' jobs as sheriff's deputy, lifeguard, chauffeur and accountant, a judge has ruled. Superior Court Judge David P. Yaffee ruled last week the county may test applicants without union-management talks. ``If the county wants to make darn sure that they don't hire a drug user for a sensitive position, they can do it,'' Yaffee said in turning down a union request for a preliminary injunction. The program, started July 2, targets certain county jobs that pertain to, for instance, public safety and financial duties. So far, only sheriff's trainees have been submitted to the tests. A coalition of unions representing 30,000 workers had wanted to stop the program until the County Employee Relations Commission could hear a complaint on the matter. ``The unions don't condone drug use, but we feel the program should not have been implemented without union bargaining,'' said Alexander Cvitan, a lawyer for the workers' coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Journey of Civil Rights Pioneer Not as Long as it Sounds
DOC.TEXT: James Meredith, the civil rights hero who now shuns that title, is working on a project to rewrite U.S. social legislation as an assistant to Sen. Jesse Helms. Meredith said he gave Helms, R-N.C., an 18-inch tall stack of proposals when they discussed his joining the senator's staff last year. ``In a nutshell, this is what I told them I want to do: To rewrite domestic policy legislation on the order of the Great Society of Lyndon Johnson and of the New Deal of Franklin Roosevelt,'' Meredith said. ``To be quite frank, no one was willing to say I could do it. But Senator Helms was willing to let me try.'' Meredith's journey from civil rights pioneer to the side of an archconservative senator isn't as surprising as it might appear. Meredith, who broke the color barrier at the University of Mississippi, was an early loner in the civil rights movement, disillusioned by infighting and unwilling to work with its leaders, according to former colleagues and a biographer. He surprised many in the movement five years ago when he described integration as a ``con job,'' and even more when he went to work for conservative Helms last year. But Meredith said his behavior should not be a shock. ``I've been saying the same thing for many years. And they have been very much aware of my position,'' he said from Washington, D.C. ``I operate on the principle that the real attraction to Senator Helms was his commitment to family and morality.'' Meredith said last week that an elite group of powerful white men pull the strings of many black leaders. He issued a statement on Helms' official Senate stationery accusing NAACP delegates of involvement in drugs. Meredith said black leaders have been co-opted by white liberals whose programs are intended to reinforce control over blacks. ``Until 25 years ago, the black race had control of all their domestic affairs,'' Meredith said. ``That included all of the periods of slavery. They raised their children.'' He said he wants authority returned to families _ authority that white liberals have taken over through social programs. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said Meredith's statements are irrational. ``I think he's had a difficult time keeping in touch with reality,'' Hooks said. Helms is facing a re-election challenge by the man who broke the color barrier at Clemson University in 1963 _ former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt. Democrat Gantt has said Meredith's statement was a way for Helms to inject race into the campaign without having to personally ``say anything that might be considered to be a racist remark.'' Helms denied that, saying that Meredith has a right to speak for himself. At age 27, Meredith returned to his native Mississippi after nine years in the Air Force to enroll in Ole Miss. Some 16,000 troops were called in to quell rioting in which two people were killed. In 1966, Meredith took off from his law studies at Columbia University for a solo march supporting black voter registration in Mississippi. He was shot and wounded on a highway. Civil rights leaders flocked to Meredith's side and stole the limelight, said Charles Evers, who took over as the NAACP's Mississippi field director after his own brother, Medgar, was assassinated in 1963. Evers, who manages a Jackson, Miss., radio station, said he was surprised when he found out that Meredith joined Helms' staff. ``He always wanted to do the impossible,'' he said. ``And he's proved that it's not always impossible.'' Tyrone Yates, who's working on a biography of Meredith, said Meredith was disillusioned by infighting within the movement ``and since his life was on the line he had no time for nonsense.'' The year after entering Mississippi, Meredith said ``intolerance and bigotry'' among civil rights activists endangered the movement. ``When he grew up, for breakfast, lunch and dinner he ate bread sopped with molasses,'' Yates said. ``He knew what poverty was. He probably sees these organizations as having advanced white causes while ignoring the poor, downtrodden blacks.''

DOC.HEAD: Spokesman Says Mrs. Quayle Should be Home This Week
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle is doing well at Bethesda Naval Hospital after weekend surgery and is expected to return home later this week, a spokesman said Monday. David Beckwith, a spokesman for Vice President Dan Quayle, said the family did not want to disclose the type of operation or the disease. Sources have told The Associated Press that Mrs. Quayle had cervical cancer. ``She's doing well at Bethesda Naval Hospital. We exometime this week,'' Beckwith said. President Bush called Mrs. Quayle over the weekend ``to wish her a speedy recovery,'' said White House spokesman Marlipect her home sn Fitzwater. Family sources who asked not to be identified said the operation was for cervical cancer detected in a Pap smear earlier this year. Beckwith said Saturday only that ``full and total recovery is expected,'' with Mrs. Quayle resuming a full schedule in four to six weeks. The Quayles urged all women to have yearly Pap tests. Pap smears are useful in detecting many medical problems, but are aimed especially at uncovering malignancies in the reproductive tract. Mrs. Quayle, a lawyer and mother of three, became active in breast cancer education last year. DOC.HEAD: Ford Motor Co. to Pay $1.2 Million OSHA Fine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs, The Labor, to note number of workers affected. Inserts 2 grafs new material after 6th graf pvs, The injuries. Deletes last graf pvs, now redundant.
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. agreed Monday to pay a $1.2 million fine for repeatedly failing to keep track of on-the-job injuries, the government said. In a separate settlement with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Ford agreed to launch a program to reduce ergonomic hazards _ or workplace injuries caused by repetitive-motion tasks _ at 96 percent of its plants. The Labor Department called that agreement the most extensive ergonomics settlement in OSHA's history. A Ford spokesman said about 150,000 workers would be affected. The $1.2 million fine involves record keeping violations that OSHA inspectors found in 1989, when they visited a Ford Electronics and Refrigeration facility in Lansdale, Pa. Ford was misrecording or failing to record injuries that workers had received, OSHA inspectors alleged. The injuries involved cumulative trauma disorders, or disorders of the musculoskeletal and nervous systems caused by repetitive motions. Such disorders are common occupational illnesses in the automotive industry, where workers often have to repeat tasks on assembly lines. Ford spokesman Dick Routh attributed the poor record keeping to ``carelessness.'' ``We had not put the effort into it that we should have. Certainly, OSHA got our attention with the size of the fine,'' he added. OSHA originally hit Ford with a $2 million fine because it was the third time the automaker had been cited for record keeping violations and Ford had failed to live up to an earlier pledge of improving procedures, the agency said. As part of the record keeping agreement signed Monday, Ford will establish, at 12 of its facilities, an audit system for keeping track of records involving workers' medical, compensation, sickness, accident and health insurance information. The company will then cross check the records against an OSHA log and provide record keeping training if the error rate is greater than 5 percent either nationwide or at an individual facility. On the ergonomic settlement, Ford has voluntarily agreed to implement a program to reduce workers' risks of developing cumulative trauma disorders. Several businesses nationwide have taken voluntary steps to reduce those types of injuries as OSHA considers mandating ergonomic programs. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, in announcing the Ford agreement, said the effort to reduce repetitive-motion injuries will be one of the ``greatest worker health and safety concerns in the next decade.'' Preventive measures include redesigning work stations, such as adjusting workbench heights, redesigning tools, training workers and using mechanical or other devices to prevent excessive lifting. Ford's ergonomic program, which will involve analyses of various jobs and their risks, will be partially administered by the United Auto Workers Union, which represents Ford workers. Last year, OSHA reached a similar ergonomics agreement with Chrysler and the UAW to control cumulative trauma disorders in five Chrysler auto assembly plants. The Ford program will include a medical management program to provide for early identification of cumulative trauma disorders. That would include periodic workplace walk-throughs by medical staff, having workers fill out questionnaires every two years to gather information on symptoms of work-related disorders and encouraging employees to report early signs of problems.

DOC.HEAD: Mink Production Increases
DOC.TEXT: Mink farmers produced more than 4.6 million pelts in 1989, the most in 20 years, the Agriculture Department said Monday. An annual report showed the number of pelts was up 3 percent from 1988, the most since 5.7 million were produced in 1969. The average market price was $25.80 per pelt last year, down from $32.30 in 1988. The total value of production was reported at $118.7 million, down from $143.8 million. Officials said 952 mink farms produced pelts last year, down 7 percent from 1988. Leading states were Wisconsin with 204 farms, Utah with 175 and Minnesota with 119.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Fails to Find Cause of Plane Crash that Killed 3
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators have failed to find the cause of a fire blamed for a plane crash that killed a top executive of Gulf Power Co., the National Transportation Safety Board reported Monday. Southern Company Services, owner of the plane and a sister company of Gulf Power, contended the crash last year was caused by a fire set intentionally by the executive, Senior Vice President Jacob F. ``Jake'' Horton. Shortly before the plane took off from the Pensacola (Fla.) Regional Airport bound for Atlanta, Gulf Power officials had accused Horton of financial irregularities. They told him he would have to retire, resign or be fired. Horton and the two pilots were killed when the plane, trailing smoke, crashed into an apartment building three miles northwest of the airport on April 10, 1989. An intense fire after the crash destroyed the plane and the building. The NTSB previously said the fire caused the crash, but was unable to pinpoint the cause of the fire. In its final report on the crash, the NTSB said its investigators couldn't find evidence of a lightning strike, an aircraft system malfunction or an incendiary device that might have started the fire. ``Obviously, we're disappointed that the NTSB has not been able to pinpoint the origin of the fire,'' Southern Company Services President Allen Franklin said. ``It's unfortunate for our company _ and more importantly, for the families of the three men who died _ that questions still remain.'' Horton's widow, Frances, has filed suit seeking damages from Southern Services, a subsidiary of the Southern Co., the Atlanta-based holding company that also owns Gulf Power and four other utilities. She claimed the company had negligently maintained and operated the plane. Southern Services filed a countersuit against Horton's estate, saying Horton intentionally set fire to the plane. Gulf Power, which provides electricity in the Florida Panhandle, was under investigation at the time by a federal grand jury in Atlanta. The utility subsequently pleaded guilty to charges of making illegal political contributions, paid a $500,000 fine and accused Horton of being the primary culprit. Also killed in the fire were Southern Company Services pilots Mike Holmes and John Major, both of Biloxi, Miss.

DOC.HEAD: Distributor to Fight British Ban on Rushdie Film
DOC.TEXT: The distributor of a film that portrays the death of author Salman Rushdie said Monday he will fight a ban by Britain's film board, arguing the film is a purely fictional. The 3{-hour movie, ``International Guerrillas,'' depicts Rushdie as a bloodthirsty murderer of Moslems and ends with divine retribution. In the last scene, Rushdie is killed by lightning bolts that emanate from the Koran floating over his head. Distributor Mohammed Fayyaz said the film left Moslems with a sense of satisfaction and calmed their offended feelings. He said if the appeal before the British Board of Film Classification fails, he will take the case to court. In the meantime, he will increase efforts to distribute the movie in Europe and North America. He said the film is the most expensive ever made in Pakistan, where ithas played to packed audiences. Rushdie, who supports the right of the film to be shown, has made the same argument for his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' The book, assailed as blasphemous by some Moslems, prompted the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran to call for Rushdie's death in February 1989. The author, born to a Moslem family in India and now a British citizen, has been in hiding since Feb. 14, 1989. Fayyaz, who has a video shop in south London, called the Punjabi-Urdu film an imaginative thriller. ``If you drop the name Salman Rushdie then it is just like James Bond,'' he said. The film classification board has refused to allow release of the film on the ground it was criminally libelous. James Ferman, chairman of the film classification board, said the board had been advised it ``could be cited as an accessory if we were irresponsibly to pass this video.'' Rushdie said the film deserves the same rights as his book. ```The Satanic Verses' was accused of being blasphemous, it had a judicial review and went through the British courts which decided it wasn't blasphemous,'' said Frances D'Souza, who spoke to Rushdie on Monday. ``The film should be treated in the same way. If it does actually infringe British law then action can be taken.'' She said censoring the film was a form of prior restraint. Ms. D'Souza is director of an organization which defends free expression and is chairwoman of the International Salman Rushdie Defense Committee. She said Rushdie ``unequivocally has said he would not take out any proceedings'' against the film. Fayyaz said 500 pirate copies of ``International Guerrillas'' are already in Britain.

DOC.HEAD: House Prepares For Debate Over Frank Reprimand
DOC.TEXT: House Democratic leaders and ethics committee members geared up Monday to defend a proposed reprimand for Rep. Barney Frank. However, conservative Republicans readied moves to stiffen the punishment for the Massachusetts Democrat's actions on behalf of a male prostitute. Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said disciplinary action would be considered Thursday against Frank, one of two admitted homosexuals in the House. The 12-member ethics panel voted unanimously last week to reprimand Frank, a punishment that would consist of a finding by the full House that the congressman brought discredit upon the body. Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., already has said, however, that he would propose to expel Frank. That resolution would need a two-thirds vote and appears headed for certain defeat. However, a number of other conservative Republicans said they expect one of their number to propose that Frank be censured, a step higher than a reprimand. A censure, like a reprimand, requires a House vote condemning a member's behavior but also requires his presence while the action is taken. Frank, an outspoken liberal in his fifth term, is expected to be on the floor regardless of the punishment, because he has promised to apologize to the House. ``I believe the committee position will be sustained on the floor,'' Foley told reporters Monday. House Majority Whip William H. Gray III, D-Pa., said, ``When the committee comes out with an overwhelmingly bipartisan report, the membership will say `12 folks are all saying the same thing. Can they be wrong?' Attempts at censure or expulsion will fail.'' The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, the ethics panel's formal name, concluded in a report released Friday that Frank brought discredit upon the House in two areas of his conduct with male prostitute Stephen L. Gobie. The panel found he used his congressional status for dismissal of 33 parking tickets incurred by Gobie while not on official business. Frank said he had employed Gobie as a personal aide from 1985-87 and paid him with personal funds. The panel recommended that Frank make restitution of an unspecified amount to the District of Columbia for the tickets. The committee said also that Frank wrote a memo that wound up in the files of a Virginia prosecutor, which made misleading statements favorable to Gobie during his probation. Gobie had been convicted on drug and sex charges. Rep. Robert S. Walker, R-Pa., said he's aware that some GOP members are considering a censure of Frank and added he would vote for such a proposal. Walker said a key factor for those favoring censure would be Frank's initial failure to pay Social Security taxes on Gobie's salary. Frank told a news conference Friday he had ``erred in apparently not withholding Social Security taxes for Gobie. Apparently when you have casual labor like this you're supposed to withhold Social Security tax. I've since made those payments. There is no other tax liability.'' Walker said the Social Security tax payments represent ``a serious question that merits a penalty greater than the ethics committee's recommendation.'' He added that the misleading statements by Frank during Gobie's probation was ``a fairly serious offense'' because he's chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on administrative law. ``When you have someone in a powerful position in law enforcement lying to law enforcement officials, that is something we ought to be concerned about,'' Walker said.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Limit TV Ads Aimed at Children
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Monday to limit the amount of advertising on children's television shows, which one lawmaker complained have become ``the equivalent of a Toys R Us catalog.'' By a voice vote, the House approved legislation that also would require regulators to weigh, in renewing the licenses of television stations, how well broadcasters are serving the educational needs of children. The bill and a similar measure approved by the Senate last week would effectively reverse the Reagan administration's deregulation of the commercial content of children's TV programming in 1984. Both would limit commercial advertising during children's programming to 10{ minutes an hour on weekends and 12 minutes an hour on weekdays. Proponents claim the restrictions are necessary because many children are unable to discriminate between ads and programs until they reach the age of 4 or 5 and are unable to recognize a pitch as such until they are 7 or 8. The Bush administration opposes the bill, particularly the provision requiring the FCC to review children's educational and informational programming as part of license renewals. The Justice Department has said it will urge President Bush to veto the bill. The House Energy and Commerce Committee estimates the average cvisions, the National Association of Broadcasters issued a statement last week in general support of the legislation. ``I think the president will sign it and I think most of the parents will stand behind him when he does,'' said Peggy Charren, president of Action of Children's Television, an advocacy group behind the legislation. Before the bill can be sent to the White House, lawmakers still have to settle a major difference between the House and Senate versions. Going a step beyond the House, the Senate attached a measure by Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., that would establish a $10 million National Endowment for Children's Educational Television in the Commerce Department. Wirth said the foundation is needed to ``reverse the trend of the 1980s, which has seen commercial television broadcasters virtually abandon their efforts at children's educational programming.'' Both bills would require the FCC to complete within six months its current inquiry into so-called ``program-length commercials'' aimed at promoting toys such at GI Joe. Charren said there were 70 such shows _ ``in effect toy commercials, many of them series'' _ aired by broadcasters in 1986. Prior to the FCC's deregulation in 1984, broadcasters had followed industry guidelines limiting ads in children's programming to 9{ minutes an hour on weekends and 12 minutes an hour on weekdays. Since then, according to the House committee, advertising on many Saturday morning children's shows has crept up to 11 minutes an hour.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Immigration Prompts New `Who is a Jew?' Debate
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials are debating whether to restrict immigration laws to curb the influx of tens of thousands of Soviet Jews who are severely taxing the country's housing market and social services. The question of amending the Law of Return, or ``Who is a Jew'' law, was argued Monday on radio broadcasts and in newspapers. Almost two years ago, proposals to amend the law, which grants automatic citizenship to all Jews, provoked outrage among American Jews, who said changes would alienate conservative and reform Jews who together form a majority of American Jewry. Michael Kleiner, chairman of Parliament's immigration committee, has claimed the immigration laws are exploited by Soviet non-Jews. He seeks to change a 1970 amendment to the law that grants automatic citizenship to the child, grandchild or spouse of a Jew, as well as the spouse of his child or grandchild. Kleiner claims that if this ammendment is not revised it would entitle at least 5 million Soviet non-Jews to Israeli citizenship and immigration benefits. Their immigration would more than double the population of Israel. Kleiner has said he wants to exclude descendants of Jewish grandfathers, unless the family arrives with the grandfather. ``If this really becomes a trend and millions of non-Jews use their Jewish grandfather to escape from the Soviet Union, this will endanger the Jewish nature of Israel,'' Kleiner said in an interview last week. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, head of the government's immigration committee, reportedly told the Cabinet Sunday he will oppose any changes in the law because ``we are dealing with an emergency situation with Jews running from the Soviet Union. ... What we must do is open the gates of the homeland to the Jewish people.'' Legislator Uriel Lynn lashed out at Kleiner Monday. ``This change may divide families and create panic and anxiety among potential immigrants. ... It has elements of racism and would present our country as racist,'' Lynn said in an interview. Eugene Sukholtzky, head of the Jewish Culture Club in Baku, Soviet Central Asia, told the Israeli daily Haaretz: ``We know non-Jews are buying documents that they are Jewish ... and we also have the widespread problem of mixed marriages.'' But he added that requiring grandfathers to come to Israel could be unfair to some immigrants ``because of the biological reason that their grandparents are no longer alive and they have no other proof that they are Jewish.'' Israel's Orthodox establishment has long fought to change the Law of Return so it conforms to Orthodox Jewish law. That law states that a Jew is one who is born to a Jewish mother or converted according to Orthodox Jewish law. This proposal enraged American Jews because it would mean all non-Orthodox converts would be considered non-Jews in Israel. Interior Minister Arye Deri, a member of the Sephardic Torah Guardian or Shas Party, has refused to comply with a Supreme Court order to recognize non-Orthodox conversions. He now backs Kleiner's effort to change the law. More than 1.2 million Soviets have requested visa applications as Jews, according to the quasi-government Jewish Agency. Since 1989 74,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel and the number is expected to reach 150,000 this year. Social services are already overloaded and a housing shortage is fast developing.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he will nominate appellate judge David Souter to a seat on the Supreme Court. If confirmed by the Senate, the 50-year-old jurist from New Hampshire would succeed William J. Brennan who resigned last Friday. Souter stood by Bush's side as he made the announcement at the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Another Line Of Defense In Texas Against `Killer Bees'
DOC.TEXT: Another line of defense has been completed in Texas against Africanized honeybees moving north out of Mexico toward the United States, the Agriculture Department said Monday. James W. Glosser, head of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the bees have not yet entered the United States but are expected to do so between late summer and next spring. Glosser said four interconnected trap lines have been completed in South Texas to capture and track swarms as they move north out of Mexico. The bees are hybrid offspring of African bees brought to Brazil in 1956. Some escaped and mated with native bees. Africanized bees can be aggressive when threatened and swarm quickly against an intruder. This characteristic has contributed to their notoriety as ``killer bees,'' which USDA officials blame on horror movies and exaggerated news reports. ``In reality, the chances of being injured by an Africanized or any honeybee are far less than the chances of being hit by lightning,'' says a recent background paper on the bees. Glosser said the four trap lines are located north of Brownsville, Texas, near the Gulf coast. The northernmost line has more than 40 traps and runs about 50 miles from Sarita to Raymondville. An intersecting line has about 60 traps and extends 80 miles from La Gloria to Port Mansfield on the coast. Another with about 30 traps extends about 30 miles south of La Gloria to Rio Grande City. The fourth, with about 60 traps, runs parallel to the coast for about 60 miles from San Perlita to Port Isabel.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: seek advice.
DOC.TEXT: Bush noted that Souter had won unanimous confirmation to the appellate bench earlier this year, suggesting his hopes that the nomination might not trigger a political free-for-all in the Senate. ``I look forward to a fair and expeditious confirmation process,'' Bush said. Bush was asked if he knows Souter's views on abortion or other difficult issues. Bush said he felt it would have been ``inappropriate'' and that he did not ask him his views on any specific issues. ``Judge Souter is committed to interpreting, not making, the law,'' Bush said. ``I have selected a person who will interpret the Constitution and in my view not legislate'' from the bench, Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Sends $98,950 In S&L Campaign Money To State Govt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Tim Wirth sent the state of Colorado a check Monday for $98,950 _ all the money contributed to his campaign committee by savings and loan industry figures and S&L customers who failed to repay major loans. The list of donors includes three key figures in the controversy over the collapse of Silverado Banking, which was closed by federal regulators in 1988. The president's son, Neil Bush, was a Silverado director. ``Recent scandals surrounding the industry have contaminated these contributions,'' Wirth said in a news statement. ``Therefore, they have no place in my campaign, past, present, or future.'' Among the donors were Ken Good, the Denver developer who allegedly defaulted on at least $31 million in loans from Silverado, Michael Wise, the former Silverado president, and Denver developer Bill Walters, who allegedly defaulted on $106 million in Silverado loans. Good donated $9,000 to Wirth; Wise, $3,100; Walters, $3,500. Wise also raised money for Republican presidential candidate George Bush in 1987 by helping sponsor a dinner for Bush that reportedly brought in $300,000 in contributions. The president's son, Denver oilman Neil Bush, was a Silverado director from 1985 to 1988 when Wise was the thrift's president. Wise also raised money for Republican presidential candidate George Bush in 1987 by helping sponsor a fund-raising dinner that reportedly brought in $300,000. The Colorado Democrat said the check to the state Department of Revenue represents all contributions made by these parties to the Wirth Campaign Committee since 1980. Dorothy Dahlquist, a spokeswoman for the revenue department, said officials had yet to decide if the money would go into the general fund or used for a specific purpose. ``At the time these contributions were made, which over the years have comprised less than 2 percent of all monies raised, there was no reason to suspect any wrongdoing,'' Wirth said. ``On the contrary, these donors were well-recognized as leaders of their communities, precisely the kinds of people from whom anyone seeking public office would hope to solicit political and financial support.'' But he said the S&L scandal has changed his opinion of those contributors. ``By its magnitude, persistence and unfairness, the S&L scandal has shaken public trust in government,'' said Wirth. ``Coloradans are angry, and I share their anger. ``A relative handful of greedy and unprincipled individuals, using the tools of an unregulated industry in an overly permissive financial environment, have ripped off millions of Americans,'' he said. ``The guilty parties must be brought to justice; our financial institutions must again be made safe and sound, and perhaps most important, the pact between people and their institutions of self-government must be reconfirmed.'' The list of Wirth campaign contributors whose money was turned over to the state showed $22,650 from people affiliated with Columbia Savings and Loan of Beverly Hills, Calif. and $11,000 from figures linked to the bankrupt American Continental Corp. of Arizona, both of which have battled federal regulators. Also listed was $8,700 from the U.S. League of Savings Associations PAC, and $8,250 from donors affiliated with Mercury Savings of Huntington Beach, Calif. The other returned contributions were for amounts $5,000 or less.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Clinic Operator Arrested
DOC.TEXT: An abortion clinic operator was charged with breach of peace after he allegedly threw horse manure at anti-abortion protesters demonstrating near his home, police said. Dr. Steven G. Kaali, 47, who operates Women's Medical Pavillion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was released on his own recognizance after his arrest Saturday. He is scheduled to appear July 30 in Stamford Superior Court. Police said six protesters had completed a brief march near Kaali's secluded estate in Greenwich when a man identified as Kaali threw a bucket of horse manure at them. The protesters had earlier participated with about 70 others in a march through downtown Greenwich. The march was the third in as many weeks. One protester said she was struck by the manure. ``I was so humiliated. I was in shock,'' said Carol Centonze, 50, of Yonkers, N.Y. Women's Medical Pavillion has been a regular target for protests during the past two years, according to Dobbs Ferry police.

DOC.HEAD: Education Officircantile Exchange. The near-month crude
DOC.TEXT: oil futures contract hasn't been that high since April, traders said. Ministers from the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are scheduled to meet Thursday. ``The market is simply gaining more and more confidence that OPEC is going to come up with a viable settlement here,'' said Bob Baker, who follows the energy futures markets for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Baker said crude oil prices have been rising for the past 12 sessions, since the September contract for West Texas intermediate was trading at below $17 a barrel. Robert Murphy, vice president in the international energy futures group at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said that as the OPEC meeting approaches, ``the more it looks likely they are going to keep their promise of last week.'' He said traders are anticipating OPEC will cut its production to 22.5 million barrels a day from current production of more than 23 million barrels. But he warned that there is still a glut in the U.S. oil inventory, and that ``you never know how inventory figures (to be released Tuesday) will affect'' prices. Prices for refined products traded on the Merc also rose, taking their cues from movements in the crude contracts. Unleaded regular gasoline for August delivery rose 0.39 cent to 63.35 cents a gallon, while later contract months up by similar amounts. The August contract for home heating oil rose 0.71 cent to close at 56.50 cents a gallon, with subsequent months up even more. In natural gas trading, the September contract closed at $1.460 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.482 Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Seattle Motorists Burning Dirtiest Gas
DOC.TEXT: Motorists in Seattle are burning the dirtiest gasoline, according to a consumer survey released Monday that also said Chevron brands nationwide contain on average the most cancer-causing benzene. The survey found widely different levels of toxic aromatics, especially benzene, in gasoline depending on regions of the country. Premium gasoline sold in Miami contained a third as much benzene as the same gasoline sold in Seattle. Earl Ross, spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, said such variations weren't unusual. ``Gasolines are blended differently for different parts of the country'' because of differences in driving conditions, climate, altitude and seasonal changes, he said. Benzene and other so-called ``aromatic'' additives, which are used to boost gasoline octane, are highly toxic and can cause cancer, studies have indicated. Clean-air legislation before Congress would require significant reductions in the use of those additives by refiners. Health specialists are concerned primarily about exposure to the toxic vapors during refueling, although the petroleum industry has said such exposure is at such low levels that it does not warrant a health concern. The Environmental Protection Agency has estimated that there are about eight chances in 100,000 of a person developing cancer from self-service refueling of motor vehicles over a lifetime. The EPA said the risk is greater for those who live near or work at gasoline stations, terminals or refineries. The survey of gasoline sold in 18 metropolitan areas was produced by Citizen Action, a Washington-based consumer and environmental group, and was based on fuel samples tested annually by the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. The American Petroleum Institute accused Citizen Action of ``misusing data ... to present an unduly alarmist picture of the health risks'' to motorists. The Citizens Action study showed that premium gasoline sold in the West generally contained higher levels of aromatics, including benzene. An exception appeared to be Atlanta, where the level of benzene in premium gasoline (2.9 percent) was second only to Seattle (3 percent). Shell premium gasoline sold in Atlanta had the highest benzene content of any gasoline tested, or 5.4 percent. Shell in recent months has touted the benefits of clean gasoline when promoting its reformulated premium SU-2000E brand. But other gasoline brands in other cities also showed high levels of benzene. Exxon's premium in Los Angeles and Chevron's premium in San Francisco contained more than 3.6 percent benzene. ``This is gasoline at its dirtiest,'' said Edwin Rothschild, energy policy director for Citizen Action. By comparison, the average benzene content in gasoline is slightly more than 2 percent. Clean-air legislation in the final stages of being approved by Congress calls for refiners to limit their benzene levels to less than 1 percent and overall aromatic levels to 25 percent. The Citizen Action survey showed that some gasoline brands already meet the anticipated clean-air requirement. In Miami, where average benzene levels in premium gasoline were only 1 percent, Mobil's premium had a benzene level of one-half of 1 percent and three other brands _ Union, Amoco and Exxon _ all contained well below 1 percent benzene. Premium brands from Exxon, Amoco and Texaco had similar levels in Dallas, Washington D.C., and Denver. ``Obviously oil companies are capable of manufacturing premium unleaded gasoline with less than 0.8 percent benzene,'' Rothschild said at a news conference. Gasoline from the same company can have widely different levels of benzene depending on region and type of gas, the survey showed. For example, while Texaco sold premium gasoline with 0.67 percent benzene in Denver, its regular gasoline sold in Boston had nearly 5 percent benzene content. Rothschild said the controversial additives should be eliminated. ``We are appalled that companies like Chevron and Shell have the audacity to tell the public that they sell quality gasoline when in many cities they are the purveyors of the most toxic gasoline on the market,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando Listens as Witnesses Recount Shooting
LaserPhoto LA6
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando listened solemnly in court Monday while witnesses described the night a shot rang out at the actor's mansion and his son Christian was arrested for shooting his sister's boyfriend. ``I didn't mean to shoot him,'' Christian Brando was quoted as telling the first police officer who reached the gated estate where 26-year-old Dag Drollet had died. ``He (Christian Brando) said he didn't care for the guy a whole lot, but he didn't want the guy killed,'' recalled Los Angeles police officer Steve Cunningham. ``He didn't want anybody to be shot.'' Cunningham testified as a preliminary hearing opened. Municipal Court Judge Larry Fidler will decide at hearing's end whether there is sufficient evidence to have the actor's son stand trial for murder and a weapons violation. Marlon Brando sat in the front row of the jammed courtroom, occasionally taking notes. Christian, 32, appeared nervous when he was led into the jammed courtroom where some spectators had to stand after all seats were filled. Reporters, camera crews and movie fans crowded the hallways. The prosecution dismissed one charge, possession of a silencer. Cunningham told of driving to Brando's Mulholland Drive estate on May 16. At the gate, Cunningham said he saw paramedics and firefighters and ``I was told there was a guy in the house that had been shot in the head and he was dead and the suspect was still in the house.'' He added later: ``I was told by a fireman the son did it.'' '' Cunningham said Marlon Brando opened the door and the officer asked where to find his son. ``He said, `I don't have any idea where he is and I can't believe he shot him.''' Cunningham said he went into the living room and found Christian Brando and his sister, Cheyenne, seated on the floor. ``He was sitting on the floor with his arms around her shoulder. She appeared to be upset,'' said Cunningham. ``... I could not hear her crying but I remember she had tears on her face.'' Cheyenne Brando was then seven months pregnant with Drollet's child. She recently gave birth to a boy in Tahiti where the Brandos have a home. She is said to be suffering from exhaustion, and a doctor told authorities she could not return to testify. Cunningham said young Brando spoke before he was asked anything. ``I got approximately 3 to 5 feet from the defendant and he stated he didn't mean to shoot him,'' Cunningham said. ``At that time, I arrested him.'' After being handcuffed, Brando continued explaining. ``All of a sudden he just started talking,'' Cunningham said. ``He stated that it was an accident, that they were struggling over the gun, wrestling around over the gun, that the deceased grabbed his hand and that made the gun go off.'' The defense contends the .45-caliber handgun went off accidentally during a scuffle over the weapon between the 6-foot Brando and the 6-foot-3 Drollet. Prosecutors say they found no evidence of a struggle and that Drollet was shot while sitting on a sofa, holding a cigarette lighter in one hand and a television remote control in the other. Cunningham said the younger Brando said he had been out to dinner with his sister ``and when they got back to Mulholland Drive things got crazy and the deceased went nuts.'' Under cross-examination by Brando's lawyer, Robert L. Shapiro, Cunningham said Christian also told him Drollet was fighting with Cheyenne and that Christian told Drollet: ``Leave my sister alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Prime Minster, Gorbachev Speak of Peace
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Indian Prime Minister V.P. Singh pledged Monday to work toward building a nuclear-free and non-violent world, Tass said. The official Soviet news agency said a joint statement spoke of the two countries' commitment to disarmament and the replacement of confrontation and force with peace through reason. But the account of the statement they signed in the Kremlin did not touch on economic issues. Indian officials had said a major Singh goal during the trip was to protect India's trade relationship with the Soviet Union, now based on barter and ruble-rupee parity. This could be undercut by Moscow's plans to make the ruble convertible. In dinner speeches, Gorbachev and Singh praised their two countries' cooperation. Singh cited Gorbachev's ``courage and visionary thinking'' and Gorbachev thanked India for its support for perestroika, his reform program. Singh arrived on Monday and was met at the airport by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. The visit is his first here since he took office last December. Before leaving New Delhi, he told reporters he hoped to establish a personal rapport with Gorbachev. ``We now have a fruitful cooperation in the economy and I am certain that new opportunities, ways and forms of cooperation will open up,'' Singh said in an interview with Tass before leaving New Delhi. ``I will give priority to this question during my visit.'' Singh's talks with Gorbachev were expected to focus on India's deep economic and military ties with the Soviet Union, which Indian newspaper said could be threatened by the Soviet Union's turn to the West. Oleg Bostorin, head of the Directorate for South Asian Countries, told Tass Singh's visit ``refutes the allegation, made recently in some circles, that the Soviet Union has lost interest in India, and in the Third World as a whole.'' Indian-Soviet trade, worth about $4 billion a year, has been to India's advantage in recent years. India bought military hardware and oil on favorable terms, and sold rice and other commodities at prices higher than those on the world market.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Department Spokesman Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Paul Kindinger, the Agriculture Department's director of public affairs, has resigned to take a job with the Pentagon's war college, it was announced Monday. Kindinger, 43, joined USDA last August. He will take at endowed chair at the Industrial College of the Armed Forces, which is part of the National Defense University at Fort McNair, Washington, D.C. The chair, or position, was endowed by USDA and will pay Kindinger's current salary of $83,600 a year, officials said. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Kindinger will instruct senior military officers and civilians ``on the importance of agriculture in the global community and for our national security.'' Yeutter said Kindinger will join the college on Tuesday and will begin instructing during the fall semester. Kindinger was raised on a farm in Reading, Mich., and holds degrees, including a doctorate, in agricultural economics. Before joining USDA last year, he had been Michigan state director of agriculture since 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Filmmaker Hopes Money Could Someday Help Finance Movies
DOC.TEXT: Filmmaker Spike Lee has opened a store called Spike's Joint, and it features products from four of Lee's films and merchandise from his ``Is it the shoes?'' sneaker ads. ``I think we're making a very important statement that we black people have to start building and owning our own businesses,'' Lee said at the Brooklyn store's opening Sunday. Franchised Spike's Joints may open in the next year in Los Angeles, Atlanta and Chicago. Publicist Pedro Barry said Monday the goods in the store are what ``the public is asking us to produce.'' ``We got letters and telephone calls everyday asking for these things,'' he said. In the last two years, the merchandise was distributed from Forty Acres and a Mule Filmworks, Lee's production company, also in Brooklyn. Lee, acclaimed for his film ``Do The Right Thing,'' bristled when a reporter suggested that some of the money might be funneled back to the community. ``When white people start a business no one says a word. Black people want to make some money, it's `So Spike, are you going to give all your money back to the community?''' he mocked. Lee said he is interested in making money because he would like to finance his own movies. His first mass-distributed movie, ``She's Gotta Have It,'' was made for only $175,000 in 1986. Now, though, he relies on studio money to finance movies, including the $10 million it cost to produce the soon-to-open ``Mo' Better Blues.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds further Bush comments, Souter comments, abortion detail; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he will nominate appellate judge David Souter to a seat on the Supreme Court. If confirmed by the Senate, the 50-year-old jurist from New Hampshire would succeed William J. Brennan. ``He is a remarkable judge of keen intellect and the highest ability,'' Bush said. The president went on to praise Brennan as well, calling the court's long-time leading liberal, ``one of the greatest figures of his age.'' Brennan resigned last Friday. Souter stood at Bush's side as the president made his surprise announcement at the White House late in the afternoon. The president said he decided on Souter earlier in the afternoon. Bush said his quick selection was not geared to abortion policy or any other single issue. ``It is not appropriate ... to use any litmus test,'' Bush said. Abortion activists believe Brennan's departure from the court could pave the way for overturning the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision. ``I hope you will understand that I think I must defer any comments'' on court issues, Souter said, until Senate confirmation hearings begin. He said it would take him all night to describe what an honor Bush had conferred on him. The nomination now goes to the Senate where a simple majority is required for confirmation. Souter was appointed by Bush earlier this year to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.
