Previously, he was a member of the New Hampshire State Supreme Court, appointed to that post in 1983 by then-Gov. John Sununu, now Bush's chief of staff. Souter succeeded Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., as the state's attorney general. Brennan, 84, one of the most liberal members of an increasingly conservative court and one of the most influential justices of the 20th century, told Bush on Friday that he was resigning because of declining health. He had served on the high court for 34 years. He was appointed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Brennan's health started to deteriorate in the last year. He recently fell at the Newark International Airport and struck his head, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said, and after consulting with his doctors he decided to step down. Bush acted with unusual speed in making his choice. He met twice over the weekend with his top lieutenants and called the Democratic and Republican leaders of Congress to seek advice. Bush noted that Souter had won unanimous confirmation to the appellate bench earlier this year, suggesting his hopes that the nomination might not trigger a political free-for-all in the Senate. ``We're not bracing for some horrendous fight with the United States Senate,'' Bush said. ``I look forward to a fair and expeditious confirmation process.'' Bush was asked if he knows Souter's views on abortion or other difficult issues. Bush said he felt it would have been ``inappropriate'' and that he did not ask him his views on any specific issues. ``Judge Souter is committed to interpreting, not making, the law,'' Bush said. ``I have selected a person who will interpret the Constitution and in my view not legislate'' from the bench, Bush said. A questioner noted that Bush and Sununu both have widely known views against abortion and asked why people shouldn't think that Souter's abortion view was known to Bush through research or some other method. ``I told you it's not,'' Bush said. ``Most of his writings have been at the state level,'' Bush said of Souter's judicial record, indicating that his views on such tough federal issues as affirmative action or free speech might not be well developed. In a 1986 case before the New Hampshire Supreme Court, Souter ruled with the majority that doctors have a responsibility to test for birth defects and inform pregnant women of the option of abortion. ``We recognize that the termination of pregnancy involves controversial and divisive social issues,'' said the opinion. ``Nonetheless, the Supreme Court of the United States has held that a woman has a constitutionally secured right to terminate a pregnancy.'' In a concurring opinion, Souter questioned the impact the decision would have on doctors who didn't support abortion. ``The court does not hold that some or all physicians must make a choice between rendering services that they morally condemn and leaving their profession in order to escape malpractice exposures,'' he wrote. Bush brushed off a question about the possibility of a liberal-vs-conservative confirmation battle, saying, ``I don't control the Senate.'' He said he did not view the Brennan vacancy _ or the prospect of replacing others among the elderly cast on the nine-member court _ as an opportunity to put ``some personal Bush imprint'' on the court. ``I'm not interested in having this known as a Bush court,'' the president said. Bush said the process of screening candidates for a potential vacancy had been going on for some time, but not with Brennan in mind. He said White House counsel Boyden Gray had played a key role in the preliminary research and at one point he denied that Sununu had played an undue role in the process that ended with Souter's selection. ``It's a process that has been going on for some time and the excellence was just there,'' Bush said.
Here is the text of President Bush's announcement Monday of his intention to nominate David Souter to the Supreme Court.

My oath to the Constitution charges me to faithfully execute the Office of President, and to the best of my ability preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States. Few duties are more important in discharging that obligation than my responsibility under Article 2, Section 2 of our Constitution to select from among all possible choices one nominee to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court of the United States. The task of narrowing the selection to one highly qualified jurist committed to the rule of law and faithful to the Constitution could never be easy, but I have found it enormous _ enormously satisfying. My choice will serve the Court and the Constitution well. I am most pleased to announce that I will nominate as associate justice of the United States Supreme Court a remarkable judge of keen intellect and the highest ability, one whose scholarly commitment to the law and whose wealth of experience mark him of first rank _ Judge David Souter of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judge Souter, I believe with all my heart, will prove a most worthy member of the court. His tenure as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the state of New Hampshire, as attorney general of that state, and more recently as a federal appeals judge, unquestionably demonstrates his ability, his integrity, and his dedication to public service. And he has a keen appreciation of the proper judicial role rooted in fundamental belief and separation of powers and the democratic principles underlying our great system of government. Let me pay tribute, too, to the justice whose retirement from the court created the vacancy, Justice William Brennan. His powerful intellect, his winning personality, and importantly his commitment to civil discourse on emotional issues that at times tempt uncivil voices have made him one of the greatest figures of our age. No one can question his dedication to the nation and the energy that he has brought to his high office. His retirement is marked by the dignity and honor that characterized his 34 years of service on the bench. And I told him the other day when I talked to him of the respect that Mrs. Bush and I have for him for his wonderful service. In choosing to nominate Judge Souter, who like Justice Brennan is largely a product of the state court system, I have looked for the same dedication to public service and strength of intellect exemplified by Justice Brennan. My selection process was not geared simply to any legal issue. It is not appropriate in choosing a Supreme Court justice to use any litmus test. And I want a justice who will ably and fairly interpret the law across the range of issues the Court faces. Our country serves as a model for the world at a time of special significance, and I stressed within the White House to the attorney general that our process could not be dominated by politics or special interests. And I believe that we've set a good example of selecting a fair arbiter of the law. Judge Souter will bring to the Court a wealth of judicial experience on the Supreme Court of his state and, before that, as a state trial court judge. Prior to his appointment to the state bench, he was attorney general of the state of New Hampshire. Judge Souter is a graduate of the Harvard Law School, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Harvard College. He was also a Rhodes Scholar. My respect for his outstanding record led me earlier this year to nominate him to his present position on the court of appeals. The Senate unanimously confirmed him to that position because of his exceptional qualities and his experience. His opinions reflect a clean intellect _ keen intellect as well as wise balance between the theoretical and practical aspects of the law. Judge Souter committed to interpreting, not making the law. He recognizes the proper role of judges in upholding the democratic choices of the people through their elected representatives with constitutional constraints. Judge Brennan's retirement took effect last Friday. The Court is now reduced to eight members. It is important to restore the bench to full strength by the first Monday in October when the Court begins its 1990 term. I look forward to presenting Judge Souter's nomination to the Senate as quickly as possible, and I look forward as well to a fair and expeditious confirmation process.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Asks Supreme Soviet to Condemn 1956 Uprising
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Monday urged the Soviet Union to condemn and declare illegal the Soviet military intervention that quashed the 1956 anti-Stalinist uprising, the state MTI news agency reported. In a resolution addressed to Soviet lawmakers, Hungarian deputies said the ``military intervention in 1956 was a violation of (Hungary's) sovereignty and a grave crime against the Hungarian people.'' ``The Hungarian National Assembly calls on the Supreme Soviet (parliament) to adopt a resolution declaring illegal the 1956 Soviet intervention in Hungary similar to its reassessment of the August 1968 events in Czechoslovakia.'' The 1968 Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion in Czechoslovakia crushed the ``Prague Spring'' reform movement. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze has criticized the intervention. ``Such a move would strengthen the Soviet Union's commitment to respect the sovereignty and independence of the Hungarian republic and would contribute to the creation of genuine friendship between our peoples,'' the resolution said. In a reversal of official policy, Hungary last year rehabilitated former Premier Imre Nagy who led the failed anti-Stalinist uprising. Nagy's remains were formally reburied at an officially-sanctioned ceremony in the same plot where his body and those of his associates were dumped by Moscow-subservient Communists in unmarked graves in 1958. The revolt broke out Oct. 23 with mass demonstrations for political reforms and demands that Soviet troops leave Hungary. Soviet troops and tanks struck at Budapest on Nov. 4, 1956, to end the uprising. Official figures put the dead at 5,000 to 6,000, but according to Western estimates up to 32,000 people died.

DOC.HEAD: Paraguay's Foreign Minister Fired for Political Comments
DOC.TEXT: President Andres Rodriguez fired Foreign Minister Luis Maria Argana on Monday after Argana set off a political uproar by saying he was ready to go to extremes if it meant keeping the Colorado Party in power. Argana, 57, the interim party president, announced his dismissal himself. He told a news conference Gen. Rodriguez ``asked that I leave the foreign minister's post and dedicate myself totally to the Colorado Party. ... So I am leaving the post immediately.'' He had been foreign minister since Feb. 3, 1989, the day Rodriguez ousted the 34-year regime of former President Alfredo Stroessner in a violent coup. Argana, who was closely associated with the Stroessner regime, said comments he made last Friday ``were badly interpreted, but that is normal in politics.'' ``I said that we (the Colorado Party) would be willing to conspire and to make a revolution as a reply to a threat issued last May by leaders of the Authentic Radical Liberal Party,'' he said. He accused that party's leaders of saying at a party meeting that ``it will be necessary to use clubs to knock the Colorados from power.'' The Authentic Radical Liberals are Paraguay's largest opposition party. Banned under Stroessner, it was recognized by the Rodriguez government and is organizing an effort to win scheduled 1991 municipal elections and national elections set for 1993. The Colorado Party, in power since 1947, supported Gen. Stroessner. It now is split into factions, including an ``orthodox'' group led by Argana and containing many people who allied themselves with Stroessner, and a ``democratic'' group that favors party democratization.

DOC.HEAD: City Employee Says He, Not Barry, Got Job Application
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with testimony that job application went to city employee, not Barry, at time of alleged crack deal. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Barry was ...'
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry's lawyers Monday attacked the credibility of an admitted cocaine dealer who said she delivered crack to the mayor at a municipal office in 1988. Barry's lawyers said at his cocaine and perjury trial that the mayor has an alibi for the time of the alleged delivery Sept. 7, 1988. Prosecutors contend Barry's alibi is non-existent. Testifying for the defense, city employee Clifton Roberson said he accepted a job application from Lydia Pearson on Sept. 7, 1988. Pearson testified earlier in Barry's trial that she handed the mayor ``crack cocaine. ... He gave me the money for it. ... I gave him'' the job application. Roberson, who works for mayoral aide Anita Bonds, said Pearson came to the office on Sept. 7, 1988, and was annoyed that neither Barry nor Bonds was there. Roberson said he accepted the job application from Pearson, who then left. Roberson said on cross-examination by prosecutors that he had no idea whether Pearson might have met with Barry after leaving the office. Earlier, defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy suggested that the mayor has an alibi for the time the government alleges Pearson was bringing him crack cocaine. A former city aide and the city fire chief testified that the mayor was addressing problems involving ambulance service in the District of Columbia on the morning of Sept. 7, 1988. The building where the crack delivery allegedly occurred is about five blocks from fire department headquarters where the meeting on ambulance problems was held. Barry was in the scheduled 10 a.m. meeting until nearly noon that day, Joseph Yeldell, former director of the office of emergency preparedness, said under questioning from Mundy. But Barry was late to the meeting, Yeldell said. How late, asked Mundy. ``I can't be specific,'' said Yeldell, but ``a slight delay of the meeting'' resulted from Barry's tardiness. Fire chief Ray Alfred said he was uncertain whether Barry got to the meeting on time. Yeldell said Barry was in the meeting for as much as an hour and 20 minutes. Alfred said Barry spoke for about an hour, possibly an hour and a half. The meeting is videotaped and a clock on the wall shows that Barry left the room eight or nine minutes before noon, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin. The clock isn't visible when Barry walks in, she indicated. In the videotape, Barry apologizes for being late and says he has been delayed by the opening of a new supermarket, said Retchin. She said prosecutors plan to show the videotape in its rebuttal case after Mundy concludes the defense case. Pearson's testimony for Sept. 7, 1988, forms the basis for one of 10 cocaine possession charges to which Barry has pleaded innocent. Barry also has pleaded innocent to one count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Modified Versions Of Banned Weapons May Be Allowed In U.S.
DOC.NOTE: EDs: RECASTS lead, INSERTS 1 graf after 13th graf pvs bgng, `The industry,' to UPDATE with Metzenbaum quote; CORRECTS spelling of Sugarmann throughout
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has told manufacturers of six semiautomatic assault-style rifles banned from import last summer that new, revised versions of the weapons conform to U.S. laws, officials said Monday. ``We have approved prototypes and said, `If you manufacture this weapon for import, it would be approved,''' said Jack Killorin, spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. The bureau was not immediately aware of whether the manufacturers or importers of such weapons as the Uzi carbine and the AK-47 had sought permits to bring in any of the new weapons, he said. Since the new designs lack the military-style hardware of the banned weapons, gun fanciers may not want them and the manufacturers may decide not to bother producing them, he said. ``They have to ask whether what we're asking for is a marketable item,'' Killorin said. The Bush administration last summer banned from import 43 types of semiautomatic assault-style rifles. That ban followed an outcry over the January 1989 slayings of five elementary school children in Stockton, Calif., by a transient wielding an AK-47. In addition, law enforcement officials had complained that the weapons were extremely popular among drug dealers. The ATF justified the ban by saying the weapons did not meet the legal requirement that imported rifles be suitable for sporting purposes. The banned guns had such military-style characteristics as threaded barrels for silencers; flash suppressors that could hide the shooter's position at night; bayonet lugs; folding or collapsible stocks; pistol grips; and large capacity ammunition magazines. Receiving approval for new versions of banned weapons were the makers of the Uzi carbine, AK-47, Galil, HK-91, SAR-8, and SAR-4800, according to documents obtained by the Firearms Policy Project through the Freedom of Information Act. The Washington Post reported on the issue in Monday's editions. Killorin said the proposed weapons have different designs as well as numerical designations. ``The prototypes that we're looking at are weapons that have none of the accoutrements, not even the pistol grip,'' Killorin said. ``The bottom line is, if the firearms conform to the changes required, without bayonet lugs, without flash suppressors, night sites, pistol grips and large-capacity detachable magazines, then we're talking about a weapon consistent with semiautomatic sporting weapons.'' Under the regulations, ATF must approve the weapons, he said. But a Firearms Policy Project official responded, ``Although these weapons may look less threatening, they are no less deadly'' than those banned from import last year. ``The industry knows this, ATF knows this and criminals know this,'' Josh Sugarmann said. And Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said, ``We are either going to keep these weapons of war off our streets or we are not. This is no area for halfhearted nonsense.'' Although the new designs do not include pistol grips _ which give the shooter control while firing from the hip or while firing one-handed _ some have a thumb hole in the stock, which Sugarmann said can serve as a pistol grip. In addition, Sugarmann said, the rifles still can accept large-capacity magazines even if they are fitted with limited capacity magazines. That is true of every firearm that accepts a detachable magazine, according to Killorin. An administration official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said purchasers of the new-style weapons could adapt them to add the prohibited features. He said such features would be prohibited by federal law under a crime bill now pending in Congress. ``We look forward to signing that crime bill,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Killorin said the ATF has rejected prototypes submitted by three manufacturers of banned guns.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: confirmation process.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Did you ask Judge Souter his views on abortion? Do you know what his views are? And affirmative action? All of these things that have become so controversial, the major issues of the day? Bush: No. And I had one meeting with Judge Souter. I was very impressed but, in my view, it would have been inappropriate to ask him his views on specific issues. This process has been going on, this selection process, not with any specific seat in mind, but just being prepared for a long, long time. Judge Souter was considered for the High Court back when Mr. Justice Kennedy was selected. And so there's a lot _ and then, of course, his name was very much in the forefront when he was nominated and subsequently confirmed for the Appeals Court. So I am familiar with him, with his, his general views, but I did not and would not, as I think I've said before when I talked about _ not just here, but other times _ the litmus test approach. I wouldn't go into that with him. Q: Does that mean you do not care what he thinks on the ... Bush: It means that I have selected a person who will interpret the Constitution and, in my view, not legislate from the federal bench. Q: Mr. President, barely three days have passed since you learned of Justice Brennan's resignation. Why did you move so quickly on this appointment? And you also called the leaders of Congress, and others, over the weekend for their advice. When did you come to the choice of Justice Souter? Bush: I came to the choice this afternoon and wanted to _ I think I told the leaders that I talked to over the weekend that I wanted to move very fast. As I said, this isn't precipitous in the sense that we just started looking for names last Saturday. I remember meeting with the Attorney General and Boyden Gray, perhaps within the first month I was President _ at least the first two months. And I've had a couple of meetings with them, and they've been in discussion with each other for a long time on this. And so just the prudence would dictate that one be prepared lest there be a vacancy. So we've been talking about who I might want to appoint for a long time. Q: Sir, if I could follow up, you're not certain in your own mind how Justice Souter will vote if Roe v. Wade comes before the Court next term? Bush: What I'm certain of is that he will interpret the Constitution and not legislate from the federal bench. Yes? Q: But, Mr. President, I believe Judge Souter is about 50 years old, and many of the candidates you considered were younger than the current justices. What kind of lasting legacy do you want to leave on the Supreme Court? Do you expect this to be a long-term shifting of the center of balance for the Court? Bush: I'm not looking _ he's in good health. I was looking over there to see how he's looking at 50 _ but he seems to be in very vigorous health, and I would expect he'd serve a long term on the bench. And I'm not viewing this as some personal ``Bush imprint'' on the Court. I have pledged to get, to seek out excellence, and I've pledged to look for somebody who would interpret the Constitution, and I'm satisfied I've found the very best in that regard. Q: Do you expect the Court would shift to the right philosophically? Bush: I haven't put it in terms of shifting left or right. I read a great deal of speculation about all that, but all I'm saying is that we've got a nominee here who is extraordinarily intelligent, has a record, has been confirmed by the Senate, and who has satisfied inquiry at the state and federal level as to his objectivity and as to his judicial philosophy. And I am satisfied as to all those counts. Q: Mr. President, as you know, the whole issue of abortion has _ over this choice is major ... Do you know if this judge has written on this issue? Has _ is he _ does he have a record on this issue that either side can point to to make it an even bigger issue? Or is he _ is it unknown and therefore more difficult to get at? Bush: In the first place, I think it would be inappropriate, although I'll let him make up his own mind for Justice Souter to make any comments on any specific issue. Out of the respect for the Senate, I would urge that he not do that. Any specific questions on specific issues should be addressed in an orderly confirmation process by the Senate. But, beyond that, Leslye, I _ you know, I think what I said earlier responds to your question. Q: No, I _ you said you hadn't asked him, but I wonder if he has a record, if ... Bush: Well, I don't know about that. I didn't consider that, as I thought I made clear. Yeah, Jerry? And then ... Q: Mr. President, since you concluded that it's inappropriate to ask about a specific case like Roe versus Wade, do you also therefore consider it to be inappropriate for the Senate committee that'll do the confirmation to ask about a specific case like that? Bush: I would let the Senate do whatever they want. They're a separate and independent body of the _ of our government, and there are certain precedents for how they approach these issues, but I'm _ listen, I've got enough problems down here without trying to tell the Senate how to conduct its confirmation hearing. I've been handed a protocol note. Marlin Fitzwater, who's not known for his protocol, but I _ he says it would be most appropriate to let Judge Souter respond at this juncture. So, with your permission, we'll proceed. Judge Souter: Thank you, Mr. President. I'm really not sure how to do that. If it were possible for me to express to you the realization that I have of the honor which the President has just done me, I would try and I would keep you here as long tonight as I had to do to get it out. But I could not express that realization and I'm not going to try to do the impossible. Beyond that, I hope you will understand that I think I must defer any further comments of mine until I am before the Senate in the confirmation process.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Flee Fighting Between Rival Shiite Factions
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem forces on Monday reinforced their front lines around a strategic mountain-top town in southern Lebanon, as thousands of civilians took advantage of a lull in the fighting to flee. Police reported a marked decrease in fighting between fighters of the pro-Iranian fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal militia. The lull occurred as the battle between the rival Shiite factions for control of the strategic town of Jarjou and nearby villages close to Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon entered its second week. Police said a Syrian combatant was killed and two Amal militiamen were wounded in daylong, sporadic exchanges of artillery and sniper fire. The dead fighter was identified by police as a Syrian who belonged to the Damascus-based Arab Baath Socialist Party. About 200 Baathists and a symbolic force of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party have been fighting alongside the Amal militia. Israeli jets made repeated reconnaissance flights Monday over southern Lebanon to monitor the Shiite fighting, police said. Monday's casualties raised the toll to 126 people killed and 369 wounded since the Shiite fighting broke out anew on July 16. The fighting began when Hezbollah attacked and seized Jarjou from Amal in an effort to expand its area of control toward the Mediterranean and open up a badly needed sea route to Iran, its main supplier of arms. It was the latest round of fighting in a 3-year-old intermittent conflict between Amal and Hezbollah for mastery of the country's 1.2 million Shiite Moslems, who make up Lebanon's largest sect. At least 1,167 people have been killed and 4,011 wounded in the inconclusive power struggle, by police count. Police said Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas, stationed between the Amal and Hezbollah forces in the disputed region, occupied four new hilltop positions west of Jarjou on Sunday. ``The Palestinian force is now capable of preventing any advance from either side against each other,'' said Lt. Col. Anwar Madi, commander of the PLO intervention force, as he inspected his positions around Jarjou Monday. PLO fighters, mainly from Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction, have been trying to stop the fighting between the two Shiite groups, apparently to halt the Hezbollah advance toward Sidon, a southern port where Palestinian guerrillas are based. It is 10 miles northwest of Jarjou. Amal and PLO guerrillas fought a three-year war in Lebanon between 1985 and 1988, but have joined together in attacks aimed at driving the Hezbollah forces out of Jarjou. Police said Amal rushed in 1,000 more militiamen with dozens of truckloads of ammunition to its positions around Jarjou over the weekend. Amal already had about 6,500 front-line fighters in Iqlim al-Tuffah, or the Apple Province, where the fighting is raging. Hezbollah set up several additional artillery and mortar batteries in Jarjou, police said. The fundamentalist group has fielded at least 2,000 fighters in the province. The reinforcements caused panic among the region's remaining 25,000 inhabitants who fear the fighting might intensify. Long lines of fleeing villagers trudged through the rugged hills, carrying their household belongings under their arms and on their heads. Most of them sought refuge in southern Lebanon's major cities of Sidon, Tyre and Nabatiyeh. Others fled to open fields, sleeping at night in cars.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communist Leader's Ashes Buried
DOC.TEXT: About 150,000 people took part in a funeral procession Monday to pay their respects to former Bulgarian Communist leader Georgi Dimitrov, whose remains were removed from his mausoleum last week. The remains of Dimitrov, revered as national hero during four decades of Communist rule, were cremated after being transferred from the mausoleum in downtown Sofia. Both the opposition and some members of the ruling Socialist Party had called for removing Dimitrov's remains and converting the mausoleum to other uses. Critics argue the mausoleum is a relic of the past out of step with the country's recent push toward democracy. The mostly elderly crowd _ many of whom had come from the countryside _ walked about three miles in the funeral procession from a square in front of Alexander Nevski Cathedral to Sofia's central cemetery, where a memorial ceremony was held. The observances were organized by the Socialists, the reform party created from the old Communist Party. As the funeral procession passed through the streets of the capital, some young people on the sidewalks whistled in apparent disapproval. No incidents were reported. Addressing the crowd at the funeral ceremony, Alexander Lilov, the Socialist Party leader, appealed to party members to close their ranks ``on the way to radical renewal and reform.'' ``Let's transform the Bulgarian Socialist Party into a model of a modern left-wing party,'' Lilov said. Lilov said the removal of Dimitrov's remains and their burial at a public cemetery did not represent any major historical revision regarding the country's first Communist leader, the state BTA news agency reported. ``He is still considered a political figure of enormous national and international prestige ... (but) he was not faultless ... and made some mistakes,'' Lilov said. Also attending the ceremony were other senior Socialist Party officials, including Premier Andrei Lukanov and former president Petar Mladenov who resigned earlier this month. The urn with Dimitrov's ashes will be buried in a family grave in a private ceremony for relatives later this week, a BTA official said. A leading figure in the international Communist movement, Dimitrov was acquitted in a trial in late 1933 in which he was charged with complicity in the fire that destroyed the German Reichstag (Parliament) building. Historians say that the arson was a Nazi provocation. In 1946, Dimitrov became leader of the Bulgarian Communist Party and also headed the government until his death in 1949. During his leadership, the non-Communist opposition parties were either disbanded or merged in a Communist-dominated mass organization. The disinterment of Dimitrov marks another step away from four decades of orthodox Communist rule since the ouster of Communist leader Todor Zhivkov in November. Despite longtime official veneration, Dimitrov has become increasingly unpopular, particularly in Sofia, where the non-Communist opposition Union of Democratic Forces emerged as the winner in last month's multiparty elections. The Socialists won a majority in the Parliament due to a strong showing in the countryside and provincial cities. A commission appointed by Sofia's municipal council will propose possible new uses for the former mausoleum, a massive stone building constructed in one week after Dimitrov's death. In the past, the mausoleum was a major attraction in Sofia, much like Lenin's tomb in Moscow. The mausoleum was guarded around the clock by two soldiers in traditional Balkan-style dress uniform, equipped with bayonet-topped rifles.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: confirmation process.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Conservatives recently have expressed some disappointment with your _ what they call the flip-flop on ``no new tax'' pledge, your position on China, Lithuania, and the like. And Governor Sununu is recognized as the champion of the conservatives in the White House. Is his connection _ is the Judge's connection to Governor Sununu, is this meant as an appeasement to the conservative right? Do you think it will appease them? Bush: Sununu's got problems with his own credentials. I mean, he's not going to help on that. And that's not what this is all about. This matter, as I've indicated, was _ there was almost a certain recusal on the part of Governor Sununu on this. Clearly, he knows Judge Souter. He has great respect for Judge Souter. But this process, as I'm sure Boyden Gray and Dick Thornburgh will tell you, came up through a system. Excellence came to the top. And, so, there is no politics of this nature in this kind of a _ this kind of an appointment. If I was looking to shore up one factor or another, there'd be plenty of more visible ways to do it. Here, we are talking about excellence, judicial excellence, and the highest degree of qualification, based on excellence, to be on the Court. Q: Mr. President, earlier today, Marlin Fitzwater said that whomever you chose as your candidate, your nominee, would reflect your general philosophy of government. Is it still your philosophy that Roe vs. Wade, the abortion law, should be overturned? Bush: Look, you all can keep trying all day long to get me to comment on abortion in relation to this nomination. And please keep _ stop trying because I'm not going to respond in that vein. It would be unfair to Judge Souter. It would be untrue because I haven't looked at the nomination in that manner. And so, I simply cannot _ and you get another question though, instead. Q: Well, my other question would simply be, just not respond in the connection with Judge Souter. How about just your own personal philosophy? Bush: I haven't changed my views, if that helps any. Q: Mr. President, I'm still not totally certain by why you feel it was inappropriate to ask the Judge's views on the issues _ Bush: Because that's _ I understand that's the customary way of doing it, and that more important are the broad concepts of excellence. Is the man qualified? Does he share a broad view that what he ought to do on the bench is interpret the Constitution and not legislate. And so that's all I need. And when you see the background of this man, I'm confident the Senate will share my views. You're looking for fairness. You're looking for equity. I wrote down a bunch of words to help me make the determination, and I wish I had them because they're all along that _ those lines. Experience. And I did say that I'd like somebody that will interpret the Constitution, not legislate. Q: But can you even be sure of that, sir? Does that mean that you've at least studied some of his rulings? Bush: There has been a great deal of work done in the Justice Department at several levels, in our General Counsel's shop, on all that kind of thing. But again, it would be inappropriate to go into those cases that he may have ruled on when he was on the state court or on the federal bench, and I would simply leave that to the Senate. But, yes, there has been a thorough study of Judge Souter's tremendously impressive record. Q: Mr. President, given the reality of getting a person confirmed to the Supreme Court these days, are you braced for a big battle? Bush: Well, I don't _ I'm not going into this nomination, or thrusting Judge Souter into the nomination, expecting a highly contentious battle. The man was confirmed by the Senate, unanimously, and _ after testimony. So, I'm not suggesting there's going to have to be or should be. I remember calmer days when there weren't. So I would not anticipate a contentious battle. I would anticipate thorough questioning. I would anticipate each Senator, having enough information to make up his or her mind, based on the record or responses to questions. But, no, I'm not _ we're not bracing for some horrendous fight with the United States Senate, and given his record, I would expect that the chances of that are minimal.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Welcomes Cameroon Prisoner Release
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Monday welcomed an announcement by Cameroon President Paul Biya that all political prisoners in his central African country would be released soon. But the human rights group noted Cameroon continues to imprison people for their political beliefs. No exact date was announced for the release. In a statement, Amnesty noted Biya's government frequently holds people in administrative detention without charge or trial, tries them unfairly before military tribunals or keeps them in jail after they have been acquitted or completed their prison terms. Abdoulaye Mazou, for example, was convicted in 1984 to a five-year term for his involvement in an unsuccessful coup attempt, the London-based group said. The former lawyer and magistrate was considered a prisoner of conscience when he was held in administrative detention for a year after he had completed his sentence. Even after his release in April, Mazou has been confined to his home, Amnesty said. The Nobel Peace Prize-winning group noted many of the more than 100 political prisoners held since 1984 in connection with the attempted coup remain in detention despite the president's promise in April that they would be released. Among those held are former transport company official Paul Daissala Dakole and Habouba Mousse, an airline employee. Former President Ahmadou Ahidjo turned over power to Biya in 1982 after 22 years in power. Though the transfer came about peacefully, the two men later had a falling-out. On April 6, 1984, a faction of the elite Republican Guard loyal to Ahidjo tried to topple Biya. Fighting raged around Yaounde for two days before the rebels were suppressed by loyal troops. Official estimates say 70 died, but observers said as many as 1,000 were killed. At least 46 of the arrested plotters were later executed. Ahidjo, who was in retirement in France, was tried in absentia and condemned to death. Biya later lifted the sentence. Amnesty noted that despite Biya's statements on the release of political prisoners two men recently were jailed after trying to set up a political party in the one-party state. Former bar association president Yondo Mandengue Black and Anicet Ekane, a company director, were sentenced to 3- and 4-year prison terms in April by a special military court, the rights group said. The two were imprisoned for attending meetings to discuss multiparty democracy and setting up a new political party. Amnesty on Monday called for the release of the men they said were prisoners of conscience. Two others, Nicole Ngakou and her brother, George Yopa, were acquitted on charges of distributing subversive material in 1987 but continue to be held in administrative detention without charge or trial. The Amnesty statement also cited the case of Djeukam Tchameni Dominique, who was sentenced by a military court earlier this year to three years in prison for bringing into the country an audiocassette containing criticism of the government. Amnesty said it welcomed Biya's statement that he was ready to allow the group to visit Cameroon and meet with government officials.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin Vows to Help Kill B-2 Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 10th graf pvs, House Speaker, with comment from Air Force chief of staff; inserts 3 grafs after 11th graf pvs, Although the, with Nunn warning on possible B-2 demise without strong administration lobbying. Informatively, Aspin may deliver speech by 8 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said Monday he'll join an effort to kill the B-2 bomber, dealing a serious blow to President Bush's effort to build the stealth aircraft. ``If the threats we face internationally were greater and the deficits we face at home were smaller, we might continue to hedge on the B-2. But they aren't and we can't,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., told reporters prior to his planned speech on the House floor announcing his decision. Aspin's announcement comes on the eve of his committee's crafting later this week of a $283 billion defense bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and is certain to give impetus to House efforts to cancel the B-2 program. Legislation sponsored by three members of the Armed Services panel _ Reps. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., John Rowland, R-Conn., and John Kasich, R-Ohio, _ would terminate the program at the 15 planes in development. Proponents said they have the 218 votes necessary in the House to kill the B-2, and Dellums predicted that with Aspin's support the campaign to terminate the program will prevail in the Senate as well. ``The more American people see and learn about this weapon system the less support there is,'' Dellums said at a news conference. ``So I'm going to stick my neck out and say this is the year that we stop the B-2 bomber.'' Kasich heralded victory in the House but declined to forecast success when lawmakers craft a final defense bill. ``This seals the fate for the B-2, certainly for the House,'' said Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., who has lobbied against the bomber program, in which the government has invested more than $26 billion, and has kept a tally on the number of opponents. In his speech, a copy of which was made available to reporters, Aspin vowed to work with the B-2 opponents and congratulated them ``on their impending success.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Aspin's announcement ``will be a very influential statement and it will have a major impact in Congress with respect to the B-2.'' The Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Michael J. Dugan, told reporters at the Pentagon that Aspin's ``voice carries some extra weight, and we'd hoped that we wouldn't have to fight that extra weight.'' Dugan vowed that the service would step up its lobbying in the House for the bat-winged aircraft and said that killing the program would ``send a message to friend and foe alike that the United States has lost its stomach'' for defense. ``It is, in my view, criminal to shut it off at this point,'' Dugan said. Although the House may kill the program, support for the bomber in the Senate remains with the Armed Services' powerful chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., backing the aircraft. But even Nunn, who reiterated his support for the bomber, said the B-2 faces problems in Congress and Aspin's decision makes the fight to preserve the aircraft an ``uphill battle.'' ``I do not believe that the B-2 program can be preserved unless the president, the secretary of defense, the Joints Chiefs of Staff and our arms control negotiators all argue forcefully for the program,'' Nunn said in a statement. ``Without this support, the Senate Armed Services Committee position is unlikely to prevail.'' In approving its $289 billion defense bill, the Senate Armed Services Committee agreed to Bush's request for two planes in fiscal 1991. The full Senate is expected to consider the legislation later this month. A proponent of the B-2, Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., said a final decision on the bomber probably won't be made until the House and Senate meet later this year to iron out the differences in their two bills. But Skelton, whose district includes Whiteman Air Force Base where a B-2 unit will be based, urged that in the meantime, the Bush administration argue a better case for the bomber. ``I'm terribly disappointed by the lack of support by the administration,'' said Skelton, who contended that former President Reagan would have members of Congress to the White House to lobby for the bomber. ``I understand they will be inviting people down to the White House soon,'' he said. ``It may be a day late and a dollar short.'' Aspin, who last year opposed a bill to kill the B-2, said he based his latest decision on the cost of the bomber, its capabilities and its mission. In the final analysis, Aspin said he found no ``unique and compelling mission for the B-2.'' ``It has not been demonstrated that we must build the B-2 now,'' he said. ``If we press ahead, we will spend additional tens of billions of dollars before we know if the B-2 will work, and before we know if it is really necessary. And that's assuming that there would be room in the budget in the first place, which will be extremely hard to find.'' In his $307 billion military budget for fiscal 1991, Bush proposed spending $5.5 billion for five of the radar-evading aircraft and related items. But in April, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney cited the lessening Soviet threat and fiscal constraints as he presented his revised plan for the program _ two bombers in fiscal 1991 at a cost of $4.6 billion and 75 planes total with a price tag of $63 billion. The Pentagon originally envisioned building 132 planes. Despite Cheney's revision, support for the bomber continued to erode in Congress, where lawmakers expressed dismay over the cost of a single plane, which under the scaled back plan rose to $815 million. Since Cheney's announcement, the Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the bomber, which is manufactured by Northrop Corp., will likely cost $865 million apiece and the total program might rise to $65 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Sailor Accused of Raping Enlisted Woman Remains In Jail
DOC.TEXT: A sailor accused of raping an enlisted woman aboard the submarine tender USS Holland remained jailed Monday pending a Navy investigation, an official said. The assault allegedly occurred July 14 while the ship was docked here, its home port, said Lt. Cmdr. Drew Malcolm, spokesman at the Charleston Navy Base. The suspect, a petty officer third class, could remain in a Navy jail for up to 90 days before charges are filed, Malcolm said. A magistrate's hearing Friday determined there was enough evidence to keep him jailed, Malcolm said. The victim, a junior enlisted woman, is on temporary leave, Malcolm said. The allegations came one day before the court-martial in another case involving the alleged rape three months ago of a female officer, allegedly by another officer, aboard an ammunition supply ship in the Mediterranean. The USS Holland spends most of its time in port here. The ship has a total crew of 1,293, including 338 women, four of whom are officers.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: are minimal.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Do you think a President these days has to do more of a selling job than in the past? Bush: I don't know, Maureen. I don't think so, if the record speaks for itself. If I'd have selected somebody out of the political arena that had never been on the bench and never had any experience but was in my view well qualified, there might well have been more intervention on my part. I'm prepared to do whatever is appropriate in not only defending but advocating this confirmation, but I don't believe there's going to be a lot of personal involvement necessary because I think his record and his standing will speak for itself. Yes? Q: Mr. President, I've got to make one more try. You say it's inappropriate to ask, but you also admit there is a lot of background paperwork on someone. Judge Souter was appointed to the New Hampshire court by Governor Sununu, whose feelings on abortion are well known. Your feelings on abortion are well known. Why should we not believe that that is a factor in your selection? Bush: Because I've told you it's not, and because you ought to listen to the testimony in the Hill, and then you can make up your mind better when you've seen the evidence. And that _ I expect people will be raising this question. I've seen a lot of speculation on it over the last 48 hours or whatever it was since Justice Brennan retired. But I'm telling you _ you asked me what my view was _ and I've told you how I approach this matter, and that's all I can do. Yes? Q: Mr. President, you said a moment ago that there are Senate precedents on how questioning happens in the Judiciary Committee. In fact, there are two very contrasting precedents. There was the Bork precedent, where the nominee answered all sorts of questions, and there was the Justice O'Connor-Justice Kennedy precedent, in which the nominee declined to answer a lot of specific questions about how the nominee felt. Do you have any preference about how your nominee handles these questions? Bush: No, but I have confidence my nominee will handle it properly, and he's _ look, the man is a judge on an appeals court. He knows how to treat with this, and the Senate is a free Senate, and they know how to treat with it. So that _ I'm not going to get into that. I think it's inappropriate for a President to do that kind of thing. Q: Do you think it's appropriate for a nominee to answer specific questions about how he might rule on _ Bush: I would leave that to the nominee, and let the Senate make the final determination. Yes? Q: Were there one or two aspects of the judge's background that _ qualifications that particularly brought him to the top of the list? Bush: Being bright, extraordinarily bright and then a record for fairness, extraordinarily fair. Well, I've made my judgment based _ you've asked me what I decided it on, and these are some of the qualifications that I think are essential. Plus I gave you the underpinning, which I want somebody that is not going to be a legislator sitting on the Supreme Court. Yeah? And then Ann. Q: Did you meet Judge Souter before you made this decision other than the last couple of days? Bush: Yes, just within the last couple of days. Q: _ the first time you've ever seen him? Bush: First time I'd met him. And who knows, the amount of time I spent in New Hampshire I might well have seen him. But I _ (laughter) we've been, as I have indicated, been talking to our attorney general and Boyden Gray on resumes, or on records for a long, long time. And the man is very highly regarded, so _ but I _ no, I just had a short visit with Judge Souter today and, obviously, was quite impressed. Yes, Ann? Q: You had already decided at that point, sir? Bush: No, I had not decided, and that's the truth _ as is everything else I said here. (Laughter.) Yeah, go ahead. Q: In _ in speaking to your advisors about resumes and records, as you say, did you ask your advisors to produce only nominees who had no extensive written record on the abortion issue _ Bush: No. Q: _ that _ (inaudible) _ more candidates who would not provoke a large debate over _ Bush: No. Yeah, Owen? Q: I wonder if you can you tell me, how is it possible to make the selection without reviewing the judge's record or a summary of his record that dealt with specific cases, if not abortion, affirmative action, civil rights issues, free speech _ a lot of the emotional issues that the country is very concerned about? Bush: Most of his writings have been at the state level and the _ the _ I made the decision based on the criteria that I gave you. Q: So you're telling us that you have no idea what his judicial opinions are on abortion, affirmative action and civil rights, flag burning? Bush: I'm telling you that you should stay tuned and let the testimony before the United States Senate determine whether he's confirmed or not, and that that will bring out all the questions that you're asking here. And the answers, that's up to the judge to see how he should handle that as one who is going to have to deal with a lot of issues in the future. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, has Governor Sununu, who is well acquainted with the nominee, given you his reading on the Judge's views on controversial issues? Bush: No, there's _ no. No. Way in the back. Q: (Inaudible). Q: Am I back far enough?

DOC.HEAD: German Unification Hits Biggest Roadblock: `Sleazy Politics'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf `The outcome' with four grafs to UPDATE with Social Democrats, Liberals refusing to attend coalition meeting, threatening pullout of government. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `It would...'
DOC.TEXT: The juggernaut of German unity suddenly has been stopped by what would appear to be a petty political clash, but which in fact could determine who runs the unified nation. Politicians in both Germanys were pointing fingers Monday while many Germans were shaking their heads over the seemingly trivial issue of whether unification should take place Dec. 1 or Dec. 2. German newspapers have derided the partisan slugfest as ``sleazy'' and ``pointless,'' especially because East Germans are struggling with mounting joblessness and soaring prices. In the past week, the issue has threatened to collapse the fragile coalition government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and laid bare intense, behind-the-scenes political maneuvering. On Monday night, the infighting intensified, when East Germany's Social Democrats and the centrist Liberals refused to take part in a meeting of coalition leaders. The two parties cited as their reason for not attending the meeting de Maiziere's insistence that unification cannot come before elections in both Germanys. Leaders of the two parties called separate meetings for Tuesday morning, saying they would recommend to their membership pulling out of de Maiziere's coalition government unless he compromises on the issue. The date of unification is considered important because it could help determine who will control the new German government, and which parties will not even have a voice. ``It would be decisive for the composition of the Parliament and the government,'' said Klaus Becher, a political analyst for the German Society for Foreign Politics in Bonn, West Germany. East Germany's left-leaning Social Democrats, the nation's second-largest party, and a Liberal alliance have demanded that unity occur a day before German elections, tentatively set for Dec. 2. They are demanding all of Germany act as a single electorate that chooses a united Parliament. De Maiziere and several smaller parties _ ranging from the former Communists to the activists who overthrew them _ want the two nations to formally unify immediately after elections are held. Under this proposal, simultaneous elections would be held in each nation. The votes would be counted separately and political representation would be based on how each party did in its own country. East Germany's Parliament already has passed a law requiring that a party receive 5 percent of the vote in order to be represented in Parliament, the same rule as in West Germany. Under de Maiziere's proposal, smaller parties in East Germany _ including the Communists _ would stand a better chance of winding up in the united Parliament. That would help the Christian Democratic parties of de Maiziere and especially his mentor, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who wants to lead a united Germany. The conservative Christian Democrats rely more on coalitions with conservative and centrist parties for parliamentary majorities. The Social Democrats, meanwhile, would be hurt by separate elections because a proliferation of small leftist parties could split the left-leaning representation in Parliament. The Social Democrats in West Germany are the main opposition party, but in East Germany they are a member of de Maiziere's broad, seven-party coalition government. The East German Social Democrats and the Liberal alliance have threatened to bolt the coalition _ and perhaps collapse the government _ unless single elections are held. East Germany's Parliament met until midnight Sunday trying to break the impasse, then finally agreed to throw the issue to committees of both German parliaments. On Monday, all the parties traded more charges. De Maiziere's chief spokesman, Matthias Gehler, said the prime minister planned to meet with Kohl this week in Austria, where Kohl is vacationing, to discuss the crisis. But time is a factor. Both Parliaments have left for their summer breaks and are not to return until the end of August. They must enact election laws by Sept. 3. ``It has become increasingly unlikely there will be all-German elections on the 2nd of December,'' Becher said. Virtually everyone involved in the debate has taken a drubbing in the press. ``This questionable, sleazy debate over trivialities throws a stumbling block in the path toward German unification,'' the Cologne Rundschau of Cologne, West Germany, said Monday. The Hagen, West Germany, newspaper Westfalenpost said: ``The wrangling over the coalition in East Berlin represents politics at its worst.'' The issue threatens not only the East German governing coalition, but Kohl's governing partnership, which is becoming increasingly divided on the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Support Millionaire Who Spray Paints Signs
DOC.TEXT: A millionaire facing criminal charges after he went around town defacing ``For Sale'' signs he said marred the landscape in tony Greenwich has become a folk hero among some residents, officials said. Town Planner Jim Sandy said he's received at least 35 letters supporting Rene Anselmo, 64, who was arrested July 3 for spray-painting a real estate sign Anselmo said was offensive and illegal. Anselmo pleaded innocent to a charge of third-degree criminal mischief. ``I'm getting letter after letter saying he should be knighted instead of cited,'' Sandy said last week. ``They love him.'' After his arrest, the 64-year-old president of Pan American Satellite Corp. said that real estate signs were ``turning all these streets into a used car lot.'' He said he spray-painted the sign because it had been illegally placed on town property and admitted he had painted others. ``The town should recognize your efforts to beautify and improve the quality of life, instead of charging you, of all people, with mischief,'' said one resident who wrote to Sandy. Said another: ``Bully for you! I have wanted to do that for years.'' Real estate agents, who are trying to sell houses in a slow market, are unhappy. Stanley Klein, president of Empire Realty Corp., called Anselmo's actions ``mindless vandalism.'' ``I was almost tempted to spray-paint Mr. Anselmo's gate,'' Klein said. Anselmo, a resident for 23 years, donated $40,000 to the town last year to plant trees and pays annually for the planting of flowers on town property. He faces a maximum penalty of a $1,000 fine and six months in prison if convicted. He is due back in Superior Court in Stamford Aug. 24.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON:far enough?
DOC.TEXT: Bush: One, two, three, and then I'm leaving. Q: I wonder if you could tell me, sir, you extolled the Judge's virtues and pointed out more than once that he was unanimously confirmed by the Senate for his present position, can you think of any reason, any possibility, the Senate would not confirm the Judge for this post _ Bush: No. Q: _ other than ideological grounds? Bush: I can think of none why they would not confirm him. None! Period. Q: And would you object strenuously to a confirmation battle over ideological grounds? Bush: Look, I've nothing to say about that. This is a separate body. I don't control the Senate. I would hope they would accept the _ when they've had a chance to ask questions and they've had a chance to review his record, would conclude, as I have, that he is outstandingly well-qualified for the federal bench, a judgment that was given to him not too long ago by the ABA itself. Well-qualified, which I gather is the highest rating a judge can have. Q: You had said you're not interested in making a Bush imprint on the Court. You may also be _ Bush: I have to, I guess, but I'm not interested in having this known as a Bush Court or something of that nature. Q: Well, you may be called upon throughout your term to actually name one or two others. Do you have those in mind? And also, if _ Bush: Yes. Q: By having those names in mind of who you would appoint, are you doing the same thing like in foreign policy, saying that you want to choose a prudent man or that the imprint would be something peculiar to you, in other words a _ Bush: Look, I'll tell you how I look at this, not in terms of some specific imprint, but I want it said when I'm about _ let's see, 66 _ about 90, 24 years from now, that I made a superb choice, and I think it will be so writ. Q: Mr. President, I'd like to ask you about the phrase you're using on you're opposed to somebody who would legislate from the bench. You're on record as wanting Roe vs. Wade overturned. You're on record as favoring a flag-burning amendment to the Constitution. Aren't those sorts of issues tantamount to legislating from the bench as well? Bush: Well, what _ you'd have to tell me the case and advise me as to how _ I don't think so. I don't think, when called upon to answer a constitutional question, that that has to be legislating from the bench. Q: But you would not be upset if the Court overturned Roe vs. Wade? Bush: No. Q: Or if the Court upheld the flag-burning amendment? Bush: No, and a lot of other things, too. I believe in the separation of powers. I happen to think that there's been a _ many, many things have troubled me, encroachment of micro-management by the United States Congress on the presidency. But I haven't asked this able judge about those things. But I could cite _ you cite two. You cite one that's been on everybody's lips ever since I _ since Justice Brennan retired. Listen, I never heard such coverage on the television. You might just think the whole nomination had something to do with abortion. And it's far broader than that. I have too much respect for the Supreme Court than to look at one specific issue and one alone. I've got time for one _ yeah, Kathy? Q: Mr. President, there's been some speculation you might name an Hispanic this time and make history in doing so. You went a different route. What do you say to those who might be disappointed that didn't happen, and what is the likelihood you might name an Hispanic should another vacancy develop? Bush: First, I say to whoever it is that inquires, I've made the best choice I possibly could make in terms of qualifications, ability, background, and temperament to serve on this court. And then I say: Look, the great thing about this country is you can achieve anything. And there's a lot of time down the road in which I'm sure you'll see a different makeup on the Court. But I don't _ I'm not going to deal in any one specific group, vis-a-vis another one. And that's what I would say. But I just would ask the American people to understand I looked at a wide array of names prior to my getting into it in as much depth as I have very recently. The Attorney General, his staff, Boyden Gray and his staff, went through this process. It's a continuance _ it's a process that's been going on for some time. And this _ the excellence was just there at the top. And so, I would not cite this as something discouraging for anybody that aspires to the Supreme Court or any group that would aspire to have representation on the Supreme Court. Listen, I really do have to go _ Q: What did you ask him when you interviewed him? Q: Did you interview the other finalists, Mr. President? Did he win in the interview? Bush: He did very, very well. Q: Two or three _ Bush: Yeah, let me get one _ I've been _ I failed to _ Q: Two or three of the candidates that were mentioned were from your home state and there was talk that you perhaps would choose somebody from the South because you felt the South was in under-representation since Justice Powell resigned. Wasn't anybody qualified in the South or why did you _ Bush: No, there's plenty of people qualified and you raise a good point because there aren't _ there is nobody from the _ what I would call the Southeast conference South, but the South, excluding Texas, that _ that is on the bench now. And there's about a quarter of the people from there. So, this is a consideration and was a consideration; it was forcefully brought home to me by key members of Congress. And yet I determined that Judge Souter, given the qualifications I've tried to extoll here, the virtues, is the choice for the federal _ for the Supreme Court at this time. But no, these calls are not easy. And Kathy asked about different ethnic groups. You asked about regional distribution. And I think one considers all these _ all these criteria. I think it's fair to say that New England, which is not represented on the bench now that Justice Brennan is retired, might look at it, if I had gone with another nominee, as why were they excluded? So, I can understand regionalism. But, please believe me, as a proud Texan, I tried to look at it on a _ in a national sense. And I think I've come up with the best nominee. Jesse, I'm sorry to disappoint you _ Q: A very quick follow-up, if I could. Senator Simpson suggested that you follow the counsel of Mrs. Bush. Did you in any way on this particular issue? Bush: How did he know? He doesn't even know who I nominated. How could he have said that? Q: He said that he hoped that that would be what you would do. Bush: Oh, I see. Wonderful fellow, Al.

DOC.HEAD: Two-term Secretary of State of San Marino Dead at 59
DOC.TEXT: Clara Boscaglia, secretary of state for finance and budget of the small republic of San Marino, died of lung cancer, her party said Monday. She was 59. Ms. Boscaglia, who had been in office 10 years, died Sunday after a lenghty illness, officials of the Christian Democrat party said. A day of national mourning has been called for Tuesday, the day of the funeral. Public offices will remain closed and flags are to fly at half-staff. San Marino is a hilltop republic of 23 square miles, surrounded by Italy near the Adriatic. The country has about 22,500 citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Says Test Shows Florida Chair is in Working Order
DOC.TEXT: A makeshift inmate _ made up of a metal colander to represent a human head, a vat of saline solution for the body and a piece of pipe as a leg _ was jolted with current in Florida's electric chair Monday. The experiment was a state-ordered test to show the chair works correctly and the botched execution of Jesse Tafero was probably caused by a synthetic sponge. ``The electric chair works as it is supposed to,'' said Mike Morse, an associate professor of electrical engineering at Auburn University and the electrical engineer who conducted the test. The test was carried out in the death chamber at Florida State Prison in front of journalists, state officials, representatives of the General Electric Co. and officials with corrections departments from Virginia and South Carolina. But lawyers who represent death-row inmates in Florida said they were unimpressed and would continue appeals based on arguments that the chair will torture the next inmate strapped into it. With the contraption sitting in the wooden electric chair, Morse conducted the 15-minute demonstration, which caused a noisy buzzing, to check whether the chair was functioning properly. The test was ordered by Gov. Bob Martinez after the botched May 4 electrocution of Tafero, who died amid smoke and flames. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has blocked several recent executions because of questions raised by defense attorneys about the chair's effectiveness. The governor said he is ``satisfied that this objective test by independent experts conclusively shows what we have been saying all along _ that Florida's electric chair is in working order. ...'' ``It is my sincere hope that defense attorneys will cease using this false argument as a basis for unsubstantiated appeals,'' he said. During Monday's test, the current was turned on and meters attached to the device showed that the chair was putting out 2,000 volts and 10 to 11 amps. ``It was a picture-perfect demonstration,'' Morse said. Defense attorneys contend the amount of electricty reaching Tafero wasn't enough to kill him instantly. The engineer said he had conducted similar tests over the weekend using the same kind of synthetic sponge used for the first time in the Tafero execution and had seen results similar to that controversial death. He said the sponge caused ``electrical arcing, flames and sparks.'' But Morse believes the jolt received by Tafero was still lethal. ``It is very unlikely after the initial shock that he felt any pain,'' Morse said. ``It would be highly unlikely that the brain would be functioning.'' State Rep. Ron Silver, a North Miami Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Criminal Justice, attended the test and said he hoped it would satisfy the circuit court. Martinez, who had earlier blamed the fire on the never-before-used synthetic sponge that won't be used again, said he ordered the tests to show the appeals judges that the chair is functioning. Defense attorneys for other death row inmates have successfully delayed several recent scheduled executions by arguing that Tafero was burned alive by low voltage and that present clients might suffer the same fate, a violation of the U.S. Constitution's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. ``I hope this demonstration and test will be satisfactory, and if it is not, we need to proceed from there to do what is necessary to carry out the laws of the state,'' Silver said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Court, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David Souter had a net worth of $621,252 on Dec. 31, 1989, according to financial records released Monday by the Senate Judiciary Committee. He listed no liabilities. Souter's largest asset was $191,000 in ``autos and other personal property,'' followed by $190,000 in securities and $150,000 in real estate. Cash on hand in banks totaled $46,323, ``other assets'' amounted to $38,342 and the cash value of life insurance was $5,586. Securities listed included shares in Flexwatt Corp., Rowan Companies, Inc. and Horizon Banks Inc. A house and land in Weare, N.H., was listed with a value of $150,000 and an individual retirement account was worth $18,342.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Reaction Wary on Souter Supreme Court Nomination
DOC.TEXT: Senators who will decide whether to confirm Judge David Souter's for the Supreme Court said Monday they want to learn more about his little-known track record before deciding whether to support him. The chief question, from many Democratic lawmakers and particularly interest groups in the debate over abortion, was Souter's views on abortion in general and on the landmark Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion in particular. Pro-choice groups, concerned the sudden Supreme Court vacancy could lead to the reversal of Roe vs. Wade, demanded that the Senate Judiciary Committee question Souter extensively about his views on the issue. A leading anti-abortion group, meanwhile, said it did not believe Souter had ever expressed an opinion on abortion. But the group, the National Right to Life Committee, said it was pleased that President Bush said he chose Souter because of his philosophy of not trying to legislate from the bench. ``Since Roe vs. Wade has no basis in the Constitution, the appointment of such justices should continue the erosion of the tragic error of Roe vs. Wde,'' the Right to Life Committee said in a statement. The reaction from key senators was far more restrained, for the most part because Souter, on the federal bench for less than a year, is little known. ``There will be a lot more known about him, I guarantee you that,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., a Judiciary Committee member. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a leading Judiciary Committee member and early opponent of President Reagan's failed nomination of Robert Bork to the court, said he would await hearing from Souter before making up his mind. Without mentioning the word abortion, Kennedy made it clear he viewed the issue as central to the Judiciary Committee's deliberations. ``The Judiciary Committee and the full Senate have a responsibility to determine whether he possesses a strong commitment to the fundamental values of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights that are obviously at stake in this important nomination and that will profoundly affect the lives and rights of all Americans,'' Kennedy said. More praise came from Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., a former attorney general of his stater who served as president of the National Association of Attorneys General while Souter was attorney general for New Hampshire. ``He was an outstanding attorney general so my initial reaction is positive,'' said Gorton, who is not a Judiciary Committee member. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, praised Souter's experience as a judge and as New Hampshire state attorney general but did not express an opinion on the nomination. Mitchell promised Democrats would conduct prompt and fair hearings. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said he expected few if any fireworks over Souter's record ``because he just went on the court in April and I don't think he's had a controversial matter since then.'' But another Democratic panel member, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio, said the swift approval of Souter to the 1st Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston should not be considered a bellweather. ``There is a difference between being confirmed for the appeals court and for the Supreme Court,'' Metzenbaum said. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, the panel's No. 2 Republican, said he wanted to ``get to know him, get to know his record, so I'll make a considered decision, and I'm sure he'll be fine.'' Some committee members said they would hold to the tradition of refraining from questions on how nominees would decide specific issues before the court. Still, Leahy said questions likely would be phrased to include abortion rights as a topic. ``I think it would be naive to think that Roe vs. Wade in one form or another is not going to be part of a lot of questions, interestingly enough, with the desire to know about that coming from both sides of the issue.'' Thurmond said he would have preferred a candidate from the South, but added: ``I'm going to support this nomination.'' New Hampshire GOP Sen. Warren Rudman, a Souter friend for years, said senators will find the 50-year-old nominee to be ``a classic conservative intellectual. ... He cannot be characterized as an ideologue in any way, shape or form.'' The pro-choice groups promised to be heard and called for detailed questioning on Roe vs. Wade. ``The American people need to know where Judge Souter stands on the issues of individual and human rights,'' said Judith Lichtman, president of the National Women's Legal Defense Fund. ``It would be a terrible injustice to confirm a nominee without knowing that he is commited to protecting Americans' fundamental constitutional rights, including privacy and the right to choose,'' said Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League. Outside of Washington, Alan Dershowitz, a liberal attorney and professor at Harvard Law School, from which Souter graduated, called the nomination ``a Sununu special.'' John Sununu, Bush's White House chief of staff, was the Republican New Hampshire governor who elevated Souter to the state Supreme Court. ``Howhe first time.
