DOC.HEAD: Pluperfect Dorm Monitor As Well As Scholar
DOC.TEXT: As a student at Harvard Law School 25 years ago, David H. Souter was a resident adviser in a freshman dorm at Harvard College, where his charges included one Charles G. Untermeyer. Untermeyer is now the White House personnel director. Souter on Monday became President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court. Untermeyer was not involved directly in the selection process. That fell to White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray, Atorney General Dick Thornburgh and others. But Untermeyer said Monday he remembers Souter's scholarly mien as a freshman dorm chief. Souter had returned to Harvard for law school after two years at Oxford as a Rhodes Scholar. ``He strikes me as sort of the pluperfect scholar,'' said Untermeyer. Souter could ``give the impression with the movement of an eye and the slightest inclination of his head that he was catching everything that goes on _ which is exactly the type of person you want watching over a freshman dorm,'' said Untermeyer.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Offers New Talks with Mohawks, OKs Human Rights Observers
DOC.TEXT: Quebec offered Monday to resume talks with Oka Mohawks regarding a violent dispute over a golf course addition planned on land claimed as ancestral territory. The provincial government also agreed that observers from human rights organizations could attend. John Ciaccia, Quebec's native affairs minister, said the province wants the talks held away from the barricades, where Indians and police have faced each other for nearly two weeks. A shootout July 11 resulted in the death of a Quebec police officer. The Red Cross, one of the few groups allowed beyond the barricades by police, would be permitted to continue providing food and supplies, according to a Quebec statement. That meets another Mohawk demand for free movement of food and medicine. Ciaccia's proposals were seen by some Mohawks as a ``step in the right direction,'' said Peter Diome, spokesman for the Mohawk Nation office in Kahnawake. ``At least they are now making an effort to reopen the lines of communication that they previously closed.'' But Diome said progress will be limited until the federal government gets involved. ``We're still talking about nation-to-nation and where is the federal government?'' he asked. Ciaccia said in an interview he wants talks held outside the barricades ``not for security reasons but to create an atmosphere of calm. ... We must accept that the only way to resolve this is through peaceful negotiations. There is no question of armed violence.'' In Ottawa, a senior Indian Affairs official told reporters Monday a ``gang of criminals'' have taken over negotiations in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. The federal official, who spoke at an off-the-record briefing, said a radical element in the Mohawk community ``has hijacked the land claims negotiations and is holding the Mohawk community in a state of armed insurrection.'' He was talking about reports that the militant Warrior Society is controlling events at Oka. Mohawks from nearby Kahnawake reserve have blockaded the Mercier Bridge into Montreal in support of the Oka Mohawks. Some commuters have to spend an extra two hours in travel daily, and an anti-Indian backlash has developed. Ciaccia wants only Mohawk representatives from Kahnawake and Kahnesetake involved in new negotiations. Kahnesatake is the Mohawk settlement at Oka. This would exclude militant Warriors from the Akwesasne reserve near Cornwall, Ontario, who moved into Oka to join the others. Indians in Canada's westernmost British Columbia province also erected barricades in sympathy and to press their own claims. Quebec police tried to storm a barricade Mohawks erected in Oka to stop the expansion of a local golf course onto what Mohawks say is sacred land. Responsibility for the death of the policeman killed in the resulting gunfire has not been fixed. Ciaccia and the Mohawks had been going into the woods behind Mohawk barricades for talks until discussions broke down a week ago. One request by the Mohawks was that observers from the United Nations or Amnesty International monitor the talks. Ciaccia suggested Monday that members of the Quebec Human Rights Commission, or other Quebec or Canadian institutions agreeable to both sides be allowed to observe the talks.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Court, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday paid tribute to retired Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. as ``one of the great figures of our age.'' Bush offered the praise in a brief letter acknowledging Brennan's retirement. Here is the text: ``Dear Mr. Justice: ``It is with deep regret that I acknowledge your letter of retirement. ``Your 33 years of service on our nation's highest court, spanning eight presidents, have been marked with great distinction and honor. Your powerful intellect, your winning personality, and your commitment to civil discourse on emotional issues that at times tempt uncivil voices have made you one of the great figures of our age. ``You have served our country admirably, and I know the American people join me in wishing you every blessing in your years of retirement. ``Sincerely, ``George Bush.''

DOC.HEAD: Feds Seize TV Evangelist's Prison Wages _ 11 Cents an Hour
DOC.TEXT: The feds are seizing Jim Bakker's prison wages to cover the fines he owes on a fraud conviction, but it'll take a long time to collect: The former TV evangelist owes $501,025 and he makes 11 cents an hour. So far, the government has garnisheed a total of $25 from the former PTL president, assistant U.S. Attorney Clifford Marshal said Monday. Bakker is serving a 45-year fraud and conspiracy sentence at the Federal Medical Center, a lockup in Rochester, Minn. Bakker cleans toilets, his attorney said earlier this year. The government is looking elsewhere for assets, including a pension fund set up for Bakker, Marshall said. ``But it's not mature for disbursement yet,'' he added. PTL collapsed amid a sex and money scandal after it was revealed Bakker had sex with former church secretary Jessica Hahn. Bakker and three other PTL employees were convicted in connection with the ministry's defrauding followers who sent $158 million to the television ministry. Brothers James and David Taggart, convicted of tax evasion, owe the government $535,174.64 each. Neither has made any payments since being sentenced to 18 years in prison, said Marshall. Richard Dortch, Bakker's top lieutenant, has paid $25 of his $200,000 fine. He was originally sentenced to eight years in prison, but that was reduced to 2{ years affer he testified against other defendants.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Cited Safety Problems To Relatives
DOC.TEXT: Two of the 17 workers killed by an explosion at a Texas chemical plant had told relatives they were worried about the plant's safety, the family members told a House panel Monday. The workers also had worries about training at Atlantic Richfield Co.'s plant in Channelview, where vapors caught fire and exploded near an electric compressor July 5. ``Safety has to come before profit,'' said Sandy Davis, widow of Greg Davis, a contract electrician killed in the blast. Ms. Davis wept while testifying that her husband told her several times he was unsure of the skills of some of his fellow contractors. The chief of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Gerald Scannell, said the agency has proposed new safety rules for the chemical industry. But the rules aren't being put into place fast enough, said two Houston congressmen, Democrat Mike Andrews and Republican Jack Fields. ``Waiting on studies is not necessary,'' Andrews said. ``There's not a chance in hell I'd work for a chemical plant unless I had a 1-year-old child and was out of work,'' said Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., referring to Davis, whose widow said he took the Arco job in suburban Houston after being unemployed for six months and becoming a new father. But Fields cautioned, ``It is doubtful that the government, or any particular company, can ever completely guarantee that something isn't going to go wrong.'' The congressmen said they were frustrated that 40 workers had been killed at chemical companies in the nine months since the House employment and housing subcommittee examined the October explosion that killed 23 at a Phillips plastics plant in Pasadena, another Houston suburb. OSHA has since cited Phillips for 575 ``willful and serious'' violations and fined the company $5.7 million. Phillips has appealed. The agency is still investigating the Channelview incident, Scannell said. As in Pasadena, many of the victims at the Channelview plant were contract laborers. OSHA began a study of the use of contract laborers at chemical plants after the Phillips incident. The study, being written at Lamar University's John Gray Institute, is expected to be complete this fall. Eleven of the Channelview victims, including Davis, were employees of Austin Industries. Arco uses such workers for ``ongoing capital programs'' at all its plants, said Harold Sorgenti, president of Arco Chemical Co. He estimated Arco saved $600,000 to $750,000 in salary and benefits annually by using the contract laborers at Channelview. The contract workers were not covered by Arco's life or health insurance. But the families of all 17 victims are receiving $250,000 with no strings attached, Sorgenti said. Davis got less training, less pay and fewer benefits than Arco's regular employees at Channelview, his widow said. He did not have the right to turn down overtime work, Ms. Davis said. ``If they refused this overtime, they put a bad mark on your record,'' said Bernard Blackstock, father of John Blackstock, an Arco employee killed in the incident. John Blackstock contributed to an anonymous letter sent recently to plant managers seeking changes in the operation, his father said. The workers did not want to sign their names because they were afraid they'd be fired, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters Stop Deliveries As Grocery Strike Moves Into Third Day
DOC.TEXT: Teamster officials voted Monday to stop deliveries to about 60 supermarkets being picketed by striking employees. About 5,300 supermarket employees in five counties were off the job Monday as a strike over medical benefits and wages moved into its third day. The strike by Local 555 of the United Food and Commercial Workers affects 116 supermarkets. Picket lines were set up at about 60 stores, and the Teamster Joint Council voted Monday afternoon to suspend deliveries to those stores, said John Trout, the council's president. If picket lines were formed at the other 56 stories, the Teamsters would consider halting deliveries there, as well, he said. Virtually all the affected stores' goods are delivered by Teamster drivers. The strike was started Saturday by 210 union members who work at 13 Kienow's stores. The other 5,180 union members joined the strike after union clerks, meat cutters and bakery and delicatessen workers were locked out of their jobs at Safeway, Fred Meyer, Albertson's, some Thriftway stores and several independent supermarkets in the Portland area. The union's three-year contract expired at midnight Saturday. Strikers picketed Monday at the Kienow's stores, at 35 Safeway stores and at two Thriftway stores. Steve Erdmann, spokesman for Food Employers Inc., said the stores were hiring replacements for the striking clerks. Consumers should expect longer lines at checkout counters and some stores that usually were open around the clock would close from 10 p.m. to 8 a.m., he said. Health care has been the major issue during contract talks, with the union pressing for employers to continue to pay for benefits. The employers want employees to assume part of the rising costs. The workers, who have not had a pay increase since 1986, also seek wage increases greater than the 2{ percent yearly boost management has offered as part of a proposed four-year agreement, said Rick Sawyer, a spokesman for Local 555. Journeymen clerks earn $11.05 an hour. The union represents employees at stores in Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Yamhill and Columbia counties.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Yugoslav Chief Says States Will be Allowed to Secede
DOC.TEXT: Borisav Jovic, the Serb now leading Yugoslavia's collective presidency, said on Monday that individual states will be allowed to secede from the fragile Yugoslav federation. The federation of six member states may itself be radically reshaped. ``Four republics are in favor of federation, two are for a confederation,'' Jovic said in a statement read to reporters after his meeting with Slovenia's President Milan Kucan in Ljubljana, the republic's capital. The local governments of Croatia and Slovenia insist that this Balkan nation of 23 million residents should become a loose association of near-independent states, which would remain united only if joint interests warrant it. Communist-ruled Serbia, the largest republic, has held until now that a confederate structure would be too unstable, and advocated retaining the federal system installed in 1945. The three small remaining states _ Bosnia and Hercegovin; Macedonia, and Montenegro _ also prefer a federation. Jovic said that if states favoring a looser union could not reach agreement with the rest of the country, they would be permitted to enter into a confederation with the other republics that would stay in the current federal structure. ``A sub-variant is that (regions that so desire) would also be allowed to secede from Yugoslavia,'' Jovic said. He said he and Kucan ``had very detailed and very open talks on the future of Yugoslavia (and) its future constitutional setup.'' ``We agreed that everybody should refrain from making any unilateral changes'' until a joint decision on the future of this ethnically diverse nation is reached, Jovic said. Slovenia's newly elected government has served notice the northern republic of 2 million people would declare itself independent if the other states do not accept its demands to turn Yugoslavia into a grouping of sovereign republics. Croatia's new center-right authorities, also support transforming Yugoslavia into a confederation, but say they want to discuss the nation's future makeup at a joint meeting of ``the legitimate representatives of all states.'' The Slovenian Parliament last week publicly refused to consider a letter from the federal presidency because it was not written in the local language. ``Slovenia will seek sovereignty, complete economic and cultural sovereignty in a Yugoslav confederation,'' Kucan said in his statement. Yugoslavia was formed as a joint kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes after World War I. Occupied and dismembered by Nazi Germany in 1941, it re-emerging as a Communist-style federation under Josip Tito after World War II, with Macedonia, Montenegro and Bosnia-Hercegovina added to the three prewar states. Serbia only now is taking a tentative step toward a multiparty system. Slovenia and Croatia held free elections this year in which center-right parties won the majority, marking the first free balloting here in 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Nominates Appellate Judge David Souter to Supreme Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material throughout; CORRECTS that Bush first met with Souter on Monday
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday said he would nominate David H. Souter, a little-known federal appeals court judge, to the Supreme Court. Bush said he acted without questioning Souter on abortion or other delicate judicial issues. If confirmed by a majority of the Senate, Souter, a 50-year-old bachelor from New Hampshire, would succeed William J. Brennan, who retired last Friday. Bush's quick decision took Washington by surprise and shifted the nation's attention to the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is certain to examine Souter's record and explore his views on abortion and other issues. With Souter standing at his side, Bush described Souter as ``a remarkable judge of keen intellect and the highest ability.'' He chose his nominee after meeting him for the first time earlier in the day. The president said it would have been ``inappropriate'' to apply an abortion ``litmus test'' on his nominee. He said the selection was not geared to any single issue but to his ability to interpret the law. Souter has been on the federal appeals court for such a short period of time that he has not yet penned an opinion. Gordon Tiffany, like Souter a former New Hampshire attorney general, said it is hard to classify Souter's judicial philosophy. ``Whether it's liberal or conservative, it's not the issue in his mind. The issue in his mind is what was intended in the Constitution,'' Tiffany said. Conservatives hoped Bush would give them a nominee who would overthrow the 1973 Roe-vs.-Wade decision that legalized abortion. The nomination appeared to underscore the influence exercised by John Sununu, Bush's chief of staff, who as governor of New Hampshire had put Souter on that state's Supreme Court in 1983. Like Bush, Sununu is an outspoken opponent of abortion. Andrew Card, Sununu's deputy, said Sununu did not suggest Souter to Bush. At a news conference, a questioner noted that Bush and Sununu both have widely known views against abortion and asked why people shouldn't think that Souter's abortion view was known to Bush even if Bush did not question him about it. ``I told you it's not,'' Bush said. The National Right to Life Committee, a leading anti-abortion group, said it did not believe Souter had ever expressed an opinion on abortion. But the committee said it was pleased that Bush said he chose Souter because of his philosophy of not trying to legislate from the bench. Bush noted that Souter had won unanimous Senate confirmation when he was nominated in January for the appeals court, suggesting his hope that the nomination might not trigger a political free-for-all in the Senate. ``We're not bracing for some horrendous fight with the United States Senate,'' Bush said. But Sen. Patrick J. Leahy, D-Vt., a liberal member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said it would be ``naive'' to think that Souter would not be quizzed about abortion. ``There will be a lot more known about him, I guarantee you that,'' said Leahy. In fact, pro-choice groups demanded that committee sound Souter out on his abortion views. ``The American people need to know where Judge Souter stands on the issues of individual and human rights,'' said Judith Lichtman, president of the National Women's Legal Defense Fund. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell praised Souter's experience but did not express an opinion on the nomination. Mitchell promised Democrats would conduct prompt and fair hearings. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said he expected few if any fireworks over Souter's record ``because he just went on the court in April.'' When Bush nominated Souter for the appeals court, the American Bar Association's screening committee called him ``well-qualified'' _ its highest rating for judicial nominees. Bush said he decided on Souter earlier in the day. ``The excellence was just there,'' Bush said. The president praised Brennan as well, calling the court's long-time leading liberal, ``one of the greatest figures of his age.'' The 84-year-old Brennan, in frail health, resigned Friday. Appointed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower, he had served longer than most Americans have been alive.

DOC.HEAD: Scientologists Offer Reward for Corrupt IRS Officials
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede to make ``arm'' into ``affiliate''
DOC.TEXT: An affiliate of the Church of Scientology on Monday promised rewards of up to $10,000 for Internal Revenue Service employees who turn in corrupt IRS officials. Representatives of the National Coalition of Whistleblowers, carrying a 5-foot-high ``wanted'' poster, camped outside IRS national headquarters and gave literature to IRS employees at lunchtime. ``We want to assist those honest IRS employees who are aware of corruption and abuses to come forward,'' said coalition spokesman Mike Lashaway. IRS employees, he said, often are reluctant to report wrongdoing despite laws to protect whistleblowers. The Church of Scientology and its branches have been involved in several tax disputes with the IRS. The coalition, created by Scientologists to collect and publicize information on IRS abuses, promised a $5,000 reward for information leading to conviction of an IRS official for criminal misconduct. Another $3,000 is added if the official is head of a national department or an IRS district. An additional $2,000 will be tacked on if it can be proved that the IRS internal inspection service was aware of the illegality and didn't take actions required to stop it. The IRS declined comment on the reward offer. The Supreme Court ruled earlier this year that fixed donations to the church are not deductible by individual parishioners. A district court in Boston held more recently that the IRS violated a law setting out procedures for auditing churches when it investigated the Church of Scientology. ``We think the exempt-organizations branch of the IRS has discriminated against the church and individual Scientologists,'' said church spokeswoman Sylvia Stanard.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Statehood Gaining but Still Short of Majority
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half of all Puerto Ricans favor statehood over the Caribbean island's current commonwealth status, and only 8 percent want independence, according to a poll published Monday. Although support for statehood appears to be growing, the poll found that it still falls short of the majority required by bills now before Congress to change Puerto Rico's political relationship with the United States. The survey of 1,204 eligible voters indicated that if Puerto Rico held a plebiscite on its status now, 48.3 percent would choose statehood, 40.6 percent commonwealth status and 8 percent independence, with the remainder undecided. The poll was published Monday by San Juan's El Mundo newspaper. A previous poll, published by the newspaper El Nuevo Dia in February, showed 43 percent favoring statehood, 36 percent commonwealth status, 5 percent independence, with the remainder undecided or refusing to reveal their preference. However, the two polls were conducted by different organizations, which did not necessarily use the same methods. The Senate and the House are considering separate bills authorizing a plebiscite on Puerto Rico's status in June 1991. Both bills would allow Puerto Ricans to choose whether they want the island to become the 51st U.S. state, keep the commonwealth relationship but with increased autonomy, or break away to form an independent nation. The Senate version would put the results of the plebiscite into immediate effect. The House version would require negotiations with Congress over implementation of the islanders' choice. Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon, leader of the pro-commonwealth Popular Democratic Party, proposed a status plebiscite in his 1989 inaugural speech following his re-election to a second consecutive four-year term. Under the 38-year commonwealth arrangement, Puerto Rico's 3.3 million residents are U.S. citizens, but they pay no federal taxes and cannot vote for president. Statehood supporters contend that the commonwealth status is a form of colonialism that makes Puerto Ricans second-class citizens. Commonwealth supporters say the current status allows Puerto Ricans to enjoy the benefits of citizenship without giving up their Spanish cultural identity. Fear of economic collapse has stymied the independence movement. The El Mundo poll found that 43.5 percent of Puerto Ricans would migrate to the U.S. mainland if the island became independent. The poll was carried out for El Mundo and the educational station WMTJ-TV by the U.S. firm Frank I. Luntz & Associates, based in Arlington, Va., and had a margin of error of 2.8 percent. Findings were based on face-to-face interviews with randomly selected eligible voters from June 23 to July 2.

DOC.HEAD: One Small Town Finds a Way to Stay Alive
DOC.TEXT: Jamesport, Mo., was dying, like many small American towns dependent on agriculture. Then, starting about five years ago, Jamesport began dressing up its Main Street and attracting businesses that helped diversify the economy and bring back some life. The revitalization of Jamesport, population 650, was held up as an example Monday for community development experts assembled to discuss, among other issues, the plight of small towns. ``Historically, we've thought the community's answers were external,'' said Don W. Littrell, an associate professor at the University of Missouri. ``Basically, now, what we're saying is, `Do it yourself.''' Littrell is among 350 experts in Little Rock this week for the 22nd annual conference of the Community Development Society. The group exchanges ideas to help solve community problems. Residents of Jamesport, a small agricultural trade center in northern Missouri, began renovating and restoring Main Street businesses about five years ago, City Clerk Cecelia Dixon said in a telephone interview. Many of the businesses are antique stores, or offer antique-restoration services, she said. ``Before that, it was just like any other small town,'' Ms. Dixon said. ``It was like a ghost town.'' Like many small towns in rural America, Jamesport's tax base was eroding and its agricultural economy was failing. Littrell said small towns often share common problems: _Young people leave for higher paying jobs in cities. _Funding for public schools drops as the tax bases erode. _Economies flounder as farming crises hit again and again. ``They're not only dying economically, they're dying institutionally,'' said Littrell. ``You look at churches _ they aren't well funded. You have to look at how this affects people socially. ``There's no quick fix,'' Littrell said. ``Each community is going to have to develop its resources on its own.'' Carl Pedersen, principal officer of the United Nations' director general's Office for Development and International Economic Cooperation, was Monday's keynote speaker. He said environmental problems, overpopulation and pollution that accompanies development in many areas threaten to strip the planet of its resources. ``Making the wrong choices today will bring the earth into a downward spiral,'' Pedersen said. ``The biggest enemy we face is our material expectactions.''

DOC.HEAD: Anonymous Man Confesses on TV to Pub Bombings
DOC.TEXT: A disguised, anonymous man described as a former IRA member confessed in a British television documentary on Monday to the Birmingham pub bombings for which six other people are serving life sentences. The two bombings on Nov. 21, 1974, killed 21 people and injured 162 in the deadliest attack ever mounted by the Irish Republican Army in its campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. ``There were only two of us,'' the man said. ``These six people are innocent. I've never met these six guys before in my life.'' He fashioned his own disguise for the Granada TV interview, conducted in Ireland as part of the ``World in Action'' series. An actor voiced over his words because it is illegal in Britain to broadcast interviews with IRA members. The man pointed out on detailed floor plans where the bombs were left in each pub, information the documentary said had not been published before. He could describe the pubs' interiors in detail. Four of the ``Birmingham Six'' confessed to the bombings. But the documentary said the confessions contained inaccuracies about where the bombs were placed and provided few details about the pubs' interiors. The six say they were beaten into confessing. Their cause has been taken up by Amnesty International and the Irish government. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, quoted a ``World in Action'' spokesman _ not identified in accordance with British practice _ as saying the anonymous man's identity was known by authorities for years. A Granada documentary shown in March identified four alleged bombers and said a fifth could not be identified ``for security reasons.'' None were among the Birmingham Six. The man in the latest documentary said he was told the targets were nearby government buildings. ``I was assured that there would be plenty of warning given and that civilians weren't the target,'' he said. The first bomb exploded within six minutes of an IRA warning call to the police, the documentary said. ``There never will be, there never can be any justification for taking the lives of innocent people. It's something I have to live with. ``I've got to live with those nightmares,'' the man said. Authorities are conducting an inquiry in the case, ordered by Home Secretary David Waddingtion. Britain in October freed the ``Guildford Four,'' who were wrongly convicted 14 years earlier for an IRA bombing, after revelations that police made up confessions in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill 20 Troops in Peruvian Andes
DOC.TEXT: Maoist Shining Path guerrillas killed 20 militiamen in attacks on two Andean towns, police said Monday. There were no reports of rebel casualties in the fighting. Police said the clashes took place July 17 in Jaujin and Chichipon, near the Maranon River, 210 miles north of Lima. Police did not arrive in the isolated towns until July 20. The bodies of the militiamen had been left unburied and were badly decomposed, according to police. Police gave the following description of the attacks: About 30 rebels killed 17 of the militiamen in a long firefight in Jaujin, after earlier killing three soldiers in an attack on Chichipon. The rebels were armed with assault rifles and machine guns while the militiamen had a few old rifles but were armed mainly with sticks and machetes. Drug traffickers are active in the area around Chichipon and Jaujin, police said. The Shining Path often provides protection for drug traffickers in return for arms and money. The Peruvian army has established militia groups throughout mountain and jungle regions to allow villages to defend themselves from rebels. The government says more than 19,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms 10 years ago. The Shining Path, following the tactics of China's Mao Tse-tung, is conducting a prolonged guerrilla campaign in the countryside and aiming eventually at surrounding and strangling Peru's coastal cities.

DOC.HEAD: Nominee Would Be Only Sixth Bachelor to Serve on Court
DOC.TEXT: If confirmed for a seat on the Supreme Court, David H. Souter would be only the sixth unmarried justice out of the 105 men and women who will have served. The other bachelors and their dates on the court: _William Moody, 1906-1910. _James McReynolds, 1914-1941. _John Clarke, 1916-1922. _Benjamin Cardozo, 1932-1938. _Frank Murphy, 1940_1949.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Starts in Winery Killing Trial
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to show motion not filed; INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf to describe Salcido in court; picks up 5th graf pvs, `The 88-item...'
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Monday in the trial of Ramon Salcido, the winery worker accused of killing seven people, including his wife and two of his daughters. Detailed questionnaires were distributed to about 100 potential jurors at the San Mateo County Courthouse. The trial was moved to the county just south of San Francisco because of extensive pretrial publicity in Sonoma County, north of the city. Defense attorneys asked the judge to consider moving the trial again because a defense-commissioned survey found that many San Mateo County residents believe Salcido is guilty. Despite objections from prosecutors, the judge agreed to consider such a request. However, defense attorneys said they would not seek another change until after all prospective jurors were interviewed. Salcido, 29, is accused of killing his wife, two daughters, his mother-in-law, her two daughters and a co-worker on April 14, 1989. A third daughter, who was almost 3, survived a slashed throat and has been living with a foster family. An interpreter translated the proceedings into Spanish for Salcido, who was dressed in a conservative gray suit, his arms and legs free of shackles. It was the first time Salcido appeared in court without restraints and wearing something other than an orange jail jump suit. The 88-item, 18-page jury questionnaire was designed to give a view of each juror's family background, work experience, intellect, personality and beliefs. Questions included inquiries about hobbies, whether potential jurors have consulted a psychiatrist and how they feel about viewing bloody photographs and videotapes. The questionnaire also asked respondents their views on the death penalty. Judge Reginald Littrell said he had summoned 120 jurors for each of the four days the court will be in session this week. The judge said jury selection is expected to take at least four to five weeks. ``I don't want any person on there with a bias against my client,'' said Sonoma County Public Defender Marteen Miller, Salcido's main attorney. Prosecutor Peter Bumerts said: ``I'm just looking for ordinary people who have common sense and can bring their life experiences into the courtroom.'' The defense survey found that nine of 10 San Mateo County residents who know about the killings believe Salcido is definitely or probably guilty. ``Everybody's heard about the case,'' Bumerts said. ``There's no doubt about it.'' Miller said he doesn't plan to dispute the facts in the case. Salcido gave a full confession to police shortly after he was arrested in Mexico, his native country. However, Miller said he plans to fight the death penalty by contending that Salcido was drunk and on cocaine at the time of the slayings and was mentally unbalanced.

DOC.HEAD: Up With People Celebrates 25 Years of Spreading Goodwill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Margriet is cq in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Up With People's clean-cut young performers have sung and danced their way around the world many times since 1965. This week, thousands of alumni are gathering to celebrate the organization's 25th anniversary. J. Blanton Belk founded the musical goodwill troupe in an effort to channel the idealism of the young and spread an upbeat message of universal brotherhood during a disruptive era of civil rights marches, anti-war protests and political assassinations. ``It was a very young world that wanted to have a say in what happened to them, much more so than past generations, '' recalled Belk, a former Navy officer. Since then, some 11,000 Up with People troubadours have performed in virtually every country. More than 5,000 alumni from 41 countries are expected to attend a four-day celebration, including concerts and slide shows, that opens Wednesday at the Colorado Convention Center. The organization takes on about 650 people aged 18 to 26 each year. President and Mrs. Bush serve as honorary co-chairmen for the event but were not expected to attend, said spokesman Julie Hammerstein said. A cast of Up With People performed at Bush's inauguration last year. Speakers at a forum to discuss global concerns such as the environment and political cooperation will include Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, Dr. Shoichiro Toyoda, president of the Toyota Motor Company, and Mexico's Oscar-winning filmmaker Manuel Orango. Others expected to attend include Princess Margriet of the Netherlands, former astronaut Eugene Cernan and Soviet journalist Vladimir Pozner. The idea for Up With People stemmed from a 1965 summer youth conference in Michigan, said Belk. ``It was a time when you really had to give young people experience, and there was no bigger challenge in the '60s than go give them a vehicle for their energy,'' he said. His Tucson, Ariz.-based organization is independent, nonprofit and educational, and has no religious or political affiliations. The group's aim of ``building bridges of communication among people of all nations'' has become easier in recent years, but many barriers remain, Belk said. ``The Berlin Wall is coming down, fences are down, borders are being crossed,'' he said. ``But there's still the walls of misunderstanding, bigotry, prejudice and fear to overcome.''

DOC.HEAD: 9-year-old Injured in Mountain Lion Attack in Glacier
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old boy was mauled by a mountain lion in Glacier National Park Monday, officials said. The lion was tracked down and killed. Park information officer Amy Vanderbilt said Scott O'Hare of Dayton, Wyo., was flown by helicopter to Kalispell Regional Hospital where he underwent surgery Monday afternoon for deep lacerations and puncture wounds to the head, face, neck and right arm. Hospital officials said O'Hare was in fair condition and added that the injuries were not life-threatening. Vanderbilt said the attack occurred at the Apgar picnic area, near the west entrance to the park and across the road from one of the park's largest campgrounds. O'Hare and two other children were playing on the beach of McDonald Lake about 11:30 a.m. when the lion apparently attacked without reason, she said. One of the other children ran to get O'Hare's parents while the second child attempted to scare the cat off by throwing rocks, Vanderbilt said. The mountain lion ran away when O'Hare's parents, Richard and Merry O'Hare, arrived on the beach. About 3{ hours after the attack, park rangers found and killed a 45- to 50-pound female yearling mountain lion less than 100 yards from where the attack took place, Vanderbilt said. The carcass is being taken to Montana State University where tests will be conducted to see if the animal might have had rabies. Rangers tracked the mountain lion, using a dog, and shot it with a high-powered rifle. Vanderbilt said officials have no idea why the mountain lion attacked. All indications are that the children did not provoke the cat in any way, she said. Vanderbilt added that mountain lion sightings in the Apgar area are not unusual, but no one has ever been attacked before. Confrontations, however, have been on the rise in western Montana in the last several years. A young child was killed near Evaro by a mountain lion last fall, and a game warden was forced to kill another as it charged him near Bigfork two weeks ago. A third mountain lion was trapped and removed from a heavily used nature area in Missoula last week.

DOC.HEAD: Souter: A Close-to-the-Vest, Conservative Judge
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 13th graf, last bullet graf: ``_As a,'' on 1983 decision
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Court
DOC.TEXT: The man President Bush wants to become the Supreme Court's 105th justice is hardly known outside New Hampshire, but his state court work _ and those who know him _ suggest David Souter is a close-to-the-vest conservative judge. ``He does not pay any attention to the emotional, political aspects'' of cases before him, said Stanley M. Brown, a Manchester, N.H., lawyer and a former American Bar Association officer. ``He doesn't go out blazing new pathways. That's not his forte.'' Gordon Tiffany, like Souter a former New Hampshire attorney general, said it is hard to classify Souter's judicial philosophy. ``Whether it's liberal or conservative, it's not the issue in his mind. The issue in his mind is what was intended in the Constitution,'' Tiffany said. Souter, a state trial judge for five years before serving on the New Hampshire Supreme Court until last April 30, appears to have had two political patrons _ Warren Rudman and John Sununu. Rudman is a moderate Republican senator from New Hampshire who as state attorney general hired Souter. Sununu, a former governor who elevated Souter to the state Supreme Court, is the conservative White House chief of staff. Rudman once said Souter, who was considered a potential Supreme Court nominee by the Reagan administration before Anthony M. Kennedy's appointment in 1988, possesses ``the most brilliant legal mind'' he had ever encountered. Souter has been serving as a judge on the Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court for less than three months. In state cases: _He was the lone dissenter in a 1985 state Supreme Court decision that struck down the use of police sobriety checkpoints. The nation's highest court upheld such police tactics earlier this year. _He was part of a 3-2 majority in a 1986 decision that allowed the main owner of the Seabrook nuclear plant to sell bonds needed to complete the long-entangled project. His court rejected appeals from the state consumer advocate and several anti-Seabrook groups. _In one of the few civil rights cases in which Souter participated, he joined the state Supreme Court's ruling in 1987 that said homosexuals may be barred from becoming adoptive or foster parents. But the state court said in that decision that homosexuals may not be barred from running day-care centers. _As a state judge in 1983, he held a 3:45 a.m. hearing at the request of then-Gov. Sununu and ordered state employes staging a ``sick-out'' over pay issues back to work under threat of $5,000-a-day fines against their union. People for the American Way, a liberal group, said its review of Souter's state Supreme Court record indicates he ``interprets constitutional guarantees narrowly, especially in criminal cases.'' The organization criticized him for an opinion that overturned a sexual assault conviction. Souter held that the defendant should have been allowed to present testimony that the victim behaved in a sexually provocative manner toward several men in a tavern, the group said.

DOC.HEAD: Nominee an Intellectual Judge, Private Man
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 7-8: ``One of,'' Rudman comments on monastic life
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Court, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: David Hackett Souter, nominated Monday to the U.S. Supreme Court, is known in his adopted home state as a brilliant legal scholar, a diligent judge, a private man. Never married, he lives alone on the family farm near Weare, N.H., where he moved from the Boston suburb of Melrose when he was 11. He's now 50. Like President Bush, who appointed him, Souter is an Episcopalian and a Republican. He never served in the military. He belongs to the Appalachian Mountain Club and is in excellent health, he told the Senate Judiciary Committee at the time he was nominated to the 1st Circuit Court of Appeals this spring. He had a net worth of $621,252 at the end of 1989 _ including $191,000 in ``autos and other personal property,'' $190,000 in securities and $150,000 in real estate _ according to financial records released Monday by the committee. He listed no liabilities. Bush said he wanted a justice who would rely on the Constitution and not ``legislate from the bench.'' And the president seemed to be getting what he wanted, judging from the comments of lawyers who know Souter _ as well as from the few personal remarks of Souter's that have made it into print. One of Souter's mentors, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., decribed him Monday as ``a classic conservative with great reverence for the Constitution and the law.'' ``He has a small circle of very good friends and lives an almost monastic life,'' Rudman said. ``If he has any fault, I believe it's that he's worked too hard all his life. But that's the way he is.'' Stanley M. Brown, a Manchester trial attorney, described Souter as a cautious judge who ignores the political and emotional consequences of each case when reaching a decision. ``If there is any weakness in the man, it is that he does not pay any attention to the emotional, political aspects,'' Brown said. ``You are not supposed to and he doesn't. ... He is not going to create a Constitution.'' And Rep. Charles G. Douglas, R-N.H., who served with Souter on the New Hampshire Supreme Court from 1983 to 1985, said, ``There's nobody with a keener mind, a better ability to read and digest material and then write an opinion that will stick to the law, interpret the law and not go rambling all over the countryside willy-nilly.'' Souter himself, in an interview in 1976, let a little of his own feeling out in remarks linking language and the law. He said, ``The more we allow language to be debased, the more free-swinging we are in our interpretation of legal language, the more arbitrary and personal, not grounded in the constitutional process.'' As attorney general of New Hampshire, Souter told Senate Judiciary Committee at the time he was nominated to the 1st Circuit Court of Appeals this year, he took ``active opposition to attempts to legalize casino gambling in New Hampshire and to the prosecution of those who refused to end their occupation of the site of the Seabrook nuclear plant in 1977.'' Asked his view of ``judicial activism,'' Souter wrote: ``The obligation of any judge is to decide the case before the court, and the nature of the issue presented will largely determine the appropriate scope of the principle on which its decision should rest.'' Souter attended Harvard College, then Oxford University, where he was a Rhodes Scholar, and Harvard Law School, from which he was graduated in 1966. If confirmed, he would be would be the first New Englander to serve on the Supreme Court since the retirement of Justice Felix Frankfurter in 1962. He would be the court's second Rhodes Scholar, joining Justice Byron R. White. After law school, Souter spent two years with a prestigious firm in Concord, then became an assistant state attorney general in 1968. Three years later he was appointed deputy attorney general, and, in 1976, attorney general. Gov. Meldrim Thomson appointed him a superior court judge in 1978, and then-Gov. John Sununu, now White House chief of staff, elevated him to the state Supreme Court in 1983. He was appointed to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston on April 30 and began that job just last month. Boston-area lawyers praised Souter's intellect and willingness to study a case. David Berman, an attorney from Medford, argued a case before Souter in June that involved questions about whether the town of Concord should pay for the education of a child suffering from multiple disorders. ``The questions he asked were highly intelligent, questions both of me and my adversaries. I was very impressed by the time he had taken to study the case,'' Berman said. On the Judiciary Committee questionnaire earlier this year, Souter was asked the 10 most significant cases he personally litigated as deputy attorney general. He included his first case, a ``simple automobile collision case.'' ``It was not significant for any novelty except to me, for it was the first case I was allowed to try solo in the superior court,'' Souter wrote. ``I had reason, despite my over-preparation, to be grateful for the court's patience, and with equal thankfulness I remember the opposing counsel, and even the opposing party, for providing that first chance for me to stand up in a courtroom all by myself.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to restore dropped last name to Justice Kennedy.
DOC.HEAD: With Bush-Court
DOC.TEXT: Under the U.S. system of separation of powers, it is the president's job to choose Supreme Court nominees and the Senate's role to confirm or reject them. Twenty-seven high court nominees in the nation's history have failed to win Senate confirmation, only seven in this century. Most recently, the Senate in 1987 blocked President Reagan's appointment of Robert Bork to fill a vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell. The Senate vote was 58-42, with six Republicans joining 52 Democrats in opposing Bork. Reagan's second choice, Douglas Ginsburg, withdrew after revealing he had smoked marijuana. The Senate then confirmed Reagan's third pick, Anthony M. Kennedy.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Shakes Up Government Ranks
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher dropped seven ministers and appointed two close aides to posts in the Foreign Office on Monday in a shakeup of the middle and junior ranks of her government. The shuffle followed the July 14 resignation of Trade and Industry Secretary Nicholas Ridley, who quit after making anti-German remarks. Ridley was replaced the same day by a former treasury official, Peter Lilley, and Monday's moves involved no further changes in Mrs. Thatcher's 22-member Cabinet. She moved or replaced about 20 lower-ranking ministers _ about a fifth of the government members who hold jobs outside the Cabinet _ in the sixth shakeup in a year. In the most senior appointment, Mrs. Thatcher named Francis Maude, 37, the Foreign Office minister responsible for Asian affairs, as financial secretary to the Treasury to replace Lilley. Among three new appointees at the Foreign Officewere Mrs. Thatcher's parliamentary private secretary, Mark Lennox-Boyd, and another staunch loyalist, Tristan Garel-Jones, a deputy whip in the House of Commons. The shakeup, designed to freshen the government, was widely expected even before Ridley resigned.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans Editor Retires, Successor Named
DOC.TEXT: Jim Amoss has been named editor of The Times-Picayune, succeeding Charles A. Ferguson, who took early retirement, New Orleans' daily newspaper announced in its Tuesday editions. Amoss, 42, has been an associate editor since 1988 of The Times-Picayune, a member of the Newhouse group. Before that, he served as city editor and metro editor. Amoss joined the staff of The States-Item, which has been merged into The Times-Picayune, as a reporter in 1974. He graduated from Jesuit High School and received a bachelor of arts degree from Yale University. He studied at Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar. He is a member of Associated Press Managing Editors. Ferguson, 53, has been editor of The Times-Picayune for the past 10 years. Before that, he was editor of The States-Item. He received bachelor of arts and law degrees from Tulane University and was a Nieman Fellow at Harvard University in 1965-66. He is a member of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and the Louisiana State Bar Association. He also is a member of the board of trustees of Dillard University and serves as chairman of its executive committee.

DOC.HEAD: EC Pushes for Peace, Ties It to Economic Benefits for Israel
DOC.TEXT: Italian Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis said Monday that the European Community would link economic cooperation with Israel to the new Israeli government making progress toward Middle East peace. De Michelis, president of the EC's Council of Ministers, made the statement after the first meeting of the so-called troika of European foreign ministers with Israel's new foreign minister, David Levy of the right-wing Likud bloc. The meeting came as European leaders are putting increasing pressure on Israel to move toward peace with Palestinians, and as Israel is seeking wider trade cooperation from Europe. De Michelis said the visiting Europeans foreign ministers, who included Jacques F. Poos of Luxembourg and Gerard Collins of Ireland, expressed to Israeli leaders their concerns about the situation in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Italian official told a news conference that the EC was willing to support any initiative toward Middle East peace even if it does not conform to one adopted by European leaders at a summit last month. The summit in Dublin recommended an international peace conference on the Middle East, including representatives from the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israel views the PLO as a terrorist organization and rejects the idea of an international conference. ``We're open to examine all possibilities offered by all parties, of course also by the Israeli government,'' De Michelis said after the meeting. He said the EC would take into consideration Israel's views of the PLO but that Israel would have to find another ``real Palestinian interlocutor.'' He also said, however, that European leaders were worried that Middle East tensions could deteriorate dangerously unless steps were taken quickly toward peace. When asked whether Israel would be granted crucial economic concessions as the 12-nation EC moved toward a single market in 1992, De Michelis said that would depend on progress toward peace. ``If the peace process continues, there will be a jump in the quality of economic cooperation in the entire region, and of course Israel has a special place in that,'' he said. ``But,'' he added, ``if there is a deterioration, economic and social cooperation will become more and more difficult.'' De Michelis said the EC leaders were concerned that a wave of Soviet Jews immigrating to Israel could adversely effect the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied territories. Levy noted that Europe does not face the dangers that Israel does in dealing with the Palestinians and its Arab neighbors. The visit by the three foreign ministers was the first by EC leaders to Israel since Prime Minister Yizthak Shamir formed a right-wing government in June led by his Likud bloc. The three ministers are to meet Tuesday with Shamir before traveling to Tunis for talks with the Arab League.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Inundate Texas; Several Record Lows Set
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to add temperature in Valentine, Neb.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms deluged parts of Texas with heavy rain Monday, while several record lows for the date were set, and dry, sunny conditions prevailed across much of the Plains and West. Thunderstorms southeast of Killeen, Texas, produced 4.35 inches of rain, five inches around Santa Anna, and up to seven inches southeast of Eden. Showers and thunderstorms developing along and ahead of the slow-moving cold front extended from southern Texas to Florida and Georgia Monday afternoon. They were most numerous along the Gulf Coast. Such storms developing along and ahead of the same cold front extended from the Delmarva Peninsula through Vermont and eastern New York state to northern Maine. A few showers and thunderstorms also were scattered in the upper Great Lakes region Monday afternoon, and from the central Rockies through Idaho to eastern Washington and Oregon. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunshine in much of the Great Plains and Mississippi Valley. Clear skies prevailed across California and Nevada. Brisk southerly winds blew through the western Gulf Coast, and along the middle and northern Atlantic coast, ahead of the advancing cold front. The low in the Lower 48 states Monday morning was 38 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. Several cities set record lows for the date. Among them: Hollywood, Fla., 67; Kansas City, Mo., 57; Valentine, Neb., 45.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Reaches 2 Verdicts; Ordered to Keep Working on Other Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that jury's vote wasn't disclosed. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Jurors had said...
DOC.TEXT: The jury in the second McMartin Pre School molestation trial announced it had reached a partial verdict Monday, but was ordered to resume deliberations on 6 counts on which it was deadlocked. Superior Court Judge Stanley M. Weisberg allowed jurors to go home for the night before resuming consideration of charges that Raymond Buckey molested three girls at his family's nursery school in the early 1980s. Weisberg disclosed in a brief court session that jurors had asked for further legal instruction, but didn't explain further. It wasn't revealed what charges the jurors agreed on, or whether they voted for conviction or acquittal. Jurors had said in a foreman's note the panel had considered all eight charges twice before concluding that they were ``hung'' on six counts. The judge urged them to deliberate further, telling them, ``Each of you must decide the case for yourself and should do so after deliberating with the other jurors.'' All eight felony charges are child molestation. Outside court, Buckey said he was nervous but optimistic. ``Of course, I'm optimistic because I know the truth of my innocence,'' he told reporters. Asked how he felt about the prospect of a third trial if the jury hopelessly deadlocks, he said, ``I think everyone is tired of the McMartin case. I think it should end.'' The jury's announcement that verdicts had been reached came at the start of the panel's third week of deliberations in a case that has stretched over six years with two trials and lengthy preliminary hearings. Buckey was acquitted along with his mother of a number of other charges in the first trial. His second trial lasted three months, far shorter than the first, which was the nation's longest criminal proceeding and cost Los Angeles County $13.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Ratzinger Attacks `Liberation Theology' on Rio Visit
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, the pope's main guardian of orthodoxy, attacked Marxist-influenced ``liberation theology'' during a visit here Monday. The West German cardinal, chief of the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, came to Rio to open a special weeklong course for Brazilian clergymen organized by the local archdiocese. ``The Congregation does not condemn all `liberation theology' but believes it is necessary to exclude a specific type, which is influenced by Marxism,'' he told a news conference. ``Liberation theology,'' a grass-roots doctrine which promotes social and political awareness among the poor, has a strong following in Brazil, where the Roman Catholic clergy is considered among the world's most liberal. Ratzinger said some liberal clergymen ``reduce faith to a predetermined socio-political position.'' ``They use the Church as a (political) party, and produce a faith that is partial, and does not respond to all of humanity,'' he added. Ratzinger did not mention by name any clergymen he considered proponents of Marxist-inspired liberation theology. The Vatican has come into open conflict with the Brazilian church on several occasions in recent years. In 1988, Bishop Pedro Casaldaliga, known for his outspoken defense of landless peasants in his diocese in the central state of Mato Grosso, had restrictions placed on his visits to Central America. Three years earlier, Leonardo Boff, internationally recognized as a leading progressive theologian, was sentenced to a year's ``penitential silence'' for his criticism of church authority.

DOC.HEAD: State Payroll Fiasco Eases
DOC.TEXT: State officials said Monday they have distributed paychecks to more than half of the 18,500 state employees whose salaries were overdue by up to 12 days because of a switch to a new computer system. The state's finance director, Alexander Holmes, said he hoped the problem of late payroll checks would be solved by July 31, when another 30,000 state workers are due to be paid. Some unpaid workers said they had run out of money to buy food or pay rent and utility bills. State payroll processors worked through the weekend, often until midnight, to clear the backlog of paychecks. By Monday, the number of overdue paychecks had been reduced to 9,600, Holmes said. More than 60,000 people are employed by the state. Officials used a $166 million cash-flow reserve fund to pay off workers, and used an older computer system to cut down on processing difficulties caused by the recent switch to a new, $13 million computer system, Holmes said. Asked if the problems will be ironed out by July 31, Holmes said: ``I have confidence in the system and the people who are working to get it done.'' He said the paycheck delays have been caused because the programming in the new computer system is not working as fast as expected and coded tapes coming in from various state agencies are not in the proper form. Officials said some child support payments were being delayed because of the computer problems. A home for mentally retarded adults in Ardmore said it may have to shut down if state checks for workers and clients are not received soon.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Parliament Ratifies Treaty on U.S. Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-8, The treaty ... by Congress, to CLARIFY that treaty does not need to be ratified by Congress, according to State Department, that administration seeking Congressional support for aid package. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Parliament approved...'
DOC.TEXT: Parliament early Tuesday ratified a new defense treaty with the United States that will allow two major U.S. military bases to remain on the island of Crete for at least eight more years. The Parliament's decision ends more than 18 months of uncertainty about the future of the U.S. bases following the expiration of the previous U.S.-Greece defense treaty in December 1988. The treaty has been a divisive issue in Greek politics _ with conservatives supporting a continued U.S. military presence and leftists demanding the removal of the bases. As lawmakers debated the treaty, hundreds of anti-base demonstrators clashed with police Monday near the city of Khania on Crete. Three policemen were slightly injured after being shot by demonstrators, the Public Order Ministry said. The defense agreement, which was signed by representatives of the two countries earlier this month, would take effect in September and run through 1998. In Greece, the treaty will become law as soon as it is signed by President Constantine Caramanlis and published in the government gazette. A State Department official, requesting anonymity, said late Monday that the United States considers the pact an executive agreement, which would not require ratification by Congress. After an exchange of notes between the two countries, the administration would only have to notify Congress about it within 60 days for it to take effect, the official said. The treaty continues a defense relationship between the two NATO allies that began in 1953. The pact guarantees that the United States will defend Greece from attack by a hostile country. The U.S. administration has also agreed to seek congressional approval for an aid package that would provide Greece with about $345 million in assistance to buy U.S. military equipment, supply surplus planes and destroyers worth about $1 billion, and write off about $50 million in past debts for military purchases. Parliament approved the defense treaty by the narrowest of margins shortly after midnight Monday following a three-day debate. A simple majority of the 300-member Parliament was required for ratification. All 151 deputies from the ruling conservative New Democratic Party voted in favor of the treaty. It was opposed by 144 Communist, Socialist and environmentalist deputies. Four deputies were absent and one abstained. The treaty allows the United States to continue operating two major military bases on Crete _ a naval support facility at Souda Bay and Iraklion Air Station near the village of Gournes. Two bases near Athens _ a Navy communications station at Nea Makri and the Hellenikon Air Base _ have been slated for closing by the Defense Department as a cost-cutting measure. Numerous relay stations throughout Greece will also close. On Crete, a coalition of leftist groups opposed to the U.S. bases staged demonstrations in Khania that lasted into the night. As many as 2,500 people took part in the protests, according to witnesses and journalists at the scene. Police fired tear gas to prevent demonstrators from entering a municipal building to deliver a petition, the Public Order Ministry said. Clashes then broke out, and three police officers suffered gunshot wounds, the ministry said Monday night. Another five officers were injured by gasoline bombs and stones hurled by demonstrators, the ministry said. A hospital source said 10 civilians were treated for respiratory problems caused by the tear bas, and another 40 people received treatment for minor injuries. A police official in Khania said eight people were arrested during the disturbances. Demonstrators set three police vehicles and part of the municipal building on fire with gasoline bombs, lighted fires in central Khania and engaged in repeated skirmishes with police late into the night, witnesses said. Police fired into the air, they said. The previous treaty expired in December 1988, but it was extended as negotiations continued through several changes of government in Greece. Seventeen rounds of talks under the socialist government of Premier Andreas Papandreou proved fruitless. The talks were put on hold last year when coalition governments held power. The conservative government, elected April 8, and the United States reached agreement in principle on May 30 after two rounds of talks. On Monday, Papandreou called for a referendum on the defense agreement and warned it could hurt Greece's relations with nearby countries. ``Crete is being turned into a fortress,'' he said. ``It provides the possibility of (the United States) undertaking air operations out of the NATO area, against countries of the Middle East and North Africa.'' Premier Constantine Mitsotakis denied the agreement harmed relations with other countries.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used AM-Minority Farmers, a0604 of July 19, may wish to use the following.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press story of July 19 on the disappearance of minority farmers did not make clear the relationship between the Minority Farmers Rights Act and the 1990 farm bill. The farm bill drafted by the House Agriculture Committee authorizes $20 million for education and technical assistance programs for minority farmers. The $20 million authorization was included in the bill at the request of Rep. Mike Espy, D-Miss., and was taken from the Minority Farmers Rights Act he introduced last month. The authorization includes $15 million in education and technical assistance programs for minority farmers, and $5 million for grants to historically black land grant colleges, Indian tribal community colleges, Hispanic institutions of higher education and Alaska cooperative colleges. Espy said he hopes to get the remainder of his Minority Farmers Rights Act enacted into law next year. Sen. Wyche Fowler Jr., D-Ga., who has introduced a similar minority farmers rights bill in the Senate, said last week he hopes to incorporate many of its provisions into the Senate version of the 1990 Farm Bill. The legislation would establish policies in the Department of Agriculture to end discrimination in the awarding of federal farm benefits, create an affirmative action program within the department and establish an appeals process for discrimination compliants.

DOC.HEAD: City Health Commissioner Shakes Up Department Over Pap Smear Scandal
DOC.TEXT: City Health Commissioner Woodrow A. Myers fired a top aide and reassigned two others Monday in a sweeping departmental shakeup prompted by the mishandling of Pap smear test results. Calling it a ``betrayal of public trust,'' Myers told a news conference that an investigation found a combination of mismanagement and poor supervision led to ``critical delays'' in notifying women tested at city-run clinics of findings that could indicate they had cervical cancer. While no women apparently have died as a result of the mishandling, Myers indicated that some could be at risk. In response to questions, he said the Health Department already was facing at least one lawsuit, but refused to discuss it further or to speculate on whether more legal actions may occur. The scandal, first brought to light in newspaper reports several months ago, involved Pap tests administered to some 3,000 women at city-run Sexually Transmitted Disease clinics. The tests were allowed to accumulate for a year without lab analysis or notice of the results to the patients. When the tests were finally read, 600 women were found to have abnormalities, including 11 cases where cancerous cells were found and 93 where pre-cancer conditions existed. All but two of 104 women whose test results were most ominous have been located by the department, Myers said. He conceded there was a ``very low'' prospect for finding the other two, one of whom he said had used a false name, while the other was wanted by the FBI in an unrelated matter. Myers named a six-member panel in May to investigate the affair. In announcing its findings on Monday, he said it was apparent that department policies since 1988 ``have resulted in an outrageous insensitivity to women who rely on this department. ``The unconscionable delays were a betrayal of public trust. This cannot continue.'' Myers said Dr. Kenneth Dressler, former assistant commissioner in the department's bureau of laboratories, had been fired, while Norman Scherzer, former assistant commissioner for Epidemiology and Prevention Services, and John Miles, former director of the Sexually Transmitted Disease Department, were both being reassigned within the department. Myers said a fourth official, Dr. Stephen Schultz, former deputy commissioner for Epidemiology and Prevention Services, had been reassigned earlier from administrative to clinical duties. In addition to those changes, Myers said he will appoint a new Deputy Commissioner for Disease Intervention to oversee the process and has agreed to have other Health Department programs reviewed by state agencies. He said all of the tests that had gone unread have since been analyzed, and department laboratories are now returning results within a week. An outside lab is under contract to handle any overload, to make sure that time frame is maintained, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Scheduled to Begin for Navajo Chairman
DOC.TEXT: The Navajo Supreme Court on Monday denied suspended tribal Chairman Peter MacDonald's request to remove the judge presiding over his election-fraud case. The trial is scheduled to start Tuesday before the tribe's District Judge Robert Yazzie in Window Rock. But the tribe's Supreme Court scheduled a hearing before the trial's start to determine if MacDonald will have adequate legal counsel. MacDonald, who was put on paid leave by the Tribal Council, faces 93 counts of election fraud in his 1986 re-election to the tribe's chairmanship. The charges allege MacDonald filed a fraudulent campaign report when he failed to report contributions from non-Indians and Indians. The charges also allege the funds received exceeded the maximum of $84,192 allowed. MacDonald asked the Supreme Court on Friday to remove Yazzie on grounds of bias. ``The prosecutors know they have a judge who is already on their side,'' MacDonald stated in a motion. MacDonald said Yazzie is biased against him because MacDonald attempted to remove the judge from the bench and claimed advisory counsel appointed by the judge is inadequate. MacDonald is acting as his own attorney, but has lawyers for advisers. ``I am not a lawyer and do not know how to conduct a trial. The special prosecutors want to make sure I cannot get a lawyer appointed beyond the `cardboard-cutout' lawyers that Judge Yazzie appointed in the last minute to make people think I am getting a fair shake,'' MacDonald said in the motion. After the election-fraud trial, MacDonald still faces two separate trials on charges of bribes and kickbacks and on conspiracy charges in the tribe's purchase of a large ranch. A lawer previously retained by MacDonald bowed out, citing health problems, and MacDonald has said was having difficulty retaining replacement lawyers. Navajo Legal Aid Attorney Peter Breen and Farmington, N.M., private attorney Doug Moeller were appointed by Yazzie to advise MacDonald. Breen said he planned to appear in court Tuesday, but Moeller said he would stay away.

Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of July 16-23:
DOC.HEAD: AP Speeds Up PhotoStream and Picture Desk Schedules
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press is accelerating implementation of its PhotoStream network and installation of AP Leaf Picture Desks, aiming to finish nationwide by the end of 1991, a year earlier than previously announced. President Louis D. Boccardi said July 19 that the decision to step up the schedule came in response to encouragement from member newspapers to put the new photo system in place as soon as possible. Installations of PhotoStream and AP Leaf Picture Desks will start in September in New York, the state in which AP will save the most money by switching from land-line transmission to satellite delivery of pictures. Installations will start in October in other Northeastern states. In February, installations will commence simultaneously in the three other divisions of the AP's domestic photo service _ Southeast, Central and West. Within each region, AP teams will work in more than one state at a time, but the general order for installations is determined by where the greatest savings can be made to help pay for the program. The original timetable had called for a 28-month installation program. ``But development of hardware and software has proceeded at a pace that indicates we should attempt to accomplish this enormous task in 16 months,'' Boccardi said. He said the AP would give its members at least a quarterly update on the progress of the installation program. In addition to the land-line savings, the Northeastern region is the first to begin conversion because of its proximity to AP's photo and computer headquarters in New York, AP's technical center in New Jersey and Leaf Systems Inc. in Massachusetts, which manufactures the AP Leaf Picture Desk. The New York region states, in order of installations, are: New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New Jersey, Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire and Connecticut. Installation in the other three regions will be in this general order: Central: Texas, Ohio, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota, North Dakota, Minnesota, Illinois, Kansas, Missouri, Wisconsin, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Colorado and Wyoming. West: California, Nevada, Oregon, Washington, Arizona, New Mexico, Idaho, Montana, Utah, Alaska and Hawaii. Southeast: Louisiana, Mississippi, Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia, Florida, North Carolina, West Virginia, Virginia, South Carolina, Maryland and Delaware. Additional photo editors will be hired for the control bureaus of each region to edit and transmit pictures from bureaus and newspapers in the states under their jurisdiction. Additional staff also will be hired to install the darkrooms and train member newspaper staffs. AP will set up a full-time Help Desk to assist members with the changeover. Black and white pictures currently are transmitted in about nine minutes and color in 30 minutes. When fully implemented, PhotoStream will allow delivery of black and white pictures in one minute and color in three minutes. The AP also announced it would use the AP Leaf Picture Desk for its internal photo computer system and would discontinue development and marketing of the AP VAX Picture Desk, which runs on Digital Equipment Corp. computers. ``The AP Leaf Picture Desk exceeds our expectations in power, speed and functionality,'' said John Reid, AP vice president and director of communications and technology. ``Work on new features is proceeding rapidly. Members attending ANPA-TEC saw the difference and demonstrated an overwhelming preference for the Leaf.'' If an AP member newspaper does not want an AP Leaf Picture Desk, it may keep its present photo receiver or accept a two-minute receiver. Or it may choose to buy an electronic darkroom from another company, in which case AP will provide a rebate of $47 weekly for five years, effective on the date the member would have received its AP Leaf Picture Desk. The present photo receiver will be left in place at sites where an AP Leaf Picture Desk is installed. Members receiving an AP Leaf Picture Desk and PhotoStream will be assessed a surcharge of between $15 and $80 weekly, depending on circulation.
DOC.HEAD: Court Rules in Favor of Newspapers in Confidential Source Case
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper cannot be held liable for breaking a promise of confidentiality to a source, the Minnesota Supreme Court ruled in rejecting a $700,000 award against the state's two biggest daily papers. Lawyers for both sides agreed the 4-2 ruling July 20 has far-reaching implications for the nation's news organizations. The court rejected a jury's award of $200,000 in compensatory damages and $500,000 in punitive damages to Dan Cohen. Cohen had sued the Saint Paul Pioneer Press and the Star Tribune of Minneapolis for 1982 stories identifying him as the source of documents showing a Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor had been convicted of shoplifting 12 years earlier. Cohen, then a Republican gubernatorial candidate's consultant, had given the newspapers' reporters the information in return for assurances of confidentiality. But the newspapers' editors overruled the reporters, believing readers should know the information came from the GOP candidate's campaign. The Supreme Court upheld an appeals court's dismissal of Cohen's claim of fraudulent misrepresentation, but reversed the appeals court's ruling allowing him to claim breach of contract. ``To impose a contract theory on this arrangement puts an unwarranted legal rigidity on a special ethical relationship, precluding necessary consideration of factors underlying that ethical relationship,'' Associate Justice John Simonett wrote. The court also said enforcement of the promise of confidentiality under a doctrine that implies a legal contract where none exists would violate the newspapers' First Amendment rights. Cohen's lawyer, Elliot Rothenberg, said he would appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court. The Associated Press filed the only friend-of-the-court brief in the case. Cohen's victory at trial had produced a spate of similar lawsuits around the country, the AP's attorneys said. The breach-of-contract theory was being used by plaintiffs elsewhere to avoid the constitutional obstacles that stand in the way of winning privacy and libel suits, said Dick Winfield, an attorney for the AP. The Minnesota ruling is ``the first definitive opinion'' by a state supreme court directly addressing the issue and the media ``can take considerable comfort'' in the case, he said. Joel R. Kramer, executive editor of the Star Tribune, said his paper was ``especially pleased that the court has ruled that the decision to publish true facts relating to the activities of `a political source in a political campaign' is one that is protected by the First Amendment.'' But Bill Salisbury, the Pioneer Press reporter who accepted Cohen's documents and objected strongly to his editors' decision to identify Cohen as the source, said the ruling will make his job more difficult. ``What the ruling tells reporters ... is that if an editor wants to overrule your promise of anonymity to a source, he or she can do so,'' Salisbury said. ``So, it will make me much more careful about granting confidentialtiy to sources, and it will make me much more reluctant to reveal the names of my sources to editors.''

DOC.HEAD: Profit Down at Gannett, Times, Pulitzer; Scripps Has Loss
DOC.TEXT: Gannett Co. Inc. reported a 6.1 percent decline in after-tax profit for the second quarter, its first quarterly earnings dip in 22 years as a public company. Other companies reporting drops in net earnings were The New York Times Co., 35 percent; Pulitzer Publishing Co., 34 percent; McClatchy Newspapers Inc., 22 percent; and Multimedia Inc., 12.5 percent. E.W. Scripps Co. reported a loss for the quarter as a result of a special charge for the cost of terminating a joint operating agreement in Knoxville, Tenn. Media General Inc. said its second-quarter profit more than doubled from a year ago, primarily because of a one-time gain from the sale of its West Coast weekly newspapers and the receipt of overdue newsprint royalties. Park Communications Inc. said its net profit inched higher.
