A weak advertising market hurt the newspaper operations of the companies reporting this past week. ``It's the same problem the whole industry has _ the ad linage numbers continue to be disappointing,'' Peter Appert, media industry analyst for the investment firm C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell, said July 18. Retail advertising, which accounts for about half of the typical newspaper's ad revenue, has been hurt because of industry consolidation and severe financial woes at some major department store chains. Classified advertising, which makes up about 40 percent of a newspaper's ad revenue, has fallen as the economy has deteriorated in parts of the country.

Gannett's after-tax profit was $105.3 million for the three-month period ended July 1, down from $112.1 million a year earlier. Operating income fell 10 percent to $193.1 million from $215.6 million. Revenue slipped 1 percent to $893.8 million from $904.2 million. Gannett said newspaper ad revenue fell 4 percent to $497.5 million. Paid advertising pages at USA Today dropped 12 percent to 929 pages, but the company said rate increases and higher readership boosted revenues. Broadcasting revenue slipped 1.1 percent to $108.6 million. Outdoor ad revenues rose 6 percent to $72.4 million. For the first six months of the year, Gannett earned $180.3 million, down 4 percent from $187 million a year earlier. Revenue slipped 1 percent to $1.71 billion from $1.72 billion.

Times earned $26.8 million in the April-June quarter, compared with $41.3 million in 1989. Revenue rose 2 percent to $468.9 million from $460.3 million. Operating profit at the newspaper group fell 25.2 percent to $50.1 million. Ad volume at The New York Times fell 13.4 percent, with about 60 percent of the decline coming in classified advertising. Ad volume at the regional newspapers rose 2.5 percent for the quarter. The magazine group's operating profit plunged 88 percent to $500,000 because of costs associated with the purchase of McCall's magazine last August. Results were steady at the broadcasting and information services segment. For the first six months, Times earned $43.4 million, down 42 percent from $74.8 million a year ago. Revenue rose 1.9 percent to $900.1 million from $883.4 million.

Scripps recorded a $162,000 loss for the quarter, compared with a net profit of $25.2 million in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue rose 3.4 percent to $332 million from $321 million. The loss reflected a $36.4 million pre-tax charge related to payments the company will make to Persis Corp. to terminate the JOA between Scripps' Knoxville News-Sentinel and The Knoxville Journal, owned by Persis. Under the agreement, which ends in December 1991, the News-Sentinel provides sales, production and distribution for the Journal. Scripps said that without the charge, net income would have been $23.5 million, down 6.7 percent from a year earlier. ``The soft advertising environment continues to impact revenue growth, particularly in the newspaper group,'' Lawrence A. Leser, Scripps' president and chief executive officer, said in a news release July 17. For the first six months, Scripps' net income fell 76.2 percent to $9.6 million from $40.3 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.2 percent to $629.4 million from $615.8 million.

Media General earned $12.5 million in the quarter, compared with $6.1 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 5.4 percent to $158.0 million from $149.9 million. The results included an after-tax gain of $6.4 million from the sale of its Golden West-Highlander weekly newspapers and past-due royalties from its Mexican newsprint affiliate. The sluggish economic climate depressed both retail and classified advertising at the company's newspapers. Ad revenues also were down at the company's TV station, but strong growth in its cable TV operation in Fairfax, Va., helped lift the revenue and earnings for the broadcast division. For the first six months, Media General earned $15.1 million, down 16 percent from $17.9 million in 1989. Revenue rose 1.7 percent to $151 million from $148.4 million.

Multimedia netted $9.6 million in the quarter, compared with $10.8 million in 1989. Revenue rose 2.4 percent to $123.9 million from $121.0 million. The company said the drop in profit reflected a one-time loss of $3.1 million from refinancing its long-term debt of $718 million as well as sluggish retail and automotive advertising. For the first six months, Multimedia's net profit totaled $15.7 million, up 2 percent from $15.4 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.8 percent to $233.7 million from $227.3 million.

McClatchy earned $7.8 million in the quarter, compared with $10 million a year earlier. Operating income was up 4.3 percent to $17.1 million from $16.4 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 10.6 percent to $107.6 million from $97.3 million. McClatchy blamed the profit decline on startup losses from a newsprint mill partnership and costs associated with its purchase of six newspapers in South Carolina earlier this year. For the first six months, earnings totaled $10.2 million, down 31.1 percent from $14.8 million. Revenue rose 10.3 percent to $202.7 million from $184.3 million.

Pulitzer said declining advertising caused after-tax profit to fall to $4.59 million in the second quarter, down from $6.92 million a year earlier. Revenues rose to $103.8 million from $103.3 million. Pulitzer said profit also was affected by depreciation and amortization connected with the acquisition of WDSU-TV in New Orleans and the sale of WPTA-TV in Fort Wayne, Ind. For the first six months, Pulitzer's earnings of $5.5 million were down 44 percent from $9.96 million a year ago. Revenue edged up 0.8 percent to $199 million from $197.4 million.

Park reported a net profit of $5.87 million for the quarter, up 0.7 percent from $5.83 million a year earlier. Revenue slipped 1 percent to $42.8 million from $43.2 million. Chairman Roy H. Park said advertising revenue was down. For the first half, Park's net profit was nearly unchanged at $8.68 million, compared with $8.67 million a year earlier. Revenue slipped to $78.9 million from $79.8 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Management Employee Misappropriated $900,000, Tribune Co. Says
DOC.TEXT: Tribune Co. said it fired its marketing director for the alleged misuse of an estimated $900,000 and referred the case to federal prosecutors. No criminal charges had been filed against Robert Dickey, who had worked for Tribune and its affiliates for 13 years. The company declined to give details on the alleged misappropriation of funds. However, the Chicago Tribune, a subsidiary of the company, reported July 18 that a source it did not identify contended the dismissal stemmed from regular payments to a Chicago-based vendor. The payments were made when Dickey was marketing director of the Tribune and ceased when he was promoted to the parent company last fall, the newspaper said, citing the source. Dickey's lawyer, James Montana Jr., said Dickey was cooperating with the company's investigation. Dickey declined to discuss the case. Joseph Hays, a Tribune Co. spokesman, said Dickey was fired July 16. ``We cannot comment further on the matter at this time, except to say that an internal investigation is continuing,'' Hays said. ``No criminal charges have been filed, but the matter has been referred to the U.S. attorney in Chicago.'' A spokesman said the company was protected by insurance.
DOC.HEAD: Report Forecasts 7.6 Percent Growth in Media Revenues Through 1994
DOC.TEXT: Media revenues will grow at a 7.6 percent yearly rate to $461.3 billion by 1994, exceeding growth in the economy but slowing from its 8.9 percent pace of the past five years, a study said July 22. But the report from the investment banking firm Veronis Suhler & Associates, which specializes in media deals, predicted revenues will rise faster for newspapers and broadcasters. In its fourth annual industry forecast, the firm said overall revenues will grow more slowly because of ``maturation of the technology-driven industries of the 1980s'' such as home video, cable TV, compact disc recordings and business information. Among the report's predictions: _Newspaper revenues will rise at a 6.7 percent annual rate over the next five years to $61.8 billion in 1994, up from a 6.3 percent annual rate the past half-decade. Annual growth at weekly newspapers will outpace growth at dailies, 7.9 percent to 6.6 percent. _TV revenues will grow 6.8 percent a year to $33.9 billion in 1994, up from 5.8 percent. Network TV, which rose at a slim 2.2 percent annual rate the past five years, will grow at a 6.6 percent annual pace. Growth at local TV stations will slow to 6.9 percent a year from 7.5 percent. _Radio will see growth of 8 percent a year to $12.3 billion by 1994, up from 7.6 percent. Cable TV will grow 8 percent annually to $19.5 billion in 1994, down from 12 percent.
DOC.HEAD: USA Today Says Financier Skewed Results of Poll on Trump
DOC.TEXT: Cincinnati financier Carl H. Lindner Jr. skewed results of a call-in telephone poll on Donald Trump, USA Today said. The newspaper said July 19 that an independent analysis of the call-in results to its ``Trump hot line'' June 8-10 found that 5,640 of 7,802 calls came from two phone numbers at Great American Insurance Co., a subsidiary of Lindner's American Financial Corp. Lindner would not comment, the newspaper said, but a spokeswoman for him said the calls were made because Lindner and others at the company admire Trump's ``entrepreneurial spirit.'' The newspaper said it studied phone records generated by Airdata Inc., a call-in service company, because of some apparent last-minute ballot-stuffing. From 5 to 6 p.m. EDT on June 10, the final hour of the three-day call-in period, more than 1,000 calls poured in. Ninety-three percent of those calls were pro-Trump, the newspaper said. Callers were asked to say which statement they agreed with: ``Donald Trump symbolizes what makes the USA a great country'' or ``Donald Trump symbolizes the things that are wrong with this country.'' Trump won in a ``landslide,'' with 5,215 votes, or 81 percent, agreeing with the first statement despite Trump's recent financial and marital problems. The second statement got 1,191 votes, or 19 percent of the 6,406 callers who cast votes. USA Today said it would take steps to prevent such skewed results in the future, while guaranteeing callers' privacy.
DOC.HEAD: Boston Globe Files Suit Against Tax Package
DOC.TEXT: The Boston Globe filed the first legal challenge to the state's new tax package July 19, claiming it is unconstitutional to tax the materials used to publish a newspaper. The tax package, which became law a day earlier, not only broadens the 5 percent sales tax to hundreds of business services, it also extends the tax to the materials and equipment used to publish a newspaper or transmit a broadcast. The Globe's suit in Supreme Judicial Court did not raise the issue of broadcasters. Instead, the Globe argued Massachusetts law exempts manufacturers from paying a sales tax on raw materials and tools used in production, and thus it would be discriminatory to apply such a tax to newspaper companies. ``Newspaper publishers are the only manufacturers of tangible personal property excluded from the manufacturing exemptions,'' the lawsuit said. The Globe also argued the tax law opens the possibility of ``burdensome taxation'' on the press that could obstruct critical comment about the government. Robert Mehrman, head of the Massachusetts Broadcasters Association, said he could not discuss whether radio and television stations also would file suit against the tax. The Globe's suit pointed to a similar tax that was enacted in Minnesota and struck down in 1983 by the U.S. Supreme Court. Minnesota taxed the ink and paper used by publishers while other businesses using those products were not subject to the tax. The Supreme Court said ``differential taxation of the press'' ran counter to the rights guaranteed by the First Amendment and said the state did not show a compelling reason to permit the tax.
DOC.HEAD: There It Was on Page 8: A Story by `Fake Byline'
DOC.TEXT: Some readers of The New York Times were treated to the debut of a writer they never knew existed: Fake Byline. Byline's first _ and, the Times hopes, last _ appearance in the paper came July 20 on page A8, where a story about a Texas-Mexico ferry appeared under bold type declaring ``By Fake Byline.'' In smaller type, it said, ``Special to The New York Times.'' ``The story was not supposed to have a byline on it, but our computer format doesn't work without one,'' explained Times spokeswoman Nancy Nielsen. ``We plug in `Fake Byline' so the format works. It's supposed to be deleted, but ...'' An inexperienced computer operator, unsure of working the equipment, failed to remove the bogus byline and out it went, she said. The byline did not appear in all editions, so it was not known how many readers saw the glitch, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Paper's Coupon Campaign Against Drug Suspects Goes Statewide
DOC.TEXT: West Virginians can join the war on drugs by using coupons to send tips to authorities under a statewide program that is an offshoot of a campaign by the Williamson Daily News. In announcing the program July 16, state police hailed it as a new wave in citizen crimefighting, but civil libertarians warned that the program _ under which tips can be mailed or phoned in anonymously _ will create a society in which people spy on each other. The program was adapted from one used by the Daily News. Authorities received nearly 700 replies after the paper printed coupons on its own and invited people to mail them to state police. Federal, state and local authorities arrested 46 people in Mingo County as a result of the coupon tips in June. Wally Warden, editor of the newspaper, said six people had been convicted so far. The Daily News got the idea from the Clinton (Iowa) Herald, which asked readers to anonymously list the names of anyone they suspect of using or selling drugs. The Milford (Conn.) Citizen also has run a similar campaign. Warden said his paper had been contacted by law enforcement agencies in Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Ohio, Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas for information about the program.
DOC.HEAD: Southern Baptist Convention Fires News Editors
DOC.TEXT: Two top editors of the Southern Baptist Convention's press agency were fired after they refused to resign. The denomination's executive committee voted July 17 to fire Baptist Press editor Alvin C. Shackleford and news director Dan Martin. Shackleford had worked at Baptist Press for 3{ years and Martin for nearly a decade. Shackleford said they were not given exact reasons for the dismissals, but said he believed the ruling fundamentalists felt the journalists were biased against the majority view. Committee members refused to comment, saying only that Chairman Sam W. Pace had ordered them to refrain from discussing the matter outside the session, which was closed to the public. Some committee members had charged the Baptist Press with supporting the denomination's moderate wing. Nashville attorney Jeffrey Mobley announced later that a new, independent press agency to be called Associated Baptist Press was being formed. ``It will not seek sponsorship or affiliation with the Southern Baptist Convention,'' Mobley said. ``It will be a stand-alone news agency that will report on issues to people interested in Southern Baptist affairs.'' The 44-year-old Baptist Press sends stories and press releases to about 400 clients, including 38 independent Southern Baptist weekly newspapers. The executive committee didn't say whether replacements had been hired. It gave the two editors seven months' severance pay and benefits.
DOC.HEAD: Feds Examining Possible News Agency Leak of Jobless Figure
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department is looking into the possibility that its June unemployment report was leaked to traders in financial markets by an unidentified news service. The matter involves the monthly report released July 6 on unemployment in June but is not a formal investigation, spokesman Bob Zachariasiewicz said July 18. He said the department was merely studying a report that the information had been leaked early and caused a fluctuation in market activity. When the report is released each month, news organizations are given copies at 8 a.m. on the condition that the contents not be released until 8:30 a.m. Markets can rise or fall based on this information, and its release even a minute prematurely has drawn the department's ire in the past. Zachariasiewicz declined to say which news organization was being reviewed but another Labor Department source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it was a Japanese service. The department recently cautioned Japanese news organizations in advance of the release of its report on producer prices, the source said. ``We've been having some trouble with the Japanese,'' the source said but would not elaborate.
DOC.HEAD: Newsweek Paid $60 to Prostitute Who `Confessed' to AIDS Infection
DOC.TEXT: Newsweek paid a prostitute $60 to tell her story of selling sex while infected with AIDS, the magazine said July 18. The woman says she was ``dope sick'' and lied to get the money. The article led to the arrest of the woman, Linda Kean, by police who wanted her charged with attempted murder for knowingly exposing her customers to AIDS. But she was released July 17 after Alameda County prosecutors decided they lacked evidence to press the charge. Newsweek included her story in a June 25 article about AIDS. Despite a magazine policy against it, Kean was paid $60 after posing for a photograph and telling her story, Newsweek spokeswoman Karen Wheeler said. ``In this case, after the photo was shot, the subject was given $60,'' Wheeler said. ``Immediately after this was discovered by the top editors, they reminded all concerned of the magazine's commitment to that policy.''
DOC.HEAD: Movies Move In on Defunct L.A. Newspaper Landmark
DOC.TEXT: The printing press and ornate lobby are real, and so is the city editor's desk. The gunshots and blood are not. Movie makers are finding a bonanza in the unusual settings of the Spanish Renaissance landmark that once housed the Los Angeles Herald Examiner. At least a dozen productions, not counting commercials, have been filmed at the domed building since the newspaper folded last Nov. 2, according to city permit files. Clint Eastwood moved in for Warner Bros.' soon-to-be-released movie ``The Rookie.'' So did Universal's ``Murder, She Wrote.'' ``It's really an ideal place for filming,'' said Ken Johnson, site coordinator for Hollywood Location Co. ``There's such a wide variety of spaces and looks ... directors of photography just love the windows in the mail room.'' Completed in 1915, the faded pink palace was designed by Julia Morgan, who created William Randolph Hearst's castle at San Simeon. The newspaper building sprawls over more than half a city block. Movie and commercial making will continue at least into the fall, said Maxwell McCrohon, the former Herald Examiner editor. He said Hearst Corp. had no plans to sell the building but was considering renting it to full-time tenants. The ornate lobby has been an exclusive men's club and a hotel. A stenciled notice to inmates makes a newsroom pass for a prison dayroom. Around the corner, there's a detective squad room; you can tell by the ``Robbery-Homicide'' plate on the city editor's desk. Sometimes the building shapes a movie. ``Occasionally they'll still be writing when they scout a location and see something with such good production values that they'll rewrite the script to get it in,'' said Johnson. He said a look at the row of hulking presses was enough to send script writers back to work on the TV movie ``Rainbow Drive.'' The bad guy wound up meeting his end being crunched in Press No. 9, still grimy with Herald Examiner ink.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Uniform Libel Law for States Criticized for Alleged Bias
DOC.TEXT: A proposed uniform libel law under which courts would decide whether statements are true or false before determining appropriate damages would not guarantee First Amendment rights for defendants, critics say. The Uniform Defamation Act is the first proposal for a nationwide standard in libel disputes. It was discussed July 20 by the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws, a group appointed by the nation's governors to draft model legislation. The 28-page draft outlines a two-stage procedure for libel trials. A court would first determine whether a statement under question was true or false. Only later _ during the trial's second stage _ would a court decide what, if any, damages to assess. Safeguards for the press _ protection if a reporter acted without malice or allowances made if a plaintiff is a public official _ would not apply in the trial's first stage. The committee said the draft was based on the premise that plaintiffs are more interested in clearing their names than in receiving damages. Harvey Perlman, dean of the University of Nebraska's College of Law and author of the draft, said the proposed law's intent was to protect plaintiffs' reputations better, but it also would benefit news organizations. Under the proposal, news organizations could print retractions or pay a plaintiff's legal fees after the first stage _ a provision proponents say would shorten trials and reduce the amount of damages awarded. ``We wanted to create some incentives for the plaintiff to stop early,'' Perlman said. But critics argue the committee's desire to design safeguards for a person's reputation would create a ``chilling effect'' on the First Amendment. ``One of our central concerns is the committee's desire to move the law in favor of the plaintiff,'' said Henry R. Kaufman, counsel for the Libel Defense Resource Center. ``There will be a chilling effect if the media believes it is going to face higher costs and greater burdens of libel and litigation.'' Others at the annual conference questioned creating one standard for an intricate field of First Amendment law and court decisions. ``I don't feel it's an area of the law where you can provide a uniform act,'' said John McClaugherty, a lawyer from Charleston, W.Va. ``The First Amendment is constantly being reinterpreted and by the time a law was passed it would already be out of date.'' The earliest a proposal would be redrafted and returned to the 350-member conference would be next year, Perlman said, but no date was set for a vote.
DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Claim of First Amendment Privilege for TV Outtakes
DOC.TEXT: Maine's highest court rejected a television station's attempt to withhold portions of a videotaped interview sought by a prosecutor as evidence in a criminal investigation. Officials of WCSH-TV declined to comment on the July 20 ruling, saying they would meet with the station's lawyers to plan their next move. In its unanimous decision, the Maine Supreme Judicial Court dismissed the station's assertion that First Amendment guarantees of a free press established a ``qualified privilege'' to protect the portions of the interview with Biddeford Police Commissioner Denis Letellier that were not broadcast. The justices said it was essential a York County grand jury view the full 12-minute tape as part of its investigation into allegations that Letellier used his position to get a motor vehicle charge against his son reduced. After the tape was subpoenaed, the station turned over the 2{ minutes of the interview that appeared on the air, but withheld the unused portions. The court based its ruling on a 1972 decision by a divided U.S. Supreme Court that said a ``a proper balance'' must be struck on a case-by-case basis between freedom of the press and the obligation of all citizens to provide relevant testimony about criminal conduct. ``The public interest in the integrity of the Biddeford police and city officials and in the effectiveness of the York County grand jury proceedings far outweighs any discernible impairment that the required production of the nonconfidential Letellier videotape outtakes might conceivably cause to the First Amendment interests asserted'' by WCSH, Chief Justice Vincent L. McKusick wrote.
DOC.HEAD: Woman Settles $30 Million Lawsuit Against Rivera
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys settled a $30 million libel suit against television personality Geraldo Rivera by a woman who was arrested during a drug raid carried live on national television. The 1987 suit by Terry Rouse of Channelview said she was falsely portrayed as a prostitute and drug seller by Rivera's Dec. 2, 1986, telecast of ``American Vice: The Doping of a Nation.'' The settlement, involving an undisclosed amount of money, came after Rivera was questioned for six hours during a deposition July 19. The lawsuit had been scheduled to go to trial Aug. 20. During the 1986 program, Rivera broadcast live outside a duplex where Ms. Rouse was staying when sheriff's deputies raided the home. Rivera said the people inside were an alleged pimp and prostitute who were supplying drugs to truckers. Ms. Rouse was dragged from the duplex and handcuffed as an estimated 15 million viewers watched, she said in the lawsuit. Ms. Rouse has maintained she was hired to paint the house, which belonged to a friend. Cocaine possession charges against her stemming from the televised bust were dismissed.
DOC.HEAD: Former Official Resolves Libel Suit With UPI
DOC.TEXT: Former state official Larry Mehau and United Press International resolved a 13-year-old libel lawsuit stemming from allegations linking Mehau to organized crime, lawyers said July 19. A federal judge dismissed the suit last September, saying UPI was protected by the ``neutral reporting doctrine.'' The judge also said Mehau, now a rancher, failed to prove the news report false. Mehau appealed the decision, and the case was sent to mediation. Under the settlement, UPI will make a charitable donation with some of the money it would have spent on continuing the legal battle, according to a joint statement from Mehau and UPI's attorneys. The 1977 story in dispute quoted an article in the now-defunct Valley Isle newspaper on Maui. The newspaper implied that underworld figures had killed Hawaiian environmental activist George Helm. UPI reporter Dennis Stone filed a story based on the newspaper report and an interview with Helm's father. The story quoted Helm's relatives as saying the missing activist had been threatened by Mehau, then a member of the state Board of Land and Natural Resources. The story also said Helm's brother, Adolph, identified Mehau as the ``godfather'' of organized crime in Hawaii. Mehau sued UPI, but lost two years later at the trial level. The state Supreme Court reversed the decision on appeal, concluding Stone acted with actual malice, and the case moved into the federal courts, where it was thrown out last year.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Society Files Libel Suit Against Florida Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Performing Arts Society of Stuart filed a libel suit July 16 against The Stuart News and its entertainment editor, saying the newspaper published a ``campaign of falsehoods'' designed to wreck the society's image. The non-profit society, headed by Dorothy Nabutovsky of Palm City, brings nationally known performing artists to Stuart and is trying to raise $12 million to build a 2,250-seat concert hall south of the city. On May 27, the News published the results of an investigation by entertainment editor Jon Pine that said the society exaggerated fund-raising claims, filed incorrect reports with state agencies and thwarted inspection of public documents. Pine wrote followup articles about a state investigation into the society's operations and an eviction action involving the office where the society had done business. ``The words themselves have caused (the society) to be regarded with scorn, contempt, ridicule and disrespect by the community and will continue to for the foreseeable future as they attack the society's reputation in the conduct of its affairs,'' according to the suit filed in Martin Circuit Court. The suit seeks more than $5,000 in damages on each of three counts. Stephen Papy, a Miami lawyer, said donations and ticket sales had dropped because of the articles. The News reported June 30 that an investigation by the state attorney general's consumer protection and fair trade practices unit found the society was operating within the law. Assistant Attorney General Mark Barnett said then: ``Do things look fishy? Definitely. There are things that should raise questions in donors' minds. Is it illegal? No, not under the current laws.'' Pine, a reporter at the News since January 1988, said he stands by his stories. ``I am very confident that the information contained in them is factual and was presented without bias or malice,'' he said. Thomas E. Weber, editor and president of the News, agreed. ``I think the suit is a measure of how far off the track the Performing Arts Society has veered. There must be a better way for the society to use its resources than to sue the newspaper,'' Weber said.
DOC.HEAD: Eastwood Can Continue $20 Million Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled July 20 that Clint Eastwood can pursue a $20 million lawsuit against a national tabloid over a report that the actor was threatened by neo-Nazis. Superior Court Judge Dion Morrow gave The Globe 20 days to respond to the suit's allegations. Eastwood contends an article in the tabloid's Jan. 2 edition was false and caused him mental anguish by making him fear for his life. The lawsuit also alleges an invasion of privacy in portraying the actor falsely. The Globe stands by the story's accuracy, said Anthony Glassman, a lawyer for the Florida-based paper. The Globe reported that Eastwood had received death threats and that a $100,000 bounty was placed on his life after he refused to speak at a convention of the Aryan Nations, a white supremacy group. ``Our position was simply that to be the enemy of American Nazis is not a bad thing. It's not offensive,'' Glassman said. ``He (Eastwood) claims, though, that he suffered emotional distress as a consequence of being put in fear that someone might act on that .. . that it might cause someone to go out and try to collect the bounty.''
DOC.HEAD: Publisher Wins Right To Seek Damages for Bike Crash
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper publisher who also is a bicycling champion has won the right to seek damages from the state for injuries he suffered in an accident on a highway bicycle path in 1985. In a 5-2 decision July 16, the Michigan Supreme Court reversed an appeals court ruling that had been based on an earlier case granting immunity to the state for injuries that occurred on a bike path separate from the road. ``The alleged defect in this case occurred upon a bicycle path that unquestionably comprised part of the improved portion of the highway designed for vehicular travel and not on an installation separated and detached from the improved portion,'' Justice James Brickley wrote. Gregg, publisher of The Daily Press in Escanaba, was training on his racing bike Sept. 10, 1985, in Delta County's Ford River Township. The paved path was along Michigan 35 between the road used by cars and its shoulder, separated only by painted white lines. While going about 27 mph, Gregg's bike struck a pothole and he was catapulted forward. He fractured his skull though he was wearing a helmet and broke several other bones. He now has epilepsy. The Supreme Court sent the case back to the Court of Claims in Ingham County to determine liability and damages.
DOC.HEAD: Philippine Broadcasters Provided Lifelines After Quake
DOC.TEXT: When Karen Yee wanted to tell her uncles she was safe after a devastating earthquake, she turned to the local radio station in Baguio to get the message through. When Red Cross official Richard Gordon needed to confer with authorities in quake-damaged Cabanatuan, he did so in a telephone patch provided by another radio station, which broadcast the consultations live. In the aftermath of the July 16 earthquake, which left hundreds of people dead, radio and television stations didn't only report the news. They helped rescuers and worried relatives circumvent poor communications and served as a spur to a clumsy, unresponsive bureaucracy. Broadcasters directed rescuers to areas of destruction, relayed messages to family members separated by the disaster and solicited relief goods. ``It was the radio stations which were coordinating rescue efforts, broacasting the need for blood, blankets, medicines, earth-moving equipment,'' columnist Luis Beltran wrote in The Manila Standard. ``Government departments went to them for guidance on what to send, where to send.'' After the quake struck, provincial affiliates of the major networks broadcast the first reports of destruction. At that time, President Corazon Aquino's staff said only that it was ``studying the extent'' of the disaster. Provincial officials, unable to get through to Manila by telephone, broadcast appeals to the capital for assistance over private stations. Radio and television reporters traveled through the affected area and briefed government officials about which towns and cities were in urgent need of help. ``They served as effective alternatives to government agencies whose addiction to routine has robbed them of the power of initiative and the ability to respond quickly,'' former Labor Minister Blas Ople wrote in The Manila Bulletin. As the extent of the disaster became clearer, stations discontinued regular programming for round-the-clock quake coverage. ``We shifted to public-service priority programming because we feel that that is the need of the present time,'' said Maria Asuncion Lanuza, program coordinator of DZBB. ``I think we are complementing the government.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Broadcasting Chief Fears `Orgy of Democracy'
DOC.TEXT: The head of Soviet television and radio says he fears ``an orgy of democracy'' now that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has loosened controls on the state broadcasting monopoly. Mikhail F. Nenashev, the chief of Gostelradio and a Communist Party traditionalist, said in an interview broadcast on Soviet TV that the change will make ``managing television ... much more complex than in the past.'' The interview was broadcast July 16, the day after Gorbachev issued his ``Presidential Decree on Democratization of Television and Radio'' to cut back on the Communist Party's monopoly on the airwaves. Until now, only groups approved by a state committee had access to Soviet television. As a result, the Communist Party received large segments of time on the airwaves. ``For a lasting time the television was under the party influence, what we used to call and still call the party monopoly,'' said Nenashev, who formerly was head of the state publishing committee. ``Now I am more afraid of an orgy of democracy rather than the party monopoly, when the monopoly is replaced by numerous demands put forth by various groups, parties, various councils, various organs,'' he said. Hundreds of new groups have sprung up throughout the country in the last several years.
DOC.HEAD: House of Commons Votes To Make TV Coverage Permanent
DOC.TEXT: The House of Commons has voted to make television coverage of its often rowdy proceedings permanent. The 131-32 vote July 19 followed an eight-month experiment that began Nov. 21 with TV cameras recording selected sessions of the proceedings. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was among those who initially opposed TV coverage, but the Conservative Party leader later changed her mind. Opponents said they feared for the reputation of the House because of frequent boisterous behavior among legislators. The House of Lords, the unelected upper chamber of Parliament, has had TV coverage since 1985.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Reporter's `Confession' Led to Execution
DOC.TEXT: Farzad Bazoft, the Iranian-born journalist who was hanged in Iraq after being convicted of espionage, might have saved his life if he had refused to make the confession his captors demanded, The Observer said July 22. Bazoft ``believed his interrogators when they told him he would be released if he confessed,'' said the newspaper, which employed Bazoft at the time of his arrest. Bazoft, 31, was executed March 15. Daphne Parish, the British nurse accused with him, refused to make a confession and was sentenced to 15 years in prison. She was freed July 16 after intervention by Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda. After her release she told reporters that she was innocent and that Bazoft was not a spy. Bazoft went to Iraq from London on an official press visit in the aftermath of the Iran-Iraq war. While there, he investigated reports of a huge explosion at a military installation south of Baghdad. Mrs. Parish, who was working in a Baghdad hospital, said Bazoft asked her to drive him to the site, and took pictures and collected dust samples. Both were arrested later. The Observer said that when Mrs. Parish refused to confess, interrogators kicked her, pulled her hair, threatened her with a rubber hose, held a knife in front of her and blindfolded her. The report said she was shown a videotape of Bazoft's confession and when she met him again, she asked why he had done it. He replied: ``Because of the electric shocks. They gave me a prepared statement.'' Both pleaded innocent at their trial by a military court, the paper said.
DOC.HEAD: Greek Court Sentences Two in Phone-Tapping of NY Times Bureau
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court has upheld the conviction of the publisher and the former managing editor of a leading Greek daily in the phone-tapping of The New York Times' bureau in Athens, a court spokesman said. The three-member court sentenced the two men to 20 days in jail, but they were permitted to avoid imprisonment by paying a fine, the spokesman said July 20 on condition of anonymity. The amount of the fine was not disclosed. Under Greek law, people convicted in cases not related to narcotics may pay to reduce or eliminate their prison terms if the terms are less than 18 months. The decision upheld the conviction of Ethnos Publisher George Bobolas and former managing editor Alekos Filippopoulos in May 1985, the spokesman said. Bobolas and Filippopoulos were found guilty of providing the former socialist government of Premier Andreas Papandreou with tapes of conversations tapped at the home and office of a journalist working for the Times and Daily Telegraph of London in July 1983.
DOC.HEAD: Radical Iranian Newspaper Accuses Western Reporters of Spying
DOC.TEXT: A radical Iranian newspaper said July 16 that many Western reporters sent to cover events in Iran were spies and warned the government to beware. The Persian-language Jomhuri Islami, which reflects the views of government hard-liners, said many Western journalists visited Iran ``to fulfill their missions assigned by the Zionists and Western spying agencies.'' The article, which was obtained by The Associated Press in Cyprus, blamed officials of the Ministry of Islamic Guidance, which is in charge of regulating the activities of foreign reporters, for giving reporters too much freedom on their trips to Iran. Journalists who visit Iran are assigned agents from the ministry who accompany them on all trips outside their hotels. Reporters are also required to submit their film and tapes to ministry officials for approval. ``It is simplicity if we think that the CIA, the (Israeli) Mossad and other intelligence services simply use one device to obtain information from Iran,'' the newspaper said. ``In addition to their set formula, they send reporters, photographers and cameramen as a cover-up.'' The Iranian government allows few Western news organizations to base representatives in Iran and other reporters are allowed to visit the country only on special occassions. Recently, reporters were allowed in to cover the first anniversary of the death of Iran's spiritual leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and the June earthquake that left about 40,000 people dead. Among the examples cited by the newspaper of ``non-journalistic activities'' during the visits: _A reporter from a major British televsion network tried to take an unauthorized photograph of a refinery. _Another British radio journalist visited downtown Tehran and tried to compile a report of illegal, black market sales of hard currency. _A Danish reporter tried to compile ``a negative report of the economy.''

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Bars Reporters From Covering Conference
DOC.TEXT: The government said July 19 that reporters for The Asian Wall Street Journal and the Far Eastern Economic Review would be barred from covering the Asia-Pacific Economic Conference. The three-day conference, which begins July 29, will discuss the economic course of the Asia-Pacific region. Representatives of the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Japan, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Philippines and Singapore are attending. The government has been at odds with the Journal and the Review, a weekly magazine, for several years over alleged interference in the domestic politics of this island city-state. Both are published in Hong Kong by Dow Jones & Co. of the United States. In a statement from New York, Dow Jones said that ``for reasons that are unclear'' it appears Singapore ``is extending its long-asserted right to restrict coverage of Singapore for Singaporean readers (and) restrict coverage of international economic meetings for all Asians.'' In 1987, the government required the Journal to reduce its daily circulation here to about 500 copies from 5,000. The Review was ordered to cut its circulation to 400-500 copies a week from 10,000 but the magazine refused to continue selling in Singapore. Dow Jones said Singapore had given reporters for the U.S.-based Wall Street Journal and AP-Dow Jones permission to attend the conference. AP-Dow Jones is a joint venture of The Associated Press and Dow Jones. The action against the Asian Journal and the Economic Review came a day after Singapore's government introduced a bill in Parliament that would require foreign newspapers wishing to circulate in Singapore to get permission annually.
DOC.HEAD: Press Freedom Group Calls Meeting To Aid Media in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The World Press Freedom Committee is urging all organizations hoping to foster a free press in Eastern Europe to coordinate their efforts through a meeting in October. ``An entirely new dimension of needs and opportunities faces all of us,'' Harold W. Andersen, chairman of the committee and former publisher of the Omaha World-Herald, said July 17. ``We all need to know what is being done _ and not being done.'' He urged interested organizations to take part in a one-day conference at the National Press Club in Washington on Oct. 10. The 14-year-old committee, which represents 33 national and international news organizations from five continents, already has surveyed the media of Eastern Europe and has prepared a list of possible projects. It also has published a ``Handbook for Journalists of Central and Eastern Europe'' and is serving as a clearing house for media organizations to match needs and resources. ``A substantial number of people and organizations, both public and private, are trying to help,'' said Anderson. ``We need to share information as to who is doing what. This should help all parties avoid duplication and cooperate more freely.'' He said the committee wanted participation from every organization already helping East European media or even thinking about it and urged them to contact the committee's Washington office. The commitee's address is: The World Press Freedom Committee, care of The Newspaper Center, P.O. Box 17407, Washington, D.C. 20041. Telephone: 703-648-1000; fax: 703-620-4557; telex: 292810.
DOC.HEAD: British Court Raps `Abuse of Power' in County's Murdoch Ad Ban
DOC.TEXT: The High Court ruled July 18 that a county authority committed a ``flagrant abuse of power'' in withdrawing its advertisements from a publication owned by Rupert Murdoch. The court said Derbyshire County Council's action was vindictive and made a ``gross attempt to deceive the court'' about its reasons. The council claimed the ban on advertising in the Times Educational Supplement was prompted by legitimate educational reasons, but the two-judge panel ruled it was vengeance against the Murdoch-owned Sunday Times for publishing articles criticizing council leader David Bookbinder. Such decision-making could only have been prompted ``by bad faith, or in a word, vindictiveness,'' said Judge Tasker Watkins. Quashing the ban as unlawful, he said it was a ``bad example of local authority maladministration which is potentially, if not actually, harmful to the interests of education in Derbyshire.'' Local authorities control education in England and have budgets to advertise for school staff. The council switched its advertising to the Guardian newspaper, which charges higher rates and reaches a much smaller readership in the education world than the Times Educational Supplement, the court was told.
DOC.HEAD: Venezuela Newsman Severely Injured in Attack
DOC.TEXT: The American founder of Venezuela's English-language Daily Journal was seriously injured when thieves broke into his home, bound and gagged him and stripped the house of valuables. Jules Waldman, 74, formerly of New York, has been in intensive care at a hospital since the June 30 incident, Daily Journal editor Tony Bianchi said July 17. Waldman and his wife, Agnes, have lived in Venezuela for more than 40 years. They founded the 15,000-circulation Journal in 1945. Waldman is chairman of the board.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Journalists To Teach Soviets About Co-ed Softball
DOC.TEXT: A baseball team from the Baltimore Sunpapers is going to the Soviet Union to teach Soviet journalists about co-ed softball. The Baltimore team, called the Slugs, is comprised of 25 reporters, artists and photographers from The Sun and The Evening Sun. The Slugs compete in the Maryland Media Softball League. The team is travelling to Kiev, Odessa and Moscow July 28-Aug. 7. The Slugs plan to play exhibition softball games on July 30 in Odessa and Aug. 5 in Moscow. The Moscow game is scheduled to be played in the Soviet Union's only baseball stadium, at Moscow University. Hosts for the Americans will be journalists from Trud, a Kiev-based newspaper. Journalists from Trud and the Odessa newspaper Znamya Kommoniza plan to come to Baltimore next summer.
DOC.HEAD: Lee Enterprises To Buy Remaining 50 Percent of NAPP
DOC.TEXT: Lee Enterprises Inc. agreed to acquire the 50 percent share it doesn't already own of NAPP Systems Inc., a maker of equipment for the newspaper industry, from Nippon Paint (USA) Inc. The transaction was valued at about $100 million. Lee said July 16 that it hoped the opening of markets in China, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union would increase sales opportunities for NAPP Systems, which is based in San Marcos, Calif. NAPP Systems makes photopolymer printing plates for newspapers and sells related equipment that others manufacturer.
DOC.HEAD: Maryville, Tenn., Paper Changing to Morning Publication
DOC.TEXT: The Daily Times will become a morning newspaper on July 30, Publisher Gerald Garcia announced. The Daily Times, begun as a weekly in 1883, has been publishing Monday through Friday afternoons since 1944. The newspaper, with an average paid circulation of 21,875, was privately owned until December when it was bought by Persis Corp. of Honolulu.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Slams Ads Aimed at Kids
DOC.TEXT: Public schools should be declared ``commercial-free zones'' to protect children from the increasing prevalence of advertising disguised as educational materials, a consumer group says. Consumers Union said July 17 that many purported teaching aids donated by businesses contain pitches for those businesses' products. Some of the come-ons are direct, others surreptitious, it said. Schools often acquiesce to the handouts because they can't afford to buy unbiased new materials, the report said. Students fall victim, because they are unlikely to question advertising disguised as schoolwork, the group said. ``The result: Schools are becoming heavily sponsored by corporations marketing products,'' the report said. ``They're `selling' the kids entrusted to them to any bidder.'' The study also criticized other forms of advertising aimed at children, including ads in children's magazines that are disguised as editorial copy, the use of celebrities to promote products, ads camouflaged as entertainment, and licensing deals that put popular symbols on a vast array of products. Interest in the issue of advertising in schools was heightened last year by the advent of Channel One, a video news program for pupils that includes commercials. Schools receive the program and viewing equipment free. Consumers Union called Channel One ``the tip of the iceberg'' and listed examples of self-promotion in corporate-supplied teaching materials. It said such materials reach more than 20 million students a year, although it did not estimate what proportion include advertising.
DOC.HEAD: Spanish-Language News Teams Left Out of Quayle Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Spanish-language television stations excluded from a July 19 interview in which Vice President Dan Quayle discussed a job bias bill attacked the action as insensitive. ``I just don't understand the reason. If they don't want to deal with the Hispanics, then that's pretty stupid,'' said Angelica Figueroa, news producer at KVDA, an affiliate of the Spanish-language network Telemundo. ``The irony of the thing is he was talking here about a discrimination bill passed by the Senate,'' said KWEX News Director Ed Barrera, whose station is an affiliate of the Spanish-language Univision network, Telemundo's competitor. Ms. Figueroa said she wouldn't call the action discrimination, but said it was ``very insensitive,'' especially in a city where more than half the 1 million residents are Hispanic. A spokesman for Quayle, who in the interviews discussed his opposition to a bias bill passed in the Senate on July 18, said no station was intentionally left out. Affiliates of ABC, CBS and NBC were invited to interview Quayle at a hotel after he spoke with newspaper and radio reporters. Two cameras were allowed to tape the interview and were asked to share the videotape with others who were present, said reporters who attended. A reporter from the Mexican network ECO also was allowed in after protesting his exclusion, reporters said. Barrera said his station had asked before Quayle's visit about covering the event and was not told of the interviews. A Quayle spokesman who spoke on condition he not be identified said the interview was not open to all news organizations and a limited number of local stations routinely are invited to interview Quayle when he travels.
DOC.HEAD: `Today' at Lowest Level in Seven Years
DOC.TEXT: NBC's ``Today'' has slipped to its lowest ratings since Aug. 6, 1983. In the most recent weekly ratings from A.C. Nielsen Co., ``Today'' was second to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for the 28th consecutive week. ABC's show rose to a 4.3 rating, while ``Today'' dipped slightly to 3.0 and ``CBS This Morning'' edged up to 2.3. Each point represents 921,000 homes. ``Real Life With Jane Pauley,'' the first of five NBC summer specials anchored by the former ``Today'' star, easily won its time period against two reruns. Pauley's one-hour show averaged a 13.5 rating July 17, handily beating the 10.3 rating for the second hour of a movie repeat on CBS and the 6.9 rating for a ``thirtysomething'' rerun on ABC.
DOC.HEAD: `Skittish' Advertisers Cost ABC $14 Million in Ad Revenue
DOC.TEXT: ABC lost $14 million in advertising revenue last season to advertisers that boycotted programs they deemed offensive, network entertainment President Bob Iger said July 22. ``It's a sorry state of affairs when advertisers are acting as skittish as they are,'' Iger said at a news conference. ``The networks get the heat, but I really think it should be the advertisers.'' The lost revenue was slightly more than 1 percent of ABC's total advertising revenues of $1 billion for this year, Iger said. Iger declined to name the advertisers who withdrew their commercials, and said the $14 million figure represented the first time ABC had counted such lost revenue since he became programming chief 16 months ago.
DOC.HEAD: Station Reinstates Talk Show Host Who Banned Black Callers
DOC.TEXT: A radio talk show host who was suspended for banning black callers returned to the air July 17 after his station manager said his action was not malicious. Tim Lennox, who had been suspended on July 12, returned to his afternoon talk show but was removed from his job as news director and will be on probation for a year, said Berkley Fraser, manager of WERC-AM. Lennox also will be required to develop, produce and serve as host of a special series for the station on the topic ``Birmingham faces the future,'' focusing on race relations in the city. Lennox said early in his two-hour talk show on July 11 that he would take no calls from blacks that day because three station employees had seen a black youth break into an fellow employee's car and take her purse just before air time. Lennox said later that he made ``an emotional spur-of-the-moment decision.'' He and Fraser issued on-air apologies the next day. Fraser said his investigation showed Lennox's action was ``not based in malice and his 14-year career was without incidence of any racial prejudice.''
DOC.HEAD: Scripps To Buy Baltimore TV Station
DOC.TEXT: Scripps Howard Broadcasting Co. said July 19 that it has agreed to buy WMAR-TV in Baltimore from Gillett Group Inc. for $154.7 million. Scripps, an 80 percent-owned subsidiary of E.W. Scripps Co., said it expected the transaction to be completed before year's end. WMAR is an affiliate of NBC and recently signed a three-year contract to continue as the flagship station for the Baltimore Orioles baseball team.
DOC.HEAD: Larry King Making Network Debut in October
DOC.TEXT: Cable and radio talk show host Larry King will make his network TV debut Oct. 28 with an NBC interview and variety special. ``Sunday Night with Larry King'' will run for an hour and feature celebrity interviews and performances. King is the host of CNN's ``Larry King Live'' and Mutual Broadcasting's ``The Larry King Show.''

DOC.HEAD: Stations Asked To Prove Compliance With FCC Political Rules
DOC.TEXT: FCC officials staged surprise inspections at 30 major market television and radio stations to check whether they are offering political candidates the lowest possible advertising rates. The FCC held its first-ever audits of broadcasters July 16-17, prompted by what an agency news release called an ``obligation to assure that broadcast stations are complying with political programming laws and rules, especially in an election year.'' The inspections, carried out in five cities, kicked off an auditing process that is expected to be completed before the fall congressional elections. The audits were not the result of any complaint, said Milton Graves, chief of the FCC's political division. ``This is just a part of overseeing how the stations are complying,'' he said. ``We want to know what their practices are.'' The FCC sent field inspectors to stations in Cincinnati, Dallas-Fort Worth, Philadelphia, San Francisco and Portland, Ore. In each city, they visited four television stations, an AM radio station and an FM radio station. Under FCC regulations, the lowest unit charge is available to political candidates 45 days before primary balloting and six days before a general election. Candidates may purchase single broadcast advertisements for the same price as commercial advertisers who buy a number of spots in the same time period. The subject of political advertising rates has been a sore spot in Congress, where proposals are pending that would guarantee that candidates get the lowest rates without fear of being preempted by commercial advertisers who come in and offer to pay higher rates. The stations audited were: _Cincinnati: WCPO-TV, WKRC-TV, WLWL-TV, WIII-TV, WCKY-AM and WWNK-FM in Cincinnati. _Dallas: KDFW-TV, KXAS-TV, WFAA-TV, KTXA-TV, KRLD-AM and KPLX-FM. _Philadelphia: KYW-TV, WCAU-TV, WPVI-TV, WGBS-TV, WPEN-AM and WWDB-FM. _Portland: KATU-TV, KGW-TV, KOIN-TV, KPTV-TV, KWJJ-AM and KKSN-FM. _San Francisco: KGO-TV, KRON-TV, KTVU-TV, KOFY-TV, KNBR-AM and KABL-FM.
DOC.HEAD: Tartikoff To Head New Development Division at NBC
DOC.TEXT: Brandon Tartikoff, NBC's boy wonder of programming a decade ago, has been named to head a new division that will try to find markets for network-produced shows. His new duties will include devising program ideas for NBC's in-house production company and overseeing the network's development think tank of executives for sports, prime-time, daytime and late-night programs. Replacing him as NBC entertainment president will be Warren Littlefield, executive vice president of prime-time programs. The move was announced July 17. Tartikoff took over NBC's prime-time schedule 10 years ago and was hailed for lifting it out of last place into first for the last five seasons.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Fines Indiana Station for Comedy Routines
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators have fined WFBQ-FM $10,000 for broadcasting allegedly indecent comedy routines. The Federal Communications Commission sent a letter July 19 to Great American Television and Radio Co. of Cincinnati, which owns WFBQ, advising it of the fine. The FCC found that portions of five broadcasts of ``The Bob and Tom Show'' aired between June 1987 and August 1989 ``contained lewd and vulgar language dwelling on depictions or descriptions of sexual organs and activities.'' The station was fined the maximum $2,000 for each violation. The station has 30 days to appeal or to pay the fine. Chris Wheat, station manager, said a decision would be made in a few days on whether the ruling would be appealed. WFBQ had argued that the routines were at most ``indirect, non-explicit, double-entendre humor about sexual matters.'' However, the FCC ruled that ``the language used in each passage was understandable and clearly capable of a specific sexual meaning and, because of the context, the sexual import was inescapable.'' In June, the FCC imposed a $20,000 fine against KSJO-FM of San Jose, Calif., for indecent broadcasts.
DOC.HEAD: Chairman, Publisher Picked in Chattanooga, Tenn.
DOC.TEXT: Frank McDonald, president of the Chattanooga News-Free Press and son of the late publisher Roy McDonald, was elected chairman of the board July 21. Lee Anderson, editor of the paper, was given the additional job of publisher. Helen McDonald Exum, McDonald's daughter, was elected executive vice president, and sports editor Roy McDonald Exum, a grandson, was named vice president. Roy McDonald, the newspaper's founder and principal owner, died June 19 at age 88. After an 18-year association with a grocery chain founded by his father, Frank McDonald joined the newspaper in 1967, working first in the paper's advertising department and later moving into production. Anderson joined the newspaper in 1942 and became associate editor in 1948. He assumed editorial page responsibilities several years later.
DOC.HEAD: Strutton Named Publisher of Rocky Mountain News
DOC.TEXT: Larry Strutton, president of Baltimore Sunpapers, has been named president, publisher and chief executive officer of the Rocky Mountain News, where he began his career 26 years ago as a linotype operator. He succeeds William Fletcher, who has been elected chairman of the board. Fletcher said July 18 that Strutton would assume the posts in six weeks. Strutton began his career in the News' composing room in 1964. He was named production director in 1972, and left in 1982 to become vice president of production at the Detroit Free Press. Strutton joined the Los Angeles Times as vice president of operations in 1983 and was promoted to executive vice president in 1986. In April 1989, Times Mirror Corp. named him president of Baltimore Sunpapers.
DOC.HEAD: Publisher, Editor Named in Longview, Texas
DOC.TEXT: Rollie D. Hyde, advertising director at the Midland Reporter-Telegram, was named July 17 to succeed James Thomas as publisher of the Plainview Daily Herald when Thomas retires Aug. 1. Both papers are owned by Hearst Newspapers. Hyde has been advertising director for the Reporter-Telegram the past 3{ years. He began his newspaper career in Anadarko, Okla., and worked in a variety of advertising management positions with newspapers in Oklahoma City, Corpus Christi, Texas, and Davenport, Iowa. Thomas, 65, had been publisher the last 11 years and had been with the Herald for 21 years. Before that, he was ad director for The Moore County News in Dumas, Texas, and worked for the Tulia (Texas) Herald. Thomas announced July 20 that Danny Andrews had been given the title of editor. Andrews, who recently marked 20 years with the newspaper, had held the title of managing editor since 1978 and has been chief of the editorial department for almost 12 years.

DOC.HEAD: Briley Named Publisher in Williamsport, Pa.
DOC.TEXT: Thomas C. Briley was named publisher of the Williamsport Sun-Gazette this month after Ogden Newspapers Inc. completed its purchase of the paper for an undisclosed price. Briley joined Ogden in 1975 as editor of The Intelligencer in Wheeling, W.Va. He became publisher of The Times Leader in Martins Ferry, Ohio, in November 1985 and was named general manager of The Messenger in Fort Dodge, Iowa, in August 1987. He previously worked for The Tennessean in Nashville and The Associated Press in Baltimore; Dover, Del.; Juneau, Alaska; Pittsburgh; and Charleston, W.Va.
DOC.HEAD: Berentson Named UPI's Chief Operating Officer
DOC.TEXT: John Berentson, a top official of Infotechnology Inc., the parent company of United Press International, was named vice chairman and chief operating officer of the wire service July 17. He replaces Joseph K. Taussig, who is leaving to pursue other business interests. Berentson will keep his post as senior executive vice president and chief operating officer of Infotechnology, which owns UPI as well as 47 percent of Financial News Network Inc.
DOC.HEAD: Bushee Named Executive Editor in Reno, Nev.
DOC.TEXT: Ward Bushee became executive editor of the Reno Gazette-Journal on July 16, replacing Charlie Waters, who resigned. Bushee had been executive editor of the Argus Leader in Sioux Falls, S.D., since October 1986. Both papers are owned by Gannett Co. Inc. Bushee made national news May 30 when he was injured in a crash of two South Dakota Air National Guard jets over northwestern Iowa. He was on one of the jets as part of an public relations effort to acquaint community leaders with Guard operations.
DOC.HEAD: DeYoung Named A.M.E. for National News at Washington Post
DOC.TEXT: Karen DeYoung, national editor of The Washington Post, was named assistant managing editor for national news July 19. DeYoung will assume the post in September, succeeding Robert G. Kaiser, who was named deputy managing editor. She joined the Post in 1975 as a metro reporter. She was named the paper's Latin American bureau chief two years later, serving first in Argentina and then Mexico. DeYoung was deputy foreign editor and then foreign editor in 1980-85, when she was named London bureau chief. She became national editor in January 1989.
DOC.HEAD: Clark Named Managing Editor in Greenville, N.C.
DOC.TEXT: M. Allen Clark was named managing editor of The Daily Reflector on July 22. He succeeds Alvin B. Taylor, who was named senior associate editor. Clark has held reporting and editing positions in North Carolina and South Carolina, including 11 years at The Greenville (S.C.) News. He most recently was an editor at the now-closed St. Louis Sun. Taylor had been managing editor since 1963. He began working full-time for the newspaper as a reporter in 1953 and was named city editor in 1954.
DOC.HEAD: Clegg Named City Editor at Boston Globe
DOC.TEXT: Ellen Clegg has been named city editor of The Boston Globe, effective Aug. 6. She succeeds Peter Mancusi, who will attend Boston College Law School. Clegg joined the Globe in 1978 as a copy editor. She also worked as assistant night editor, night editor and senior assistant metro editor. Before joining the Globe, she worked for The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer for five years.
DOC.HEAD: Francois Chatel
DOC.TEXT: Francois Chatel, foreign news editor for Agence France Presse, died of a heart attack July 17 while on a visit to Rabat, Morocco. He was 46. Chatel joined the agency in 1968 and subsequently worked in London, Washington, Paris, Manila and Peking. He was named one of the agency's two editors in chief for foreign news in May 1989. He is survived by his wife, Marie, and two children.
DOC.HEAD: Madge Garland
DOC.TEXT: Lady Ashton, better known as Madge Garland, the fashion editor of English Vogue in the 1930s and founder of the Royal College of Art's Fashion School, died July 15 at age 92. She became a journalist in the 1920s, first working for English Vogue and later free-lancing for Women's Wear Daily in the United States. She returned to English Vogue as fashion editor in 1933 and then entered the fashion business during World War II. She was married briefly twice and had no children.
DOC.HEAD: Hank Grant
DOC.TEXT: Hank Grant, a longtime entertainment reporter for all-news KNX radio and a former columnist for the Hollywood Reporter, died July 19 of cancer. He was 77. After a career in entertainment shows in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago, Grant joined the Hollywood Reporter in 1956 as a columnist. He became KNX's entertainment editor in August 1965 and did weekend entertainment news broacasts and reviews. He left the Reporter in 1986, but continued his reports for KNX. He is survived by his wife, Lucille, two sons, two granddaughters and two sisters.
DOC.HEAD: William R. Peterson
DOC.TEXT: William R. Peterson, the Chicgo correspondent for The Washington Post, died of cancer July 18 during a visit to Washington. He was 47. Peterson began his career at The Courier-Journal in Lousivlle, Ky. He joined the Post as a metro reporter in 1975 and joined the paper's national reporting staff two years later. He had been the Post's correspondent in Chicago since 1987. He is survived by his wife, Linda, two sons, his mother, three brothers and a sister.

The leading critic of the British press _ at least as measured by his 180 complaints filed with the Press Council _ is an American ex-tabloid journalist. Bob Borzello, who now runs a greeting card company in London, told The New York Times he is motivated by a desire to get the national British papers to drop what he considers harmful habits, primarily their use of racial and ethnic slurs. .. . Jane Pauley told the Chicago Tribune she's not a candidate to be co-anchor of the NBC ``Nightly News'' with Tom Brokaw, and added, ``I feel obligated to say even if I was asked, I couldn't do it.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's attorney says he can prove the mayor was attending a meeting at the time a government witness says she provided Barry with drugs. Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy planned to present that argument today as the mayor's drug and perjury trial enters its eighth week. Mundy planned to attack one of the misdemeanor cocaine possession charges Barry faces by showing a videotape of a meeting among Barry and top city officials on the morning of Sept. 7, 1988. Government witness Lydia Reid Pearson has testified that shortly after 10 a.m. that day, she delivered cocaine _ and a city job application _ to Barry at a municipal building.

A government satellite due for a ride into space on an unmanned Atlas rocket is to spray the cosmos with chemicals for a look at the Earth's usually invisible magnetic and electric fields. A third attempt at launch was scheduled for 3:26 p.m. today, despite predictions for bad weather. Launch Sunday was called off less than two hours before liftoff because of the threat of severe thunderstorms. The first attempt, on Friday, was postponed because of a helium leak. A liquid helium vent duct used for engine cooling apparently slipped off an engine outlet in the rocket's upper-stage thrust section. As a precaution, all four vent ducts were replaced with a new set Saturday, said Jack Isabel, spokesman for rocket builder General Dynamics.

Argentine novelist Manuel Puig, who abandoned filmmaking for a literature with cinematic style and gained fame for ``Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' has died of a heart attack at age 57. Puig, suffering complications from gall bladder surgery, died Sunday at a hospital. He had earned a reputation as a leading member of the younger generation of Latin American writers. Puig's works often explored the relationships between his characters' impoverished lives and their rich, if unfulfilled, fantasies. He turned away from a potential career as a filmmaker to devote himself to literature. But his style reflected the influence of screenplays _ with little descriptive prose.

President Samuel Doe says he won't leave the besieged capital until the civil war is decided, though sources say fleeing would not be easy because the soldiers guarding Doe won't let him go without them. The 500-member presidential guard, made up of soldiers from Doe's Krahn tribe, fear massacre at the hands of the rebels, who have fought their way to within a mile of Doe's oceanfront mansion. The rebels, who are mostly from the rival Gio and Mano ethnic groups, were locked in street combat with Doe's regular troops on Sunday, the sources said. They said some government soldiers were urging the president to flee to avoid a bloodbath and that there was bitter infighting in the executive mansion. Doe has been deserted by nearly all senior members of his government.

The Navy today is undertaking a needle-in-a-haystack search of the ocean floor for a cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jumbo jet and caused nine people to be swept to their death over the Pacific 17 months ago. Investigators hope the door will help them establish beyond doubt the cause of the accident. During the weeklong search, a deep-sea probe equipped with sonar and a video camera will be dragged across a 24-square-mile area about 100 miles southwest of Honolulu. If the door is spotted, another device will be used at a later date to recover it. Flight 811 was bound for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989, with 355 people aboard when the door tore popped off at 22,000 feet, carrying away a section of fuselage and causing sudden decompression of the Boeing 747. Nine people were sucked out; five others were seriously hurt. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu.

President Bush said Monday he will nominate appellate judge David Souter to a seat on the Supreme Court. If confirmed by the Senate, the 50-year-old jurist from New Hampshire would succeed William J. Brennan. ``He is a remarkable judge of keen intellect and the highest ability,'' Bush said. The president went on to praise Brennan as well, calling the court's long-time leading liberal, ``one of the greatest figures of his age.'' Brennan resigned last Friday. Souter stood at Bush's side as the president made his surprise announcement at the White House late in the afternoon. The president said he decided on Souter earlier in the afternoon. Bush said his quick selection was not geared to abortion policy or any other single issue. ``It is not appropriate ... to use any litmus test,'' Bush said. Abortion activists believe Brennan's departure from the court could pave the way for overturning the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision.

President Corazon Aquino asked lawmakers Monday for a half-billion dollars to pay for earthquake recovery, but many accused her of not doing enough to help their country rebuild emotionally and physically. In a speech marking the end of Congress' summer recess, Mrs. Aquino rejected proposals to divert foreign debt payments to finance recovery. She also did not pay tribute to the more than 1,000 people killed in the July 16 quake. Strong aftershocks jolted areas of Luzon island. One aftershock measured 4 on the Richter scale. Another sent hundreds of people rushing into the streets of Baguio, a hard-hit city 130 miles north of Manila. Official figures put the death toll at 1,055, but it was expected to rise. Presidential adviser Jose de Jesus said 393 were killed in Baguio, although figures in Manila put the count there at 232.

The busiest month yet for the savings and loan bailout ballooned the federal budget deficit to $11.2 billion in June, a month when corporate tax payments usually produce a surplus, the government said Monday. The shortfall, compared with a $7.8 billion surplus in June 1989, brought red ink for the first nine months of fiscal 1990 to $163.1 billion, more than half again as much as the $105.4 billion deficit at this time last year. If the deficit continues to accumulate at this pace, it could top the record fiscal-year deficit of $221.1 billion set in 1986. The White House Office of Management and Budget is officially forecasting a budget gap of $218.5 billion, just short of the record. White House negotiators and congressional leaders are attempting to put together a major deficit-reduction pact for fiscal 1991, starting Oct. 1.

A bedeviled, beleaguered NASA is hoping the Magellan spacecraft's rendezvous with Venus next month will provide our best look yet at Earth's hellishly hot neighbor. If all goes according to plan, the $413 million unmanned device, centerpiece of a $744 million mission, will orbit the cloud-shrouded planet on Aug. 10 after a 15-month journey from Earth. And NASA desperately wants everything to go according to plan. ``This thing must succeed because of the Hubble Space Telescope effect and the generally bad impression we've all been getting of how NASA has been conducting its affairs lately,'' said Steve Saunders, the Magellan project's chief scientist. But those setbacks _ the crippling of the $1.5 billion Hubble observatory due to mirror imperfections; the temporary grounding of the space shuttles due to hydrogen fuel leaks _ have not dimmed the agency's enthusiasm for Magellan.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
Today is Saturday, Aug. 4, the 216th day of 1990. There are 149 days left in the year. ^
DOC.TEXT: Today's Highlight in History: Two hundred years ago, on Aug. 4, 1790, the Coast Guard had its beginnings as a U.S. naval task force known as the Revenue Cutter Service was formed.
DOC.HEAD: On this date:
DOC.TEXT: In 1735, a jury acquitted John Peter Zenger of the New York Weekly Journal of a charge of seditious libel brought by the royal governor of New York. In 1830, plans for the city of Chicago were laid out. In 1892, Sunday school teacher Lizzie Borden was arrested in Fall River, Mass., charged with the hatchet murders of her father and stepmother. (Borden was later acquitted.) In 1914, Britain declared war on Germany and the United States proclaimed its neutrality in World War I. In 1916, the United States purchased the Danish Virgin Islands for $25 million. In 1944, Nazi police raided the secret annex of a house in Amsterdam and arrested eight people _ including 14-year-old Anne Frank, whose diary, published after her death, became a classic depiction of the Holocaust. In 1964, the bodies of missing civil rights workers Michael H. Schwerner, Andrew Goodman and James E. Chaney were found buried inside an earthen dam in Mississippi. In 1977, President Carter signed a measure establishing the Department of Energy, the first cabinet-level department created since the Department of Transportation in 1966. In 1987, the Federal Communications Commission voted 4-0 to rescind the Fairness Doctrine, which required radio and television stations to present balanced coverage of controversial issues.
DOC.HEAD: Ten years ago: The speaker of Iran's parliament, Hashemi
DOC.TEXT: Rafsanjani, announced that debate on the American hostages would be postponed, in retaliation for what Tehran charged was mistreatment of Iranian prisoners in the U.S. Five years ago: A pair of milestones were achieved in major league baseball as Tom Seaver of the Chicago White Sox gained his 300th victory and Rod Carew of the California Angels got his 3,000th hit. One year ago: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani offered to help end the hostage crisis in Lebanon _ prompting President Bush to say he was ``encouraged.''
DOC.HEAD: Today's Birthdays: Britain's Queen Mother Elizabeth is 90. The
DOC.TEXT: dean of the White House press corps, Helen Thomas of United Press International, is 70. Track star Mary Decker Slaney is 32. Baseball pitcher Roger Clemens is 28.
DOC.HEAD: Thought for Today: ``A beautiful soul has no other merit than
DOC.TEXT: its own existence.'' _ Friedrich von Schiller, German author (1759-1805).

DOC.NOTE: For release Monday, July 30, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Part II: Islam Resurgent
Vibrant Faith of Koran Surviving Dying Faith of Communism
LaserPhoto NY302 of July 23; Graphics SOVNEWSOL, SOVNEWSOG
DOC.TEXT: After three generations of uneasy coexistence with the Communists in the Kremlin, the Moslems of Central Asia are asserting themselves anew. This is the second installment of a four-part series based on an AP special correspondent's journey through the Soviet south.

A stonework galaxy of crescent moons has risen above the jagged outlines of tombs in the 1,000-year-old Chigotai cemetery, symbolically ending the long Soviet eclipse of Islam. ``Now Communist Party officials mourn their dead in the open instead of performing Moslem rites secretly at home,'' the aged guardian told visitors. From Ashkabad to Alma Ata, across a 1,200-mile sweep of the Soviet Union, Central Asians are embracing Allah with the fervor of long-lost prodigal sons. On Fridays, row after row of barefoot, bearded men in braided skullcaps chant centuries-old litanies and bow not toward Moscow but to Mecca. Koranic schools are filling with youngsters, and countless mosques are reopening. ``I cannot even say how many,'' said Mohammed Zakhir, deputy grand mufti of Central Asia. ``But a new one opens every week. It is endless.'' Religious leaders insist the new mood is joyous rather than militant, a sign that tenacious faith has prevailed over an ideology that used propaganda and sometimes brute force to try to wipe it out. ``This is no revival of Islam because it was never dead,'' said a Tashkent professor, who asked not to be quoted by name. ``We always did in private what we can now do in public.'' In fact, many Central Asians say, Islam is an important force in the new political current carrying five of the Soviet Union's 15 republics further away from Moscow. At the rural level, power slipping away from local Communist Party officials is shifting to imams, and in cities the party curries favor with the clergy. An aggressive new attitude is evident in scattered outbreaks of violence. In May, in the crowded Fergana Valley east of this old Uzbek capital, witnesses said masked fundamentalist leaders led youths on a rampage of burning and looting in an apparent play for power. Three months earlier and farther south, in Dushanbe, capital of mountainous Tadzhikistan, Western visitors reported that Moslem faithful went directly from praying to rioting _ and to demanding the resignation of local officials.
