Tashkent and the populous republic of Uzbekistan are shared by nearly 100 ethnic groups, with beliefs ranging from orthodox Islam to Marxist atheism. In many areas, they compete intensely for land, housing and jobs. Mostly, Islam is a conduit for new feelings of identity. For Central Asians, it is as much a way of life as a religion, the arbiter of family life, community traditions and spiritual values. From the first Russian incursions to the south, Islam was a principal target, and many Soviet Moslems say they feel a deep-seated prejudice against Russian people. After the 1917 Russian Revolution, Moscow condemned Islam as divisive superstition and sought to eliminate it along with other religions. Most mosques were closed and many were destroyed. During some periods, Islam was banned outright. More often, it was vilified by intense propaganda, and faithful Moslems had to choose between Allah and advancement in a party-controlled society. No muezzins wailed from minarets before prayer. Hardly a trickle of Soviet Moslems made it to Mecca for the annual pilgrimage. ``These past oppressions are ending,'' said Usmonhon Alimov, imam of the graceful al-Bukhari Mosque near Samarkand, among the few Islamic holy sites to remain mostly unmolested since the 1920s. ``Young men are flocking to the faith, openly, and mosques are being established in every village,'' he said. Today, 55 million Moslems, most of them in Central Asia, make up a fifth of the national population, and every second child born in the Soviet Union is a Moslem. A decade ago, during the height of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic revolution in neighboring Iran, powerful Iranian radio transmitters urged Moslem brothers to rise up against the Soviet state. At the time, Moscow was at war in Afghanistan, deploying some Central Asian soldiers against anti-communist Moslem guerrillas. Today, although Moslem militancy seems to be growing, political analysts see only limited outside meddling from across the Iranian and Afghan borders. In Soviet Central Asia, fundamentalists are far outnumbered by more moderate Moslems, and Shiites _ Khomeini's branch of Islam _ by Sunni Moslems. But analysts say the potential for pan-Islamic militancy is a serious cause for concern. Common values and even blood ties draw together populations separated for 70 years by an impenetrable border. Stanislav Prozorov, head of an Islamic studies group in the Soviet Academy of Sciences, faults Soviet leaders for misreading Moslems, ignoring them on one hand and overreacting on the other. Recently, he told the daily paper Komsomolets Uzbekistana he saw a definite danger of an ``Islamic explosion'' because of ``Islamophobia'' on the part of Soviet leaders and thinkers. Frustrated Moslems might unite and respond with unpredictable vehemence, he said. Had the Kremlin understood Islam in Soviet Asia, it would never have invaded Afghanistan, he added. Western scholars agree. Michael Rywkin of City College of New York has described growing masses that are ``practically unassimilable and indifferent to most official Soviet values.'' In March, Anatolii Luk'yanov, chairman of the Soviet national Parliament, met with the grand mufti of Central Asia, Mukhammad Sadik Mukhammad Yusuf, to discuss Islamic affairs. The 36-year-old mufti was named chairman of the Religious Board of Moslems of Central Asia last year after widespread complaints that his predecessor toadied to Moscow. In the meeting, he assured Soviet leaders he supported perestroika and was trying to help free captured Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan. But in April, on Moscow television, he sharply criticized the Kremlin for interfering in Islamic affairs and not giving Moslem leaders the same access to the media as the Russian Orthodox hierarchy. He said that because of ignorance of Islam, official policy tried to restrict the religion rather than take advantage of its ability to inspire social change and ethnic harmony. Episodes of zealotry should not raise fears that the fading Soviet states will give way to harsh new Islamic regimes, Central Asian leaders say. Imam Alimov blamed fanatics for trampling women's rights, abusing non-Moslem settlers and frightening people whose ideas of Islam were colored by fundamentalist excesses elsewhere. ``These things are holdovers from the past, the result of oppression,'' he said. ``People are learning again about Islam. Young men are studying the Koran. These things will change.''

DOC.TEXT: Each year about 4 million babies are born in the United States, about 200,000 of them with serious defects. In the past decade, however, pediatric surgeons working with sophisticated and tiny instruments have been able to make remarkable repairs to newborn babies. Now they are even going inside the fetus, opening a new medical frontier.

The fetus, that incredible assembly of cells following its own blueprint toward human life, was once a citadel as daunting to doctors as the human brain. Not anymore. The surgeon's knife is entering the womb to correct errors of nature in the fetus only 23 weeks into pregnancy, a 1-pound humanoid with arms the size of your little finger, a heart the size of a walnut, and tiny lungs that would fit inside the skin of an orange. These dramatic techniques _ and some to come that are even more dramatic _are used to rescue a very few fetuses, just as heart repair and transplants are used for very few newborns. Not everyone agrees that fetal surgeries are appropriate or even necessary. Rarely, some doctors say, are they so critical that they can't be postponed until after birth with the same results. But they offer a window to the future, a future that is not very far off. And they reflect the advances in pediatric surgery over the last decade, a decade that has seen newborn heart transplants become almost commonplace, with doctors reaching into tiny chests to do all kinds of shunts and plumbing repairs, restructuring valves, replacing what nature forgot. Of the 4 million or so live births each year in the United States, about 200,000 infants have serious defects and about 40,000 of those die. There is a lot of work to do. Researchers are working now on ways to implant cells or genes into 12-week-old fetuses whose functions are limited because of the lack of even a single enzyme or protein; their cells are missing a vital blueprint to make those chemicals and ensure normal growth. But for the time being, at least, fetal surgery remains anatomical, the fixing of structures gone awry. The most recent instance: A surgeon in San Francisco opens the womb, makes a 2-inch incision in the chest wall of the fetus below the ribs on the left side. He finds what the sound-pictures told him he would: The diaphragm that separates the chest and abdominal cavities has not grown properly, a disorder that occurs once in only 2,000 pregnancies. The organs and intestines from the lower cavity are crushing the developing left lung. He delicately rearranges things, patches the diaphragm to hold everything in the right place, and departs the sanctity of the womb to let the pregnancy progress. His patient, the mother, delivers a normal baby. But in six attempts at this kind of surgery, only two fetuses have survived. What astonishes the doctors is ``these fetuses heal without a scar,'' says the surgeon, Dr. Michael R. Harrison of the University of California, San Francisco. Now he and his colleagues are trying to find out why. Is it something the youthful cells produce that allows that kind of healing, and what would that mean to the adult world that is not so equipped? At the very least, Harrison says, it suggests it might be a good idea to correct some serious defects to the fetus before birth ``to take advantage of this scarless healing.'' He emphasizes how few are the candidates for any of these new advances in pediatiatric and fetal surgery. What makes much of it possible is the diagnosis of many ailments shortly after gestation. In the 1970s, Chinese and Soviet scientists discovered that they could look into the future of the fetus by studying the chorionic villi, the primordial placental cells, the gestational bed in the uterus. They used a needle to enter the uterus very early in pregnancy and using suction they removed some of the villi for study. This is chorionic villi sampling or CVS, developed as an alternative for amniocentesis, which is an analysis of the fluid in the womb, which cannot be done as early. Concurrent with the refinement of this work was the use of ultrasound to actually picture the fetus in the womb, enabling doctors to see what they were doing. ``I guess the basic idea is that we can do bone marrow transplants a whole lot better before birth,'' Harrison says. But what of the rejection problem? Working with sheep and monkeys, Harrison says, ``amazingly the rejection was circumvented if you took stem cells, the blood-forming cells from the liver at a time when the liver acts as the bone marrow.'' ``We're using fetal cells that won't recognize they are not at home. ... It seemed like a fantastic script, and it is.'' ``The alternative strategy is, rather than transplanting the whole cell, why not transplant the gene?'' Harrison says. ``The gene folks are getting so clever that they are pretty close to being able to do that.'' Rejection is still the major problem in newborn heart transplants, and so they are not considered a cure for a bad heart in the traditional sense of the word ``cure.'' They are only a treatment, and patients with transplanted hearts must continue to take anti-rejection medicine for the rest of their lives. Which is why a heart transplant is a last-ditch method. Surgeons try first to repair the heart, its malformed valves, its missing chambers, its badly arranged plumbing. The heart of a newborn is about the size of a plum, yet surgery is possible shortly after birth, if not always practical. ``A heart transplant is an open-heart procedure and it is technically sometimes much less demanding than some of the repairs that we are doing,'' says Dr. Jan M. Quaegebeur who has recently come to New York's Columbia-Presbyterian Babies Hospital from the Netherlands. ``We know that babies are strong enough to go through the operations. The question is whether you have to do a transplant. The reason you would do a transplant is because you have doubts you could do a good repair.'' The human heart is in essence a pumping machine, the right side of which pumps blood to the lungs to be oxygenated while the left side sends the freshened blood coursing through the body again, taking oxygen to distant tissues and picking up carbon dioxide for exhalation from the lungs.

DOC.TEXT: When a baby is born with an underdeveloped left or right ventricle, the main pumping chambers of the heart, it basically has a single-chamber heart. It was just such a maldevelopment that led to the first infant heart transplants. Two early attempts dating back to one in 1967 were failures. Then in 1984, Dr. Leonard Bailey of Loma Linda University Medical Center near Los Angeles transplanted a baboon heart into a 12-day-old infant known only as Baby Fae. Baby Fae survived only 20 days. The cross-species transplant was more a reflection of the lack of human donors than anything else. Baby Fae would have surely died if nothing were done. Desperation is sometimes the mother of progress. Thirteen months later Bailey transplanted a human infant heart into the breast of a 14 day old, code-named Baby Moses, who was discharged a month and a half later in 1986. That transplant took, and the heart grew with its recipient, Eddie Anguiano, who will be 5 years old in November. Since then Bailey has done some two-thirds of the nearly 70 infant heart transplants performed at Loma Linda, 53 of which survive. To this day, not everyone agrees heart transplants are the answer. There may be other repairs that would do as well. ``You can't make a four-chamber heart out of a two-chamber heart or a three-chamber heart,'' says Dr. Welton Gersony of Columbia-Presbyterian's Babies Hospital. ``The structures are just missing. But we have found great success with a total bypass of the missing right heart, allowing the blood to flow from the veins directly into the lungs. ``That's an exciting area. We've shown you can live without a chamber on the right side.'' In short, surgeons have made considerable progress on infant heart repair since doctors in England showed how to inflate a tiny balloon in infant heart valves to force them to enlarge. ``If we look at the scope of operations that have been performed on different kinds of abnormalities, we can do good operations with low mortality in the first year of life, mortalities of two or three percent,'' Quaegebeur says. ``Now there are diseases which are so severe that we don't have a good anatomical correction.'' It is conceivable that something might be done in the fetal stage in those cases, he says. ``In the last decade a group of surgeons dedicated to repairing as completely as possible and as early as possible virtually every defect have come to the fore,'' Gersony says. Not all are of equal proficiency, although many try. ``Essentially what we have is earlier and earlier repair and there's a logic to it: to make the heart normal as early as possible.'' Harrison and his fellow fetal surgeons think ``as early as possible'' means in the womb. Besides correcting the herniated diaphragms, he has entered the uterus to fix blocked bladders so the fetus can urinate. This is important to prevent damage to the kidney and the lungs. ``It took us many years to find out. But the simple answer is most of the amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus is made up of fetal urine. If the block won't let the kid pee, then the fluid goes away, the uterus collapses on the kid and that affects his lung growth.'' He is also working on animals to see if it is practical to unblock the ducts in the brain that allow spinal fluid to vent. When blocked, the spinal fluid backs up and produces the enlarged heads of hydrocephalus. ``A couple of very interesting things that will be done, have been done, involve tumors,'' Harrison says. ``One is a benign growth in the lung. It gets so big it impairs lung development. We don't talk about things until they are published, but it is ready.'' Along the same lines is a teratoma, a growth that emerges on the fetus' back and sometimes becomes as large as the fetus itself. It kills by stealing the fetus' blood. Harrison says it needs to be removed in the uterus. There is also the case of the slow heart, apparently because of an electrical block in the heart muscle. ``The kid is perfectly normal in every other way except the heart beats so slowly, about 45 beats a minute, that the kid dies. Now the solution to that would be to implant a pacemaker in the fetus.'' Harrison tends to view the developing of a child as a continuum. But the medical profession is reluctant to go that far in treating its patients. There are certain ethical problems that go to the life of the mother. The origin of 95 percent of the maldevelopment at birth is happenstance, as opposed to inherited genetic problems. In the complex process that begins with simple cell division, then to differentiation, nature makes rare mistakes, a miracle in itself. Of all the things that go wrong, the heart is the most correctable. The toughest part of heart transplantation is the availability of hearts. If surgeons differ on when and how, they do not differ much on their personal involvement or their dedication or their vulnerability. For Quaegebeur, the expert in newborn surgery: ``I am better at it now than I was a few years ago. I still have problems when I have to go back and speak to the parents. Bringing good news is easy and even then you can't become involved emotionally. ... It's more difficult, naturally, when you have to bring bad news. It still troubles me. I am not emotionally detached. ``When I'm doing the surgery, it is a different matter. You are in this heart and with that surgical team. You are not with the family. You are trying to get everything done and that means you have to remain professional.'' For fetal surgeon Harrison: ``We don't give up. We work as hard as we can until we succeed. Or the fetus dies.''

DOC.TEXT: When Susan Cox was pregnant with her second child, she had a suspicion that something was wrong. Call it maternal instinct. The doctors did constant tests ``to reassure me that everything was fine,'' she says, ``but I just couldn't believe it.'' The 30-year-old woman so reveres life that she named her daughter Zoe and planned to name a son Vidal, words derived from ``life'' in other languages. When the baby was born the doctors told her he was just fine, ``except that he was just cold and a little blue.'' Ingy, as the boy came to be called after his middle name, Ingmar, was in intensive care hours after he was born in Morristown, N.J. He was transferred to Columbia-Presbysterian Babies Hospital in New York City the next day. His case demonstrates the uneven road of pediatric heart surgery, and some of the pitfalls along the way. Ingy is 3{ years old now, a lively, bright bundle of energy who has had four brushes with death. At Babies Hospital a more complete examination of his heart showed it had inverted ventricles, the pumping chambers, with no connection to the pulmonary artery that carries blood to the lungs. In addition, there was a wide hole between the reversed ventricles. It was ``one screwed-up heart,'' as one hospital staffer put it. The first surgery came when Ingy was 4 days old. A shunt was installed from one pumping chamber to the pulmonary artery. A block developed and 10 days later the infant was operated on again and a new shunt was installed. For three years Ingy seemed to be living a normal, active life. But then he began turning blue again. A third operation showed he had outgrown the shunt. It was replaced and the hole between the two pumping chambers was fixed. It was as close as surgeons could come to a complete repair, considering what they started with. There were ups and downs in the ensuing months after the family moved to Princeton, N.J. Ingy developed respiratory problems and then heart failure that miraculously reversed itself. The doctors ascribed the heart failure to a virus and postponed any further work until after December. ``God gave us Christmas,'' Mrs. Cox says. ``We had a wonderful Christmas.'' Then Ingy developed pneumonia. This time the surgeons decided that no further repair was possible. The only alternative was a heart transplant. At Babies Hospital it is Dr. Daphne Hsu's job to find a heart and type it to see if it is immunologically compatible with a potential recipient. ``We get our donors from the same kind of tragedies as those that supply our adult patients _ accidents, neurological ailments, even tumors,'' she says. ``We'll take hearts from donors who have problems that don't involve the heart because our donor supply is so limited.'' The only supply of hearts for newborns are the hearts of other newborns. The heart has to be about the same size as that of the child who will receive it, besides being immunologically compatible. And there is urgency. A heart will keep only four hours after it is removed. Kidneys can be kept viable longer. But a heart has to be rushed to an airport, flown to where the sick recipient is and sped to the bedside. They found a heart for Ingy on Valentine's Day this year. ``We were very lucky to get a heart within a week,'' Susan Cox says. Most kids have to wait weeks, even months, getting sicker all the time. ``This is not a cure,'' she says. ``It's a treatment. That's one thing that really has to be emphasized.'' For the rest of his life Ingy will have to take the drugs that suppress his immune system and ensure that he will keep his heart. ``We lost a couple of teen-agers who were feeling so good they didn't think of themselves as sick anymore and quit taking their medicine,'' says Hsu.

DOC.TEXT: He was a crusader for liberal causes forced to make a painful decision. If he wanted to remain a priest, Robert F. Drinan had to give up politics. Now he's found other forums to get his views across, beginning in a classroom at Georgetown University. Here's another article in an occasional series called Class Act.

A decade ago, Jesuit priest Robert F. Drinan was ordered by Pope John Paul II to choose between the priesthood and his seat in Congress. The clerical collar he still wears speaks of his choice. In his office at Georgetown University Law Center, Drinan pulls out a thick volume of church law and reads aloud: ``No priest or nun may hold any office ...'' ``They changed canon law after my case,'' he says. ``Now it's very clear. They legitimized their preference. It's all spelled out with long footnotes about Drinan.'' And then he sums it up, sums it up with a bit more bite. ``The pope threw me out,'' says Drinan, known for his espousal of liberal causes as a member of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts. On May 5, 1980, Drinan accepted the pope's order ``with regret and pain.'' But neither pain nor regret seem evident in his chosen role as Drinan the priest. Nor is it surprising that he chose a ministry in the classic Jesuit mold, the priesthood of the intellect. His forum is a classroom, his subject one that confronts conflicts, challenges certitudes and stirs the Jesuitical juices: legal ethics. It is 7 p.m. as Drinan surveys his class gathered in seven rows of desks before him in a large room walled with concrete blocks painted blue. Four large television sets are suspended from the ceiling but they are silent and Drinan speaks without competition. Legal ethics? ``Anyone who says that legal ethics is an oxymoron, a contradiction in terms, will have to leave the room,'' Drinan had joked earlier. But now he's asking questions. ``Does a lawyer have an obligation to report on his fellow lawyers when he sees something wrong?'' He tells of a lawyer in Chicago who was suspended for a year, caught between the competing demands of the attorney-client privilege and the obligation to report another lawyer's wrongdoing. ``Was there an injustice?'' Drinan asks his students. ``Should he have gone to jail, had his finger cut off, or what?'' Drinan moves out from behind the lectern, paces, hands shoved deep in his pockets, continuing the lecture in a strong, raspy voice. ``There's a lawyer in New York who represents the bad lawyers. He seems to enjoy this line of work. Maybe you'll get into legal ethics as a career after this midsummer night's dream? ``No?'' Drinan scrawls case citations and legal rules on a blackboard, then selects a book from a desk covered with books in staggered piles. He licks his thumb and turns a page. ``We now come to a very juicy subject. Should you turn in your brother and sister lawyers?'' Drinan interlocks his fingers, pulls them apart, laces them back together. ``What to do? It's not black and white. That's the nature of it.'' Drinan's fingers splay up, framing his balding head. ``Would you require every lawyer to have malpractice insurance? There would be a whole new wave of litigation. It would bring up more problems than it would solve.'' Drinan's hands interlock on his chest. ``Confidentiality,'' he says. ``This is the biggie. This is going to haunt you all of your life. Lawyer-client privilege. ``It's based on the theory that somewhere in society there must be secrecy, that someone needs a father confessor. ``We've had it for 400 or 500 years and for 400 or 500 years lots of people have been banging on the desk and saying, `Why do these clowns have this?''' Drinan bangs on his desk. The 90-minute class breaks up for the evening. ``Most of his students are repeats,'' one of them says, leaving the room. ``He has a real strong following here.'' Drinan has never been one to avoid controversy and has never lacked for a following.

DOC.TEXT: He ticked off a list of activities that drew attention in the Vatican: his opposition to the war in Vietnam, his opposition to the military draft, his leadership in the abolition of mandatory retirement, his work from within to abolish the House Internal Security Committee, formerly the House Un-American Activities Committee. He listed his work for human rights, his campaign to liberate imprisoned Soviet human rights activist Anatoly Sharansky, his involvement in improving U.S. law involving civil liberties, crime, copyright and bankruptcy. ``I am grateful to have had these opportunities as a moral architect,'' Drinan says. ``I can think of no opportunities more worthy of the involvement of a priest and a Jesuit.'' When Drinan gave up his vote as a representative of Massachusetts' 4th Congressional District he did not give up his voice or abandon his liberal causes. For two years after his departure from Congress he served as president of Americans for Democratic Action, one of the nation's most outspokenly liberal political organizations. Now he not only teaches but also writes and lectures. Drinan's interest in the ethical conduct of the legal profession led to the founding three years ago of the Georgetown Journal of Legal Ethics, a publication that has won praise as an important source of scholarly ideas and information on issues facing lawyers and judges. A recent issue includes articles on legal malpractice, lawyer advertising, the issue of whether elected judges should disqualify themselves in cases involving campaign contributors. Drinan, who serves as the journal's faculty adviser, says, ``There has been a renaissance of legal ethics in America and this is the bible.'' But there is more to the Drinan agenda, much of it stemming from issues he pursued in his decade as a congressman _ human rights, civil rights, arms control. Since leaving Congress, Drinan has written three books, bringing his total since 1963 to seven. The latest: ``Cry of the Oppressed _ The History and Hope of the Human Rights Revolution.'' Drinan takes credit for persuading the American Bar Association to endorse the Civil Rights Act of 1990. He soon will become chairman of the group's committee on individual rights. His work has not gone unnoticed. Drinan now holds 20 honorary degrees, 11 of them awarded since he left Congress. What does he miss about Congress? ``I still use the swimming pool,'' he says, then laughs and adds: ``The taxpayers pay for the towels. ``I guess the thing I miss most is the parking perks at the airport.'' But there was more to Drinan's congressional career than that. He was in the thick of the battle to end to the war in Vietnam, the issue on which he was first elected. ``Mr. Speaker, I urge all of these people to make war on war,'' Drinan said during a 1971 speech. Drinan's congressional papers _ 520 linear feet of them _ are now housed in the archive of Boston College. Drinan was law professor and dean of the Boston College Law School from 1956 to 1970. The papers contain the first impeachment resolution ever filed against former President Nixon. It had nothing to do with Watergate but rather with Nixon's ordering the U.S. invasion of Cambodia. The archive also records Drinan's participation in the impeachment inquiry conducted later by the House Judiciary Committee. Drinan, again pulling books and pamphlets off his shelves, says, ``Here are some more of my babblings.'' There is a reprint of an opinion piece in the Boston Herald condemning the U.S. invasion of Panama as a violation of international law; an article in the National Catholic Reporter questioning lotteries and suggesting that gambling can weaken the strength of individuals and the nation; an article examining ``the political earthquakes in Eastern Europe.'' Drinan grins. ``Helps me stay off the streets,'' he says.

DOC.TEXT: He was called a ``political prodigy,'' an eloquent spokesman for the young Israeli nation. Now he feels the Jewish state he so strongly defended has taken a wrong turn. But Abba Eban at 75 has no real political power now and he vents his frustrations mainly through the media.

The cultured Cambridge-accented wit and oratory of Abba Eban once was the voice of Israel, extolling the young nation's virtues before the world and defending it from attack by its enemies. The voice has been muted for some time now and when Eban, at 75, does speak up he is more likely to admonish than praise the Israel that has grown up in the past 42 years. The tall, stately former ambassador and politician is saddened by what he sees as a besmirched image of Israel stemming from the incessant conflict with the Palestinians in the occupied lands. ``I think there is a sense of a paradise lost,'' he says. ``There is a kind of broken heart especially among Jews about the image Israel once projected and the image it presents now.'' Still, Eban keeps his fervor for the Jewish state. In articles, lectures and television appearances, the retired diplomat urges a return to the Israel of his youth, even as he damns the Israel of his advanced years. He is frustrated by Israel's political turn to the right, sharpened in the past 2{ years by the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. He criticizes both the right-wing government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his own left-of-center Labor Party, which exiled him from politics in 1988 by refusing him a nomination to run for Parliament. He strongly objects to Israel's refusal to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization or to consider trading occupied land for peace, a policy the United States advocates for solving the Middle East conflict. Israel ``is really tearing up its own birth certificate'' by refusing to share land and offer political rights to the Palestinians, Eban said in an interview with The Associated Press. Eban spoke by telephone from New York City. These days he spends much of his time abroad on projects that stress Israel's legacy of humanity and enlightenment. ``There is salvation and significance for the Jew only when he stands straight and aims high within his own authentic frame of values,'' Eban wrote in his book ``Heritage,'' which was made into a series for American public television. ``The Hebrew Messianic idea is alive with a sense of hope and purpose,'' he wrote. ``It is worthwhile to strive for human perfection, for social progress ... for universal peace.'' Dazzling words for Israel's Jewish ideals _ accompanied by doubts over the government's political actions _ were a theme of Eban's career. The South African-born Eban was always more dovish than Israel's other leaders on the Arab-Israeli conflict. In four decades as Israel's U.N. and U.S. ambassador, foreign minister and leading member of Parliament, Eban often objected privately to policies he supported publicly. In 1956, he argued bitterly with Israel's first prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, over Israel's hesitation to withdraw from Egyptian Sinai after the 1956 Suez War. But he then went before the United Nations and eloquently defended Israel. It is said Ben-Gurion later joked to Eban that it wasn't until he heard the U.N. speech ``that I became convinced of why we shouldn't withdraw.'' Today, with no real leadership role, Eban is more publicly critical. Israeli newspapers once called Eban ``a political prodigy'' for his youthful success in diplomacy. He was only 33 when he became Israel's first U.N. ambassador, at the time the youngest head of mission at the world body. In 1950, when Eban was 35, he was appointed ambassador to Washington, Israel's most important diplomatic post. He was 48 when he was named deputy prime minister and 51 when he got his most prestigious post, foreign minister. Now he has dropped into political oblivion. Eban said on Israel radio recently that he is keeping ``a certain distance'' from politics. In the past, he has acknowledged that his popularity overseas was not always matched at home. ``I could have been elected prime minister if people abroad could vote in Israeli elections,'' he once jokingly told an AP reporter. Eban's home is in Herzliya, a wealthy Tel Aviv suburb named for Theodore Herzl, who conceived of the Jewish state. Eban and his wife of 46 years, Susan, have two grown children, a daughter and a son who is a clarinetist with the Tel Aviv Philharmonic. Last February, Eban's 75th birthday went virtually unnoticed in Israel. At the United Nations, a gala party was thrown. Sponsors included four former U.S. presidents, Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. Eban's polished British manners and wan complexion from his many days in the corridors of power never fit in with Israel's culture of tanned, rough-hewn, native-born ``sabras.'' Eban settled in Israel after World War II, having served as a British liaison officer at Allied headquarters in Jerusalem.

DOC.TEXT: His detractors accuse him of being snobbish about his British upbringing and education. At Queens' College, Cambridge, he won first-class honors in the classics, Hebrew, Arabic and Persian. Though he is conversant in 10 languages, Eban has been criticized at home for his formal Hebrew. Isser Harel, former head of the Mossad intelligence agency, said Eban ``always spoke such a literary Hebrew, rather than the popular spoken tongue. It never sunk in very well.'' In the early 1960s, Eban as education minister used an antiquated phrase for ``youth'' while addressing a group of high school students. One bewildered teen-ager thought Eban was making a derogatory remark and shouted at him in protest. Eban at first was disappointed by his fall from political power. Now he says he is happier with a television career in which he reaches millions of people. ``It is a unique opportunity to try to correct the image of the present by bringing the illumination of the past,'' Eban says. In lectures, newspaper columns and interviews, Eban relishes his freedom from diplomatic strictures and speaks out sharply against Israeli policies toward the Arabs and the United States. He feels Israel has forsaken the stance of compromise and moral rectitude that was the key to world support for the Jewish state. A main target is Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, which objects to relinquishing any of the West Bank and Gaza. It claims the lands captured in the 1967 Middle East war _ home to 1.7 million Palestinians _ are integral parts of the historic land of Israel. Eban notes Israel won world recognition in 1948 only after its leaders agreed to partition historic Palestine, sharing the land with the Arabs. ``As a central witness in the drama, I can say that if we had claimed that 100 percent of the territory was ours then ... the world would have successfully organized to prevent our emergence,'' he says. ``So today when the government claims 100 percent of the right, it is really tearing up its own birth certificate. Israel's birth is intrinsically and intimately linked with the idea of sharing territory and sovereignty.'' He also denounces Israel's refusal to involve the PLO in Middle East peace moves, which has been a stumbling block to starting U.S.-mediated negotiations. ``Our policy was always to speak to the adversary,'' Eban says. Eban complains, too, that his own Labor Party has failed to persuade the Israeli public of the wisdom of a more conciliatory stance. Despite his worries about present-day Israel, Eban does not despair when he views the Jewish state within the sweep of history and Jewish destiny. At one moment Eban talks about the blow to Israel's image from the suppression of the Intefadeh, or Palestinian uprising. But then he quickly recalls that in 1948 the survivors of the Nazi Holocaust founded a new nation. ``The Intefadeh,'' he says, ``is only an episode in a long story.''

DOC.TEXT: With some 41 million more foreigners expected to visit America this year, it's important for the business executive to know how to entertain them. That can be complicated, depending on where they're from. Here's a guide to help you avoid cultural gaffes, such as inadvertently inviting your guests to commit hara-kiri.

Look who's coming to dinner. The big overseas client. It's decision-making time. Do you: _ Lock the dog in the basement? _ Order a dozen long-stemmed red roses? _ Search through the gourmet shops for sheeps' eyeballs, sea slugs and fresh-frozen bear paws? _ Greet the overseas visitor with a slap on the back, a firm handshake, perhaps three kisses on the cheek, or will just two suffice? _ See if the library has a recipe for stir-fried bees? _ Dare do anything about s-e-x? After all, in many parts of the world, sex is regarded as a hospitable gesture, a normal part of a business deal. The outcome of your entire negotiations may depend on how you cope with a cross-cultural crisis, warns Roger Axtell, a consultant and lecturer on worldwide business protocol. After all, trying to seduce a female client or a visiting wife is hardly getting things off to a crisp start, which, as Axtell points out, is what a dozen red roses connotes to a guest from West Germany. Besides, a bouquet of even-numbered flowers is considered bad luck in her country, where etiquette further dictates that you remove the paper first. Make sure the paper is not white if the guest is Japanese or the flowers purple if the recipient is from Brazil or Mexico. These are the colors of death in those climes. Also, white chrysanthemums in much of Europe and flowers of any kind in Kenya convey condolences. Further regarding gifts, Axtell recalls the curious case of a Grand Rapids, Mich., furniture dealer who didn't know the foreign territory. Playing host at a dinner for buyers from Japan, he put a silver pocket knife as a gift at each place setting. His guests left the gifts behind, in silent dismay at what to them was an invitation to commit hara-kiri. Axtell spent 30 years as vice president of world marketing for Parker Pen Co., traveling in 80 countries, observing, and sometimes inadvertently committing some of the cultural gaffes that can result in an abrupt jagged line on the sales chart and the boss's cardiogram. Now a roving consultant on global business behavior, Axtell has just finished his third book, ``The Do's and Taboos of Hosting International Visitors.'' Citing Department of Commerce figures, Axtell notes that some 41 million international visitors will come to the United States this year and spend $50 billion just for travel, food and accommodations. ``For the first time, there are more tourists arriving than departing. A $1.5 billion balance of tourist trade is projected, so it's important that we welcome them by recognizing the differences in their cultures, their way of having fun and doing business.'' Axtell warns that a host ``only invites disaster by attempting to duplicate any exotic foreign cuisine. Better to serve a typically American meal, with due regard for religious dietary regulations. But spare the corn on the cob. It's considered cattle food in many countries.'' Axtell urges a quick course in international body language as a basic survival tool in the global market place. Even a simple yes or no gesture can mean the opposite in other cultures.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
COS COB, Conn.: other cultures
DOC.TEXT: When a visitor from Bulgaria or Sri Lanka nods his head, that means no. A head shake connotes yes. A Turk signifies no by ``raising his chin, shutting his eyes and tilting the head backward.'' Ordinary gestures can convey extraordinary meanings to a foreign visitor, advises Axtell. ``Placing your hands on your hips is an aggressive gesture to a Mexican. Forming a circle with the thumb and forefinger while elevating the other three fingers is a most obscene gesture in Brazil.'' Similarly, thumbs up is a rude gesture in Bangladesh, as is winking or beckoning with the middle finger in Hong Kong and Malaysia. ``The Japanese,'' he went on, ``dislike being pounded on the back. Touching is unacceptable. To them an open mouth is offensive. So yawns, belly laughs and chewing gum are out.'' At table, the differences can be perplexing. A Swede crisscrossing the utensils on his plate is asking for another helping and not signifying he is full. Among Egyptians it is impolite to eat everything on the plate. In Finland, it is bad luck to pass the salt hand to hand. The shaker should be set down before the guest. A Japanese will accept a second helping only if asked twice. Zambians compliment the hostess by asking for seconds. Axtell regrets that ``toasting is a skill most Americans never hone. But at a dinner or banquet, in less than a minute, a well-composed toast can convey more elan and diplomacy than a month of slick talk.'' Unless you are an accomplished linguist, Axtell warns against attempting a toast in the visitor's language. He once tried memorizing the Chinese words for, ``Thank you for a wonderful dinner. I ate so much I must loosen my belt.'' Later, he learned what he actually said was, ``I ate so much the girth of my donkey's saddle is loose.'' But his embarrassment was less than that of an Iranian deputy oil minister who hoisted a glass at the Petroleum Club in Houston with the toast, ``As they say in your country: Up your bottoms.'' But as Jimmy Carter found out on his 1977 trip to Poland, using an interpreter can sometimes double the trouble. His interpreter made the arrival speech unforgettable even today in Warsaw with the translation: ``The president says he is pleased to be here in Poland grasping your secret parts.'' Finally, there is the question of s-e-x. While hosting a foreign client, is one obliged to arrange for some group interaction in a hot tub, an all-purpose escort service or a visit to a local pleasure palace? ``While in other countries sex often is an expected part of business entertainment,'' Axtell answers, ``not once in over 30 years of hosting scores of business visitors from all over the world did one of them request or show any expectation for a hired sexual partner.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 graphic.)
DOC.TEXT: Prowling the streets at night, tailing suspects, bringing the villains to justice is a new type of private eye. They are women, just as savvy and cynical as Sam Spade or Phillip Marlow and the rest of the macho male bunch that for so long dominated the whodunit genre.

Sue Grafton recalls scheming in the night about a way to kill one of her two ex-husbands. After she'd carefully worked it out, she realized, ``I knew I could never pull it off. I thought, `I'll just put it in a book.''' Grafton didn't want to write a psychological novel in which the reader identifies with a killer. So she created somebody to foil her own plot. ``I gave the reader somebody virtuous to identify with, the wisest move I ever made in my life.'' Thus was born Kinsey Millhone, one of a new breed of professional private investigators who have emerged in the long evolution of the ``whodunit,'' women to stand shoulder-to-shoulder with Dashiell Hammett's Sam Spade, Raymond Chandler's Phillip Marlow and Ross MacDonald's Lou Archer. There have always been female detectives in modern literature, such as Agatha Christie's Miss Marple. But they have been almost without exception genteel amateurs. The new ones, on the other hand, are professionals. Six months before Kinsey Millhone's first appearance, in ``A Is for Alibi,'' private eye V.I. (Victoria) Warshawski had solved her first case in Sara Paretsky's ``Indemnity Only.'' Paretsky, who wrote it in 1979, says that too often in American crime novels sexually active unmarried women are the villains. ``In six of seven Chandler novels, a sexually active woman is the main villain. I really wanted to try to counteract that image,'' she says. Paretsky was working full time as a manager at an insurance company when she started working on the novel. ``Women were making it into the ranks of management,'' she says. ``There were people who pushed us as hard as they could to see if we'd crack. I wanted a woman who was experiencing what I and my friends were _ being challenged on her right to do the job. She was a pioneer, being called an aggressive bitch.'' A third private investigator, Carlotta Carlyle, was born after her creator, Linda Barnes, had written four books about amateur sleuth Michael Spraggue. ``I'd always wanted to write a woman P.I.,'' Barnes says. ``As soon as I finished the first Spraggue in 1981, I talked to my editor about doing a woman. He told me there's no market for hard-boiled women. Since I don't write for posthumous glory, I figured I would continue with Spraggue. ``I thought how nice it would be if people would knock on a detective's door with problems. It's very hard to get amateurs realistically involved in mysteries. I killed off all Spraggue's friends and relatives. He was getting very depressed.'' Each of these female private eyes is divorced; each of the writers is married. All three write in the first person. The point of view, mind and personality the reader gets to know is the private detective's and, to some extent, the writer's. Paretsky, who was born in Iowa and grew up in Nebraska, lives in Chicago. Her husband calls her a pit bull. She has had V.I. tangle with corruption in Chicago politics, Great Lakes shipping, malpractice, the Roman Catholic Church and Vatican Bank. ``I find it very disturbing the way in which people in large institutions can commit tremendous amounts of crime, violating public trust. The damage that can do runs very deep in individual lives,'' she says. ``Three or four times a week I make these moral decisions. Am I brave enough to write about this issue, to stand up to this person? Three times out of five I chicken out. ``Every day I try to make myself take on the things I'm afraid of. V.I. can do it in a way that I can't. I suppose it is that kind of integrity and passion that matter most to me.'' In contrast to Paretsky's big issues, Grafton says, ``My stories come out of an instance in the family dynamic. I use a small canvas, the human heart. I'm interested in the dark side of human nature, what it is that makes us kill each other instead of going into therapy as we should.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 3 b&w photos. ColorFoto subscribers get 2 35mm slides.)
DOC.TEXT: The wooden roller coaster, the flagship of amusement parks in the Roaring '20s, is making a noisy comeback. One reason is nostalgia. Park operators say the traditional thrill ride attracts older people trying to relive their youth. Others say they are just simply more fun. Whatever the reason, new ``woodies'' are being built in cities across America.

The walls in Curtis Summers' office show that times are good for people whose idea of a good time is a white-knuckle ride on a giant wooden roller coaster. On one wall is a drawing of the American Eagle that Summers designed in 1981 for the Great America amusement park in suburban Chicago. At the other end of the room is a picture of his Timber Wolf, which opened last year at Worlds of Fun in Kansas City. In between are some of the coasters he designed in the 1970s, and other examples of his newly booming business. ``We're working on No. 29 right now,'' Summers says. The past 10 years have been generous to traditionalists who forgo the smooth ride of steel-framed roller coasters in favor of roaring down rougher wooden coasters at speeds that can top 65 mph. In that time amusement parks have built 21 full-size wooden roller coasters, from the Judge Roy Scream built in 1980 at Six Flags Over Texas between Dallas and Fort Worth to Thunder Run set to open at Kentucky Kingdom in Louisville, Ky. ``The last two or three years have been incredible for building coasters in general, and wooden coasters are a big part of that,'' says Mark Wyatt, who edits the roller coaster newsletter Inside Track. There are now 80 wooden roller coasters in the United States, Mexico and Canada, along with 144 steel roller coasters. Three new ``woodies'' debuted earlier this year, all designed by Summers: the Texas Giant at Six Flags Over Texas, the Georgia Cyclone at Six Flags in Atlanta and the Predator at Darien Lake Park near Buffalo, N.Y. ``I keep telling everybody you can't be too rich, too thin or have too many roller coasters. They are the staple ride of a theme park, and they make a great landmark,'' says Harold Hudson, a Six Flags Over Texas Corp. vice president whose division supervises coaster construction. Dallas-based Six Flags runs nine wooden coasters and 29 steel coasters at its seven theme parks. Hudson says the company plans two more coasters next year, both wooden. ``One reason is nostalgia,'' Hudson says. ``That's what coasters were made of in the past and that's what everybody remembers. It also has a little broader demographics. A wooden coaster might get older people who might be interested in riding it.'' Tom Timko, who runs an information hot line for the 2,300-member American Coaster Enthusiasts, says the heyday for wooden roller coasters was the 1920s, when an amusement park wasn't considered complete without one. ``Then, with the Depression, a lot of parks closed,'' Timko says. ``In the '70s, with Walt Disney World, they started to get popular again.'' A wooden coaster, The Beast, built in 1979 at Kings Island near Cincinnati, has topped Inside Track's reader poll of the world's best roller coasters for the two summers the magazine has conducted the poll. ``The attraction, to me anyway, is that you have more freedom of movement. You're out in the air. When you get in a steel coaster, you're sealed in a little car,'' Wyatt says. ``The wood coaster is a different feeling. They move a little bit to take the shock of the train going around.'' Summers says he has received inquiries about designing wooden roller coasters for North Africa, Europe, Korea, Australia and Singapore. He also is bidding to build the first wooden roller coaster in Japan. ``There are very few wooden coasters outside of North America, but the demand is ever-increasing,'' he says. Summers says a roller coaster he is designing for a Midwest amusement park will surpass the 67 mph speed of the American Eagle, as well as the Texas Giant's 140-foot height record among wooden roller coasters. ``With present-day speeds, we just about have to build a Swiss watch 150 feet high,'' Summers says. ``And you don't want absolute smoothness. You want a little bit of roughness for that wood feel.'' At Dorney Park in Pennsylvania, the Hercules coaster spreads over a hillside that lets cars drop 157 feet in their first dip, while the coaster's structure stands only 95 feet above the ground. ``It was a very smart move of them, using that hillside where nothing else would fit,'' Summers says. ``It's dynamite to save money on structure and get the world's highest drop on a coaster.'' Competition for the title of the highest ``woodie'' was intense enough to lead Dorney Park to sue Six Flags in federal court in Pennsylvania. The parks settled in April, agreeing that while the Hercules had the longest drop in the world, the Texas Giant had the highest lift.

From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Gil Gerard still remembers enough chemistry to understand the environmental issues tackled in his new CBS fall series ``The E.A.R.T.H. Force.'' ``I used to be a chemist, and I can still boil water,'' he says. Gerard worked as a chemist in his native Arkansas after college. He says he was in line to become vice president of a chemical company when he decided to become an actor. In the series, which debuts on Saturday this fall, Gerard heads an elite environmental group called E.A.R.T.H. Force. It stands for Earth Alert Research & Tactical Headquarters. The group's mission is to protect the environment from criminals polluting the world's resources and from natural disasters. ``When I first began discussing this project I asked where are we going,'' Gerard says. ``They said it would not be a crisis of the week. People get bored with that. We're going to concentrate on people stories, with an overview of the environment. If we tell about an oil spill, the story will be about its effect on one person. ``We also want to show people how they can deal with a big issue like, say, depletion of the ozone level. People think they might not be able to do anything, but if 20 million people watch the show and do something, it'll make a big difference.'' The series, the fourth for Gerard, also stars Joanna Pacula, Robert Knepper and Clayton Rohner, and two Australian performers, Tiffany Lamb and Stewart Finlay-McLennan. It is a joint American-Australian production and will be made in Australia. Gerard plays Dr. John Harding, a heart surgeon and geneticist and a former Green Beret. ``Harding's a guy who's not afraid to take chances,'' Gerard says. ``I think he has a good overview of what has to be done. He acts as a leavening agent for the more radical members of the force. ``There seem to be some people in the environmental movement who seem more intent in polarizing issues than solving them. Harding says let's solve it, not beat up on everyone. He looks for a common ground.'' Gerard made his series debut in the title role of ``Buck Rogers in the 25th Century'' on NBC in 1979. He starred in two other short-lived series, ``Sidekicks'' and ``Nightingales.'' The latter show caused protests from nursing groups for its sexy portrayal of student nurses. ``It seemed to be begging for some sort of reaction,'' he says. ``It was like two different shows. There was the show Suzanne Pleshette, Barry Newman and I did and the one with the nurses. Nobody was undressing when we did our part.'' After completing ``Nightingales'' last spring, he starred as a private detective in ``Final Notice'' for the USA Network. He has an independent feature film, ``Soldier's Fortune,'' coming out soon. In that, he plays a mercenary who returns from Central America to find that his daughter has been kidnapped. Naturally, he gets her back. Gerard says he hopes to be able to go to Australia early enough to find a place on the beach to practice his avocation, scuba diving. He also hopes to be close enough to the Great Barrier Reef to get in some diving. First, he is off for several days at a training program in Georgia conducted by the Environmental Protection Agency. There he will study techniques of surveillance and gathering evidence. Gerard's son, Gib, 8, is also off on a foreign visit. He will accompany his mother, Connie Sellecca, on a vacation to Japan. Sellecca stars in the new ABC series ``Baby Talk,'' based on the hit movie ``Look Who's Talking.'' When Gerard decided to switch to acting, he studied at the American Musical and Dramatic Academy in New York. He drove a taxicab at night. He worked as an extra on the 1970 movie ``Love Story'' and appeared in 450 commercials over the next six years. He also had a role on the soap opera ``The Doctors.'' He used his business experience to start a production company and star in a low-budget feature film, ``Hooch.'' He moved to California to play Lee Grant's lover in ``Airport '77.'' A guest appearance on ``Little House on the Prairie'' led to starring in a pilot movie written, directed and produced by Michael Landon. The next year, he landed the title role in ``Buck Rogers.'' Gerard has also starred in a number of television movies, such as ``Help Wanted: Male,'' ``Hear No Evil,'' ``Runaway,'' ``For Love or Money'' and ``Stormin' Home.''

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: In a monumental undertaking, the Guthrie Theater celebrates Shakespeare's history plays this summer with stirring, sweeping productions of ``Richard II,'' ``Henry IV'' (parts 1 and 2) and ``Henry V.'' They are not only monumental pieces of theater, but major acting and logistical challenges for the regional theater, which was founded in 1963 by Tyrone Guthrie. The three productions _ with the two parts of ``Henry IV'' combined into one play _ are being performed in repertory through Sept. 2 with a special encore week of performances Oct. 9-13. They employ two directors, the theater's entire 28-member acting company and a trio of distinctive settings by design wizard Douglas Stein. The effort pays off handsomely. It's an amazing theatrical journey through more than 50 years of English history. What makes it special is the chance to see these plays together, to follow the arc of this history from the doomed reign of the foolish, foppish Richard II to the monarchy of the charismatic Henry V who rallies his nation to military victory over France. These works are linked by many of the same characters _ watch Bolingbroke turn into a troubled Henry IV or the hedonistic Prince Hal grow into an impressive Henry V _ and they reverberate with ideas that echo from play to play to play. Among other things, the plays are about power. How people use it, and how power uses them. In ``Richard II,'' the king doesn't appreciate the power he has until he loses it. Richard, in a lyrical, galvanizing performance by Charles Janasz, gains spiritual strength as he loses control of temporal power. He stands in contrast to Bolingbroke, who decisively takes control of his life _ and the crown _ to become Henry IV. But once king, he has little rest from guilt over Richard's death and self-doubt about his ability. Stephen Yoakam admirably projects Henry's world weariness, the machinations he must go through to hold onto the throne. Prince Hal also undergoes a transformation. As played by Barton Tinapp, he goes from roustabout to ruler with remarkable skill. He's at home with Falstaff and the other rowdies at the Eastcheap Tavern, but can dismiss them curtly when he is called upon to fulfill his royal duty. Stein's innovative settings dazzle. There's a burnished copper design for ``Richard II,'' a gnarled, rustic wooden environment for ``Henry IV'' and then bare, exposed rehearsal space for ``Henry V'' with glimpses of the sets from the first two productions as a backdrop. The costumes, designed by Ann Hould-Ward, are opulent, except for one stunning bit of theatricality in ``Henry V'' in which the actors playing the English wear rehearsal clothes. The designer perhaps took a cue from the opening chorus of ``Henry V,'' which entreats the audience to use its imagination in seeing and hearing the play. The three plays were co-directed with a fine sense of historical pageantry and drama by Garland Wright, the Guthrie's artistic director, and Charles Newell, a one-time resident director at the theater. ``Garland and I decided early on that the only way we could see it work was if both of us were responsible for everything,'' Newell said in an interview. ``Each of us would do all of it.'' The idea to do the history play cycle at the Guthrie came from a plan to have Richard Iglewski, an actor in the company, play Falstaff. ``In the winter of 1988-89, we did a reading of the `Henry IV' plays just to listen to them,'' Newell said. ``And we realized `Henry IV Part 2' had difficulty standing on its own.'' Then Wright had the idea of cradling the two ``Henry IV'' plays between ``Richard II'' and ``Henry V.'' ``Suddenly, it became a very big project,'' said Newell. ``It was decided the acting company wasn't ready to do that. But after much thought on Garland's part, he decided that that very reason _ we weren't ready to do it _ was the reason we should be doing it.'' The two directors began informally discussing the plays in July 1989. In September, historians and scholars were brought in to talk about the history of the period, the manners of the time, the difference between Shakespeare's history and actual history. ``Most helpful were professors of social history,'' Newell said. ``Scholars who could talk about what it was like to live in a castle or what was an inn like and who was there and what did people eat and drink. Things that, for actors, are very useful in terms of understanding character.'' Wright, Newell and Michael Lupu, the Guthrie's dramaturge, worked on ways to transform the two ``Henry IV'' dramas into a single work. ``We made a decision to try and tell the entire story of what both plays were about in one play,'' Newell said. ``But we didn't want to cut out major sections of the plays as a way to condense it. Rather, we wanted to just trim everything that was there and somehow compact it.'' Rehearsals began March 13, nearly three months before the first preview performance on June 9. The three shows opened June 30 in an all-day, 12-hour marathon. Wright and Newell made an unusual decision about those early rehearsals: The co-directors would do very little talking the first month and let the actors find the plays on their own. ``We were there to guide and focus, but primarily we wanted the company to discover the plays themselves as well as to discover something about the actual rehearsal process itself,'' Newell said. The actors were encouraged to talk about the scenes they were working on. ``It was scary for them because they didn't have a single voice, or in our case, two voices telling them what they were going to do,'' Newell said. ``We had rehearsals in which everybody was in the room at all times, and anybody could say anything they wanted about the scene that we were working on,'' he added. ``Suddenly the work became about what the company is.'' After a month of this work, Wright and Newell split into separate rehearsals. But they maintained a dialogue with each other that allowed them to shape the plays with equal input. ``One of the hardest moments was that first day of rehearsal in which we were all sitting at tables that had scripts that came off the table about 4 or 5 inches,'' Newell said. ``The sheer size of the project was daunting. But like anything that big, you just do it one step at a time and somehow you get it done.''

DOC.SECOND: BC-Soviet New South I, Adv29-2 Takes,1029
DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, July 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Part I: New Mood
Islam, Economics, Ecology: Recipe for Unrest in Soviet South
LaserPhoto NY301 of July 23; Graphics SOVNEWSOL, SOVNEWSO1, SOVNEWSOG
DOC.TEXT: In the heart of Asia, far from the tumult of the Kremlin, a new mood of defiance and independence is taking hold. This is the first installment of a four-part series by an AP special correspondent who traveled through the restive Soviet south.

Townsfolk in this ancient capital of tiled turquoise domes and haunting memories are starting to refer to the Soviet state in the same past tense they apply to Tamerlane and Genghis Khan. ``The Soviet Union is rotting away,'' said Alex Ulko, a young painter and English student at the University of Samarkand. ``Within a few years, Asians will be shaping their own nations.'' Moscow is omnipresent in Soviet Central Asia, from government offices and Communist Party headquarters to donkey-riding KGB informants in remote hamlets. But new political currents, rooted in an Islamic religious revival, economic resentment and environmental concerns, are carrying Asian peoples inexorably further from the Kremlin. Although Lenin's iron-cast goatee still juts resolutely forward in city parks, Asians revere their own wise men, in flowing white beards and colored robes, who evoke a past few have forgotten, a past almost palpable at night when Islamic chants can be heard down twisting lanes shaded by mulberries. The five Central Asian republics _ Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia _ stretch from the Caspian Sea to China, an area almost as big as the United States. Their 50 million inhabitants, 20 million in Uzbekistan, make up a fifth of the Soviet population. A few examine 21st century problems in nuclear physics and biochemistry, but many more live in rag tents or mud hovels, as in the days of the Golden Horde. In some ways Central Asia is marked indelibly by a century of Russian czars and commissars. But many here see the Russian interlude as destined to be yet another turn of history, no more vital to the present than when camels plied the Silk Road from China to Europe. New political parties, ecological movements, Moslem clergymen in reopened mosques and young radicals all press for broader freedoms leading to independence. Even local Communist Party cadres are insisting on greater home rule. ``Perestroika has brought truth, but truth has brought unrest,'' noted Agzam Rahmidov, an English professor in this old crossroads city in Uzbekistan. For one thing, Central Asians complain of economic exploitation. The Uzbekistan prime minister, Shukrulla Mirsaidov, contends his people pay out three times as much to the central government as they get back. In June, Uzbekistan and Tadzhikistan refused to export food to other republics at the low prices decreed by the state. Later, the Uzbek Parliament adopted a preliminary ``declaration of sovereignty.'' Anti-Moscow sentiment reaches deep into daily life. Russian settlers are leaving the region at a quickening pace, spurred by sporadic pogroms against ethnic minorities. Youths are evading the military draft and rebelling against officers they accuse of bias. In a nation fraught with more immediate crises, these pressures stew largely out of sight. In June, a border clash between Uzbeks and Kirghizis in the old holy city of Osh commanded attention as the official death toll mounted to as high as 800. But when Soviet troops imposed calm, the spotlight moved on. ``The situation in Central Asia is very serious, and we don't understand it fully,'' said Igor Krupnik, a conflict specialist at the Academy of Sciences in Moscow. ``No one has the data.'' The problem, Central Asians say, is that distant analysts are often thrown off by convenient generalities about peoples who are anything but homogeneous. Over millennia, borders were traced across the sands by conquerors, from the Mongol hordes, to Turkish tyrants like Tamerlane, to the Russian czars. Josef Stalin drew the last map in the 1920s, when the regions of Turkestan and Eastern Bukhara were transformed into five republics. The plains of Kazakhstan, biggest and northernmost of the five, separate European Russia from Asia. To the south lie the other four: in the east, the small mountainous enclaves of Tadzhikistan and Kirghizia, bordering China and Afghanistan; in the west, the highlands and deserts of Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan, stretching toward the oilfields of the Caspian Sea. These Central Asian neighbors are linked by the Koran and often by common linguistic roots. But just as often they are divided by disputes over land and water. In the Soviet grand plan, the whole region was given over to cotton. Fields were irrigated from the majestic rivers Amu Darya and Syr Darya, and Russian migrants settled frontier lands. Today only 40 percent of the Kazakhstan population is Kazakh. But decades of poor planning have so bled the rivers that they no longer replenish the Aral Sea. Half of the world's fourth largest lake has dried up, its exposed lakebed now just loose salt poisoned by pesticide runoff. To revive the Aral Sea, Uzbeks want to cut off the Karakum Canal, used by the Turkmens to water their desert. ``Land was exploited in the most disgusting colonial way,'' said Sergei Kapitsa of the Physical Problems Institute in the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Central Asian planners want to diversify from cotton. But the region is short of energy. And the Tadzhiks, ensconced in high mountains, balk at flooding villages for more hydroelectic dams. In this climate of tension, an isolated skirmish over a piece of scarce farmland, like the one in Osh, can flash overnight into pitched battles in capital cities hundreds of miles apart. Explosive mixtures have resulted from past Soviet policies of dispersing inconvenient minorities to once-remote areas, such as the Fergana Valley, which includes Osh. Last year, rampaging Uzbeks killed at least 100 people in pogroms against Turks resettled from Georgia almost two generations ago. Other minorities, including Russians, were also targeted.

DOC.SECOND: BC-Soviet New South I, Adv29-1st Add,0394
DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, July 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: SAMARKAND, U.S.S.R.: also targeted.
DOC.TEXT: This February, an estimated 50 people were killed in riots in the Tadzhik capital, Dushanbe, reportedly touched off by rumors that Armenian refugees would settle there. In May, mobs burned 47 homes of Armenians and Jews in the Fergana Valley. Authorities cite local causes for each outbreak, sometimes blaming unnamed political opportunists, religious fanatics or drug-crazed hooligans. But others see deeper roots. ``The problem is social frustration among a generation of youths who are losing their old values and see nothing to replace them,'' said Munira Shadheedi, a historian in Dushanbe. Opposition politicians, mostly writers and other intellectuals, see a policy vacuum as Communist Party stalwarts push ahead with only modifications of ideas that have failed to inspire confidence. These new leaders say it is too early to design specific programs for independence. First, most say, they must abolish entrenched official corruption, which impoverishes and embitters their populations. Alternative parties are beginning to attract wide support. The Uzbekistan popular front, Birlik, has inspired similar movements in other republics. Krupnik said he saw signs these disparate opposition groups were linking up, forging the beginnings of a grass-roots movement across Central Asia. Their main obstacle is a historical aversion to mixing among ethnic groups in the region, he said. If Central Asia mixes anywhere, it is here in Samarkand, a city of 390,000 people that recently celebrated its 2,500th anniversary. The old mud synagogue blends unnoticed into a block of Moslem houses. Men of all religions wear the same square black skullcaps embroidered in white. A multitude of nationalities sits together for tea and patterned wheels of bread, escaping the sun under shade trees. But a chat with Samarkand university students suggests that this harmony of old is changing fast. A Crimean Tatar woman felt growing antipathy and said her family wanted badly to get home. Her Russian-Ukrainian friend said Uzbeks are making up for lost time in reasserting national pride. ``There is a very dark fear which is difficult to understand,'' concluded a young Russian, like the others reluctant to be quoted by name. ``We see discrimination against others. The Russians are next.''

DOC.HEAD: Thumbnail Look at Five Soviet Republics
With BC-Soviet New South I, b0532-b0533
DOC.TEXT: In the 1860s and 1870s, Russian czarist forces subjugated the Central Asian regions of Turkestan and Khiva, and the cities of Tashkent, Samarkand and Bokhara. After the 1917 Russian Revolution, the territories were reorganized as five Soviet republics. Here is a brief look at the history, people, land and economies of the Central Asian republics:
DOC.HEAD: History:
DOC.TEXT: Originally formed as an autonomous republic within the Russian republic by joining the provinces of Uralsk, Turgai, Akmolinsk and Semipalatinsk in 1920. Made a constituent republic of the Soviet Union in 1936.
DOC.HEAD: People and Land:
DOC.TEXT: Population: 16,470,000. Ethnic breakdown: Kazakhs 36 percent (largely Sunni Moslem), Russians 40.8 percent, Ukrainians 6.1 percent. Area: 1,049,155 square miles. Capital: Alma Ata.
DOC.HEAD: Economy:
DOC.TEXT: Grain, cotton, tobacco, rubber plants and mustard are among the crops grown. Orchards and vineyards are common. Rich in coal, tungsten, oil and other minerals.
DOC.HEAD: History:
DOC.TEXT: Turkmenistan was made a constituent republic of the Soviet Union in 1925. It is made up of the former Trans-Caspian region, the Charjiui vilayet of Bokhara and part of Khiva.
DOC.HEAD: People and Land:
DOC.TEXT: Population: 3,455,000. Ethnic breakdown: Turkmens 68.4 percent (largely Sunni Moslem), Russians 12.6 percent, Uzbeks 8.6 percent. Area: 186,400 square miles. Capital: Askhabad.
DOC.HEAD: Economy:
DOC.TEXT: Grain, cotton, vegetables, dates, figs, sesame, fruits and berries. Produces Astrakhan fur and Karakul wool. Rich in ozocerite, oil, coal and other minerals.
DOC.HEAD: History:
DOC.TEXT: Became a constituent republic in 1925, comprising lands formerly included in Turkestan. It encompasses much of the Samarkand region, the southern part of the Syr Darya, Western Fergana, the western plains of Bukhara, the Kara-Kalpak autonomous republic and the Uzbek regions of Khorezm.
DOC.HEAD: People and Land:
DOC.TEXT: Population: 19,026,000 Ethnic breakdown: Uzbeks 68.7 percent (largely Sunni Moslem), Russians 10.8 percent, Tadzhiks 3.9 percent, Tatars 4.2 percent. Area: 172,741 square miles. Capital: Tashkent.
DOC.HEAD: Economy:
DOC.TEXT: Cotton, fruit, silk, rice, grain, and grapes. Karakul sheep are raised. Oil, coal and copper are important.
DOC.HEAD: History:
DOC.TEXT: The Tadzhik Soviet Socialist Republic was formed from those regions of Bokhara and Turkestan where the population consisted mainly of Tadzhiks. It was admitted as a constituent republic in 1929.
DOC.HEAD: People and Land:
DOC.TEXT: Population: 4,807,000 Ethnic breakdown: Tadzhiks 58.8 percent (largely Sunni Moslem), Uzbeks 22.9 percent, Russians and Ukrainians 10.4 percent. Area: 55,240 square miles. Capital: Dushanbe.
DOC.HEAD: Economy:
DOC.TEXT: Grain, cotton, potatoes, vegetables, apricots, figs, olives, pomegranates, citrus fruit, berries, and grapes. Eucalyptus and geranium are grown for the perfume industry. Coal, lead, zinc, uranium and radium are important minerals.
DOC.HEAD: History:
DOC.TEXT: In 1924, Kirghizia was separated from Turkestan and made into an autonomous region. It was transformed into an autonomous republic in 1926 and was proclaimed a constituent republic in 1936.
DOC.HEAD: People and Land:
DOC.TEXT: Population: 4,143,000. Ethnic breakdown: Kirghizians 47.9 percent (largely Sunni Moslem), Russians 25.9 percent, Ukrainians 3.1 percent, Uzbeks 12.1 percent, and Tatars 2 percent. Area: 76,460 square miles. Capital: Frunze.
DOC.HEAD: Economy:
DOC.TEXT: Grain, cotton, sugar beet, hemp, tobacco, medicinal plants, rice, vegetables, fruit, berries, and grapes. Beekeeping is important. Sugar refineries and tanneries are important industrial enterprises.
