DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: ``The Josephine Baker Story,'' the first major film on the life of the legendary American expatriate, has wrapped up production in Budapest, Hungary, after nine weeks of on-location filming. Lynn Whitfield (``The Women of Brewster Place'') stars in the title role, with Ruben Blades, David Dukes, Academy Award-winner Louis Gossett Jr. and Craig T. Nelson co-starring. The ``Josephine Baker Story'' will debut on HBO in February 1991.

Glenn Close, Niels Arestrup and Erland Josephson head the cast of Enigma Productions' ``Meeting Venus,'' which starts shooting for Warner Bros. on Aug. 6 in Budapest, Hungary, and Paris. ``Meeting Veuns'' is a comedy about the chaos and confusion surrounding a conductor's efforts to stage an opera with a mutinational company in Paris. Close stars as an internationally famous soprano. But the soundtrack will use the voice of opera great Dame Kiri te Kanawa. Also featured will be tenor Rene Kollo. The music _ Wagner's ``Tannhauser'' _ will be performed by the Philharmonia Orchestra and Ambrosian Singers, conducted by Marek Janovski.

``Just sing!'' Jackson Browne has heard the audience taunts. Weary of his tireless politicking, many fans have lost patience. Browne remains dedicated to his causes _ El Salvador, Amnesty International and Nelson Mandela among them these days. Yet his current 30-city concert tour is scarcely a litany of death squads, human-rights abuses and anti-apartheid slogans. Instead, it is a celebration of some of plaintive ballads, such as ``Farther On,'' ``For a Dancer'' and ``Before the Deluge,'' that first brought Browne acclaim. The concert series, Browne hopes, will be as much of a revelation for his followers as it is for Browne himself. ``This is an acoustic tour, and the song list is open to whatever can be played on two guitars and percussion,'' Browne said in an interview. ``I can hear myself singing in a way I can't when I play with a band. ``For a lot of people (in the audience), it's like hearing the words for the first time. For me, it's the first time since I'd written the words that I'd heard them. ... The whole purpose of the tour is to highlight the writing.'' In recent years, Browne has been more an activist than a musician. Now, he says, he's heading back toward love songs. ``To succeed with a political song, you have to get people to examine themselves,'' he said. ``If you preach to them, you're lost.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 26, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: No Rest for the Weary: Priests, Nuns Face Bleak Retirement Picture
DOC.TEXT: They labored 60, 70, 80 hours a week in schools, hospitals and parishes, turning an immigrant church into the nation's largest or helping American Catholics achieve education and income levels on a par with Protestants. Now, when their contemporaries are enjoying days of golf and theater and retiring in comfort to Florida or Arizona, what earthly reward awaits many of the nation's priests, brothers and sisters? More work. The priest shortage has led many dioceses to set their retirement age at 75, while the dearth of vocations in religious orders has led some nuns in their 70s to go out looking for work to financially support their communities. ``The personal issue is not to be able to retire in this particular culture until one is 75 is almost inhuman,'' said Monsignor William Stanton of St. Ambrose Church in Buffalo, N.Y. ``How many people last that long?'' As it is in American society, the prospect of widespread retirement is relatively new for those who have sworn their lives to the church. ``Once a priest, always a priest'' was the expectation of most priests ordained before the Second Vatican Council in the early 1960s, said the Rev. David Brinkmoeller, executive director of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops' Secretariat for Priestly Life and Ministry. ``That used to be the normal thing _ that people would die with their boots on,'' he said. But as the church opened itself up to American culture, the influence of Social Security and other programs that gave the average person the expectation of a period of retirement in which one would enjoy life gradually filtered into the priesthood. Ironically, said Monsignor Charles J. Fahey of the Third Age Center at Fordham University, one of the motivating factors for offering retirement programs was a glut of priests in top positions that was clogging the traditional paths of advancement for younger priests. ``It was about 1970 that the notion of the retirement of priests began to come into parlance,'' Fahey said. ``At the same time the rest of the country was doing away with mandatory retirement, we were putting it in.'' Sister Jane Frances Power said when she entered the Sisters of St. Joseph of Orange in 1933 some of the younger members thought anybody over 50 shouldn't be teaching. But demographic changes that once motivated dioceses to, in Fahey's words, ``get the old bucks out'' now have them offering incentives to keep priests, nuns and brothers working into their 70s and beyond. In 1989, 1 percent of Catholic sisters were under 30 and 41 percent were 70 and over. Of the nation's 155,000 men and women in religious orders, 44,000 are past 70. The lack of younger members bringing in income has resulted in a shortfall of retirement funds estimated at more than $3 billion, and provided an incentive for older members to keep working to help out. Power, who was for 30 years the chief executive officer of a hospital in Fullerton, Calif., signed on three years ago at age 74 to become coordinator of health and hospitals for the Archdiocese of Los Angeles. She is not alone. ``It certainly appears to us that there are a number of religious who are still working part-time, if not full-time, into their 70s,'' said Sister Mary Oliver Hudon of the Tri-Conference Retirement Project. ``We have religious in their 60s who are looking for other jobs. ... That's a new phenomenon.'' Sister Jane E. Shappelle runs Project Encor in Cincinnati, a job service started in 1987 for women religious 50 and over and whose clients have included a 76-year-old woman with a doctorate. The pressure to keep working is particularly felt by priests, in demand by a growing laity for a functions from Sunday Mass to funerals and weddings. The number of American priests has dropped to 53,000 from 59,200 in 1970. The ratio of worshipers to priests has gone from about 700 per priest in 1955 to almost 1,000 today. Pressures both overt _ not allowing full pensions before age 75 _ and subtle, such as ``pep talks'' from the bishop, are exerted on diocesan priests to keep them in the pulpit. ``We have never followed a retirement age as we have traditionally in civil society,'' said the Rev. Roland Faley, executive director of the Conference of Major Superiors of Men. ``Most of the people that I know would want to continue working as long as they're able.'' Both Brinkmoeller and Fahey said that while there is no hard data, dioceses seem to be pushing back retirement ages. In a recent survey conducted by the Third Age Center of 156 dioceses, only two reported a mandatory retirement age of 65. Twenty-four dioceses set their retirement age at 70, while 114 reported a mandatory retirement age of 75. Stanton, who at 66 runs a large parish and a parochial school, said the 75 retirement age is unreasonable. In the Diocese of Buffalo, more than 85 percent of 283 priests surveyed said they wanted a lower retirement age than the current one of 75, with the majority favoring a retirement age below 70. Throughout the nation, Fahey said, ``there is a bit of a collision course between the expectancies of priests and the needs of the diocese.'' The tension will increase, Fahey said, with the aging of priests who were ordained after Vatican II and share more of the dominant cultural perspective that one should expect an earned leisure period in the final stage of life. Even with early retirement, most ordained men and women likely would still help out in lesser roles, church officials said.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 26, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Multimillionaire Turns Soviet Base Into Clothing Factory
DOC.TEXT: Harold Willens, a businessman-peacenik, has turned a military base in his native Soviet Union into a children's clothing factory. There will be no money profits, but Willens, 75, expects a return. ``I see this not as a gift or charity but as a sound investment in the protection of everything I've talked about,'' he said. ``Having hostility between two nuclear powers is a clear and present danger to my six grandchildren.'' Willens, a multimillionaire who made his fortune in real estate, said he's sunk about $400,000 into the project. By early July, he said, the factory was operating at 75 percent capacity, turning out 100,000 pieces of clothing a month. ``The clothes are all beautifully made and very affordable,'' he said, but he didn't have exact prices. The plant _ formerly the Kingisepp army base housing 6,000 soldiers _ is one of the first private enterprises designed to move the Soviet Union away from weapons buildup and toward economic independence. Joining Willens in the venture are Soviet actress Sophia Lansky, who is project director and interpreter, and entrepreneur Ilya Baskin of the Garant Cooperative in Leningrad. The base, about 60 miles southwest of Leningrad, officially was deeded to the cooperative last year. Activism has long been part of Willens' life. The Don Quixote of the Dom Perignon set co-founded Business Executives Move for Vietnam Peace in 1967. Two years later, he was national chairman for the Businessmen's Education Fund, a group concerned about growing military spending and foreign policy. He was an adviser to President Carter, and in 1978 was a member of the U.S. delegation to the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament. He also founded the Center for Defense Information in Washington, D.C., and co-founded the Interfaith Center to Reverse the Arms Race. In 1982, he was state chairman for the California Bilateral Nuclear Weapons Freeze Initiative. And he wrote ``The Trimtab Factor: How Business Executives Can Help Solve the Nuclear Weapons Crisis'' in 1984. Willens is known at the University of California, Los Angeles as ``someone who has been very active for years in arms control, disarmament, peace and bettering U.S.-Soviet relations,'' said Andrew Korbonski, professor of political science and head of UCLA's Center for Russian and East European Studies. On his latest project, Willens said, he's met with some stodgy resistance. ``On our side, resistance came from experts, including the Rand Corporation. There was a combination of skepticism and an accusation of naivete _ a question of `How can this nutty guy believe that this thing can be helpful?''' George Regas, who co-founded the Interfaith Center to Reverse the Arms Race, told the Los Angeles Times in 1982 that Willens was ``the most tenacious man I have ever met.'' Willens was ``more than twice my age but has three times my energy,'' Regas said. ``It stuns me. He'll call you at seven in the morning and again at 11 the same night. It's as if the guy never stops thinking about the issue.'' The barracks-to-baby clothes-venture began in 1988 with an open letter in a Soviet newspaper in which Willens offered U.S. consulting gurus, free of charge, to struggling Russian businesses. He got several thousand responses. Meetings, letters and telephone conversations followed as he played matchmaker between U.S. experts and Soviet entrepreneurs. Soviet news media reported the bridging of communist and capitalist ideals, and in the influential Soviety weekly Arguments and Facts, Raisa Gorbachev sent the Americans ``warmest wishes.'' In March 1989, the soldiers were kicked off the base and the capitalists moved in. Willens was 8 when his family left the Soviet Union in the aftermath of the Bolshevik Revolution. Right after high school, Willens worked as a grocery box boy 10 hours a day, six days a week, for $10. His family of four lived on that income. These days, he can relax after breakfast at the posh Bel-Air Summit Hotel. With all that's filled his life, one of the most satisfying aspects is his relationship with his wife, he said in an interview at the hotel. Their 55th wedding anniversary is Nov. 30. They have three children. ``I've been lucky enough to meet the perfect partner in my life, my wife, Grace,'' he said. ``That fabulous type of relationship puts into life a flavor all too rare these days. I've been lucky enough to be fulfilled.'' Mrs. Willens has said that teamwork has made some of her husband's visions reality. ``I've always supported whatever he initiated. There'll be a discussion between us. He'll say, `You can be a big help to me.' Boom, boom, boom and I'll do it,'' she told the Times. ``Could he have done it without me? I think it takes a team to do most anything. It's just too bad more (married) teams don't have this experience.'' Willens said he'd like to be 50 again. ``Having learned so much, it would be fun to do this again with the additional knowledge I had gained,'' he said. But he is happy to share what he knows with his grandchildren. Heather, a freshman at Stanford University, asked his help on a project about the Soviet Union. Sara, 15, asked for his advice with Shakespeare. ``You can see they realize Grace and I have a wealth of experience. My advice therefore is for them to do what they're now doing, remembering that their grandparents love them immensely,'' Willens said. ``It's sheer ecstasy that they can turn to our experience.'' And what does he think of his status as one of the not-so-young anti-nukesters? ``I'm a good example of what a person can do. I've done well, now I'll do good. I'm a citizen as opposed to a resident. A citizen, of course, is someone who cares about the country.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 26, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Cookbook Author Simone Beck Turns 86, New Book on the Way
DOC.TEXT: Diets and retirement are anathema to Simone Beck, master cook and teacher, co-author with Julia Child of ``Mastering the Art of French Cooking.'' With her 86th birthday just past, she's looking forward to publication of her fifth book next spring. It will be an intimate autobiography, as well as a cookbook. ``Cooking can't keep you young, but it can surely help keep fit,'' said Beck, sitting on the sunny terrace of her Provencal farmhouse between Cannes and Grasse. ``Crash diets can do you little but harm.'' It has been 32 years since Beck, Child and Louisette Bertholle published what became the first volume of ``Mastering the Art,'' the bible of French cuisine for Americans yearning to learn the secrets of sauces like bechamel, Bordelaise or Hollandaise. A second volume by Beck and Child followed, with equal success, while Bertholle branched off to write her own cookbooks. Eventually, all three were doing their own thing. After ``Mastering the Art,'' Beck wrote ``Simca's Cuisine'' in 1972 (her friends call her Simca) and ``New Recipes'' in 1979. Although a celebrity in American culinary circles and mentor to a couple of generations of American cooks, Beck is relatively unknown in France. ``I hope my main statement in life _ my memoirs and new recipes _ will take off when published by Viking next spring,'' said Beck. ``It doesn't have a title yet, but it tells all,'' she said with a wink, ``including a bit about my love life. Also my tricks in cooking, well known to my pupils. But I have new ones up the old sleeve.'' Her new book was inspired by Child's encouragement, Beck said. When Beck's husband, Jean Fischbacher, died in 1986, Child and her husband, Paul, who have owned a house on Beck's property since the 1960s, came over to give moral support. Child was fascinated by Beck's life, particularly some hair-raising adventures during World War II, and persuaded her to write it down. ``It's all in the book, including how I met Julia at a cocktail party when I was looking for an American collaborator for a book of French recipes,'' Beck said. ```Mastering' was an epic effort, a labor of love,'' 10 years in which Beck, Bertholle and Child hashed over French techniques for a trans-Atlantic audience. Writing her life story was another challenge. It recalls her privileged childhood in Normandy, two marriages and her professional life, weaving traditional and new menus and recipes into the narrative. ``I'd learned food basics in Normandy with the family cook, Zulma,'' Beck said. ``But when I was a young bride in Paris, I took up bookbinding.'' She won a prize, and looked around for something more interesting. After she stumbled onto the Cordon Bleu school while driving around Paris in the 1930s, she lured the top teacher, Henri Pellaprat, home to help her prepare fancy dinner parties, jotting down his tips. But she didn't start teaching herself until well after World War II. ``During the war, I'd spent much of the time bicycling around Normandy, bargaining with farmers to get food to send to my second husband, who was in a German prison camp,'' she said. After the war, Beck became involved in cooking and teaching at l'Ecole des Trois Gourmandes, founded by the co-authors of ``Mastering.'' Later, Beck taught cooking on her own, giving lessons in her Paris flat, at her guest house in southern France and on world demonstration tours. Today, she teaches less, but likes to philosophize on food. ``Don't talk to me about nouvelle cuisine,'' she said. ``It made food attractive-looking for anorexics, but that's about all. And I never could stand eating raw fish, an abomination.'' And she appreciates her audience in the United States. ``I always preferred to write for Americans,'' Beck said. ``French people think they already know everything about cooking.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 26, and thereafter
DOC.BYLINE: Advertisers Catching on as Baby Boomers Mature? ^By KARIN MILLER
DOC.TEXT: That Americans are aging should have marketers racing to attract a huge maturing generation, but they're slow to catch on, an author said. ``You've got young creators and they're working from their own value systems,'' said David Wolfe who wrote ``Serving the Ageless Market: Strategies for Selling to the Fifty-Plus Market.'' ``They have a sympathetic understanding of older people, but not an empathetic understanding,'' he said. He cited Buick as a company trying to attract an older market, with its 1991 Park Avenue, showcased recently in Nashville at the National Association for Senior Living Industries exposition. Seniors gave the car's flat, plush seats a thumbs-up over bucket seats, and the car also features safety features such as air bags and has easy-to-use door handles. John Dabels, general director of divisional marketing for Buick, said the car was redesigned after test-marketing showed older consumers wanted different accessories. One complaint was: ``I don't want a cockpit. I want an easy-to-read instrument panel,'' Dabels said. So the company designed a panel that wraps around to the driver's door and has larger, more easily distinguishable control buttons. Senior citizens ``want to buy an experience, not a product,'' Dabels said. Wolfe agreed. ``The gateway to experience is the No. 1 principle of marketing to older people. They do not buy products for services. They buy the consequential experience that purchase will make possible.'' Wolfe, who founded the National Association for Senior Living Industries five years ago, said marketers are having a difficult time with that idea. ``This is what's driving marketers nuts,'' he said. ``Older people don't buy in such a way that they can be arranged in groups.'' Wolfe said the Infiniti car advertisements, which never showed the product, had the right idea in showing the experience, but they didn't follow through and grab the consumer. On the other hand, the McDonald's commercial that featured an older man returning to the restaurant for a job he held as a young man unexpectedly increased patronage by older people. ``They understand us,'' was the reaction of older consumers, who were actually being targeted to work for the fast food company, Wolfe said. The median age in this country is 33. By the end of the decade it will be 39, Wolfe said. ``What we have is an aging society that is moving toward agelessness. It is a worldwide movement. We need to understand it to better be able to capitalize on it,'' he said. The term agelessness means that as a person grows older age loses significance in terms of influencing behavior, Wolfe said. ``And what we're concerned with in marketing is human behavior,'' he said. ``... It is the stages of life that we really need to focus on, not the ages of life.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 26, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Dad, Son Attend Senior Day Care Program
DOC.TEXT: It had been about 70 years since William J. Lockerman's son has asked him to take him to a magic show or concert. But he gave in when his son insisted they go to the same adult day care program. ``I don't like to change places often,'' said Lockerman, 95. But once he got out of the house and joined his son, he was glad and they've been going to the Queen Anne's County program daily for more than a month. ``Being an only child, he always spoiled me a bit,'' said William L. Lockerman, 77, who added that his father still tells him what to do. The Lockermans are the first father and son to attend the program, said Michele Mitchell, a nurse who accompanied the senior citizens to a magic show recently. In addition to attending shows and concerts on Fridays, the two men go on all the day trips, Mitchell said. They recently spent the day at an auction and took a boat ride on the Miles River. At the center, the Lockermans like to coach pool and play dominoes. Both were farm workers. The senior Lockerman retired at age 90, and his son at 75.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 26, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Reverse Mortgages Can Be Avenue to Financial Relief
DOC.TEXT: The scene is common _ older people sitting in their equity-rich homes struggling to pay the monthly bills. For many, a reverse mortgage, also known as a home equity conversion, may provide relief. Generally, reverse mortgages are available to individuals 62 or older who owe nothing, or very little, on their homes. A homeowner entering into a reverse mortgage receives monthly payments from the lender based on several factors, including the type of mortgage selected, age and life expectancy, the value of the house, the predicted value of the house at the end of the loan, the interest rate, and the amount of equity available. Upon death or sale of the home, the loan is repaid. Currently, there are three basic options from which to choose when selecting a reverse mortgage: term, tenure, or line of credit. Under the conditions of a term loan, borrowers receive monthly payments for a fixed number of years. Although the loan does not have to be repaid until the house is sold or the borrower dies, interest accrues on the amount received. Since term loans expire after a stated number of years, the monthly payments received by the borrower usually are larger compared with the other options. Term loans generally are best for those who actually plan to move at the end of the term, thus avoiding additional interest charges. Borrowers who choose a tenure mortgage receive monthly payments for as long as they live in the home, and, like a term loan, repayment is not due until the borrower dies or the house is sold. However, since the exact duration of the loan cannot be determined, payments normally are less than those paid under a term loan agreement. A line of credit loan allows an individual to borrow against a line of credit, as needed. The lump-sum amount available is based on the aforementioned factors, and, once again, need not be rapaid until the borrower dies or the house is sold. In conjunction with any of these loan alternatives, borrowers may pledge all or a portion of the appreciation on the house to a lender, increasing the amount of the monthly payments or the line of credit. Upon death or sale of the house, the borrower (or the borrower's estate) will be responsible for the repayment of the principal, interest and the agreed upon portion of appreciation. As with any financing arrangement, there are advantages and disadvantages associated with a reverse mortgage. Since a reverse mortgage is nothing more than a loan, the proceeds are received tax-free. The loans usually are non-recourse, meaning the borrower never will be liable for more than the value of the house. The biggest advantage, though, for many borrowers is the ability to continue living in a house and neighborhood that have become familiar, while at the same time using the house to increase the quality of life or peace of mind. As for the downside, many people do not want to deplete what generally is their single most important asset; they have worked long and hard to pay off the mortgage and collect the deed from the bank. They also may want, or feel it is their duty, to leave the house to their heirs. Moreover, a premature sale of a house due to unforeseen circumstances by individuals involved in a shared appreciation reverse mortgage may cause them to end up both house poor and cash poor. Borrowers still are liable for property tax and insurance costs associated with the house. Lastly, because most reverse mortgages are non-recourse loans, lenders are reluctant to offer them. In response to this reluctance, however, the Federal Housing Administration is sponsoring a pilot program that if successful, could lead to more lenders willing to offer reverse mortgages.
Rebecca Godkin is an academic in the tax planning division of the College for Financial Planning.

Interest on fixed-rate home mortgages dipped below 10 percent this week for the first time in six months, raising hopes that the sluggish real estate market may pick up slightly. The fixed rate for 30-year mortgages averaged 9.99 percent this week, down from 10.11 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., which indirectly finances about one in eight American home purchases, said Friday. The rate was the lowest since fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.90 percent during the week ending Jan. 19.

A bomb blew a hole in the London Stock Exchange but no one was injured and trading hummed along without interruption on computers. A telephone caller earlier had warned of an IRA bomb. Authorities rushed to the exchange Friday and evacuated scores of traders and other employees minutes before the market was to open to hundreds of visitors. The stock exchange index was up for the day, but options trading was suspended until Monday.

A federal judge highly critical of the Manville trust fund was granted broad powers that could ensure his ability to overhaul the system for paying asbestos victims. In an Friday order by the chief judge of federal courts in southern New York, U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein received the power to rule on any bankruptcy court appeal involving Manville Corp.'s 1988 reorganization or the trust. The future of the $3 billion trust, created as part of Manville's court reorganization, has been up in the air since it disclosed it had run out of money to pay 130,000 pending claims and any new ones.

Chrysler Corp. proposed a multi-employer health-care system as it joined the rest of the Big Three automakers in contract negotiations with the United Auto Workers union. But the proposal Friday drew a cool reception from General Motors Corp., which opened negotiations with the UAW on Wednesday, and Ford Motor Co., which began contract talks Thursday. The UAW offered no reaction Friday.

American Brands Inc., moving to take advantage of the lucrative home remodeling market, said it would buy The Moen Group, a plumbing fixture manufacturer, for $975 million in cash. The deal was announced Friday. American Brands is a conglomerate of liquor, office products, tobacco and life insurance businesses. MasterBrand Industries includes Master Lock, makers of doorsets; Aristokraft, a manufacturer of kitchen cabinets and bathroom vanities; and Twentieth Century, a plumbing supply company.

John O'Brien, who resigned suddenly as head of the Grumman Corp., is under investigation by a federal grand jury for possibly accepting loans from a Grumman defense subcontractor, a source said. A grand jury at U.S. District Court in Uniondale has been hearing testimony for about a year, the source told The Associated Press Friday. The case stems from a broader investigation by the U.S. Justice Department into wrongdoing in defense contracting.

The Boeing Co., which has never been content with its de Havilland commuter aircraft division, said it is discussing selling the Canadian operation to Aeritalia of Italy and Aerospatiale of France. Boeing Canada's de Havilland Division, based in Downsview, Ontario, builds the Dash 8-series turboprop commuter plane. Boeing bought de Havilland from the Canadian government in 1986. The plan was announced Friday.

State regulators approved a $2.3 billion takeover plan and a new rate structure for Public Service Company of New Hampshire, paving the way for the utility to emerge from bankruptcy. The Public Utilities Commission's 200-page report released Friday found Connecticut-based Northeast Utilities' acquisition ``consistent with the public good.'' The reorganization plan's rate agreement projects seven annual rate increases of 5.5 percent beginning in 1990.

Federal regulators accused four West Germans and three European entities of trading in the securities of Contel Corp. with inside information about a pending $6 billion merger with GTE Corp. The seven were identified in court papers filed Friday in New York, one week after the original charges were brought against ``individuals or entities whose identities are as yet unknown.'' The identities of some defendants remained unknown, said the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.

New disappointments in high-technology profits helped send stock prices into a sharp decline Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chips fell 32.67 to 2,961.14, finishing the week with a net loss of 19.06 points. The dollar ended slightly lower against every major currency but the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar. Bond prices rose slightly. Soybean futures prices fell sharply; corn and wheat futures closed lower; oats were narrowly mixed; petroleum futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; copper futures rose; and precious metals slipped.

DOC.HEAD: New Book Asks: Why Can't a Woman Be More Like a Woman?
LaserPhoto WX6 of July 22
DOC.TEXT: Sally Helgesen has some advice for the women of corporate America: be yourselves. In a new book that follows four top female executives through their workday, Helgesen argues that women shouldn't scrap the values they were raised with to try and think and act like men in the workplace. For more than a decade, thousands of aspiring women executives in tailored pinstripes and floppy bowties have been told they need to act more like men in the corporate jungle. So they took up golf, learned to like _ or at least understand _ football and surpressed their emotions. And just like their male counterparts, they have sacrificed their personal lives. Instead they should focus on ``the values that women recognize as a source of their strength _ values that for too long have been dismissed as signs of weakness,'' Helgesen states in ``The Female Advantage: Women's Ways of Leadership.'' Those values include listening, teaching, favoring cooperation with colleagues over competition, encouraging subordinates rather than dominating them. At a time when a Fortune magazine cover story wonders ``Why Women Still Aren't Getting to the Top?'' Helgesen's book looks at ``women's skills, talents and values as a plus that can add to companies and organizations,'' she said during a recent interview in Washington. The book takes a close look at the work day of four women: the national executive director of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America, in New York; the president of a Denver, Colo.-based industrial contracting company; the chief of Ford Motor Co.'s executive development center in Detroit and the head of a Baltimore-based broadcasting company that owns three radio stations. Influenced by a 1973 landmark study by organization expert Henry Mintzberg, who followed five male executives through their day, Helgesen observed the work habits of four women who already hold senior positions, writing down everything that happened to them from opening mail in the morning to meetings and phone calls into the evening. In contrast to the traditional corporate leaders, ``men of vision'' who impose that vision from the top down, Helgesen's four women have found what she terms ``a distinctive voice'' for ``stressing empowerment and human development rather than subordination to the chain of command.'' These women make time in their schedules to reflect, read or simply rest. They make time for their families and expect their staff to do likewise. They encourage creativity and downplay hierarchy through structures that resemble a circle or web rather than a pyramid, said Helgesen. They also pay attention to details and see the morning mail as an opportunity to connect with clients and colleagues _ not a distraction. Two even have in-house rules that all correspondence must be answered within three days. One of the executives, Ford's Nancy Badore told Helgesen that ``Most women don't realize that they're good at their jobs until about five or ten years after men do.'' ``What I would like `The Female Advantage' to do is cut that time from 10 years to two. Then I'd really feel like I made a contribution,'' said Helgesen. But she said the book is not meant as an attack on the way men manage. ``One of the things I believe is that women have benefitted tremendously over the last 20 years by really studying how men do things,'' said Helgesen, 42, a free-lance writer living in New York's Greenwich Village, who was drawn to business topics after writing a book about Texas oilmen. ``We've been reading books about strategic thinking and assertiveness training and learning all these skills that a lot of us were not really raised to have,'' she said. But the old-fashioned, male dominated, power-oriented corporate hierarchy is on its way out, she believes, forced to change by global competition, changing technology and an ever-increasing female workforce. In its place, kinder, gentler corporate structures are evolving where innovation is encouraged and winning the corner office at all costs is not as important as being a well-rounded person who is fulfilled on and off the job. As an example of this, Helgesen points to John F. Welch Jr. president of General Electric Co., who goes home at 6 p.m. every night and encourages his staff to follow his example. ``Part of what he has said is important to GE is people who are able to spend time with their families and be rounded, whole people. And when you get someone like the president of GE talking like that, you know you've got tremendous change in values,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Forecasts 7.6 Percent Communications Spending Growth Thru 1994
DOC.TEXT: Media spending will grow at a 7.6 percent yearly rate to $461.3 billion by 1994, exceeding growth in the economy but slowing from its 8.9 percent pace of the past five years, according to a new study. The report from the investment banking firm Veronis Suhler & Associates, which specializes in media deals, covers spending on media ranging from radio and TV to newspapers, books, magazines, music and the movies. In its fourth annual industry forecast released Sunday, the firm said communications industry spending would grow faster than the economy from 1990-94. The firm expects the economy to grow 7.2 percent including inflation for each of the next five years, up from 6.9 percent in the past five. But it said communications spending will expand more slowly in the next five years than in the past five because of ``maturation of the technology-driven industries of the 1980s'' such as home video, cable TV, compact disc recordings and business information. Broadcasting spending is expected to grow at a 7.1 percent compounded annual rate to $46.2 billion by 1994, up from 5.8 percent for 1984-89. Network TV advertising spending, which rose at a slim 2.2 percent annual rate over the past five years as audiences fled to cable and independent TV and other pursuits, will grow at a 6.6 percent annual pace through 1994, the report said. Spending growth at local TV stations will slow to 6.9 percent a year from 7.5 percent in each of the past five years, the report said. It said total TV spending will grow at a 6.8 percent rate to $33.9 billion in 1994, up from 5.8 percent annual growth in the past five years. Spending growth in radio will rise to 8.0 percent a year to $12.3 billion by 1994, the report said. It had grown at a 7.6 percent rate in the past five years. The forecast for cable TV called for an 8 percent annual growth rate to $19.5 billion in 1994, down from more heady 12 percent annual growth in the past five years. Newspaper spending is expected to rise at a 6.7 percent annual rate over the next five years, up from 6.3 percent a year in the past five, and reach $61.8 billion in 1994. Annual growth at weekly newspapers is expected to outpace growth at dailies, 7.9 percent to 6.6 percent. The report said growth in magazine spending will hold steady at 7.2 percent annual rate in the next five years, the same as the past five, and reach $24.1 billion in 1994. Growth at consumer magazines will slow to 7.5 percent a year from 8.0 percent, the report said, while growth at business magazines is expected to accelerate to 5.7 percent from 3.9 percent. The report offered these estimates of annual spending growth in other communications industry segments for the next five years: _8.2 percent for filmed entertainment, down from 17.0 percent annual growth in the past five years, and reaching $35.2 billion in 1994. _5.3 percent for recorded music, down from 8.1 percent, and reaching $8.4 billion in 1994. _8.3 percent for book publishing, down from 9.2 percent, and reaching $26.9 billion in 1994. _8.6 percent for business information services, down from 11.4 percent, and reaching $32.2 billion in 1994. _8 percent for promotion, down from 9.4 percent, and reaching $144.0 billion in 1994. _7.3 percent in direct-mail, Yellow Pages and misellaneouys other forms of advertising, down from 8.5 percent, and reaching $62.9 billion in 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Threats Cast Shadow Over OPEC Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Against a backdrop of Iraqi threats to punish cheaters, OPEC ministers meet this week to work out a strategy for restraining output and pushing up oil prices. ``The atmosphere will be very heavy,'' said Pierre Terzian, editor of the oil publication Petrostrategies, based in Paris. Paul Mlotok, head of energy research at the Morgan Stanley investment firm in New York, said: ``There is definitely concern within OPEC about this turn of events, with Iraq making threats.'' On Thursday, oil ministers of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries open their midyear conference to set price and production guidlines. An eight-member monitoring panel convenes a day earlier. A brief meeting had been anticipated until President Saddam Hussein of Iraq threatened last week to use force if necessary against Arab countries that surpassed their OPEC production quotas and caused prices to drop. He claimed lower prices had cost his country $14 billion in the last year. Saddam did not mention names, but he clearly meant Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, which have violated their quotas regularly. A week before Saddam complained, analysts said, Saudi Arabia and four other Persian Gulf producers proposed an arrangement under which Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates would reduce production to 1.5 million barrels a day each. They had been pumping up to 2 million barrels a day. Analysts say the cartel probably will settle on an overall ceiling of about 22.5 million barrels a day, not far from 22.1 million for the first half of the year. The International Energy Agency estimated OPEC production in June at 23.2 million barrels a day, off 400,000 from May and down nearly 700,000 barrels from April. OPEC ministers are considered likely to hold their price target steady at $18 a 42-gallon barrel, but Iran and Iraq are expected to press for a higher goal. Gholamreza Aqazadeh, Iran's oil minister, expressed hope last week that the cartel would lift its target to $20. ``It's possible that, as a sop to Iran and Iraq, they will adopt $20 immediately,'' said Lucy Mullins, analyst at the London firm of Barclays de Zoete Wedd. The OPEC meeting comes a week after the American Petroleum Institute in Washington reported a higher U.S. dependence on foreign oil. The API said the U.S. imported 49.9 percent of its oil in the first half of 1990, the highest percentage since records began in 1947. The August contract for the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, West Texas Intermediate, rose 62 cents Friday to $19.61 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It had risen 44 cents a barrel Thursday. Sadek Boussena, the Algerian minister and acting president of OPEC, urged ``unity and discipline'' among members. The cartel's news agency quoted him as saying: ``It is in the interest of everybody to cooperate in order to stabilize oil prices and enhance our revenue.'' If OPEC is able to reduce production, even slightly, analysts predict prices will rise. Terzian of Petrostrategies believes Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have begun reducing output, and Mlotok of Morgan Stanley said: ``I would expect, even with a little bit of leakage, as long as OPEC stays under 23 (million barrels a day), prices would rise.'' Prices have climbed recently, partly on the possibility of OPEC production cuts. Traders also were nervous about Iraqi saber-rattling, since the gulf region contains about two-thirds of the world's proven oil reserves. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the August contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American crude, closed at $19.61 last week. In the spring, oil prices plunged far below OPEC's target of $18, reaching $13.64 in June, then gained about $1 in July. The price had been $20.46 in late January. Analysts attributed the spring decline to excess production and weak demand by consuming nations. The oil held an emergency meeting in early May to seek ways of halting the slide. They pledged production cuts of 1.445 million barrels a day to get closer to the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels. The OPEC members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Honey Board Campaign to Help Consumers; Take Aim at Pretenders
DOC.TEXT: The nation's beekeepers have launched a logo campaign they hope will make life sweeter for consumers while stinging manufacturers who use only token amounts of honey. Last August, the National Honey Board launched the ``Bear'' Facts campaign to authorize manufacturers to use its logo _ a cuddly bear guzzling honey from a jug _ on products that have honey as the primary sweetener. Mary Humann, acting executive director of the board, said the campaign has a twofold purpose _ to help consumers identify honey-sweetened products quickly by looking for the bear symbol and to target products that use the word, honey, but only contain a minute amount or a honey substitute. Each product is tested by a panel of food scientists to make sure the board's criteria are met before the logo's use is allowed. More than 55 products _ from wine to bird food _ have added the logo to their packaging, Humann said. ``We felt that it was a strong addition to our label. Honey has a strong sweetener quality with a lot more positive impact,'' said Patrick Ferrill, a spokesman for Ralston Purina, which makes Honey Chex cereal. The campaign comes at a time when the U.S. Food and Drug Administration is researching proposed sweeping changes in food labeling. One plan would require percentage listings for each ingredient, which would give consumers a better idea of exactly what they're buying, said Chris Lecos, FDA press officer in Washington, D.C. Stuart Greenblatt, a spokesman for Keebler Co. in Elmhurst, Ill., said the honey board campaign is one of several that have cropped up recently in the food industry. ``Everybody is looking for something extra, some added value,'' he said. Keebler has five products, including Honey Grahams, that use honey as flavoring, but not as the primary sweetener, he said. Honey Grahams, which has been on the grocery store shelves for more than a dozen years, was named after honey primarily to promote its flavor. Gary Evans, president of Sioux Honey Association in Sioux City, Iowa, which makes Sue Bee honey products, said apiarists are worried by the trend toward capitalizing on honey's reputation without using substantial amounts of the sweet, gooey substance. ``That's why, with the National Honey Board's help, we can kind of police the industry,'' he said. ``Honey is getting to be very popular. I think some of them are taking advantage of the word honey.'' Ferrill said he didn't know if the logo had gained recognition among consumers yet, but ``we hope it'll improve the competitive edge of our product and that's why we go to the trouble of putting it on our product.'' The National Honey Board was authorized by Congress and established by the Agriculture Department in 1986 to promote honey and honey research. Beekeepers pay 1 cent per pound of honey to fund the board.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Bailout May Run Out of Money Just As It Hits Stride
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is running out of cash for savings and loan bailouts with the job less than half finished. The administration panel that oversees the bailout, the Resolution Trust Corp., has gained widespread praise for stepping up its activities, but just as it is hitting its stride a cash crunch threatens to slow progress to a limp. Analysts fear that a slowdown in the cleanup could just make the S&L mess worse, allowing struggling S&Ls to continue to pile up losses. The bulk of the S&L cleanup lies ahead. Some 250 failed institutions remain in government control, and at least another 250 failures are expected. But Peter Monroe, president of the administration panel controlling the RTC's policy and financing, said the agency will have only $7 billion in borrowing authority left after Sept. 30. That, plus the proceeds from any S&L asset sales it manages, will be all that's available to spend unless Congress comes to the rescue. Congress authorized $50 billion last August and may have to come up with another $50 billion for fiscal year 1991 beginning Oct. 1. The issue is at the center of budget negotiations between the White House and congressional leaders. ``Nobody should conclude that the major portion of the problem has been dealt with. It hasn't,'' economist James Barth of Auburn University said. The RTC announced ambitious plans last week to close or sell 77 failed thrifts in the July-September quarter, including some of the largest now in government hands. Among them: City Savings Bank, Bedminster, N.J.; Empire of America, Buffalo, N.Y.; and Merabank, Phoenix, Ariz. That will follow ``Operation Clean Sweep'' during which 155 institutions were closed or sold from April through June. In the roughly 210 institutions dealt with so far, the trust corporation has had to keep about half of the institutions' assets. It will take a major sales job to unload the sour loans, real estate and junk bonds now in the government's hands. ``Most of the assets have been put on the books of the RTC, not disposed of. ... And there are hundreds more institutions they have to deal with,'' Barth said. Election-year politics is complicating the administration's effort to get the money needed to finish the job. It was difficult for many legislators to vote for $50 billion for the bailout last August, with midterm congressional elections more than a year away. Now, with the S&L mess the focus of many congressional races, more lawmakers will find it impossible to, at least in the public's perception, throw good money after bad. Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va., fears Congress may wait until a lame duck session after the election to approve a budget deal, delaying new S&L money until December. ``We could get into a stop-start mode and that would be really unfortunate,'' he said. ``We have picked up the pace, but we need to maintain that pace for at least two years if the administration is to declare by the summer of 1992 that it has cleaned up the mess.'' Economist Martin Regalia of the National Council of Savings Institutions, a trade group, said regulators may be tempted to use a recently announced shift in bailout strategy _ finding acquirers for failed thrifts before they are seized _ as an excuse to leave insolvent thrifts open. That, he said, would be a return to the bad old days when the Federal Home Loan Bank Board left hundreds of failed thrifts open and piling up losses because the board didn't have the money to shut them down. ``We're hearing now that the way to deal with institutions is to somehow prop them up until bidders come along,'' Regalia said. ``But that's not good for taxpayers and that's not good for healthy thrifts. ... I think the quicker we address this problem, the better off everyone is.''

DOC.HEAD: Companies Say People Most Important For Productivity, But Put Money Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Most manufacturers contacted in a survey say improving their work force is most important for enhancing productivity, but many continue to put their money elsewhere. In the survey by the accounting and consulting firm Grant Thornton, 69 percent of the 250 manufacturing companies cited productivity as a problem. About 12 percent called productivity a ``major'' concern. For 54 percent of those admitting to a productivity lag, managers said people are the problem. Yet nearly four out of 10 manufacturers surveyed, or 38 percent, cited investment in new plant or equipment as the single most important step their companies have taken in the past three years to increase productivity. In contrast, only 24 percent said investing in their workers was their No. 1 answer to the productivity problem. Only 6 percent mentioned pay incentives as a way to increase worker output. While most manufacturers already have incentive plans, ``many of these programs offer room for improvement, particularly as they affect production workers,'' said Michael N. Cantwell, chairman of Grant Thornton's National Manufacturing Industry Committee. The telephone survey of mid-sized manufacturers was conducted for Grant Thornton in February. The margin of error was plus or minus 6 percentage points, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Tumble in Tokyo, Dollar Inches Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices tumbled today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, and the dollar inched up against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 526.73 points, or 1.62 percent, to 31,894.79. The index lost 634.10 points on Friday. Volume on the first section was estimated at 300 million shares, down from Friday's 500 million shares. In bond dealings, the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond stood at 85.77 points as of 5:00 p.m. here, down from Friday's close of 86.14 points. The yield was 7.465 percent, up from 7.385 percent. The dollar closed at 148.50 yen, up 0.15 yen from Friday's finish of 148.35 yen. It opened at 148.56, the day's high, and fluctuated in a narrow 148.10-148.56 yen range. Spot transactions totaled a thin $8.021 billion, down from Friday's $8.487 billion. Currency dealers said the dollar remained almost unchanged against the yen as the market took a wait-and-see attitude, anticipating a slide in the dollar after its rebound Friday. The dollar was lower in the morning but advanced in the afternoon session. Investors flocked to the dollar after the Nikkei index shed nearly 600 points at one point, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. ``Due to a lack of fresh market news, however, there's no sign for any big movements (of the dollar),'' Ms. Takeuchi said. Currency dealers were expecting a further drop in the dollar's value because preliminary figures for second-quarter U.S. economic growth, to be released Friday, were expected to show a decline, said Chiyuki Watanabe of Sanwa Bank. On the stock market, traders said today's decline reflected a carryover from Friday's sharp drop. In addition, investors were unwilling to make any big moves with the Japanese government bond showing weakness. Arbitrage-related selling, in which professional traders attempt to profit from slight differences between prices of stocks and futures indexes based on stocks, also depressed prices, market watchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Higher
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede to make it better than expected sted improved trade deficit. Picks up 2nd graf, Dealers said ...
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were higher at midday Monday, rallying from an early decline on the heels of a strong futures market and aided by release of better than expected trade figures for June. Dealers said the September Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index futures contract was driving the cash market higher as it opened up a 75-point premium over equities. Normally the premium is about 45 points, dealers said. The United Kingdom balance of payments data released Monday morning were slightly better than expected, adding to the rally. The current account showed a June deficit of 1.36 billion pounds, or $2.46 billion, compared with a deficit of 1.3 billion pounds, or $2.35 billion, in May and a deficit of 1.73 billion pounds, or $3.13 billion, a year earlier. Many analysts had expected the June deficit would have been 1.4 billion pounds, or $2.5 billion. At midday, the broad-based FT-SE 100-share index was up 4.1 points, or 0.17 percent, at 2,404.2. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index was up 2.5 points, or 0.13 percent, at 1,900.6. Volume at midday was 1.439 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: UAW, Big Three Get Down to Labor Talks
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union and the nation's Big Three automakers have given few clues about how labor negotiations will progress during the next eight weeks. The UAW opened talks with General Motors Corp. on Wednesday, with Ford Motor Co. on Thursday and with Chrysler Corp. on Friday. The contracts expire Sept. 14. There were no surprises in the three opening days of bargaining, and there aren't likely to be any in the next few weeks. Beginning today, negotiating committees break up into subcommittees focusing on specific areas, including job security, overtime and health-care benefits and costs. At news conferences after the opening day of talks at each of the automakers, union and management officials spoke mostly about general concepts, except for Chrysler chief negotiator Anthony St. John. Chrysler, the company which could be hurt the most in this round of talks, said it proposed setting up a multi-employer health-care trust. Like the other automakers, Chrysler has said it will be seeking relief from the soaring costs of health care for its active and retired employees. But unlike the others so far in the talks, Chrysler outlined a method designed to do that. And Chrysler isn't limiting membership in the plan to the automakers. St. John said Chrysler would consider hooking up with all sorts of industries in the health plan. With a larger group, the plan would have more clout with insurers and costs could be driven down. He also said formation of such a trust would get around a change in accounting rules in 1993. St. John said the change, which would require employers to set aside money in benefit programs instead of paying as they go, could add $7 an hour to its labor costs. So far, GM and Ford have been cool to the idea. Chrysler and Wall Street analysts said Chrysler's second-quarter earnings should be about half of last year's $341 million. The company is expected to lose a considerable amount of money in the third quarter when two of its most profitable plants close for retooling. Shrinking profits, car and truck sales running 13 percent behind last year's pace at the end of last month and the company's health-care costs, which ran at a $684 million annual rate last year, spell financial trouble for Chrysler. GM says it spent about $3 billion last year in health-care costs and Ford said it shelled out about $781 million last year. The union has acknowledged that health-care costs are huge. It has used that as a lever in its efforts to pry loose support for a move to a national health-care plan. For that, the union and its supporters must negotiate with Congress. For now, the UAW's focus is at the three automakers. The union is bargaining for somewhere around half a million active and laid off employees. Nearly that many retirees also are counting on the union to secure a boost to their pensions, which they say have been chewed up by inflation. In the past, UAW contracts have set the model for other heavy industries in the United States, but that's changed. Union membership in the United States generally has declined _ the UAW has shrunk by about a third to a million members _ and Japanese competition has increased in nearly all manufacturing _ especially in the steel and auto industries. There has been speculation that Chrysler will bolt from the tradition the UAW has used of focusing on one company late in the bargaining and using that contract as a pattern for the other two. But Bieber said Friday he doesn't intend to let that happen. ``This round of bargaining is on pattern and that's where it will stay,'' he said Friday.

The stock market was broadly lower in early trading today amid sustained pressure from disappointing second-quarter earnings. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials continued its retreat from the 3,000 level, falling 22.28 points to 2,938.86 in the first half hour of trading. Volume on the Big Board came to 25.32 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 1 on the NYSE, with 258 up, 784 down and 458 unchanged. A flurry of disappointing quarterly earnings reports for the second quarter pushed the Dow lower last week, and analysts expected more bad news to hasten the decline. McDonald's had not yet opened for trading today after a poor earnings report released late Friday. Adding to the downward pressure, prices of long-term Treasury bonds fell sharply in early trading after a sharp selloff in Tokyo overnight. Also, traders said there was little incentive to buy bonds ahead of the government's monthly budget statement today, which is expected to show a deficit. The widely watched Dow average, which measure the stock price of 30 large industrial companies, last week cracked but failed to close above the 3,000-point level. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 1.29 to 196.36. The American Stock Exchange composite index was 1.71 lower at 358.74. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 32.67 to 2,961.14, finishing the week with a net loss of 19.06 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 on the NYSE, with 577 up, 904 down and 514 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 177.81 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Rises Slightly in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Monsanto Co. said Monday it had a 2 percent rise in its profit for the second quarter because of a $31 million one-time gain from the sale of some assets in a Japanese joint venture. Without the gain, its profit would have fallen 11 percent. For the quarter, which ended June 30, the chemical giant had net earnings of $247 million, or $1.90 a share, up from $241 million, or $1.77 a share, for the same period a year earlier. Earnings per share figures were adjusted for a two-for-one stock split in May. Sales in the second quarter of $2.36 billion were up 1 percent compared with $2.34 billion for the same period a year ago. The $31 million gain came from the reorganization of Monsanto's joint venture with Mitsubishi Kasei Corp. in which Monsanto and Mitsubishi each retained certain products while a new joint venture was formed to sell other products. Richard Mahoney, Monsanto's chairman and chief executive officer, said extreme weather conditions around the world hurt the company's second biggest division, agricultural products. He said sales of herbicides, such as Roundup and Lasso, dropped off in several major markets because it was either too wet to plant or too dry for weed growth. ``The weather is always a factor in our agricultural business, but no year in memory has produced such difficult conditions for our herbicides,'' Mahoney said. The company also had lower profits in its chemicals unit, the company's largest division, because of the continuing slump in the U.S. auto industry along with difficult economic conditions in Brazil and Argentina. For the first six months, Monsanto had a profit of $441 million, $3.37 a share, down 5 percent from the $463 million, or $3.39 a share, earned during the first half of 1989. Sales for the first half were $4.65 billion, up 1 percent from $4.61 billion in the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Net Loss Narrows; Sales Up 5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. on Monday reported it lost $108 million in the second quarter, an improvement from a year earlier when it had a 66 percent larger deficit. The shortfall reflected interest payments and other costs related to the record $24.53 billion leveraged buyout of the food and tobacco giant last year. RJR Nabisco's red ink in the three months ended June 30 compared with a loss of $319 million in the second 1989 quarter. The latest loss was also narrower than the $222 million-shortfall posted in this year's first quarter. Second-quarter sales grew 5 percent to $3.46 billion from $3.30 billion the year before. Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, expressed satisfaction with the company's performance. ``By any measure, RJR Nabisco had a very successful quarter,'' Gerstner said. ``Both free cash flow and operating income were up strongly. New product introductions remained at a high level in both food and tobacco operations and margins continue to improve across the board.'' Operating income expanded 34 percent to $735 million from $547 million in 1989's second quarter. RJR Nabisco had free cash flow, before proceeds from asset sales, of $637 million in the quarter. By midyear, RJR Nabisco's loss amounted to $330 million, 41 percent smaller than $558 million in the middle of 1989. Sales through two quarters of 1990 totaled $6.66 billion, up 7 percent $6.23 billion half way through 1989. New York-based RJR Nabisco is a major consumer products company. Its R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. division makes some top selling cigarette brands. Its Nabisco Brands Inc. and Planters LifeSavers Co. subsidiaries are responsible for numerous well known snacks and foods.

The stock market was sharply lower in volatile trading today, as the Dow Jones industrials average tumbled more than 100 points before regaining some lost ground. A wave of computer program selling, weak corporate earnings and concerns about broad economic factors sent stocks down at the opening bell. In the first 90 minutes of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was down 60.15 points at 2,900.99. Volume on the Big Board came to 87.09 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 8 to 1 on the NYSE, with 139 up, 1,299 down and 353 unchanged. The sharp drop in the Dow followed a week in which the key market indicator flirted with the 3,000-point level, breaking the barrier several times but failing to close above it. The Dow average fell more than 107 points before rebounding. At the same time, trading was halted for one hour in the Chicago stock-index futures markets when the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 20 points. Analysts blamed the decline on continued disappointment with second-quarter corporate earnings and on concern over larger economic issues, such as the federal budget deficit and the costly savings and loan bailout. A big selloff overnight in the Treasury bond market also help pushed down stocks. ``I think we're in the midst of a substantial and abrupt shift in psychology,'' said Eugene Peroni, technical research director at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ``There'll be more of a pessimistic attitude where some external factors will not be as routinely ignored as they have been,'' he said. McDonald's was down 3} to 31} after reporting lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings. DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Drop, Following Stock Market
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were substantially lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. An early plunge in the stock market of more than 100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average triggered active selling in the crop markets after a mostly lower opening. The loss in the stock market was later trimmed. Favorable crop weather also weighed heavily on the corn and soybean markets. A weekly Agriculture Department report due out this afternoon was expected to show continued improvement in crop conditions. Further pressure stemmed from a report in the Financial Times of London quoting a high Soviet official as saying the Soviet Union will import far less grain this year than last. Richard Feltes, director of commodities research with the Chicago-based futures brokerage Refco Inc., said bearish developments were pounding the crop markets from all sides. ``You've got supply, you've got demand, you've got fears of a weakening economy. It's a triple-hit day for agriculture,'' he said. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 3} cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.97 a bushel; corn was 2} cents to 3} cents lower with September at $2.56{ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to \ cent higher with September at $1.22 a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents to 9} cents lower with August at $5.82 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .23 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 76.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent lower to .25 cent higher with August at 87.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent lower to .30 cent higher with August at 59.87 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.2 cents lower to .28 cent higher with July at 46.15 cents a pound. Livestock futures rose on Friday; pork bellies retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Mining Posts Higher Second-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co. said Monday its profit rose 4.7 percent in the second quarter as its sales climbed 6.9 percent. The diversified manufacturing company, also known as 3M, said it earned $342 million, or $1.54 per share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $327 million, or $1.49 per share, a year earlier. Sales in the second quarter rose to $3.234 billion from $3.025 billion in 1989. For the first six months, net income rose 5.0 percent to $677 million, or $3.05 a share, compared with $645 million, or $2.92 a share, in the first half of last year. Sales for the first six months increased 5.9 percent to $6.398 billion from $6.042 billion in the year-ago period. ``Second-quarter results benefited from a pickup in our U.S. unit-volume growth and from continued productivity-improvement efforts,'' said Allen F. Jacobson, chairman and chief executive officer. The company's domestic unit volume increased about 3 percent for the quarter, including strong growth in life sciences and solid gains in the health care and traffic and personal safety businesses. 3M also reported sizable volume gains in its industrial and electronic segment, its largest which includes telecommunications systems, electronic products and specialty chemicals, Jacobson said. Outside the United States, 3M achieved double-digit unit growth for the 10th consecutive quarter, he said, although international profits declined slightly from the second quarter last year. ``This reflected the impact of economic changes in Brazil, negative currency effects and investments in new businesses,'' Jacobson said. ``The company estimates that the Brazilian situation reduced second-quarter earnings by approximately 3 cents a share. In addition, currency effects reduced earnings by about 1 cent a share,'' Jacobson said. Jacobson said he expects higher sales and earnings for 3M in the second half. ``We look for slightly stronger growth in the U.S. economy in the second half,'' Jacobson said. ``This, coupled with ongoing productivity-improvement efforts, should help U.S. results for the balance of the year. ``In addition, our international profits will benefit from continued solid volume growth, as well as from recent weakening of the U.S. dollar and improvement in our Brazilian business,'' he said,

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Climbs 21 to Total 1,022
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States increased by 21 this week to total 1,022, according to a widely-watched index released Monday. The oil toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. reported this week's increase reversed a series of declines, including a drop of 10 rigs last week. A year ago, the count was 830. Baker Hughes' rig count reflects the nuber of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. The company has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Oklahoma posted the largest increase with 11. Wyoming's count was up six, Colorado was up by five and Michigan was up one. Texas, Pennsylvania and Ohio each gained three rigs. New Mexico's rig count was down by six, Louisiana lost four rigs and North Dakota dropped one rig.
