DOC.HEAD: General Mills, Nestle Buy British Cereal Maker
DOC.TEXT: General Mills Inc. and Nestle SA on Monday announced an agreement to buy a British cereal company for about $168 million through their joint venture, Cereal Partners Worldwide. A partnership between the two companies, to be called Cereal Partners UK, has agreed to buy London-based RHM Breakfast Cereals, a division of Ranks Hovis McDougall PLC. The price was 93 million British pounds, or about $168 million at current exchange rates of about $1.81 for a British pound. The purchase has been approved by the RHM board of directors and the transaction is expected to be completed on or before Aug. 17, the companies said. The deal will include fixed assets, stock and a piece of land adjacent to one of the premises. RHM Breakfast Cereals operates the third-largest breakfast cereal business in the United Kingdom, making both branded and private-label products. Cereal Partners Worldwide was formed earlier this year by Golden Valley-based General Mills and Nestle to manage the development of a major breakfast cereal business in Europe. The European ready-to-eat cereal market, the partnership's initial area of concentration, includes $1.6 billion in annual sales and is expected to quadruple by the year 2000 to sales of $6.5 billion, the size of the U.S. market in 1989. The RHM cereal products command a more than 15 percent share of the $1 billion British breakfast cereal market.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls Sharply, Gold Jumps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with closing Euroepan figures, midday New York prices.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply Monday against other major currencies in Europe, hit by a sharp decline in a key stock market index on Wall Street. Gold prices jumped more than $6 an ounce, boosted by the drops in stock prices and the dollar. The dollar had been under pressure all day but activity was modest until the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 100 points after the first 90 minutes of trading, dealers said. The index later recovered but was still sharply lower at midday. The dollar was hit particularly hard in dealings against the Swiss franc, which is supported by firm Swiss interest rates. The dollar stabilized somewhat after a nearly hour-long burst of selling, dealers said. But they noted broader European interest in selling the U.S. currency. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8215 from $1.8140 late Friday. At midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at $1.8255. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6278 West German marks, down from 1.6410; 1.3880 Swiss francs, down from 1.4070; 5.4598 French francs, down from 5.5045; 1.8430 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8485; 1,192.00 Italian lire, down from 1,201.75, and 1.1568 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1565. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 148.50 yen, up 0.15 yen from Friday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 148.40 yen and at midday ion New York, it was quoted at 148.275 yen. Other selected dollar rates at midday in New York included: 1.6285 West German marks, 1.38725 Swiss francs, 1,192.25 Italian lire and 1.15575 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $368.15 a troy ounce from $361.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $367.75 from $361.50 late Friday. Gold rose 11 cents an ounce in Hong Kong on Monday to close at $362.28. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $4.90 a troy ounce from $4.87 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Dial Posts Second-Quarter Net Loss
DOC.TEXT: Grehyound Dial Corp. posted second-quarter earnings of $39.2 million on continuing operations, up from $35.6 million last year, but suffered an overall loss of $60.1 million due to the bankruptcy of the bus line it sold in 1987, the company reported Monday. Second-quarter revenues were $912.3 million, down from $925.5 million in the same quarter last year, the company said. Income per share from continuing operations was 97 cents, up from 92 cents. Overall, however, the company sustained a net loss of $1.54 per share for the quarter. John W. Teets, chairman, president and chief executive officer, attributed the loss to a one-time, $100 million loss provision for the bankruptcy of Greyhound Bus Lines. Greyhound Dial sold the bus line in 1987, but retained a 22.5 percent stake in the company's parent, GLI Holding, and also has other Greyhound Bus Lines holdings. Greyhound Bus Lines sought protection from creditors in U.S. Bankruptcy court in June. The action followed a March strike by bus line workers. Teets said Greyhound Dial's consumer-products division had a strong quarter, with operating income up 22 percent, paced by its Dial bar soap and Liquid Dial anti-bacterial soap. Greyhound Dial's services segment, meanwhile, recorded an 18 percent increase in operating income, led by Greyhound Exposition Services and Dobbs companies operations, Teets said. Travelers Express, a leading issuer of money orders, and Premier Cruise Lines, also posted strong second-quarter performances, he said. The transportation manufacturing division reported a sharp decline in earnings and operating income, however, due to problems with a major transit order and uncertainties in inter-city coach sales resulting from the Greyhound Bus Lines strike and bankruptcy, Teets said. The financial group, on the other hand, reported a 13 percent improvement in net income, he said. Overall, he said the outlook for the company remains positive. ``The operating results of the second quarter, coupled with an excellent first quarter, indicates the company is on target with its plans and objectives,'' Teets said. ``This performance builds on the fine results recorded in both 1988 and 1989 and demonstrated that the company is in a strong position to continue its steady growth.'' For the first six months of the year, Greyhound Dial reported revenues of $1.8 billion, up from $1.77 billion for the first half of 1989. Income from continuing operations was $56 million, compared to $50.4 million for the same period last year. However, the company reported a net loss of $43.9 million for the first half of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Fall Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell sharply on London's Stock Exchange Monday, pulled down by a big decline on Wall Street. But British stocks rebounded from their lows to steady just before the close. Most of the session was listless, as London investors found few reasons for getting involved in the market during the usually stagnant summer season. But once the New York Stock Exchange opened, and moved downward decisively, London stocks began to decline quickly. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was off by more than 100 points before regaining some of the loss. By the close of the London trading session, the Dow Jones average was off 69.80 points at 2,891.34, following Friday's 32-point decline on Wall Street. ``It came quickly and sharply and obviously sentiment has been knocked in our market. But I wouldn't say there was an awful lot of selling pressure,'' one London market maker said. Said another dealer, ``We're not strong enough to go it alone. We're at their mercy.'' The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 40.4 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at 2,359.7. The index's session low was 2,352.5 and its high was 2,406.3. The Financial Times 30-share index was off 31.0 points at 1,867.1 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 18.83 points to close at 1,272.58. Volume came to 369.8 million shares, compared with 437.6 million shares Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Manville Reports Decrease in Net Income
DOC.TEXT: Citing eroding construction-related markets, Manville Corp. on Monday reported second-quarter earnings of $52.6 million, down from $69.3 million a year ago. Shareholders also saw smaller per-share earnings during the quarter _ 41 cents, down from 55 cents during the second quarter of 1989. Manville reported net sales of $561 million for the quarter, down slighlty from the $564.5 million reported a year ago. For the first six months of 1990, the company reported net income of $77.5 million, or 58 cents per share, down from $103.7 million, or 80 cents per share, in 1989. Sales were up slightly over the first six months of last year, at $1.079 billion, compared with $1.072 billion during the earlier period. ``Our second-quarter results reflect a mixture of forces driving our company,'' said Tom Stephens, chairman, chief executive officer and president of the Denver-based building products company. ``Construction-related markets continued to erode slowly, and while demand for our coated paperboard products was strong, packaging sales were down,'' he said. ``In Brazil, our domestic markets continue to be negatively affected by the country's new economic program, but our exports from Brazil remain on targe,'' Stephens said. ``We remain confident about Manville's long-term prospects in Brazil and continue to strengthen our position in worldwide paper markets.'' Stephens said the competitive pressures in all of the company's product lines are expected to intensify during the second half of 1990. While Manville deals primarily in building products, it also makes fiberglass and industrial insulation products, paper and wood products, packaging, roofing and filtration systems and is involved in mining. Manville, which employs more than 18,000 people at 50 plants and four mines worldwide, filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in 1982 as it faced billions of dollars worth of lawsuits stemming from the company's previous asbestos-related business operations. The company emerged from Chapter 11 protection in 1988 with a plan to repay creditors and people claiming personal injury or property damage from asbestos.

DOC.HEAD: Clash Over Agriculture Postponed As Senior Officials Meet
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the European Community on Monday postponed a showdown over agricultural subsidies as senior negotiators launched a new bid to speed the progress of talks aimed at a more open global economy. But officials from Washington and Brussels made it clear that, with less than five months remaining in the talks, there are still vast differences over farm policy. U.S. Deputy Trade Representative Julius Katz said the United States would continue pressing for elimination of trade-distorting export subsidies. But Guy Legras, senior EC negotiator on agriculture, indicated the 12-nation trading bloc would stand by its defense of export assistance to help European farmers compete in world markets. Agriculture is the most contentious of the 15 sectors covered by the negotiations sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The talks were launched in Uruguay in 1986 and are scheduled to end in December with accords to reduce barriers to trade and expand rules into new areas worth an estimated $1 trillion. Negotiators from 105 countries in the talks are in Geneva for the five-day meeting of the GATT's top-level Trade Negotiations Committee to push the ambitious talks and identify the sticking points. Arthur Dunkel, director-general of GATT, higlighted textiles and services, such as banking and aviation, as two areas of impasse. Dunkel told a news conference that governments were ``playing cat and mouse'' in the negotiations by making progress in one sector conditional on their demands being met in another area. But he said there was a possible opening in talks on agriculture reform. This was after an agricultural working group meeting agreed to use a compromise proposal on farm policy as to intensify the negotiations, as agreed by world leaders at the Houston economic summit earlier this month. A statement issued by the group's chairman, Aart de Zeeuw, said negotiations on substantive work would start at the end of August. The decision averts a crisis at the Geneva meeting, but merely delays the inevitable clash. The compromise text by de Zeeuw focuses on cutting domestic farm payments and price supports, and converting all import barriers into tariffs which will be reduced. It is toughest on export subsidies and states these should be reduced more than other forms of support and protection. Legras said the EC's still was strongly opposed to the proposals on export subsidies. The EC Commission agress there should be tightening of export aids but refuses to take firm steps to reduce them. Katz insisted subsidy cuts must be a central part of any deal on farm policy. ``It is not sufficient to have treatment of export subsidies as a residual issue. The conclusion of the negotiations has to deal with export subsidies with specific commitments,'' he said. Current state assistance to farmers costs consumers and taxpayers an estimated $245 billion annually. U.S. President George Bush has warned that failure to reach a satisfactory agreement on slashing farm supports will cause the collapse of the entire Uruguay Round, risking further trade wars and protectionism. The removal of agriculture from the agenda at the TNC meeting leaves the 450 negotiators free to concentrate on other problem areas. These include trade in textiles, worth some $177 billion in 1988. Trade is currently regulated by the Multi-Fiber Arrangement, MFA, and not by GATT. Under this system import quotas are fixed in bilateral deals. Washington wants to abolish the MFA and replace it with a global quota system, with quotas negotiated on a multilateral basis and increased over a ten-year period. Critics say a completely new system would enable Washington to slip in new restrictions. There also is stalemate in efforts to set up a General Agreement on Services to help liberalize services trade, worth at least $600 billion annually. Most countries favor an accord covering all sectors. But the United States wants a narrower framework which would allow it to continue bilateral deals which benefit the U.S. aviation and shipping industry and offer some control over financial services.

DOC.HEAD: Government: Some Price Differences Narrow Between Japan and Other Countries
DOC.TEXT: Some of the sharp differences between prices in Japan and other countries have vanished, although more competition and deregulation are needed to narrow the gap further, a government report said Monday. The Economic Planning Agency's report on prices also offered little hope for change in the amounts Japanese pay for utilities such as gas and electricity. Those charges were from 10 percent to more than 100 percent higher than the prices paid by consumers in the United States and Western European countries. The report said the weakening of the yen in foreign exchange during the past year and lower yen prices in Japan had erased the price differential between Japan and its Western trading partners in international air fares, international telephone calls and exported Japanese manufactured goods. That's good news for foreign companies that complain about communications prices inflating the cost of doing business in Japan. However, they get no relief in Japanese rents and land prices, which are the world's highest. For Japanese consumers, relief is yet to come in the prices of imported goods, many foods, energy and other areas, although they do not have to worry about inflation sending prices even higher. The rise in the consumer price index has been 3 percent or less since 1982. Prices are lower than overseas in such areas as photo printing, dry cleaning and facial tissues, the report said. Dry cleaning, for example, showed New York at 105 on a price scale where Tokyo equaled 100. Hamburg was at 147, London 138 and Paris 166. Price differentials were one of many areas covered in the recent U.S.-Japan negotiations on structural barriers to trade. Japan said it would try to reduce price differentials where possible and the Economic Planning Agency report surveyed some of the recent developments in that area. It attributed some price drops in Japan to market pressures that followed the increase in the yen's value starting in 1985. That increase made prices in Japan _ already high _ even higher when quoted in U.S. dollars. But, the market mechanism ``does not work sufficiently if there are regulations that hinder competition or if there are obstacles in the distribution process,'' the report said. It said ``regulations should be relaxed and the Antimonopoly Act should be strictly implemented.'' Both measures were important U.S. demands in the trade talks, which ended in June. Yoshiro Tokunaga, director of the agency's Price Research Divison, told reporters that high utility prices were due mostly to high infrastructure costs and the need to build more power plants to cover peak electricity demands in the summer. Regarding air fares, the report said in September 1988 a traveler in the United States, Britain or France buying a ticket to Tokyo paid only 74 percent to 82 percent of the price that a ticket on the same route cost if bought in Tokyo. But early this month the traveler outside Japan was paying 109 percent to 125 percent of the Tokyo-bought fare. The report attributed the reversal to the gradual lowering of yen-based air fares under market pressure, and to the weakening of the yen, from 134 to the dollar in September 1988 to 153 in early July. The yen recently has strengthened somewhat and closed at 148.50 against the dollar on Monday. The Japanese consumer suffers from high prices on imported goods, the report said. American goods sell for 30 percent to 40 percent more in Japan than in other countries, and European goods were 30 percent to 50 percent higher than in their countries of origin and 20 percent higher than in the United States. The report blamed the difference partly on foreign companies' strategy of charging high prices because Japanese consumers want prestige brand names at almost any cost. Also responsible were costs of adapting foreign products to Japanese standards, high land and labor costs and the practice of sole import agents imposing standard prices, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Bell Atlantic's Quarterly Net Up 6.2 Percent; Contel's Net Off
DOC.TEXT: Bell Atlantic Corp. on Monday posted a 6.2 percent gain in second-quarter income as both its telephone and non-telephone business volume expanded. The regional telephone holding company said its net income came to $362.8 million, or 92 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $341.7 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose nearly 7 percent to $3.08 billion from $2.88 billion in 1989's second quarter. Separately, Contel Corp. reported that its second-quarter profit contracted about 36 percent due to costs associated with the purchase of 13 Southeastern cellular telephone systems from McCaw Cellular Communications. Contel netted $43 million, or 27 cents per share, in this year's second quarter, compared with $67 million, or 42 cents per share, in the corresponding 1989 period. Revenue rose about 12 percent to $844 million from $755 million.
DOC.HEAD: Bell Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: By midyear, Philadelphia-based Bell Atlantic earned $718.1 million, an increase of 6.8 percent over the $672.5 million earned during the first half of 1989. Earnings per share for the first half were $1.82, up from $1.71 for the same 1989 period. The per-share amounts reflect a two-for-one stock split April 10. Commenting on the quarterly results, Raymond W. Smith, Bell Atlantic chairman and chief executive officer, said: ``Revenues reflected continued growth in volumes in both our telephone and non-telephone businesses and demonstrated the continued strength and resiliency of our regional services-based economy.'' Expenses of $2.39 billion included the January purchase of Control Data Corp.'s third-party maintenance business and the June acquisition of Northern Telecom's Meridian Business Systems Group. Bell Atlantic is the parent company of Bell of Pennsylvania, New Jersey Bell, Diamond State Telephone serving Delaware, and the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Companies serving Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and the District of Columbia. The corporation is also the parent company of businesses that provide mobile communications as well as computer maintenance and financial services.
DOC.HEAD: Contel
DOC.TEXT: In the first half of 1990, Contel earned 26 percent less than it did during the first two 1989 quarters, or $97 million, down from $131 million. Per-share earnings fell to 61 cents in the first half from 82 cents a year ago. Revenue through the first two quarters of this year rose 9 percent to $1.6 billion from $1.5 billion. The latest results covered the quarter prior to the July 12 announcement that the Atlanta-based independent telephone company had agreed to merge with GTE Corp. Under the merger plan, GTE would issue 1.27 shares of its common stock for each outstanding share of Contel common stock. In a separate report, Contel subsidiary Contel Cellular Inc. said it posted a net loss of $29.3 million, or 29 cents per share, for the recent quarter, compared with net income of $1.1 million, or 1 cent per share, in the same period last year. Contel Cellular said the loss was due to financing costs and amortization of goodwill relating to the 13 systems acquired in the first quarter of 1990 from McCaw. Those costs totaled $31.6 million in the second quarter. Contel Cellular said its revenue for the second quarter were $44 million, up from $15.2 million in the same period in 1989.

The stock market was sharply lower in volatile trading today as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled more than 100 points before recovering some lost ground. About five minutes before the close, the Dow average of 30 industrial stocks was down 61.64 points at 2,899.50.

The stock market fell sharply in volatile trading today, as the Dow Jones average tumbled more than 100 points before regaining some lost ground. Waves of computerized program selling, weak corporate earnings led by McDonald's and concerns about broad economic factors sent stocks lower from the opening bell. ``There was panic without a doubt,'' said Chung Lew, head trader at Kleinwort Benson North America Inc. The sharp drop followed a week in which the key market indicator flirted with the 3,000-point level, breaking the barrier several times but failing to close above it. Analysts said that failure added to pessimism about the market's underlying strength. They blamed the broad decline on continued disappointment with second-quarter corporate earnings and on concern over larger economic issues, such as the federal budget deficit and the costly savings and loan bailout. Computerized program trading strategies whipsawed the markets, extending the morning drop and playing a role in a subsequent rebound and another drop, market participants said. The program trading activity came despite a request by the New York Stock Exchange that member firms voluntarily and temporarily restrain from the activity, which has been blamed for intensifying market volatility.

DOC.HEAD: Government Might Sell Electricity Company to Hanson
DOC.TEXT: The British government said Monday it might sell the state-owned electricity generator PowerGen to British conglomerate Hanson PLC rather than to the public. PowerGen would cost about 1 billion pounds, or $1.82 billion, analysts said. PowerGen and the larger state-owned National Power are scheduled to be privatized in February through the sale of shares on London's Stock Exchange, as part of Britain's biggest privatization yet. Energy Secretary John Wakeham said the government was holding discussions with Hanson, the only company to approach him so far. In a statement to the House of Commons, Wakeham said that if Hanson decides to make a binding offer for PowerGen, he would invite other companies to place competitive bids. Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson, confirmed his company had a ``firm interest'' in making a bid for PowerGen. Wakeham said that if a serious offer was made for National Power, he would consider its private sale as well. Hanson owns considerable coal assets, including Peabody Holding Co., the biggest coal producer in the United States. Since many PowerGen power stations are situated on the coast with port handling facilities, Hanson coal could be easily imported, analysts said. The government's willingness to consider other options ``may indicate the feedback on the enthusiasm of the privatizations hasn't been what the government might have hoped,'' said Arthur Hepher, an analyst with the investment firm Laing and Cruickshank Ltd. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government has sold off 28.3 billion pounds, or $52 billion dollars, worth of state-owned companies since 1979 to promote capitalism in Britain. The sales have been largely successful. The notable exception was the sale of the government's remaining one-third stake in British Petroleum Co. PLC, which coincided with the October 1987 stock market crash. Investors shunned the shares, which were left in the hands of underwriters. The government previously has privatized companies by selling them to one buyer. The latest such sale, of the Rover car group, to British Aerospace PLC in July 1988, was marred by the European Commission's rebuke of the government for including hidden sweeteners for British Aerospace. The EC last month ordered millions of dollars in sweeteners returned to the government.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Bailout Swells June Red Ink
DOC.NOTE: Eds: STANDS for AM-Budget Deficit on Business News Digest. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The busiest month yet for the savings and loan bailout ballooned the federal budget deficit to $11.2 billion in June, a month when corporate tax payments usually produce a surplus, the government said Monday. The shortfall, compared with a $7.8 billion surplus in June 1989, brought red ink for the first nine months of fiscal 1990 to $163.1 billion, more than half again as much as the $105.4 billion deficit at this time last year. If the deficit continues to accumulate at this pace, it could top the record fiscal-year deficit of $221.1 billion set in 1986. The White House Office of Management and Budget is officially forecasting a budget gap of $218.5 billion, just short of the record. White House negotiators and congressional leaders are attempting to put together a major deficit-reduction pact for fiscal 1991, starting Oct. 1. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush would sit down with the leaders of Congress for daily ``hard bargaining'' sessions for the rest of the week in hopes of reaching an agreement. ``The president wants to give it a major push,'' Fitzwater said. Pessimism about the eventual success of those talks contributed to the stock price tumble Monday, analysts said. Absent an agreement, OMB projects the 1991 deficit at $231.4 billion. ``The deficit is totally running out of control,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, who heads a Washington-based consulting firm. ``Through January, the deficit was apparently in good shape. Starting in February, it started going bananas.'' Evans attributed the ballooning budget gap to S&L bailout spending and to sluggish economic growth, which is producing lower-than-expected tax revenues. Bailout spending by the government's Resolution Trust Corp. totaled $15.8 billion in June _ a third of its total spending through June of $45 billion. June was the bailout's busiest month. The RTC dealt with 83 institutions, bringing its total of bailouts and closings to 207. Eventually, the government expects to sell real estate, loans, securities and other assets inherited from failed thrifts. That revenue should help reduce the budget deficit in future years. The economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew at a sub-par 1.9 percent annual rate in the January-March quarter and is projected by most economists to have grown at an even slower 1.6 percent rate in the April-June period. As a result, corporate tax collections, through June, were $72.5 billion, down 9.2 percent from the same period a year ago. All revenues totaled $110.6 billion in June and $777.7 for the year to date, up 3.8 percent from the same period a year ago. Spending totaled $121.8 billion for the month and $940.8 billion for the first nine months of fiscal 1990, up 10.1 percent from 1989. The biggest spending categories, as usual, were the military, Social Security and other programs in the Department of Health and Human Services, and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $27 billion in June and $219.4 billion so far this year, down 0.9 percent from 1989. Social security payments amounted to $24.6 billion for the month and $183.4 billion so far this year, up 7.8 percent from 1989. Other HHS payments, including Medicare and Medicaid, totaled 17.9 billion in June and $144.1 billion thus far in fiscal 1990, up 12.1 percent from the same period in 1989. Interest on the national debt amounted to $42 billion in June and $210.2 billion for the fiscal year so far, up 9.9 percent from 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Dates for the Dow Jones Industrial Average
With AM-Market Drop Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of historic dates for the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks: 1896 _ First appears in The Wall Street Journal. Jan. 12, 1906 _ Closes above 100 for the first time, at 100.25. Sept. 3, 1929 _ Reaches its closing peak for the bull market of the 1920s, at 381.17, less than two months before the Great Crash. Oct. 28, 1929 _ Plummets 38.33 points, the worst drop on record until 1986, cutting nearly 13 percent of the average's value, closing at 260.64. July 8, 1932 _ Closes at its Depression low of 41.22, having fallen 89 percent in less than three years. March 12, 1956 _ Closes above 500 for the first time, at 500.24. Jan. 18, 1966 _ Reaches 1,000 for the first time in mid-session, but drops back to close at 994.20. Nov. 14, 1972 _ Closes above 1,000 for the first time, at 1,003.16. Jan. 11, 1973 _ Peaks at 1,051.70. Dec. 6, 1974 _ Closes at a 12-year low of 577.60, ending the worst bear market since the '30s. April 27, 1981 _ Closes at an eight-year high of 1,024.05. Aug. 12, 1982 _ Closes at a two-year low of 776.92, just prior to the start of a historic rally. Aug. 17, 1982 _ Rises 38.81 points, to 831.24, in its then-largest one-day gain as the long rally begins on Wall Street. Dec. 11, 1985 _ Increases 12.50 points to close at 1,511.70, its first finish above 1,500. Jan. 8, 1987 _ Breaks the 2,000 level for the first time, rising 8.30 to 2,002.25. Jan. 23, 1987 _ Plunges to end day down 44.15 points at 2,101.52, after being up 64 points at midafternoon; NYSE volume hits a record 302.39 million. July 17, 1987 _ Climbs 13.07 to 2,510.04, closing above 2,500 for the first time. Oct. 16, 1987 _ Plunges 108.36 points to 2,246.73, falling more than 100 points for the first time. Oct. 19, 1987 _ Dives a record 508.00 points to 1,738.74, a drop of 22.6 percent that dwarfs the drop on Oct. 28, 1929, in the market's Great Crash. Oct. 21, 1987 _ Soars a record 186.84 to 2,027.85, a climb of 10.1 percent in the second day of the rebound from the Oct. 19 collapse. The broader market also rebounds. Feb. 4, 1988 _ Falls 5.63 to 2,057.86, the same day New York Stock Exchange announces it will experiment with a 50-point ``collar'' on program trading. The exchange bars the use of its computers for index arbitrage on days the Dow rises or falls 50 points or more from its previous close. Feb. 8, 1988 _ Falls 14.76 to 1,895.72, its low for the year. March 25, 1988 _ Closes down 44.92 to 1,978.95; the 50-point ``collar'' is triggered on the down side for the first time during the session. April 6, 1988 _ Jumps 64.16 to 2,061.67, triggering the collar on the up side for the first time. Jan. 24, 1989 _ Gains 38.04 to 2,256.43, regaining its Oct. 16, 1987 level for the first time since the Black Monday crash on Oct. 19, 1987. Oct. 9, 1989 _ Gains 5.89 to 2,791.41, its high for the year. Oct. 13, 1989 _ Falls 190.58 to 2,569.26 on Friday the 13th selloff sparked by failure of UAL Corp. buyout group to get financing. Oct. 16, 1989 _ Gains 88.12 to 2,657.38 in rally led by Dow industrials. Jan. 2, 1990 _ Gains 56.95 to 2,810.15, reaching a record high for the first time since the Oct. 13 plunge. Jan. 12, 1990 _ Falls 71.46 to 2,689.21 on worries about higher inflation and earlier declines in the Tokyo and London stock markets. Jan. 22, 1990 _ Falls 77.45 to 2,600.45, putting the Dow industrials 7.47 percent below its record high of Jan. 2. May 11, 1990 _ Rises 63.07 to 2,801.58 in rally sparked by economic reports suggesting mild inflation. May 14, 1990 _ Gains 19.95 to 2,821.53, topping the Jan. 2 record close for the first time. May 29, 1990 _ Jumps 49.57 to record 2,870.49. June 1, 1990 _ Gains 24.31 to 2,900.97, first close above 2,900. July 13, 1990 _ Crosses 3,000-point level during the session for the first time before slipping back in later trading. Finishes at 2,980.20, a new record high. July 23, 1990 _ Finishes down 56.44 at 2,904.70, rallying from earlier declines that saw it down about 107 points.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Takes Big Hit But Recovers Some Ground
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 new grafs to UPDATE with closing Dow, advances and declines. Picks up 9th graf pvs, The severity ...
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street was spooked by a sudden drop of more than 100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average today, but the battered market recovered nearly half the lost ground by the close. The Dow average, which had flirted with an all-time high finish of 3,000 last week, plunged about 107 points in the first 90 minutes of trading. By the end, the average had struggled back to 2,904.70, down 56.44 points or 1.9 percent. The loss extended Friday's slump of 32.67 points and sent a disturbing signal about the health of the market and the broader economy. ``It just scared the hell out of everyone,'' said John Eberley, head of equity trading at the Chicago Corp. ``It caught our attention.'' ``It went from sell to buy to sell again just between 9:30 and 11,'' said Leigh Stevens, a strategist at PaineWebber Inc. ``It's unusual to see such back-and-forth like that in such a short time span.'' Declining issues outnumbered advances by 6-to-1 on the New York Stock Exchange, where trading was heavy and hectic. As money was flowing out of stocks, it flowed into the bond market during the early going, but long-term Treasuries finished slightly lower on the day as stocks recovered. The abrupt drop in stocks also influenced the dollar's value, which declined against the West German mark and British pound. But the dollar strengthened against the yen in Japan, where stock prices fell sharply overnight. The severity of the stock market drop was intensified by computerized strategies known as program trading, which can dump enormous amounts of shares on the market. NYSE spokeswoman Sharon Gamsin said the nation's biggest stock exchange had asked for a voluntary restraint on program trading after the Dow's sharp drop. Federal regulators also were paying close attention to the market's behavior. ``We're aware of the situation and watching it closely,'' said John Heine, a spokesman for the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. The swift selloff caused a brief automatic halt in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures contract, an important influence on stock prices, traded in the Chicago futures markets. The halt was triggered by a ``circuit-breaker'' mechanism put in place by the financial markets in the wake of the crash of Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow average fell a record 508 points. Brokers blamed the market's latest weakness on a number of causes, ranging from disappointing corporate earnings reports of leading U.S. companies, to the uncertain outlook for interest rates and the economy, to the abrupt fall in Tokyo stock prices. ``This market behavior is going to discourage people,'' said Chung Lew, head trader at Kleinwort Benson North America Inc. in New York. Some said investors were bothered by a report in The Wall Street Journal this morning about the prospect of financial collapse for the largest guarantor of student loans in the country. The account suggested the Higher Education Assistance Foundation's $9.6 billion in loan guarantees may have to be salvaged by the federal government, aggravating the problem of easing the federal budget deficit, already overburdened by the enormous cost of the savings & loan bailout. Other brokers said the Dow drop was a symptom of the market's performance in recent days. They said the average showed signs of weakness in the past several trading sessions as it struggled unsuccessfully to close above the 3,000 mark. ``I've been expecting a correction,'' said Lawrence Helfand, a senior strategist at Rodman & Renshaw, a Chicago investment firm. ``I wouldn't be surprised to see the market pull back 8 to 10 percent. There's lots of negative news around, with no real reason to anticipate any positive news.'' Although the 3,000milestone has proved elusive, the Dow average of 30 industrial stocks has posted a string of new highs during July, peaking at 2,999.75 at mid-month.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street's Selloff Pushes Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: A selloff on Wall Street helped push the dollar sharply lower Monday against most other major currencies in foreign exchange. Gold prices, meanwhile, surged as a result of the dollar's decline and as investors sought refuge from stocks, traders said. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.10 a troy ounce, up $7.80 from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $368.15 an ounce, $7.40 higher. Currency dealers said the dollar started out softer amid continued worries about falling interest rates, but it declined more rapidly as traders around the world learned of the sharp drop in stock prices. The closely watched Dow Jones industrial average, which measures stock prices of 30 of the biggest U.S. companies, plunged around 100 points in the first 90 minutes of trading. It later regained some ground before ending the session with a drop of around 56 points. Waves of computerized program selling, weak corporate earnings and concerns about broad economic factors were largely responsible for Wall Street's selloff. All that helped spook dollar traders, too. ``It was kind of a psychological thing,'' said Trevor Woodland, chief coporate trader for Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. ``If you're a trader you're not going to buy a currency when the equity market is faring poorly.'' This is particularly true among foreign traders. As demand for equity falls, so does the need to convert foreign currencies into dollars to buy stocks. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 148.50 yen, up 0.15 yen from Friday's finish. The dollar traded lower at 148.40 yen in London, and at 148.19 yen in New York, down from 148.65 yen Friday. The dollar was weaker against the British pound compared to Friday. Sterling bought $1.8215 in London, up from $1.8140, and $1.8255 in New York, up from $1.8185. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's levels, included: 1.62225 West German marks, down from 1.6385; 1.3815 Swiss francs, down from 1.4043; 5.4410 French francs, down from 5.4965; 1,187.50 Italian lire, down from 1,200.00; and 1.15545 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15495. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday: 1.6278 West German marks, down from 1.6410; 1.3880 Swiss francs, down from 1.4070; 5.4598 French francs, down from 5.5045; 1.8430 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8485; 1,192.00 Italian lire, down from 1,201.75, and 1.1568 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1565. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $368.15 an ounce from $361.25 Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $367.75 an ounce from $361.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 11 cents to close at $362.28 an ounce. Silver prices also strengthened. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.882 a troy ounce, up from $4.848 late Friday. Silver rose in London to $4.90 an ounce from $4.87.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Net Income Up 6 Percent at Baxter
DOC.TEXT: Medical supply giant Baxter International Inc. on Monday reported a 6 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, citing stronger sales and higher profit margins than in the second quarter of 1989. Baxter reported earnings of $110 million, or 37 cents per share, for the three months ending June 30, compared with $104 million, or 35 cents per share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for the quarter totaled $2 billion, an 8 percent increase over $1.9 billion for the second quarter of 1989, Baxter said in a statement from its headquarters in Deerfield, a north Chicago suburb. Baxter said its performance was even better than the bottom line indicates because the 1989 second-quarter results included one-time gains of $19.6 million, or 7 cents per share, from the sale of some assets. ``Our performance this quarter was excellent,'' said Vernon R. Loucks Jr., Baxter's chairman. ``These results are consistent with our projection for at least a 15 percent increase in operating income for the full year, excluding our restructuring program costs,'' Loucks said. Early in April, Baxter announced plans to pare its workforce of 64,300 by 10 percent and close or sell 21 of its 100 manufacturing plants in 24 countries. The company made a provision of $566 million in the first quarter to cover the restructuring costs. Because of that charge, Baxter reported a net loss of $273 million, or $1.22 per share, for the first six months of 1990, compared with net income of $205 million, or 69 cents per share, for the same period of 1989. Six-month sales totaled $3.9 billion, an 8 percent increase from $3.6 billion in the first six months of last year. Baxter spokesman Les Jacobson said he knew of only one plant closed so far. But he said 500 to 700 jobs had been eliminated at the company's headquarters and another 1,000 headquarters employees had been transferred to the field.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Posts Loss of $51 Million in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. said Monday it lost $51 million in the second quarter due to costs and interest expenses related to Time's $14 billion purchase of Warner Communications Inc. But the company said earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization climbed to a record $536 million for the quarter, and said four of its six business segments _ films, records, cable TV systems and programming _ had record second quarters. Time bought controlling interest in Warner last July, but did not complete its purchase of the rest of Warner's stock until January. As a result, Time Warner presented its earnings both on an historical basis, reflecting only a pro-rated portion of Warner's results for 1989, and on a pro forma basis, stated as if the companies were combined for all of 1989. Time Warner's loss of $3.29 per common share after preferred dividends for the three months ended June 30 contrasted with a profit of $92 million, or $1.65 a share, on an historical basis a year earlier. On a pro forma basis, it lost $52 million, or $3.32 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter amounted to $2.59 billion, up more than double from $1.22 billion a year earlier on an historical basis but only up 4.4 percent from pro forma revenue of $2.48 billion. Time Warner said its filmed entertainment division earned a second-quarter record $75 million before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, up 23 percent from pro forma earnings of $61 million a year earlier. Its home video unit was a major contributor, with strong worldwide sales of ``Tango and Cash,'' ``Lethal Weapon II'' and ``Christmas Vacation.'' The recorded music and music publishing division earned a second-quarter record $125 million before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, up from a pro forma $118 million a year earlier. The latest results were led by strong domestic sales from Madonna, Paula Abdul, Anita Baker and Keith Sweat. Second-quarter records were also set in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $188 million in the cable division and $46 million in programming. Pro forma results were $160 million in cable and $43 million in programming a year earlier. The company's magazine division had earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $85 million in the second quarter, down from $99 million on a pro forma basis a year earlier. Results were affected by a soft climate for magazine advertising and the anticipated startup costs at Entertainment Weekly, launched in February. Its books division reported earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $17 million in the quarter, down from $38 million on a pro forma basis a year earlier. The decline was blamed on absence of profits from Scott, Foresman and Co., a textbook publisher sold in December 1989. For the first half, Time Warner said it lost $102 million, or $6.54 per common share after preferred dividends. It earned $146 million, or $2.54 a share, on an historical basis a year earlier but lost $133 million, or $7.15 a share, on a pro forma basis in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue for the first half amounted to $5.33 billion, more than twice as much as historical revenue of $2.35 billion and up 6 percent from pro forma revenue of $5.03 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Tyson Profit Up In Latest Quarter; IBP Net Higher
DOC.TEXT: Two of the nation's biggest processors of meat, Tyson Foods Inc. and IBP Inc., each reported strong profit gains for their latest quarters on Monday. Tyson, a leading producer and marketer of poultry and other food products, said its profit rose 21.8 percent in the three months ended June 30, including results from its 1989 acquisition of Holly Farms. IBP, the nation's biggest meatpacker, said its quarterly profit nearly doubled due to strong consumer demand for beef and pork.

Tyson reported earnings of $33.4 million, or 51 cents a share, in its third fiscal quarter compared with $27.4 million, or 43 cents a share, for the third quarter of 1989. Revenue rose to 978.7 million from $606.1 million. For the nine months ended June 30, Tyson posted a profit of $82.8 million, or $1.26 a share, compared with $69 million, or $1.08 per share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.8 billion from $1.6 billion. Tyson spokesman Gerald Johnston said the Springdale, Ark.-based company was operating at about the rate expected following its acquisition last year of rival Holly Farms. ``We're operating pretty well what we expected to be doing,'' Johnston said. ``The biggest part of the sales (increase) obviously came from the acquisition, but we really don't have those figures broken out.'' Tyson acquired Memphis-based Holly Farms in June 1989 for $1.29 billion after a seven-month battle with ConAgra Inc. of Omaha, Neb., for control of the poultry company.

IBP posted a profit of $15.8 million, or 34 cents a share, in its second quarter ended June 30. That compared with a profit of $8.57 million, or 18 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Sales rose to $2.6 billion from $2.3 billion. ``Continued strong consumer demand for both beef and pork led to the improvement in margins,'' said IBP's chairman, Robert L. Peterson. ``A reduction in live cattle prices during the quarter was also a factor. However, livestock prices remain high, especially on the pork side.'' IBP is one of the world's largest producers of fresh beef and pork, employing 24,000 people in plants in the United States and overseas. During the first six months of the year, IBP's profit nearly doubled to $20.2 million, or 43 cents a share, from $9.9 million, or 21 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose to $4.97 billion from $4.58 billion.

DOC.HEAD: KCPL Makes $857 Million Offer for KG&E
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Power and Light Co. made an $857 million tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric Co. Monday, a move KCPL officials said would cut costs for both utilities and delay their need to add generating capacity. KCPL executives say they could freeze rates for all customers until Jan. 1, 1993 if the merger goes through. The offer, for $27 in cash per common share, would be financed by a $1 billion credit agreement that KCPL has signed with two banks, Westpac Banking Corp. and the First National Bank of Chicago, company officials said. The share price offered is 37 percent more than KG&E's stock price Friday, according to KCPL. KG&E stock, which closed at $19.75 Friday, closed at $24.37{ Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, while KCPL's stock fell 87{ cents to close at $31.50. At least 90 percent of KG&E's shares must be offered. The tender offer also requires approval of state and federal regulators, KCPL officials said. ``The only comment I can make is we have received the offer. We will evaluate it. We will respond after that evaluation is complete,'' said Lyle Koerper, a KG&E spokesman in Wichita. Koerper said he did not know when the evaluation would be complete. The offer is scheduled to expire at midnight Aug. 20. In a letter to KG&E officials, KCPL's president and chief executive, A. Drue Jennings, said the merger would make more complete and efficient use of KG&E's generating capacity and delay KCPL's need to add capacity. At a news conference, Jennings said for several years he has discussed the merger idea informally with Wilson Cadman, KG&E president and board chairman. Jennings described Monday's tender offer as a ``nudge.'' ``Our companies are very good friends,'' he said. ``They've done a lot of commercial business together over the past 25 years. I think it's a good deal, I really do.'' KCPL also filed a federal lawsuit Monday seeking a court order requiring KG&E to comply with a Kansas law that would require it to call a special shareholders meeting within 30 to 50 days. The meeting would be to authorize KCPL to vote all of the shares it acquires through its tender offer. Jennings said his company proposes to expand its board of directors by five members to add representatives from KG&E's service headquarters and to add a citizens' advisory commission to represent consumers in KG&E's service territory. Jennings said he was optimistic that both KG&E and regulators would be receptive to the offer. ``I think they'll appreciate what they see,'' he said. ``This is a strategic combination that really does make sense. It probably should have been done years ago.'' KCPL has about 409,000 customers in 23 counties in western Missouri and eastern Kansas, including the Kansas City area. It has about 2,800 employees. KG&E serves about 254,000 customers in southeastern Kansas, including the Wichita area. It employs about 1,330. KCPL said it plans no layoffs if the merger goes through. The two utilities each own 47 percent of the Wolf Creek nuclear power plant in southeast Kansas. Kansas Electric Power Cooperatives Inc. owns the remainder. Jennings said the merger would not affect the hybrid corporation that runs Wolf Creek or the plant's day-to-day operations.

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide Earnings Down 38 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tomm in 3rd graf is correct.
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. on Monday reported a 38 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, citing cyclical softness and economic problems in Brazil where the chemical giant has several plants. For the quarter ended June 30, after-tax income totaled $116 million, or 81 cents per share, on revenue of $2.1 billion, compared to $186 million, or $1.33 per share, on revenue of $2.3 billion for the same period a year earlier. ``The chemical business is very cyclical, and we are currently in the downturn of that chemical cycle,'' spokesman Tomm Sprick said. Reduced sales of ethylene glycol, which is primarily used to make antifreeze, contributed to the downturn, the company said. Union Carbide's Brazilian operations added just 3 cents per share to second-quarter earnings, compared to 10 cents a share in the second quarter of 1989, the company said in a news release. Increased sales and gross profit from the Brazil operations were offset by high inflation, increased overhead, foreign currency translation losses and higher income taxes in that country, the company said. Robert D. Kennedy, Union Carbide president, said operating profit and earnings improved 17 percent and 25 percent, respectively, in the company's industrial gases operations, excluding Brazil. The company's earnings for the first six months of 1990 totaled $210 million, or $1.47 a share, on revenue of $4.3 billion. In the first six months of 1989, the company reported earnings of $387 million, or $2.76 a share, and revenue of $4.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Ingersoll Management Delighted With Newspaper-Saving Deal
DOC.TEXT: A last-minute, cost-cutting agreement reached with unions at Irish Press newspapers paves the way for the Ingersoll-managed group to restore the titles to a prime position in Ireland, the management said Monday. The group, Irish Press Newspapers Ltd., was founded nearly 60 years ago by former Irish premier and president Eamon de Valera. It is 50-percent owned by embattled U.S. publisher Ralph Ingersoll's British company, Ingersoll Publications Ltd. The group reached the agreement with the National Union of Journalists and the Irish Print Union on Sunday, just before it was to close down the Irish Press, Evening Press and Sunday Press. The settlement calls for 200 voluntary layoffs, the immediate start of the use of new technology, and the introduction of a basic 5-shift, 35-hour work week throughout the company. Journalists have been working a four-day, 28-hour week. The 750 workers had rejected the same proposals on Thursday. ``We are delighted with the agreements we have reached with the Irish unions. The Irish Press Group has been at the heart of Irish national life for 60 years,'' said James Plugh, chief executive of London-based Ingersoll Publications. ``Through the use of the latest technology, our newspaper expertise, and the remarkable pool of creative talent in Ireland, the way is now clear for our partners and ourselves to restore the Irish press titles to their preeminent position in the Republic of Ireland,'' he said. Ingersoll Publications, which bought a half-stake in the newspaper group in December 1989, also manages the newspapers. The remainder of the company is owned by Irish Press PLC, the company founded by de Valera, and now chaired by his grandson Eamon de Valera. Ralph Ingersoll, hit by his heavy debt load of mostly junk bonds, and a downturn in the U.S. newspaper industry, relinquished ownership of his U.S. newspaper company, Ingersoll Publications Co. earlier this month. The New York investment firm E.M. Warburg Pincus and Co., his partner for seven years, agreed to acquire all the stock in Ingersoll's three American companies which publish daily newspapers in New Haven, Conn., Trenton, N.J., and other cities. Ingersoll closed down his startup daily newspaper the St. Louis Sun earlier this year, after seven months of publication. The publisher, who has said he believes there are more publishing opportunities in Europe, agreed to acquire Warburg's 50-percent interest in the British Ingersoll company, which also owns the Birmingham Post and Mail, Coventry Evening Telegraph and other British newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler to Offer Stripped Down Shadow-Sundance for '91
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. will offer special versions of its 1991 Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance cars to recapture market share lost when the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon died, the company said Monday. The cars will be called ``America'' versions and carry base prices of $7,599 for a two-door version and $7,799 for the four-door model. Chrysler said the Shadow and Sundance America cars would be offered with a limited number of options. Each will have a driver's side air bag. The Omni and Horizon cars, versions of which Chrysler also marketed as ``America'' models, ended when the Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit shut down Feb. 2. Since then, Chrysler has effectively been out of the subcompact market. In 1989, Chrysler sold 79,500 Omni and Horizon cars and 167,288 Sundance and Shadow cars. The ``America'' versions of the Shadow and Sundance are seen as plugging a hole in Chrysler's lineup until the company either develops a new subcompact on its own or joins with an overseas automaker to develop such a vehicle. There has been speculation that Chrysler has been talking with the Italian automaker Fiat SpA about making a subcompact based on the Fiat Tipo sold overseas. Chrysler and Fiat officials have declined to confirm or deny such speculation. Chrysler officials said earlier this year that introduction of a new subcompact to take the place of the Omni and Horizon wouldn't take place until the mid-1990s, after the company introduces an all-new mid-size car code-named ``LH.'' In addition to the Shadow and Sundance America cars, Chrysler also said that it would introduce upscale versions of the same vehicles and a Shadow convertible. Prices for those cars will be released later.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Hits 2-Month High On Weak Stocks, Mideast Buying
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices surged to their highest levels in two months Monday as sharply lower stock prices, a weaker dollar and signs of Middle Eastern buying fired investor interest in the metal. On other commodity markets, silver also advanced, stock-index futures tumbled; energy futures climbed; livestock and meat futures retreated; and grains and soybeans were mostly higher. Gold futures settled $7.70 to $7.80 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in August up $7.70 at $369.70 a troy ounce. The spot July contract settled at $369.10 a troy ounce, the highest settlement of a spot gold contract since May 22. Silver futures settled 3 cents to 3.4 cents higher with July at $4.882 a troy ounce. Gold opened with a surge in New York following news of a large purchase of gold bullion in London that analysts believe originated in the Middle East. Some previous Middle Eastern transactions have been large enough to swing prices wildly, leaving the market sensitive to signs of Middle Eastern interest. Shortly after the strong opening, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 107 points, sending many stock investors fleeing to the perceived safety of the precious metals. The stock market slowly trimmed its losses throughout the day. But gold remained strong, with new support stemming from higher oil prices _ an inflationary signal _ and a weaker dollar. Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc., said the Federal Reserve Board's recent moves to lower interest rates have been a boon to the gold market. ``It looks like some foreigners are concerned about the possibility that (Fed Chairman Alan) Greenspan's stance toward inflation may be weakening, which pulled the props out from under the dollar,'' Savaiko said. Analyst Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said reports of new violence in South Africa surfaced shortly after the close, which could give gold prices another boost on Tuesday. The stock market's slide prompted sympathetic selling on many commodity markets. Stock-index futures, which sometimes shadow and sometimes lead the stock market, also fell sharply in early trading and closed with smaller, although still steep, losses. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Standard & Poor's 500 futures settled 7 points to 7.25 points lower with September at 357.80. The contract is valued at $500 per point. The September contract fell 12 points early in the session, triggering a ``circuit breaker'' trading halt designed to guard against a stock market collapse. Energy futures continued to rise amid optimism that OPEC oil ministers meeting this week in Geneva will agree on measures to reduce their crude output and raise prices. OPEC's mid-year meeting begins Thursday. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 44 cents to 49 cents higher with September at $20.50 a barrel; heating oil was .71 cent to 1.06 cents higher with August at 56.5 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .39 cent to .70 cent higher with August at 63.35 cents a gallon. Livestock and meat futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by limit losses in the pork-belly market for the third time in the last four sessions. In addition to weak bacon demand and lower cash markets, bellies were pressured by Friday's monthly Agriculture Department cold storage report, which showed larger stocks of frozen bellies than the market had expected. Live cattle settled .12 cent to .63 cent lower with August at 76.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .58 cent lower with August at 87.30 cents a pound; live hogs were 1.02 cents lower to .13 cent higher with August at 59.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.67 cents to the limit 2 cents lower with July at 44.20 cents a pound. Most grain and soybean futures advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade, erasing most of the losses posted early in the session. Analysts said the main influence in the crop markets probably will continue to be bearish fundamentals that include good weather for corn and soybean developement. After the close, the National Weather Service issued a new six-to-10-day outlook predicting normal temperatures and above-normal rainfall for the Midwest in the first half of next week. The USDA released its weekly crop-progress report after the close, showing little improvement in the corn and soybean crops, with development well behind the norm. The USDA reported the winter wheat harvest was 83 percent complete as of Sunday, which is near the average pace. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents lower to 1} cents higher with September at $3.01} a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 4} cents higher with September at $2.64 a bushel; oats were 5 cents to 5\ cents higher with September at $1.27 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 3{ cents higher with August at $5.91 a bushel.
