DOC.HEAD: Nestle Enterprises to Sell Restaurant Unit
DOC.TEXT: Nestle Enterprises Inc. will not proceed with an expansion of its Stouffer Restaurant Co. and instead will try to sell the subsidiary, the Swiss-owned conglomerate announced Monday. ``The decision follows an extensive evaluation of the long-range business strategy of Nestle in the United States,'' Nestle Enterprises stated. Nestle, one of three American subsidiaries of Swiss-based Nestle SA, reported it would begin ``an orderly process of preparing the restaurant group for sale.'' Stouffer operates 65 restaurants, including outlets under the names of J.B. Winberie, James Tavern, Rusty Scupper and Parkers' Lighthouse as well as the ``Top'' restaurants in New York, Boston, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Columbus, Ohio, and Cleveland. James M. Biggar, Nestle Enterprises chairman, said operating restaurants is better suited to specialty chains and entrepreneurs than a large corporation. He said Nestle will focus its efforts on its Nestle Foods Corp., Nestle Hills Coffee Co., Stouffer Foods Corp., Stouffer Hotel Co., the L.J. Minor Corp., Wine World Estates, Sunmark Inc., and FreshNes Foods Corp.

DOC.HEAD: France to Give Thomson Aid for TV Research
DOC.TEXT: The French government said Monday it will provide state-owned Thomson SA with the equivalent of $540 million over the next five years to finance research and development of high-definition television. The Industry Ministry said the electronics company has agreed to a program that sets specific targets in terms of research, product development and the launch of a product. Thomson has linked up with NV Philips of the Netherlands in a 20 billion franc, or $3.6 billion, high-definition TV joint research and development program over five years and has already devoted 6 billion francs, or $1.08 billion, to its research. Under the agreement signed in May, Thomson will put up 9 billion francs, or $1.62 billion of the total amount and Philips the remainder. The French group is one of the 14 founding members of a group of European broadcasting and telecommunications companies that are seeking to have high- definition TV operating commercially in Europe by 1992. The European standard is incompatible with that being developed by Japanese manufacturers. High-definition TV offers better picture and sound quality than conventional television.

DOC.HEAD: Market Plunges More Than 100 Points, But Rebounds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, Student loan ... the economy, to CORRECT that report said HEAF could face bankruptcy. Pick up 17th graf, Kansas Gas ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Market Drop Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The stock market was hammered Monday in a chilling reminder of past crashes as the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted more than 100 points before recouping about half of its decline. In its biggest drop since January, the Dow average of 30 industrial stocks _the market's best known barometer _ finished down 56.44 points at 2,904.70, extending Friday's 32.67-point decline. In the broader market, virtually all market indicators and industry groups were lower. ``There was a whiff of panic in the air,'' said Jack Conlon, head of equity trading for Rothschild Inc. ``Clearly there was a good deal of damage done.'' Still, the decline was only the third worst of 1990 _ the Dow industrials tumbled 77.45 points on Jan. 22 and 71.46 on Jan. 12. It left the Dow average above the 2,900 mark, although it has largely retreated after coming within a whisker of 3,000 last week. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 227 up, 1,430 down and 365 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 209.03 million shares, up from 177.81 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 250.50 million shares. Waves of computerized stock selling programs, weak second-quarter corporate earnings reports, and concerns about inflation and interest rates thrust stocks lower from the opening bell. The New York Stock Exchange asked member firms voluntarily to restrain from program trading, but the request did not appear to have much impact as buy and sell programs whipsawed the market later in the day. The activity has been blamed in the past for contributing to big intraday price swings. Traders said the speed of the morning tumble was reminiscent of the 1987 market crash and the October 1989 selloff that scared away individual investors and helped bring on a recession in the securities industry. The market lost 107 points in the first 90 minutes of trading before quickly recovering about 50 points. It then drifted lower and hovered there until a spurt just before the close. A sharp decline in two key stock-index futures _ which link trading in the stock and futures markets _ triggered a ``circuit-breaker'' in the Chicago index futures market prohibiting the products from trading at lower levels for 30 minutes. Helping lead the drop was a weaker-than-expected earnings report by McDonald's, which fell 3 to 33 and was the most active NYSE issue. The report was issued too late Friday for the market to react. ``An earnings surprise in a supposedly stable stock like that is going to spook people,'' said Phil Roth, chief technical analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Blue-chip stocks declined across the board. IBM fell 1} to 115~, Philip Morris lost 1[ to 49, General Electric dipped 1{ to 72{, Boeing lost 2[ to 55~ and Upjohn declined 1~ to 41\. Student Loan Marketing Association, also knows as Sallie Mae, fell 4[ to 49~. A published report said the the nation's largest loan guarantor for student aid, Higher Education Assistance Foundation, of which Sallie Mae is a major creditor, may face a bankruptcy filing. The report stirred concern about debt problems in the economy. Kansas Gas & Electric rose 4| to 24]. The utility said it was reviewing a $27 a share tender offer by Kansas City Power & Light. Other gainers included precious metals and trucking issues. Analysts said the market's inability to break 3,000 _ it twice closed at 2,999.75 last week _ added to underlying weakness. Eugene Peroni, technical research director for Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia, said after the Dow hit 2,000 in January 1987 ``the market stalled for some time.'' ``The fact that we were around 3,000 just adds to the psychological woes at this point and makes it more of a mystical level,'' he said. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $61.365 billion, or 1.78 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 3.43 to 194.22. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 7.90 to 420.79, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 6.30 to 355.31. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market declined 10.63 to 444.66. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 354.92, down 5.53.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Switches Ad Agencies
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. fired Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide as its U.S. advertising agency and awarded the multimillion-dollar account to the agency Young & Rubicam, the office products company announced Monday. The company declined to specify how much it spends on domestic corporate and product advertising, but one source familiar with the matter said it was about $25 million a year. The Stamford, Conn.-based Xerox said the move was part of a marketing strategy calling for more integration between corporate and product campaigns around the world. Young & Rubicam has been the agency for more than 20 years for most of the European advertising for Rank Xerox Ltd., a joint venture in which Xerox owns 51 percent. Backer Spielvogel Bates, a New York-based subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC of Great Britain, has handled Xerox corporate and product advertising in the United States since 1986. Xerox said its direct marketing assignments would remain at Lowe Direct in the United States and Ogilvy & Mather Direct in Europe. Backer will continue to work for Xerox for three months, but the company said Young & Rubicam's work may begin showing up in September.

DOC.HEAD: No Deal Yet On Eastern; But Rumored Plan Could Split Creditors, Trustee
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines' chairman wants to oversee a controlled sale of Eastern Airlines' assets and buy many of Eastern's planes and gates in Atlanta, according to a published report. The story in Monday's editions of The Wall Street Journal said the proposal was expected to be made Monday, but Eastern said it had received no offer from Northwest to buy parts of the airline. The newspaper reported that Northwest Chairman Alfred A. Checchi was expected to make the proposal to Eastern and its creditors. The Journal reported the plan would call for Northwest to take over certain Eastern assets, including 80 of Eastern's newer aircraft, airport gates in Atlanta and maintenance facilities in Atlanta and Miami. In return, the story said, Checchi would volunteer to broker a controlled liquidation of Eastern's remaining assets for the benefit of creditors. The story, which cited unidentified people familiar with the proposal, said the plan was expected to be offered today. Such a proposal could cause a split between creditors and Eastern's bankruptcy trustee, an analyst said. Timothy Pettee, who tracks airlines for Merrill Lynch Research-U.S., said the reported deal would run against Eastern trustee Martin Shugrue's plans for keeping the airline together. But it might find favor with creditors whose main concern is getting their money back without regard for a future for Eastern, he said. ``It may come down to the creditors having to relieve Mr. Shugrue of his duties,'' Pettee said in a telephone interview. The Journal's story said several difficult issues would have to be resolved, including what to do about Eastern's financial liabilities. It noted that by some estimates, Eastern's pension plan alone is underfunded by at least $500 million. Checchi has said he wants no obligations that would result in additional debt for Northwest. Northwest officials declined comment Monday, saying they would not respond to speculation and rumor. In a mid-afternoon release, Eastern said it had received no offer from Northwest, adding that a breakup of the carrier wasn't acceptable to Shugrue. Guy Cook, president of the Northwest Airlines Machinist's Union, said he didn't feel that ongoing negotiations were far enough along for a concrete proposal. Cook said when he heard about the report, he did some checking and determined that, although Checchi is in New York, he is not meeting with creditors. ``That confirms my belief that no deal is going to be made,'' Cook said. But Pettee said, if a deal is made, it would probably cost Northwest about $500 million dollars. ``Northwest does not have debt problems. They are in good shape,'' he said. Helane Becker, an airline analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton, said the reported proposal would give Northwest a presence in the Southeast with additional gates in Atlanta as it strives to become one of the mega-carriers of the 1990's. Pettee agreed, saying the Checchi's goal is to shift it's Southeastern hub out of Memphis, where it's losing money, to Atlanta. ``By moving that plant to Atlanta, he might be able to make some money,'' Pettee said. Eastern is a unit of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. of Houston, formerly Texas Air Corp. It filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws in March 1989, and a bankruptcy judge appointed Shugrue as trustee for the airline in April. Checchi had been a top strategist for the Marriott Corp. hotel concern and the Bass brothers of Texas before winning a bidding war last year with a $3.65 billion leveraged buyout proposal for NWA, the St. Paul, Minn.-based parent of Northwest.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon, Ashland Post Higher Profit, Arco, Amerada Hess Drop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Amerada Hess, Amoco
DOC.TEXT: Oil giant Exxon Corp. said Monday its second-quarter profit soared nearly seven-fold from a year ago, when it set aside a special provision to handle the massive cleanup from the oil spill in Valdez, Alaska. Meanwhile, Atlantic Richfield Co. reported a 16 percent drop in quarterly earnings, Amoco reported a 23 percent decline for the second quarter and Amerada Hess Corp. reported a $72.1 million net loss. Ashland Oil Inc. said net income for its fiscal third quarter more than doubled. New York-based Exxon earned $1.1 billion, or 87 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with earnings of $140 million, or 11 cents a share, in the 1989 quarter. Revenue totaled $26.08 billion, up 10 percent from $23.61 billion a year ago. Last year's results included an $850 million provision for the Valdez spill. Without that, Exxon said, it would have earned $990 million, or 78 cents per share, in the 1989 quarter. Arco's second-quarter earnings fell to $391 million, or $2.36 per share, from $467 million, or $2.66 a share, in 1989. Sales of the Los Angeles company fell 7 percent to $4 billion from $4.3 billion. Ashland, based in Ashland, Kentucky, reported record net income of $100 million, or $1.79 a share, for the quarter ended June 30, 1990. The amount was more than double the $44 million, or 78 cents a share, in 1989. Sales were $2.2 billion, the same as in last year's quarter.

Exxon Chairman L. G. Rawl said earnings from petroleum and natural gas operations increased $205 million, or 22 percent, despite lower crude prices. He said that helped offset a $115 million drop in chemical earnings. Earnings from U.S. exploration and production activities were $81 million, down from $29 million in 1989. But earnings from foreign exploration and production operations rose $75 million to $464 million. From coal and minerals operations, Exxon earned $12 million, co9mpared with $22 million last year. For the first half of 1990, Exxon earned $2.38 billion, or $1.88 per share, up 22 percent from earnings of $1.95 billion in 1989. Revenue rose 15 percent to $52.0 billion. The 1989 results included an $880 million provision related to the Valdez accident and a $535 million cumulative accounting gain following adoption of new income tax accounting standards. Exxon said it would have earned $2.29 billionn, or $1.79 per share, in the 1989 half year excluding the provision and special gain.

Arco said lower crude oil prices, less production in Alaska and higher international exploration expenses more than offset a sharp rise in profits from refining and marketing operations. Earnings for the first half of 1990 fell by 16 percent to $983 million, or $5.91 per share, from $1.17 billion, or $6.66 per share, last year. Six-month revenue fell fractionally to $8.25 billion from $8.30 billion.

Ashland Chairman John R. Hill said the fiscal third-quarter results were led by growth from Ashland Petroleum Co. and a strong third quarter from SuperAmerica. Improvement in Ashland's construction and exploration operations and higher equity income from coal investments also helped boost earnings, he said. Ashland had net income of $123 million, or $2.21 a share, for the nine months ended June 30, compared to $126 million, or $2.26 per share, last year. Sales totaled $6.5 billion, up from $6.2 billion.

Amoco posted a $379 million profit, or 75 cents per share, on revenues of $7.4 billion. In last year's second quarter, Amoco's profit was $497 million, or 96 cents per share on revenues of $6.8 billion. The company blamed the decline partially on the cost of preparing for possible future environmental cleanup operations and on unfavorable foreign currency effects, as well as on lower prices and sales volumes. The second quarter earnings for 1990 included a net gain of $471 million related to the settlement of claims arising out of Iran's seizure of Amoco facilities in that nation during the 1978-79 revolution there, but company officials said that gain was more than offset by other factors.
DOC.HEAD: Amerada Hess
DOC.TEXT: Amerada Hess's net loss of $72.1 million, or 89 cents per share in this year's second quarter, compares with a profit of $133.5 million, or $1.65 per share, for the second quarter of 1989. The New York-based oil company said revenues in the second quarter of 1990 were $1.233 billion, down from $1.474 billion for the same period last year. Refining and marketing operations lost $44.3 million in the second quarter, a drop from $125.5 million in earnings for the same period last year. Capital expenditures were $192.2 million in the second quarter of the year, up from $177.1 million for the 1989 second quarter. For the first six months of the year, the company lost $32.5 million, or 40 cents per share, down from a profit of $353.7 million, or $4.35 per share for the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: AP Computer Problems Cause Incomplete Options Tables
DOC.TEXT: Computer problems at The Associated Press resulted in transmission of incomplete stock options tables Monday. A problem in computer programs that process incoming trading data resulted in some transactions being excluded from the tables, said John Reid, AP vice president and director of communications and technology. It could not be immediately determined how many transactions were missing, he said. The situation was compounded because the tables couldn't be checked until computers had finished processing them, which took three hours longer than normal because of the computer glitch. Reid said the problem did not affect any other stocks tables produced by AP. The problem was corrected and Tuesday's stock options tables would be complete, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Schwab Agrees to Fine, Censure in NYSE Case
DOC.TEXT: Charles Schwab & Co. Inc. was fined $375,000 and censured after a New York Stock Exchange investigation of trading practices by Schwab's Reorganization Department, company officials announced. From January 1985 through September 1988 the department, which processes tender and exchange offerings, stock purchase rights and warrants, and convertible redeemable securities, would sometimes submit more securities than it had instructions from the customer to tender, according to a company statement issued Monday. The trading practices sometimes resulted in gains for Schwab, the statement said. When gains occurred, Schwab disbursed the related net credits, with interest, to affected customer accounts. The NYSE Hearing Panel found that the department had acted principally to avoid losses when the firm received and honored late customer instructions and to protect against errors in complex junk-bond transactions, according to the statement. In addition to the fine, two employees have been censured, the company said. ``We have undertaken strong internal measures to prevent such practices in the future, including new policies governing each type of reorganization transaction, separation of functions and a complete restructuring of the reorganization department,'' said Charles R. Schwab, founder and chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Turner: TBS Could Lose $26 Million on Goodwill Games
DOC.TEXT: Ted Turner said Monday that Turner Broadcasting System Inc. could lose as much as $26 million on the Goodwill Games _ doubling earlier projections by the company. Asked if losses this summer would equal the $26 million shortfall from the 1986 Goodwill Games in Moscow, the TBS board chairman said the deficit would be ``in that range.'' He declined to detail the reasons for the losses at the annual TBS shareholders' meeting Monday. But Turner was upbeat about the international athletic event that got under way Friday and ends here Aug. 5. He said it is increasing world exposure for TBS and helping the Atlanta-based company market its Cable News Network and other services abroad. ``We're very happy with the way things are going in the Goodwill Games,'' Turner said after the session. During the meeting, Turner was taken to task for his personal views by Accuracy in Media, a conservative watchdog group. And a shareholder's proposal to place his frequent companion, actress Jane Fonda, on the company's board of directors died for lack of a second. The company's 1989 annual report listed $266 million in total losses from cable network operations, movie and video enterprises, and two professional sports teams _ the Atlanta Braves baseball and Atlanta Hawks basketball clubs. But Turner told shareholders that ``1989 was the best year that the company has ever had. We cracked a billion dollars in volume for the first time.'' He blamed the losses on costs of refinancing ``junk notes'' issued in conjunction with Turner Broadcasting's purchase of MGM-UA and said TBS would be within its projected budget for fiscal 1990, even with the Goodwill losses. Turner spent most of the meeting countering jabs from Accuracy in Media and self-appointed corporate watchdog Evelyn Davis, who holds stock in 120 corporations. Davis spends much of her time heckling executives at the companies' annual meetings and also publishes a newsletter ``Highlights and Lowlights,'' detailing her opinions about their operations. She asked whether TBS was about to merge with any other companies, and if Turner was going to run for political office. Turner responded to both queries with a forceful ``no.'' Davis offered the proposal to place Ms. Fonda on the 15-member TBS board of directors. ``She is not only a good actress, but above all she is a good businesswoman, and I think we need a good businesswoman on this board,'' she said. The motion failed. Turner had less trouble with AIM, which urged him to retract ``pro-Communist'' statements made on the CNN opinion program ``Crossfire,'' and to ask Ms. Fonda to retract similarly characterized statements allegedly made in 1968. Turner made no apologies for his own statements, though he said he opposes totalitarian government. He promised he would talk to Ms. Fonda. AIM alleged that only views shared by Turner _ who holds 62.9 percent of TBS shareholder voting power _ are aired in company programming. Among those mentioned by AIM representatives included his belief that criminals are products of their environments, that Fidel Castro is ``a hell of a guy,'' and sympathy should go to those who pulled the triggers as well as the victims of Tiananmen Square, Kent State and other tragedies.
